DOC.HEAD: Oakland A's Win Pennant; Pirates Stay Alive in National League
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf, `In the...,' to add playoff series score for National League.
DOC.TEXT: The Oakland Athletics swept to the American League pennant and their third straight World Series Wednesday in a 3-1 defeat of the Boston Red Sox, whose pitching ace Roger Clemens was ejected by an umpire. In the National League playoffs, the Pittsburgh Pirates beat the Cincinnati Reds 3-2 to stay alive in the best-of-seven series. Before a hometown crowd, the Pirates relief pitcher Bob Patterson extinguished a ninth-inning rally by intentionally walking one batter to load the bases and getting the next man to ground into a double play. The Reds lead the series, three games to two. American League Playoff Game 4 was the second victory in the series for pitcher Dave Stewart, and his eighth straight win in a head-to-head matchup with Clemens. The Boston ace was ejected in the second inning for arguing over balls and strikes with umpire Terry Cooney. A wild 10-minute game interruption followed. Clemens charged the plate and shoved another umpire. Several Red Sox spilled onto the field, along with two water coolers and a trash bin full of bubble gum and sunflower seeds from the Boston dugout. Stewart maintained a two-hit shutout until the ninth inning, when Ellis Burks doubled and scored on a Jody Reed single. Relief pitcher Rick Honeycutt took over and sent Boston to its eight straight playoff defeat. The A's, the first team to reach the World Series three straight times since the 1976-78 New York Yankees, will begin their baseball championship defense Tuesday night in either Cincinnati or Pittsburgh.

DOC.HEAD: Pilgrim Nuclear Plant Neighbors Seek More Action After Cancer Study
DOC.TEXT: Neighbors of the Pilgrim nuclear power plant said Wednesday that a study showing higher than normal leukemia rates in their area justified emergency efforts to lower the plant's radiation emissions. About 80 residents attended a meeting called by the state to discuss the Department of Public Health report released the previous day. The study showed that adults who lived within 10 miles of the Pilgrim nuclear power plant in the 1970s and early 1980s were four times more likely to develop leukemia than were those who live farther away. The study does not prove that the plant, which opened in 1972, caused the cancers. Many health experts believe the emissions from nuclear plants are safe. Also, Public Health Commissioner David Mulligan said emission levels have declined since the 1970s. The report found no increased risk associated with the plant after 1984. But Mary Elizabeth Lambert of the Duxbury Nuclear Affairs Committee was not satisfied. ``Clearly radiation has been here. It will be in your Thanksgiving dinner in your cranberry sauce,'' she said. Pat Granahan of Hingham said, ``You should be declaring a public health emergency. There's too much at stake.'' Lambert urged Mulligan to implement radiation monitoring within the plant's emission stack, rather than just monitoring in the area outside the plant. Mulligan said the state was moving toward stricter standards, cutting the acceptable level of emission from 25 to 10 millirems per year. He said the new limit, which was a recommendation in the report, would be in place with within six months. A rem is a measurement of radiation absorbed in living tissue; a millirem is a thousandth of a rem. A diagnostic chest X-ray involves 20 millirems to 30 millirems of radiation. Some of the people attending the meeting asked the state to study other, long-term cancers, in addition to leukemia, in the region. Mary Ott, co-chairman of the Citizens Urging Responsible Energy, based in Duxbury, said the plant should be closed. ```We feel we have been subjected to enough risk from Pilgrim,'' she said. No Pilgrim officials spoke at the meeting. Boston Edison, which operates the plant in Plymouth, said earlier that the report contradicts other evidence, including a study released last month by the National Cancer Institute. In the cancer institute study, researchers surveyed more than 900,000 cancer deaths in 107 counties around 62 nuclear facilities across the United States. They found that people living near nuclear plants had no greater risk of dying from cancer than did people who lived far away from them.

DOC.HEAD: Food, Gas Shortages Plague Caribbean Nation; Protests Mount
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Francia Martinez stood in line for rice, beans and flour. She wanted sugar, too, but knew there would be none of that sweet staple. Sugar, the foundation of this Caribbean nation's economy for 400 years, is gone from store shelves. It is being shipped to foreign buyers, who pay more than Dominicans can afford. ``Nobody understands what's going on in this country,'' said Freddy Sanchez, waiting in a nearby gas station line that was four blocks long. ``Prices go up, but we're still short.'' Mrs. Martinez, taking shelter from the midday sun under a black umbrella, said she was ``lacking everything at home'' for her husband and three children. Rising consumer prices and shortages of gasoline, food, electricity - even water - are causing hardships and widespread protest among the Dominican Republic's 7 million people. Two nationwide protest strikes since August have led to violence between security forces and demonstrators in which at least 14 people have been killed and 90 wounded. Police report 2,300 arrests, but strike leaders say the number is higher. A few days before a strike in September, three Santo Domingo university students were killed by the explosion of a bomb they were making on campus. Police found an arsenal of explosives in Santiago, the second-largest city. Protest began when President Joaquin Balaguer imposed economic austerity shortly before beginning his second consecutive four-year term in August. He ended subsidies for such basic goods as flour, cooking oil and gasoline, causing prices to triple in some cases. Gasoline has risen since August from 55 cents a gallon to $1.42, with added help from the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. Balaguer's government could not afford the normal level of oil imports after the Persian Gulf crisis drove world prices up, so it began importing about one-third less and rationed gasoline. ``There's no flour, sugar, gas, medicine because the country has no dollars, no foreign currency, no reserves,'' said Andres Dauhakre, a leading economist. ``Certainly the crisis in the Middle East doesn't help.'' Economic problems have mounted since world sugar prices collapsed and U.S. import quotas were cut in the 1980s. Last year's crop was smaller than usual. The Dominican Republic, which shares the island of Hispaniola with Haiti, has a foreign debt of $4.1 billion. By conservative estimates 28 percent of its workers are jobless and annual inflation is 70 percent. A $500 million building spree largely tied to the 500th anniversary in 1992 of Columbus' discovery of America has created schools, roads, housing, irrigation dams and monuments, but the government has financed it by the inflationary means of printing money. Power plants have deteriorated from neglect, causing blackouts of up to 18 hours a day. Many homes and factories have their generators, but fuel shortages make them unreliable. Breakdowns of electric pumps cause water shortages. The International Monetary Fund demanded the austerity measures. Balaguer, 84 and blind from glaucoma, says they are necessary and has urged Dominicans to conserve. ``We have to use less gas, go out less, go to the beach less,'' he said recently. ``We must appeal to Dominican patriotism so that we can overcome this crisis.'' There is no current agreement with the IMF. Because the country could not pay interest on most of its debt in the past year, it is ineligible for loans and has no credit. Talks with the IMF are under way, but Dominicans are wary. The last IMF program in 1984 led to higher prices and riots that took 100 lives. Tourism, the really bright prospect, is expected to net $1 billion this year, but visitors may start choosing islands with fewer problems. Officials blame the unrest on supporters of leftist former President Juan Bosch, 81, whom Balaguer defeated by 1 percent of the vote in May. Jose Luis Arteaga, Balaguer's economic adviser, said: ``The opposition thinks the Balaguer government is illegitimate because of the elections. They want to make life impossible for us.'' Bosch accused Balaguer, his longtime political foe, of widespread vote fraud, but an independent electoral board said a lengthy review of voting tallies produced no evidence. Balaguer's narrow victory deprived his conservative Social Christian Reformist Party of a congressional majority and critics accuse him of ruling by decree. To soften the the austerity measures, the government gave public employees a 30 percent pay raise and froze some prices. The freezes have led to speculative buying, creating further shortages. Unions demand a 150 percent general raise. The minimum wage now is equivalent to $72 a month.

DOC.HEAD: Southern States Weed Constitutions of Antiquated Provisions
DOC.TEXT: The framers of Mississippi's 1890 Constitution envisioned a pay-as-you-go government, with the governor and treasurer counting - by hand, twice a year - the money locked away in a huge black vault hidden in the Capitol. The voters are being asked to lift that 100-year-old burden in the Nov. 6 election. Historians say the provision hasn't been followed since at least the turn of the century. The requirement dates to when state governments paid all their bills in cash, Treasurer Marshall Bennett said. ``I don't think the framers had computer printouts in mind,'' Bennett said. ``As a procedural matter, it is impossible to comply. We don't keep money in the vault anymore. It's distributed to financial institutions. ``The best the governor can do is to see a computer printout, or an electronic blip in a computer chip. It will relieve the burden of noncompliance for a procedure left behind by technology.'' Amending state constitutions is almost a fall ritual in the South. Mississippi has amended its cumbersome, 24,000-word constitution 102 times over the last century. It has four more constitutional ``housekeeping'' amendments on the ballot this fall. Earlier this month, Louisiana tacked 14 amendments on its 1973 Constitution for a total of 41 in less than two decades. In Arkansas, voters will decide Nov. 6 whether to remove a constitutional provision that ordered government officials to resist integration under threat of arrest and prosecution. The provision was put in the state's constitution in 1956 as federal courts were beginning to strike down segregation laws, but it was never enforced. Texas voters are being asked to clear up confusion over when the state Senate must approve gubernatorial appointments. Earlier this year the state attorney general ruled such appointments must be confirmed in the Senate's first session - whether special or regular - after the appointment. An amendment before the voters would require the Senate to consider the matter in the Legislature's first regular session after the nomination, allowing an unconfirmed appointee to hold office in the interim. In Mississippi, the voters also will be considering amendments that would: - End the state's pension obligation to Civil War veterans and their widows. The last person eligible for one, Kate Jobe Nelms of Corinth, died March 28, 1987, according to state records. Her pension for that year was $2,500. - Remove a provision setting the boundaries of the state. Backers say the boundaries are now set in law and are not needed in the constitution. - Delete a provision giving the Legislature authority to elect U.S. senators and appoint presidential electors. Federal and state law now provide for direct election of senators, while presidential electors are put on the ballot by political parties. - Remove a requirement that county supervisors must own land in the district from which they are elected before they can take office. Backers says court decisions have rendered the provision unconstitutional.

DOC.HEAD: Straws in the Wind: Americans Disquieted About Deployment in Gulf
DOC.TEXT: When The Daily Mail asked eight people if they thought the United States should invade Iraq and Kuwait to resolve the Persian Gulf crisis, only two said yes. Debbie Harnish, 29, of Hagerstown, said U.S. troops ``should just get back over here.'' When the organization Americans Talk Security asked how long U.S. forces should remain in Saudi Arabia if there's a stalemate, only 12 percent said indefinitely. But 32 percent predicted that's how long troops will be there. It was the ``ghost of Vietnam question,'' said Alan Kay, founder of the bipartisan group of pollsters. Sen. Bob Kerrey may have spoken for more Americans than he thought when he said he is ``profoundly uneasy'' about the deployment of U.S. troops in the Middle East. The uneasiness is quiet. People who are uneasy don't usually march in parades and carry banners about it. They're just uneasy. Public opinion polls show broad support for President Bush's actions so far in the gulf crisis, but also show that a large majority of Americans oppose quick military action against Iraq. In Pasadena, Calif., the Rev. George Regas, rector of All Saints Episcopal Church, said ``I think there is a lot of despair. I think Bush is going to be surprised when he thinks that the support he has can be translated into real support for the tragedy of war. I just don't think it's going to be there.'' In Philadelphia, Harold Jordan, coordinator of the National Youth and Militarism Program of the American Friends Service Committee, reported receiving 550 to 600 calls and letters since early August from people who ``never had any contact with organized peace or anti-war movements in the past.'' Some, Jordan said, ``say they would fight if they felt this country was truly threatened, but they don't see this as being a threat.'' Kerrey, a Nebraska Democrat, said in a Sept. 19 speech on the Senate floor, ``I am profoundly uneasy about the instant deployment of over 100,000 American troops, sold to the American people on false assertions that Saddam Hussein is Adolf Hitler, that our way of life is at clear and present danger, that we have as much at stake as we did in World War II.'' Kerrey also said that ``many - probably a majority - of Nebraskans'' had accepted President Bush's rationale for the deployment. More than two weeks later, Kerrey's press secretary, Steve Jarding, said ``That hasn't changed. It's still pretty strong that he ought to be supporting the president.'' Rep. Jim McDermott, D-Wash., on the other hand, said telephone calls and letters from his district have reflected ``a lot of support for the position of getting out of the Arabian desert.'' McDermott voted against a resolution supporting the president's actions in the crisis but emphasizing the need for diplomacy to resolve it. The resolution passed the House 380-29 on Oct. 1 and the Senate passed a similar measure the following day. McDermott said that when he was attending meetings in his home district during the August recess, ``the question was raised, what are we doing in the gulf? It was more a questioning than a statement of support or attack.'' More recently, he said, ``People began to raise the question of: why don't we get out of there?'' Some of the dissent, of course, comes from longtime critics of U.S. military involvement abroad. Demonstrators have begun to appear in Lafayette Square across Pennsylvania Avenue from the White House. On one recent afternoon, reprising a refrain from the Vietnam era, they shouted, ``Hell no, we won't go!'' And the president has his all-out backers as well. ``I support his action and know he has far more advisers with a lot more knowledge of what's going on than I could ever imagine,'' said Darlene Brown of Rockville, Md., president of the Young Republicans of Montgomery County. Yet Jordan of the Quaker-based Friends Service Committee said he is getting calls from people, hardly any of them Quakers, from a ``wide variety of fairly ordinary backgrounds.'' ``We see people from hillbilly country in West Virginia, folks in Idaho, all kinds,'' he said. ``We are getting calls from pay booths on military installations. Some people have made it clear that if they are ordered they are not going. These are people who have been pushed over the edge by the Persian Gulf situation.''

DOC.HEAD: Tough Anti-Tax Measures Face Voters in 11 States
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Voters in 11 states may vent their frustration over government waste and sluggish school reform by passing some of the toughest taxing and spending limits ever considered. The number of anti-tax, anti-spending measures on Nov. 6 ballots doesn't match the peak ``tax revolt'' years in the early 1980s: 18 states had them in 1980, just two years after California's Proposition 13 started it all. But several of this year's crop rank with the most stringent ever considered - a gauge of how fed up many voters may be over what they see as government waste, excessive or unfair taxes, and a much-touted school reform movement that has yet to live up to its promise. ``These people are saying to government, you've failed us. People are really, really up in arms,'' said John Keast, an analyst specializing in ballot measures for the conservative Free Congress Foundation in Washington, D.C. And to the dismay of many politicians and educators who stand to lose the most if the measures are passed, opinion polls show several with an excellent chance of approval. ``They're all bad and we're working hard to defeat them,'' said Keith Geiger, president of the National Education Association, the 2-million member teachers union. ``It would be a tremendous blow to public education in any state that passed them.'' Among the toughest: - Massachusetts' Question 3, a $2 billion tax rollback, 15 percent of the state budget. It would be the largest state tax cut in history. Opponents argue it would gut public education and lead to tens of thousands of state layoffs. But polls show broad support. - Oregon's Measure 5, a permanent cap of 1.5 percent on property tax increases phased in by 1995. Oregon voters defeated five previous attempts to limit taxes. This time, an early poll shows 69 percent favoring. - Colorado's Amendment 1, requiring voter approval for any state or local tax increases, effective Dec. 31. A similar proposal lost by a wide margin in 1988. - Nebraska's Measure 405, which backers call the ``2 percent Solution,'' would put a 2 percent limit on annual state and local budget increases. Local spending restrictions could be overriden by referendum; at the state level, it would take a vote of 40 of the 49 legislators. - California's 28 statewide ballot measures include three proposed tax increases, among them a sharp hike in alcohol taxes. But another issue that would require a two-thirds majority on any ballot issue raising taxes could instantly cancel out any such tax increases. - In Montana, a proposed constitutional amendment would abolish all state income, property and sales taxes and licensing fees, replacing them with a scantly defined ``transaction charge'' of 1 percent on all financial dealings. The plan is so radical that neither backers nor opponents seem sure if it would increase or cut taxes. A second Montana initiative would hike the state cigarette tax 140 percent to 43 cents a pack, which would be the highest in the nation. Elsewhere, Utah voters will decide whether to exempt most food from the state sales tax. A Florida proposal would permit local governments to avoid complying with state laws requiring local funding unless the law fulfills ``an important state purpose.'' An advisory referendum in Wisconsin asks whether the state should be required to pay for any program it mandates on local governments. In Nevada, Gov. Bob Miller and state business groups have begun a $200,000 media campaign o defeat a proposed corporate tax increase to aid education. The state teachers union, the original backer, withdrew its support when it was assured that another tax package would be supported in the 1991 legislative session. But polls still suggest the outcome could go either way. Nevadans also will vote on a constitutional amendment prohibiting personal income taxes. A similar initiative passed in 1988 but must be approved a second time to become part of the state constitution. Three Maryland counties, Anne Arundel, Baltimore and Montgomery, will vote on proposed property tax limits. A fourth, wealthy Talbot County, will decide whether to relax an existing property tax freeze. The Massachusetts and Oregon issues are among the most worrisome to the NEA's Geiger. In Oregon, the tax issue is one of eight volatile ballot initiatives and the potential for confusion is high, he said. Massachusetts officials fear the poorest school districts including Fall River, New Bedford, Holyoke and Lawrence might go bankrupt because they rely almost solely on state education aid. ``We would be on the brink of an educational meltdown,'' said state Education Commissioner Harold Raynolds Jr. The tax battle has also turned bitter in Nebraska, where college leaders, local educators and municipal officials are claiming disaster and massive layoffs if the 2-percent cap is passed. But Omaha tax activist Ed Jaksha, who led the successful petition drive, challenged those dire predictions. ``Can any of you deny the right of the people to enter into the budget making process?'' he demanded at a summit of mayors last month.

DOC.HEAD: Moral Decay? New Study Warns Young Adults Lack Bedrock Values
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Watergate was a word you learned in grade school. Your teen-age years coincided with the ``me decade.'' And come job-hunting time, the ``greed-is-good'' mantra from ``Wall Street'' echoed everywhere. You belong to a generation that is ``less anchored in bedrock ethical values than any other,'' according to a study by the Josephson Institute for the Advancement of Ethics. ``An unprecedented proportion of today's youth lack commitment to core moral values like honesty, personal responsibility, respect for others and civic duty,'' concludes the report scheduled for release Friday. But critics - including educators, ethicists and some of the 18-to-30-year-olds in question - say the Los Angeles-based, non-profit institute's study is overstated. ``I don't see rampant amorality,'' said Stephen F. Davis, a psychology professor at Emporia State University of Kansas. His survey on cheating among 6,000 college students nationwide was one of about a dozen studies on which Michael Josephson based his report. ``There are some messages in our data but certainly I wouldn't go so far as to indict an entire generation based on it,'' Davis said this week. But Josephson said his conclusions, which were drawn from published and unpublished polls, articles and about 40 original interviews, indicated ``a meaningful, demonstrable ... discernible disintegration'' in moral standards. ``It's a total picture that really tells the story,'' said Josephson, whose non-partisan institute conducts ethics programs for the Internal Revenue Service, the Pentagon, several major media organizations and educators. The study's source material included surveys conducted at the California Department of Education, Rutgers University, the University of Delaware and the Higher Education Research Institute at the University of California, Los Angeles. Among the indicators Josephson cites: - During the 1980s, the majority of college freshman surveyed admitted to cheating in high school. - Young Americans are 40 percent less likely to identify frequent newsmakers than those over age 30; those 24 or under vote less than any previous generation. - Professional resume and reference-checking services estimate that from 10 percent to 25 percent of jobseekers - a large percentage of whom are under 30 - falsify their credentials. - A recent published survey found 70 percent of females under 18 were sexually active in 1989 compared with 54 percent a decade earlier; for males, the increase was from 66 percent in 1979 to 72 percent last year. ``It's an interpretation of many isolated pieces of information. They're entitled to their interpretation and maybe they're right, but I'm not in agreement,'' said Elaine El-Khawas, vice president for research at the American Council on Education in Washington, D.C. ``I find much that is heartening.'' John Gabarro, a professor at the Harvard Business School, agreed. ``I've been teaching now for about 18 years and I have not experienced a decline in either the ethical values that students espouse or their concern with those issues,'' Gabarro said. ``In fact, if anything I've seen a keener awareness and interest.'' This is the generation that has watched the stock market plummet, the real estate market bust and the environment grow worse. They rattle off names like Gary Hart, Michael Milken, Ivan Boesky and Donald Trump. ``We've seen that happiness isn't just getting ahead at any cost,'' said Laura Rich, 25, a medical student at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. ``We're trying to make ourselves happy ... but don't see a reason to abandon our morals.'' Arthur Levine, director of Harvard University's educational management institute, said young adults are a product of the ``me era,'' and do in many ways feel a false sense of entitlement. But after more than a decade of surveying his students' values, Levine said he has noticed a welcome swing in recent years toward community commitment and social awareness. ``I'm very optimistic about this generation,'' he said. ``There will always be people willing to do anything to get something,'' said Beth Springer, a brand assistant at The Clorox Co. in Oakland, Calif. ``But there are also lots of people looking to give back to their community.'' But Josephson's study concludes otherwise. ``There are undeniable signs that the moral fiber of our country is weakening,'' the study warns. ``The new generation acts as if the world owes them, as if they have a right to win, as if they need whatever they want and deserve whatever they need.''

DOC.HEAD: American Diplomats' Holdout in Third Month
DOC.TEXT: They are in their third month of holding out against all odds - 10 U.S. diplomats refusing to bow to Iraq's annexation of Kuwait or to leave other Americans in the terrorized Persian Gulf country without an official U.S. presence. Not that Ambassador W. Nathaniel Howell and his beleaguered staff can do much for their 500 or so countrymen, many of whom are in hiding and several of whom are desperately ill. Telephone conversations are intentionally brief, on the supposition that Iraqi eavesdroppers are listening for useful information about the whereabouts of the elusive Americans, their risk-taking Kuwaiti protectors or Washington's intentions. Through satellite communication, the embassy also is in touch with the State Department. Periodically, Iraqi troops seize Americans and dispatch them to oil fields and other installations to serve as human shields against a U.S. assault. They are beyond the reach of Howell and the other diplomats, who themselves are prohibited from leaving the embassy. Nor can anyone or any vehicle enter the embassy with supplies or for whatever reason. More than 100 Americans are forcibly scattered through Kuwait, which Iraqi President Saddam Hussein now regards as a province of his country. There is no indication that the Bush administration is hatching a plot to rescue them. One by one, other governments have yielded to circumstances and closed their embassies. Among Western nations, only Britain, Canada, France and Germany are holding out along with the United States. Conditions inside the compound are rough. An undisclosed number of Americans who managed to take refuge there are sharing limited resources with the diplomats. Water and electricity were cut off a month ago as Iraq tried to enforce its order for foreign embassies to close now that Kuwait no longer was an independent country. The Americans were reduced to boiling the water in the embassy swimming pool. There is some water left, but it is not being replenished. Bathing is out, of course. Generators provide intermittent electricity. Howell, deputy ambassador Barbara Bodine and the other Americans are using outside latrines. They sometimes sleep outdoors at night to keep cool, despite swarms of mosquitoes, according to Jesse Jackson and others who returned from Kuwait last month. ``Their food situation is adequate,'' a U.S. official told The Associated Press on Wednesday. The Americans are subsisting on canned food and perishable items that were stocked in the embassy before Iraq's Aug. 2 blitzkrieg invasion. Nothing has come in since. ``I don't want to speculate how long they are going to hold out,'' said the official, who requested anonymity. The 10 American diplomats are the remnants of a once-sizable embassy. Before the invasion, the heat and dearth of fast-breaking events made assignment to Kuwait less than exciting. On the other hand, the wealth and stability of the oil-rich emirate made Kuwait one of the least difficult posts in the Arab world. About 50 American diplomats and their families left for Baghdad in a motorcade in August only to find when they got there that only the dependents were permitted to fly home. So those diplomats also are stuck, but under less onerous conditions. Life in the Kuwait embassy is ``kind of hot, stuffy and boring,'' the U.S. official said. ``They are still there because we don't recognize the annexation, we will not recognize an order based on annexation, and we want to help American citizens.'' The countries that gave up haven't accepted annexation either. ``They left because they were no longer able to maintain their personnel,'' the official said. Among the Americans, he said, ``morale is pretty high. And yet, they are bored stiff.''

DOC.HEAD: Highlights of Plan Before Senate Finance Committee
With PM-Budget Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are key provisions in the deficit-reduction plan being considered today by the Senate Finance Committee. The plan was proposed by the chairman, Sen. Lloyd Bentsen, D-Texas. The House Ways and Means Committee is considering a similar package, although Chairman Dan Rostenkowski, D-Ill., has not yet presented his recommendations. ENERGY: Raise the 9-cent gasoline tax by another 9 cents in two steps. Home-heating oil would not be affected. ALCOHOL: Double the beer tax to 32 cents a six-pack. Raise taxes on all types of wine; table wine, for example, would go from the present 3 cents a 750-milliliter bottle to 25 cents. The tax on 100-proof liquor, now $12.50 a gallon, would rise to $13.70, or $2.74 a fifth. TOBACCO: Raise the 16-cent tax on cigarettes by 8 cents in two steps. Taxes on chewing tobacco, cigars, snuff and pipe tobacco would go up 25 percent. LUXURIES: Impose a 10 percent tax on the portion of the sales price of cars over $30,000; jewelry and furs over $5,000 and boats over $100,000. AIRLINE TICKETS: Raise the 8 percent tax to 10 percent. MEDICARE WAGES: Apply the 1.45 percent tax that finances part of Medicare to a worker's first $85,000 to $90,000 of wages each year, rather than the first $51,300 under present law. MEDICARE: Boost to $100 the $75-a-year deductible that beneficiaries must pay before Medicare begins paying hospital costs. There would be no increase in the monthly premiums for Medicare Part B. CAPITAL GAINS: Exclude from taxation 30 percent of gains from the sale of property owned three or more years. INCOME-TAX RATES: Eliminate a provision in the law that taxes part of the earnings of the wealthiest Americans at a top rate of 28 percent, while people earning slightly less can face a maximum rate of 33 percent. This would mean a tax increase, for example, for a single person with taxable income above $97,620 and for a couple with no children and a taxable income above $162,770.

DOC.HEAD: 101st Congress Has Much to Do and Little Time
DOC.TEXT: Two weeks from the end of its two-year term, the 101st Congress has little to brag about and much to do. The preoccupation with getting a budget has backed up other important legislation on subjects ranging from clean air and housing to civil rights and child care. With anti-incumbent sentiment running high across the country, no member of Congress wants to face voters having done little more than approve job protection rights for the disabled, an inadequate savings and loan bailout and a congressional pay raise. ``It's been a thin session so far, there's no question about it,'' said Thomas Mann, who studies Congress for the Brookings Institution, a Washington think tank. Before they can go home for an abbreviated campaign season, lawmakers still must pass the nuts and bolts: taxes and spending cuts to enact the vague guidelines they have agreed to in the budget; and the 13 annual spending bills needed to run the government through next Sept. 30. That won't be easy. The bill implementing the budget agreement will have to include $135 billion or more in new taxes, possibly including levies on gasoline, alcoholic beverages and cigarettes, and about $40 billion in Medicare savings including higher deductibles for beneficiaries. ``If the budget deal is genuine, that overwhelms everything else and becomes the major piece of legislation by which the Congress is remembered,'' said Mann. ``They will have tackled the biggest problem that has haunted government for a decade.'' On top of those must-d bills, leaders in both houses have a pared-down list of other items they want badly to complete. Topping the list is a compromise Clean Air Act, the first rewrite since 1977 of the law setting air quality standards. The House and Senate have passed significantly different versions, and negotiators have struggled since July to reconcile them, with little success. The bill would impose broad new air pollution control requirements on factories, power plants and automobiles to ease acid rain and urban smog, and for the first time require broad industrial controls on toxic chemical releases. Estimates are that it would cost as much as $25 billion a year to comply with the tougher regulations when they go into effect toward the end of this decade. Another top priority is legislation providing federal child care assistance, including money to low-income families through tax credits. The House and Senate have passed differing versions, and the bills have been stuck in a conference committee for months. But congressional leaders are pushing their negotiators to agree so a bill can be sent to President Bush. Negotiations are continuing, as well, to compromise on House and Senate versions of a bill providing support for affordable housing for low-income families. One little-noticed measure that falls into the must-pass category is new money for the Resolution Trust Corp., which has run dry as it seeks to take over failed savings and loans. An estimated $90 billion will be needed this year to cover losses and provide working capital. House and Senate conferees also are to begin resolving differences over an anti-crime bill, following House action last week to broaden use of capital punishment and curtail the appeal rights of death row inmates. Negotiations on a new five-year farm bill, which stalled over indecision on the budget, were to continue today with discussion of conservation provisions. Still to be worked out is exactly how commodity subsidies will be trimmed to make the required $13 billion in savings over the life of the bill. Also pending, and facing a presidential veto threat, is a civil rights bill aimed at protecting employees from job discrimination. Elements range from a ban on racial harassment in the workplace to a provision locking in court-approved fair-hiring agreements. The core of the bill would ease the way for minorities to win discrimination suits against employers. The administration and some business groups say the Senate-passed measure would prompt companies to hire by quota as a way of insulating themselves against such suits. The bill would negate or modify 10 Supreme Court decisions since 1985. While the leaders would like to avoid it, many on Capitol Hill believe Congress may have to come back after the elections in November for a lame-duck session to tackle unfinished business. Other items expected to come up in the final days of the congressional session include: -An intelligence authorization bill that has been the focus of a battle between the House and Senate over whether to continue covert U.S. support for rebels in Angola, Afghanistan and Cambodia. -A bill authorizing activities of the National Endowment for the Arts, and deciding how far the government should go in determining whether a work is obscene. -An extension of the nation's borrowing authority to $3.444 trillion. -Whether to grant most-favored-nation trading status to China.

DOC.HEAD: No Phones in the Desert, But Soldier Calls Reach America Anyway
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report. ^By LARRY NEUMEISTER
DOC.TEXT: You can't step into a phone booth in the Saudi Arabian desert and dial up Westport, Mass., but Army Spec. 4 Mike Orr still managed a chat with his wife, Jennifer. The 22-year-old father was told that his 2-month-old son, whom he has seen only briefly, ate baby cereal for the first time Monday. ``He made some funny faces,'' Mrs. Orr said. ``I wish I could have been there,'' he answered. When the soldiers who are part of Operation Desert Shield yearn to hear a voice from home, they have to wait in line at Jeeps to use short-wave radios. They're connected with relatives and friends back home thanks to the hundreds of people in the United States who are licensed to operate on military radio channels and link the transmissions to phone lines. One of them, James Sylvester, operates from the basement of his Queens apartment as a part of the Military Affiliated Radio System. Sylvester and everyone else who uses the radio system never say Saudi Arabia or the desert. They simply refer to it as ``the sandbox.'' In the last three weeks, Sylvester has made more than 350 connections between GIs and the folks at home, while continuing to work at his regular job, as a bus mechanic for the Transit Authority. On some nights, he has skipped sleep entirely rather than leave soldiers disappointed in the desert. Sometimes the static makes mincemeat of the dialogue. For instance, Army soldier 20-year-old Rick Pascoe of Wildwood, Ill., asked Brigid Cromie, a family friend, to make sure he is sent 20 cans of tuna fish in water. The word ``in'' got lost in the transmission. ``I'll ask them to send 20 cans of tuna and a couple of jugs of water,'' Cromie told him. ``No, tuna in water, not water,'' Pascoe corrected. Nearly all of the messages are simple. The soldiers ask about relatives. One asked about a car. Another warned his brother to use condoms. Relatives on the home end ask about the weather or if mail is being received. ``The mail is stockpiling. It's being handed out very slowly,'' said Orr. ``Is it real hot?'' his wife asked. ``It's 3 o'clock in the morning and it's probably 75 degrees,'' he replied. Each person being called in the United States must be told to say ``over'' at the end of each statement so Sylvester knows when to flick the switch back so the soldier can do the talking. The soldiers are warned not to tell about their mission or location. They are limited to five minutes each. One of the soldiers operating a radio from a Jeep in the desert Monday was Sgt. Rich Larue of Scranton, Pa. ``It makes my job really worthwhile,'' he said. ``The guys are really happy once they're connected to be able to talk to their family or spouse.'' Sylvester agreed. ``Some really turn loose,'' he said, referring to calls that bring more tears than words. ``I think after this I might change occupations and become a psychologist.'' ``I love you'' was the most common message among about 15 calls placed Monday evening. One woman cried while she spoke. It appeared to matter little what was said. ``Some people don't care about static,'' Sylvester said. ``As long as they hear a little of the person's voice, that's all that matters.''

DOC.HEAD: Budget Fiasco Makes Government Work Less Appealing, Workers Say
With PM-Budget Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Government job recruiting will suffer following the latest budget dispute, say federal workers who call the weekend shutdown a direct threat to their job security. ``If you were in the top 5 percent of your class, and were excited about doing some significant research for a cure for AIDS, would you want to come to work for the federal government? I think not,'' said John Sturdivant, president of the American Federation of Government Employees. Federal workers have always known they're not going to get rich, added Robert Tobias, president of the National Treasury Employees Union. ``But there was an implicit agreement that they had job security. That agreement has been ripped apart the past few weeks.'' But government hiring officials dismissed the likelihood of any long-term damage from the weekend government shutdown. ``Other than a political brouhaha in Washington, I'm not sure abot any lingering effects on recruitment. This could all be forgotten in three weeks,'' said Richard McGowan, a spokesman for the Office of Personnel Management. ``How much is a kid on a university campus in Cleveland paying attention to this? It looms very large for us in Washington. My own estimate is it probably won't have a big impact on the campuses in the hinterlands,'' added Len Klein, OPM's director of hiring. The government's below-average pay scale - not job security concerns - is what's hurting recruitment, Klein said. Hundreds of thousands of federal workers were spared Tuesday, at least temporarily, from being furloughed after Congress and the White House struck a budget deal and ended a government shutdown that hit over the three-day Columbus Day holiday weekend. The shutdown affected mostly national monuments, parks and museums, which were closed for lack of workers as thousands of disappointed tourists were turned away. The threat of a government shutdown had hung over federal employees for weeks. They still could face furloughs if lawmakers can't reach a budget agreement by Oct. 19. The well-publicized budget dispute - and the way federal workers were caught up in it - will make government work less appealing, especially while the government is trying to spruce up its image, said Sturdivant, president of the 700,000-member AFGE. The federal government already has a bad knock for its pay scale. Federal workers, on average, earn about 22 percent less than their counterparts in the private sector, Sturdivant said. In addition, the government pays about $1,100 a year less in health care premiums for each worker than is paid by the average medium-sized or large corporation. However, OPM's McGowan dismissed the likelihood of any long-term impact, saying there are dozens of ``rewarding and challenging'' career paths available in the civil service. In March, OPM waged a six-city job fair blitz in a bid to lure new hires, bringing along astronauts and undercover agents to show off government careers, McGowan noted. ``We had 30,000 people wrapped around the Labor Department (in Washington) trying to get into government service,'' he said. Federal workers said the latest threat of a shutdown is hurting the United States in other ways. ``Other countries of the world have got to be laughing their heads off. We try to run the world, but we can't manage our own affairs,'' complained Tom Doherty, an Occupational Safety and Health Administration inspector from Allentown, Pa. ``You have no idea the turmoil this has caused for some people, the ones trying to support a family on one paycheck,'' Doherty said. ``I keep telling them, your voice is at the ballot box. Come election time, good, bad or indifferent, we just go in and vote for the guy's opponent.''

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: Bush Defends Abrasive Sununu
DOC.TEXT: John Sununu may have the reputation on Capitol Hill of a bull in a china shop, but his boss says ``there's bound to be a little broken china'' when passions get high. President Bush rallied to the defense of his abrasive chief of staff and his almost equally abrasive budget director, Richard G. Darman. ``I have full confidence in them,'' Bush said at a news conference Tuesday. ``They did an outstanding job.'' Even so, following the collapse of a budget agreement negotiated by the White House and congressional leaders, the two top White House aides have been the target of heavy criticism from congressional budget negotiators of both parties. Sununu and Darman got the vote of confidence from the man who counts. But the residual hard feelings could make it harder for Bush to patch up differences with congressional leaders - and heal the gaping rift among House Republicans - in the coming days. At one point last weekend, Democratic budget negotiators refused to meet with their Republican counterparts if Sununu and Darman were at the table. Rep. Jim Lightfoot, R-Iowa, wrote a letter to Bush urging him to come to Capitol Hill on a peacekeeping mission but to leave the ``pit bulldogs'' at the White House. Lawmakers have bristled at what they say is Sununu's arrogance and heavy-handedness in dealing with members of Congress. Sununu, asked by reporters Tuesday if he thought he had gone too far, retorted: ``I don't think so. We got a budget passed, didn't we?'' Bush, asked if he had taken any members of his staff to the woodshed as a result of the congressional criticism, said: ``Absolutely not.'' ``When the passions get high, I understand that there's bound to be a little broken china up there,'' the president said. It's not the first time that Sununu has been in trouble with Congress on budget issues - or that Bush had to rally to his defense. Early in the budget negotiations last summer, Sununu suggested that the president really didn't mean it when he suggested for the first time that he would consider tax increases to reduce the deficit. Democrats were outraged. White House press secretary Marln Fitzwater had to disavow the remarks. But in the end, Bush stood fast by his embattled aide. Nor is Sununu the first presidential chief of staff to generate harsh feelings. Donald T. Regan, who was President Reagan's chief of staff for most of his second term, was almost universally disliked by Democrats in Congress, many other White House staffers and - perhaps more significantly - by first lady Nancy Reagan. Like Sununu, Regan was accused of being caustic and arrogant. Some of the same criticism was leveled at H.R. Haldeman, President Nixon's heavy-handed chief of staff and a central figure in the Watergate scandal. And President Carter's chief of staff, Hamilton Jordan, so angered then-House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill, D-Mass., that O'Neill deliberately and consistently mispronounced his name, calling him ``Hannibal Jerkin.'' Lawmakers claimed Jordan was arrogant and insensitive and did not understand the workings of Congress. An outsider to Washington, like Sununu, Jordan also didn't work very hard at massaging huge congressional egos. In fact, he probably wouldn't have gotten into so much trouble if he hadn't slighted Tip O'Neill on inauguration tickets back in 1977. One budget negotiator, speaking on the condition of anonymity, said Sununu, a stamp collector, sometimes annoyingly sat at the bargaining table leafing through stamp catalogues. In one episode, reported by The Washington Post, Sununu and Darman put their nameplates along a row of chairs reserved for congressional leaders - and that Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., moved them to the back of the table, saying, ``Staff doesn't sit with the leadership.'' Dole may have more reason to resent Sununu than most. It was Sununu who organized Bush's New Hampshire primary campaign that was the beginning of the end of Dole's 1988 presidential candidacy. But Bush shows no sign of losing confidence in either Sununu or Darman, saying more Republicans have praised than criticized them. ``So what you hear is the squeaking wheel. You hear those that aren't particularly happy,'' he said. --- EDITOR'S NOTE - Tom Raum covers the White House for The Associated Press.

DOC.HEAD: Milan Brings Back the 1960s
DOC.TEXT: Remember the 1960s with its miniskirts, hot pants, shift dresses, colorful prints and false eyelashes? Thirty years later, the Milanese have brought it all back in a sexier, more brazen version: hemlines are shorter, hips tighter and breasts barer. Stretch cottons, rayons and silks are the latest fabrics. Prints are not only painted on rich silk, but also stitched together in a myriad of sparkling sequins. In the makeup department, eyes are as bright as a Barbie dolls', with lashes longer than Liz Taylor ever batted at Richard Burton during the 1961 filming of ``Anthony and Cleopatra.'' The return of the dress is probably the most significant pickup from the 1960s, especially for Milan, famous for its man-tailored look. In fact, trousers have no place in the 1991 spring-summer wardrobe. Legs are either bared by super-short hemlines and snug shorts, or wrapped in skin-tight unitards. The new version of the shift is shorter, often rising to mid-thigh, and tighter, especially when in stretch fabric. And there are lots of A-line and trapeze dresses, as well as halter top sun dresses for town and beach wear. Perhaps most successful at the 1990s style was Krizia, who showed her collection Tuesday. In this era of tough come-and-get-it design, the prettiness of the Krizia collection was refreshing, as was the music which accompanied the show - Nat King Cole oldies. Shifts in demure floral silk prints adorned the first part of the show. For the cocktail hour, Mariuccia Mandelli, the lady behind the Krizia label, offered white silk shifts trimmed with silver, or simple silk apron dresses. As the evening went on hemlines got shorter, brushing the upper thigh. Micro hot pants and bra tops appeared as a reminder that the real '60s are behind us. There have not been a lot of clothes to wear to work in the current collections, unless your job is an aerobics teacher or a nightclub hostess. Therefore, Genny's neat, trim navy blue suits spruced up with large gold buttons received grateful applause from fashion buyers, worried about extravagant styles and shrinking pocketbooks. Genny also had a series of comfortable shifts in muted shades, worn with matching duster jackets and accessoried with gold chain belts with a buckle in the shape of a sea star. The Mediterranean motifs, starfish, coral branches and sea plants appeared throughout the collection from patterns on daytime blouses, to jewelry and belts, to elaborate sequined prints on evening wear. Coral beads decorated simple black A-line dresses, while sea blues and greens provided the background for the glittery coral and starfish prints. The Genny collection, displayed at the midpoint of the five-day ready-to-wear collections for next year's warmer weather, showed that the 1960s could be revived without going to avant-garde extremes, such as the pop-art sequined jackets and fiery hot pants presented by Gianni Versace. The showbiz designer was hailed as the maestro of the 1990s by fashion experts looking for inventive design. But buyers worried by recession, rising oil prices and a falling dollar were relieved to see some stylish, sensible clothes. The fashion crowd was waiting to see what Gianfranco Ferre has to say about all this in his new collection to be presented at the Milan fairground, site of most of the collections seen this week. The final word on the 1960s styles with a 1990 sexy approach is reserved for Giorgio Armani, father of Milan's tailored look, whose collection closes the showings tonight.

DOC.HEAD: FBI Agent Convicted Again of Espionage
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to CORRECT to Tuesday sted Monday.
DOC.TEXT: Former FBI agent Richard Miller was convicted a second time of selling out his country to a Soviet seductress for sex and promises of cash and gold. U.S. District Judge Robert Takasugi, who heard the case without a jury, on Tuesday rejected Miller's claim that he romanced Svetlana Ogorodnikov in a self-styled attempt to infiltrate the KGB. Miller, 54, is the only agent in FBI history to be convicted of espionage. The conviction on charges of passing secrets to the Soviets came after six years and three trials in which prosecutors portrayed him as a weak man lured into treason by lust and greed. The jury at his first trial deadlocked and the guilty verdict at his second trial was overturned on grounds that lie detector evidence was improperly admitted. Miller, who already has served five years in prison, could get up to two life terms plus 50 years at sentencing Jan. 7. He was allowed to remain free on bail. ``I'm dumbfounded. I didn't expect this outcome. I really didn't,'' he said. The judge conceded that Miller may have first dreamed of using his romance with the Soviet agent to infiltrate the KGB. But he concluded that Miller ultimately became the tool of Mrs. Ogorodnikov, a Russian emigre. ``In the battle of wills, Mr. Miller finally succumbed, begrudgingly perhaps,'' Takasugi said. ``He became entangled with Svetlana and compromised his position in the FBI.'' Takasugi said the strongest evidence against Miller was an FBI tape recording of Miller and Mrs. Ogorodnikov. The judge said the conversation clearly demonstrated her dominance over the agent. In that discussion, Miller was heard telling his lover, ``You've stolen my heart,'' to which Mrs. Ogorodnikov responded, ``That's my job.'' Assistant U.S. Attorney Adam Schiff said Miller agreed to accept $50,000 in gold and $15,000 in cash. Lawrence Lawler, agent in charge of the Los Angeles FBI office, said the FBI assessment of damage from the spy scandal remains classified. ``The relationship was not that old,'' Lawler said, adding that damage could have been ``incalculable had it continued until today.'' Defense attorney Joel Levine had argued that the obese, inept Miller was an FBI misfit who tried to redeem a 20-year career by infiltrating the KGB. ``Mr. Miller's plan was procedurally flawed,'' Levine said. ``But everything Mr. Miller did in the FBI was procedurally flawed.'' The prosecutor argued Miller was ripe for recruitment when Mrs. Ogorodnikov lured him with sex and money in 1984. By then, he said, Miller had been repeatedly suspended for obesity; he was plagued by financial problems, had been excommunicated from the Mormon church for adultery, and his marriage was falling apart. ``She was exotic to him,'' Schiff argued. ``He slept with her because he was infatuated with her, not because he was trying to infiltrate the KGB.'' Miller was arrested in 1984. The FBI claimed he had been about to flee the country with Mrs. Ogorodnikov after passing her a classified FBI document titled ``The Positive Intelligence Reporting Guide.'' Mrs. Ogorodnikov, who pleaded guilty and is serving an 18-year term in federal prison, did not testify at the third trial.

DOC.HEAD: US to Vote in UN Against Israel on Jerusalem Killings
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Lead prospects uncertain
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration intends to condemn Israel in the United Nations for using excessive force against Palestinian Arabs in a melee outside the Temple Mount in Jerusalem, U.S. officials say. At least 19 Arabs were killed and more than 100 wounded in a battle Monday with Israeli police. Eleven Jews were hurt, as well, in a barrage of rocks and bottles hurled by Arabs as the Jews prayed at the Western Wall. Authorities in Israel said the police had responded to rock-throwers who used the Temple Mount for violent activities. But President Bush said the police should have exercised more restraint, and American diplomats framed the resolution condemning Israeli security forces during day-long negotiations Tuesday at the United Nations. It was uncertain when the vote would take place because the U.N. Security Council did not convene Tuesday night as scheduled. Diplomats reported scant progress in their search for a compromise. The Palestine Liberation Organization, meanwhile, rejected the U.S. draft as too weak. The United States rarely votes against Israel in the Security Council. Two such instances were condemnation of Israel's destruction of Iraq's nuclear facility near Baghdad in 1981 and criticism of Israel's actions in Lebanon in 1982. Much more often the United States stands with Israel against what generally is considered by the two governments as unjustified or unfair criticism. The resolution, drafted by American diplomats, was adopted by the four other permanent members of the U.N. Security Council - the Soviet Union, China, Britain and France - and is thus veto-proof, said the U.S. officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity. It condemns the violence that broke out Monday ``and particularly the excessive Israeli response,'' one official said. The resolution also welcomes a decision by U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar to send a delegation to Jerusalem to investigate the incident. The officials said the resolution calls on all parties to refrain from violence. In a gesture to Israel, it expresses regret that worshipers also were attacked. ``I am very, very saddened by this needless loss of life,'' Bush said at a news conference Tuesday. He added: ``Israeli security forces need to be better prepared for such situations, need to act with greater restraint, particularly when it comes to the use of deadly force...'' Meanwhile, the State Department in a travel advisory suggested Americans avoid the West Bank and Gaza because of recurrent disturbances in the territories. A department notice said U.S. citizens who must travel there ``should be aware of continuing unrest and tension, including stone-throwing, which can affect visitors.'' At the United Nations, a representative from occupied Kuwait joined Iraq, which annexed his country, and more than 30 speakers in condemning Israel's treatment of Palestinians and demanding that Israeli withdraw from territories captured in the 1967 Middle East war. ``We know full well the bitterness and sufferings of the unarmed Palestinian people under occupation, because we are passing through a similar experience,'' said Sheik Sabah al-Ahmad al-Jaber al-Sabah of Kuwait. Iraq's deputy permanent envoy Sabah Talat Kadrat accused the United States and its allies of ``hypocrisy'' for shielding Israel over the years and failing to condemn and punish Israel for violence against Palestinians. During his news conference, Bush appealed for ``calm on all sides'' and three times referred to ``the Palestine question'' as needing a solution. Previous presidents are not known to have used the phrase. Arabs and their supporters long have demanded the establishment of a state called Palestine on Israeli-held land. Bush's Mideast policy deals with East Jerusalem, Gaza and the West Bank as occupied territory but has been opposed to Palestinian statehood. The president did not intend to signal anything with the phrase and there is ``no change in policy,'' said Roman Popadiuk, a deputy White House press secretary. Bush also said Iraqi President Saddam Hussein should not use ``this unfortunate incident'' to link his occupation and annexation of Kuwait and its oil fields with the Israeli-Palestinian dispute.

DOC.HEAD: Give Him a Foreign Crisis Any Time
DOC.TEXT: President Bush says he doesn't want to submit his presidency to the psychiatrist's couch, but he agrees that he finds it more satisfying to deal with a foreign crisis than one closer to home. The president conceded, for example, that he was more comfortable putting together the coalition of nations that confront Saddam Hussein in the Persian Gulf than horsetrading with Congress on a deficit solution. Bush offered his observations at a news conference Tuesday when he was asked, ``Why do you think you're so much more comfortable with and better at foreign matters than domestic?'' The questioner continued: `To some people, it seems like almost two presidents.'' ``I've read that sophisticated analysis,'' Bush replied, ``and I'm troubled because I don't really know the answer to it.'' He said he did not want ``to get stretched out on the couch too far in terms of analysis'' of his conduct of the presidency, but he didn't quarrel with the questioner's proposition. ``People really basically want to support the president on foreign affairs and partisanship does, in a sense, stop at the water's edge,'' Bush said. ``Whereas on domestic policy, here I am with Democratic majorities in the Senate and Democratic majorities in the House, having to try to persuade them to do what I think is best.'' On the Persian Gulf crisis, he said he enjoyed trying to ``put the coalition together and keep it together and work towards what I think is a proper end, seeing that this aggression doesn't succeed. ``I can't say I just rejoice every time I go up and talk to Danny Rostenkowski, my dear friend, about what he's going to do on taxes.'' Rostenkowski is an Illinois Democrat who chairs the House Ways and Means Committee. Bush's questioner commented, ``It doesn't sound like you have as much fun (with a domestic problem) than with the other.'' The president replied, ``That's about right.''

DOC.HEAD: Workers' Paradise in Ancient Egypt: Eternity with the Boss
DOC.TEXT: Even death couldn't free some workers from their bosses, archaeologists are finding in a newly discovered cemetery near the pyramids. It's the first burial ground ever found for the Egyptian working man of 45 centuries ago. Five other cemeteries with 4,000 tombs flank the pyramids, on the horizon above. But all 4,000 were reserved for royalty, their families and officials, said Zahi Hawass, director-general of antiquities for the pyramids area and the new dig's excavation chief. ``What we haven't found until now is the working class,'' said Hawass. ``We were shocked when we looked at inscriptions of who was buried in the new tombs. Overseers holding their sticks. And behind, skeletons of workers.'' He said it appears the workers were members of the foremen's crews. The first eight tombs, three miles south of the Sphinx, lie at the base of sand hills stretching endlessly into the desert. Hawass said the cemetery undoubtedly extends deep into the dunes. Tombs date from the fourth dynasty - 4,600 years ago when the Giza pyramids were built - until the sixth, 300 years later. It's a mysterious period when legend says workers grew tired of almighty pharaohs and of building pyramids for them. Because no middle-class burials had been discovered on sacred Giza plateau, some Egyptologists have theorized that the afterlife was perceived as off-limits to the working man. But the new cemetery proves that pharaonic blue-collar workers prepared for eternity as their betters did, being buried with amulets, limestone tablets, offering tables, pottery vessels and more. The largest tomb, built for a fifth-dynasty overseer named Ptah-Shepses, is 20 feet by 6{ feet with an arched ceiling. To the rear of the tomb, in a honeycomb of compartments, excavators found six skeletons buried in the fetal position. Hawass said they were members of one work crew. Ancient Egyptians didn't practice human sacrifice, so the workers were not killed and buried at the same time as their bosses. And Hawass said there's no indication so far how a foreman chose the workers to be buried near him. ``Perhaps they were his favorites. Or perhaps we'll find others when we keep digging,'' Hawass said. ``We have no idea how many people an overseer would have had on his staff.'' Foremen handled day-to-day administration of the pharaohs' estates, with responsibilities comparable to farm managers or assembly-line supervisors in today's world. ``They dressed better, ate better and wanted better tombs than the men who worked for them,'' Hawass said. ``They looked at the pyramids and the fancy tombs of the officials. They knew they couldn't afford such luxury. Still they wanted a nice place to spend eternity.'' More information about the ancient blue-collar workers will come from medical tests Egyptian doctors are performing on the skeletons. Data is expected to indicate the workers' general appearance, their height and weight, what they ate, what diseases bothered them, even what killed them. In 1987, Hawass and Egyptologist Mark Lehner of Yale University began a search for homes of workers who built the three Giza pyramids. At a site some distance from the monuments, they uncovered ruins of a business center and other artifacts. They stopped excavating in early 1988. The recently discovered tombs lay undetected only a few feet away. But early last summer, a tourist hired a saddle horse for a ride around the pyramids. During the tour her horse fell through the sand, ending on top of what proved to be the roof of the first tomb. Nobody got the tourist's name, and chances are she still doesn't know her outing made history. For years, riders heading for the most spectacular view of the pyramids have passed in front of the Sphinx and through an ancient stone gate into the desert. No records existed to explain the gate. But ``once we found the cemetery we understood,'' Hawass said. ``The gate divided the world of the pharaohs from the world of the average man.'' He explained that the foremen and their crews lived and were buried in their own world behind the gate. By day they passed through the gate into their pharaoh's sacred world, then returned at sunset to work on their own tombs.

DOC.HEAD: Martin Media Adviser Calls Simon `Slimy,' `Weenie'
DOC.TEXT: Rep. Lynn Martin's media adviser called Democratic Sen. Paul Simon a ``weenie'' and said he was ``slimy.'' Simon has ``slandered'' Martin by running TV ads that say the former teacher is an enemy of senior citizens and schools, said Roger Ailes, the ad man who formerly worked for President Bush's campaign. Ailes acknowledged Tuesday that Martin voted against increasing Medicare spending and against lowering the rate of out-of-pocket costs, ``but these were not votes to cut Medicare.'' ``Simon is just being Simon, which is unfortunately being slimy,'' Ailes said at a news conference. Ailes also called Simon a ``weenie,'' a comment that later led to an apology from Martin, the Republican challenging Simon for his Senate seat Nov. 6. Martin trails Simon in polls and is running out of money for ads. Simon campaign manager Anne Roosevelt said Martin is ``getting awfully desperate if she's sending in her media adviser as a hatchet man to call Paul Simon names.'' Roosevelt said calling Simon ``slimy is a little like Saddam Hussein complaining about American aggression.''
DOC.HEAD: House Hopeful Blames Personal Problems for Failure to File Reports
DOC.TEXT: Congressional candidate Robert H. Gaffner says business and personal problems are to blame for his failure to file federal campaign reports for two years. The Republican is challenging Democratic Rep. Jerry Costello but admits he hasn't filed financial reports on his 1988 run against Costello. ``It hurts my candidacy, there is no question about that,'' he said. ``I am in arrears; I have no excuse other than the personal excuse.'' He promised to have financial reports in the mail to the Federal Election Commission no later than Friday. Gaffner's father, who is 90, is gravely ill, and the candidate said he had been working to liquidate his father's truck-repair business. Also, Gaffner recently completed a successful campaign on behalf of his employer, St. Louis Community College, to get voter approval for higher tuition. He is assistant to the chancellor and director of the college foundation. Gaffner could face civil penalties of $10,000 if the commission finds that he willfully violated the rules.
DOC.HEAD: Williams Outspends Richards 2-1
DOC.TEXT: Republican Clayton Williams has outspent Democrat Ann Richards more than 2-1 in the most expensive governor's race in Texas history. Since March, Williams has raised about $8.1 million and spent $7.5 million, according to finance reports filed Tuesday. Richards has received $4.3 million and spent $3.7 million over approximately the same period. Williams spent about $8.5 million - $6.6 million of it from his personal ranching and oil fortune - in winning the GOP primary campaign, according to the reports filed with the secretary of state's office. Richards spent about $5.75 million in the Democratic Party primary and runoff.

DOC.HEAD: TV's Old Shows Dominate Ratings
With PM-Nielsens-List
LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: Television's old favorites continue to dominate the fall season while most of the networks' new shows draw mediocre ratings. For the third consecutive week, NBC's 9-year-old ``Cheers'' was the most-watched show on television, followed by the network's ``The Cosby Show.'' In the overall ratings, NBC squeaked past the competition for the No. 1 spot, the A.C. Nielsen Co. reported Tuesday. NBC had a 12.9 average, ABC a 12.6 and CBS a 12.3. Each ratings point represents 931,000 homes. Since the Sept. 17 opening of the new season, the networks have been separated by less than a point. The only new show among last week's top 10 was ABC's ``America's Funniest People,'' in seventh place. ``Grand,'' which aired in the spring as a replacement series, placed 14th with its fall premiere. The next-highest spot claimed by a new program was 32nd place, where CBS' ``The Trials of Rosie O'Neill,'' featuring former ``Cagney & Lacey'' star Sharon Gless, tied with NBC's ``Fresh Prince of Bel-Air,'' starring the rap star Fresh Prince. CBS' first ever baseball playoff coverage provided lackluster ratings. The second game of the American League playoffs between Oakland and Boston, broadcast Sunday, ranked 28th. The first game of the National League playoffs between Cincinnati and Pittsburgh, broadcast Thursday, ranked 41st. In the network news, ABC and Peter Jennings placed first with a 10.2 average, followed by NBC and Tom Brokaw with an 8.5. CBS and Dan Rather had an 8.2. Here are the top 10 shows, their network and rating: ``Cheers,'' NBC, 21.1; ``The Cosby Show,'' NBC, 19.5; ``A Different world,'' NBC, 19.4; ``America's Funniest Home Videos,'' ABC, 18.9; ``Designing Women,'' CBS, 18.2; ``Roseanne,'' ABC, 18.1; ``America's Funniest People,'' ABC, 18; ``Murphy Brown,'' CBS, 17.7; ``Unsolved Mysteries,'' NBC, 17.2; ``Golden Girls,'' NBC, 17.1.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd item to CLARIFY Monahan also appeared in `Porky's' sequels.
DOC.TEXT: The last time some people saw Dan Monahan he was a wimpy high school student named Peewee, peeking through a hole in the girls' locker room in the 1981 movie ``Porky's.'' Monahan is still hanging around locker rooms. This time, he's not acting. The hot-to-trot nerd in ``Porky's'' and two sequels has given up acting to be the sales representative and promotions director of the Northern Indiana Basketball Corp., Fort Wayne's new franchise in the Continental Basketball Association. ``It's still entertainment in a sense, and yet it's different,'' Monahan said Monday. ``That's what I need.'' The team, as yet unnamed, begins CBA play in the 1991-92 season.

DOC.HEAD: Invasion Not Seen As Threat To Rare Gorillas, And May Even Help Them
DOC.TEXT: Rwanda's rare mountain gorillas do not appear endangered by a guerrilla insurgency, and may even benefit if the fighting scares off tourists who in large numbers can threaten the animals health, conservationists say. Since the rebels invaded the central African nation from neighboring Uganda late last month the gorillas' habitat - the setting for the 1988 movie ``Gorillas in the Mist'' - has remained calm. Fighting has been concentrated in the north and northeast and in the capital, Kigali, 75 miles southeast of the volcanic Virunga Mountains where the world's remaining 310 mountain gorillas live. ``We are working on the basis that this will not alter the existing conservation programs,'' a spokesman for the main international wildlife consortium operating in Rwanda said by telephone. The Kenya-based consortium includes the Africa Wildlife Foundation, the Flora and Fauna Preservation Society and the Worldwide Fund for Nature. It withdrew its foreign staff from Rwanda in January as part of plans to form a new joint body to cover the gorillas' entire remaining natural habitat along the borders with Uganda and Zaire. Revenue from gorilla-gazing tourists is Rwanda's third-largest source of income. But conservationists have expressed concern over the government's desire to increase the size of tourist parties allowed into the narrow 25-mile strip of forest on foot. They argue that the present system of four groups of six tourists per day is the maximum both the gorillas and the ecology can stand. With an entry fee to the nature preserve of $200 per person, the government wants to increase the size of the groups to eight people each per day, with an even larger number during the peak mid-year holiday season. ``It's tempting but it really is a question of whether you want kill the goose that lays the golden egg,'' said Rosalind Eveling of the Africa Wildlife Foundation in Nairobi. ``We are dealing with a very fragile resource.'' Groups of up to eight tourists were taken into the forest during the peak season this year. But they were later reduced to the original limit of six. ``We would be very concerned if they put it up again. From an economic point of view, they also risk destroying the elite experience of seeing the gorillas,'' she added. Because the treks on foot take several hours, tourists already are allowed to hire African bearers to carry cameras, packed lunches and extra clothing. According to conservation literature distributed by American anthropologist Dian Fossey's Digit Fund, the gorillas risk catching human illnesses from visitors or from their garbage, such as eggshells and fruit peels. The fund says the rare primates are close enough biologically to humans to be susceptible particularly to human parasites passed in urine and feces. Tourists with contagious illnesses should never be allowed into the Parc des Vulcans, says the fund. Fossey, portrayed in ``Gorillas in the Mist,'' was mysteriously murdered in her mountain hut in 1985 while she worked to save the animals from poachers. The Digit Fund, an Englewood, Colo.-based organization, is named after a slain gorilla Fossey knew for its twisted finger. Fossey got to know many gorilla families, making them approachable to within the reach of a human arm, although touching them is strictly prohibited today. For many years, the 200-pound, growling, chest-beating gorillas were thoght of in the West as King Kongs, but ``Fossey discovered they are gentle and understanding'' and only attack when provoked, says the fund. The rebels, who invaded Sept. 30, belong mostly to Rwanda's minority Tutsi ethnic group. They were chased from power three decades ago by the majority Hutu tribe in clan fighting that killed tens of thousands of people. The rebels accuse President Juvenal Habyarimana of abuse of power and corruption and say they want to install a democratic government.

DOC.HEAD: House Panel Rebuffs Justice Department on Probe of Iraqi Loans
DOC.TEXT: Congressional investigators are rejecting a protest from Attorney General Dick Thornburgh and continuing their examination of secret loans to Iraq from an Italian bank's Atlanta office. ``The Congress has the supremacy of the right to know and obtain information,'' Rep. Henry B. Gonzalez, D-Texas, chairman of the House Banking Committee, said Tuesday. Thornburgh told Gonzalez in a Sept. 26 letter that taking public testimony from prosecutors and potential witnesses in the Banca Nazionale del Lavoro case could jeopardize the Justice Department's criminal investigation. He expressed his ``profound disappointment'' that Gonzalez had ignored his department's ``strong objections'' and scheduled a hearing for Oct. 16. ``This is a sensitive case with national security concerns,'' Thornburgh wrote. Gonzalez replied Tuesday that the case ``involves a serious regulatory breakdown'' and could cost the U.S. government hundreds of millions of dollars because it had guaranteed some of the loans. He said the committee would base its investigation on publicly available information and said the administration's reluctance to cooperate represented ``fear of embarrassment more than anything else.'' According to Gonzalez, the Atlanta office of the Rome-based institution approved $2.9 billion in unauthorized loans to Iraq during and just after its war with Iran. About $1.8 billion was actually disbursed. The activity went undetected by Georgia banking regulators and examiners from the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta and was not stopped until August 1989, when the FBI raided the office. ``The state banking agency responsible ... fell asleep at the switch, and the Federal Reserve ... was found asleep at the same switch,'' Gonzalez charged. ``These unauthorized loans increased Iraq's credit capacity and permitted Iraq to spend more of their scant hard currency on the very weapons now aimed at our children,'' he said. Now, repayment is in doubt and U.S. taxpayers may end up owing the Italian bank between $400 million and $600 million, according to the Banking Committee's staff. The Agriculture Department's Commodity Credit Corp. had guaranteed a portion of the loans, which were used to purchase U.S. farm products. State and federal regulators are scheduled to appear before the committee next week. Gonzalez said he would like to subpoena other witnesses. But he could not on Tuesday because only he and three others on the 51-member panel attended a meeting to hear a staff aides outline the case. The House had been in session until early morning working on budget legislation. Gonzalez said the Banca Nazionale del Lavoro affair raises larger questions about whether U.S. laws are able to prevent foreign governments from carrying out their policies through the American banking system. Foreign banks now own more than $520 billion, or 22 percent, of U.S. banking assets, he said. Banca Nazionale del Lavoro is primarily owned by the Italian government and is Italy's second-largest bank. It fired most of its employees in Atlanta and maintains the Iraqi loans were recorded only on a secret set of books. It has said the loans were unauthorized either by its regional headquarters in New York or by top bank officials in Rome. However, Dennis M. Kane, a banking panel aide, said an internal audit obtained by the committee showed bank officials in New York were aware of discrepancies in the Atlanta office's books by the end of 1988, yet failed to inform federal or state regulators. Italian legislators are investigating the case from Rome, where it is referred to as Iraqgate.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Praises Business Role in Campaign Against Drugs
