DOC.TEXT: President Bush says American business is making progress toward driving drug abuse out of the workplace and the community at large. ``It's almost like some of you are adopting the communities in which you live, and it's a wonderful thing,'' Bush told top executives gathered Tuesday for a briefing from the administration on drugs in the workplace. ``Now, many corporations fighting to make the workplace and the larger community drug-free are exactly what we talk about when we talk about this concept points of light,'' Bush said, referring to his volunteerism. campaign. He told the business leaders that the fight against drugs in the workplace represents more than merely a ``do-good'' project. ``It's smart business and it is, indeed, in many instances the key to our economic survival,'' he said. ``To maintain our edge in an increasingly sophisticated international economy, our workers have got to be literate and well-trained and indeed drug free,'' the president said. ``And so when I talk about competitiveness now, I talk about the workplace being drug-free.'' He said there were ``countless ways in which corporate America can make a real difference in the communities in helping them be drug-free.'' ``There are counseling and treatment programs in the workplace for drug-dependent workers,'' he said. ``Education programs show employees how to avoid the temptation of drugs.'' Bush described as ``outstanding'' the job that national drug policy director William Bennett has done. He said the administration has done its part in the campaign by strengthening interdiction efforts, supporting law enforcement and expanding treatment efforts. The president said, however, that the government alone will never be able to win the war against drugs. ``It simply cannot be,'' he said. ``And so we have to enlist the aid of every corporation.''

DOC.HEAD: Governors, Administration Look at National Exam
DOC.TEXT: Governors and Bush administration officials disagree over the need for a national exam to keep track of students' academic performance but favor giving schools a list of what students should know in each subject. Colorado Gov. Roy Romer insisted Tuesday that assessment can be used to promote true educational reform in the United States but stopped short of endorsing the idea of national testing in America. South Carolina Gov. Carroll A. Campbell Jr. said states need to know how their students compare with each other. But Missouri Gov. John Ashcroft said state-by-state comparisons could be made without ``national uniform tests.'' The governors led the discussions during the inaugural meeting of a bipartisan panel created this summer to assess and report on progress to achieve national goals to improve education. Education Secretary Lauro Cavazos and White House domestic policy chief Roger Porter were the administration's representatives but top congressional leaders were absent because of budget battles on Capitol Hill. The idea of national testing already is being discussed by the President's Advisory Committee on Education Policy. But some educators argue that education is a local and state responsibility and a national test would destroy the tradition. ``Can we help ... each school building in America arrive at better assessment? I think the answer is `yes,''' said Romer, chairman of the Education Goals Panel. ``But we need to be cautious and careful about how we do it. ``One of the initial steps we can help (with) is to say, `This is what you need to know and this is what you need to be able to do ...' And then we can leave it to the school to design its own curriculum,'' he said. Romer said experts generally agree, for instance, that there are specific things students should know for various levels of mathematics. Porter said the panel must search for ways to measure competency without federal testing. He said an appropriate approach would be to establish a national reporting system, while maintaining local assessments that can allow state-by-state comparisons. Indiana Gov. Evan Bayh agreed with Porter on that approach. ``I would say it is not necessary to have a national uniform test to demonstrate proficiency in certain skills,'' said Missouri's Ashcroft. ``We do want to be able to assess our own performance against the rest of the country, not necessarily nationally uniform ....'' Campbell insisted that states need to be able to compare students' progress. He said comparisons would be difficult if there are wide varieties of student assessments and tests. ``States need to know where they stand nationally, to compare apples and apples, instead of apples and oranges,'' said the South Carolina governor, who took part in developing the national goals. ``Our state is a struggling state, but if we struggle only against ourselves, we're not going to go anywhere,'' Campbell said. ``I think I need to know what tests results are in Missouri ... California ... and I need to know where our students compare.''

DOC.HEAD: National Gallery Plans Huge Show for 500th Columbus Anniversary
DOC.TEXT: The National Gallery of Art is mounting a huge show about the world of 1492, to mark the 500th anniversary of Christopher Columbus' first voyage to America. ``It is the most complex and ambitious we have ever put on,'' gallery director J. Carter Brown said Tuesday of the exhibit, which opens in a year. It embraces not only the Mediterranean countries Columbus knew and the America that he opened to Europe, but also the Asia that he always thought he had reached. Brown said 1492 marks the beginning of the modern era. The voyages of Columbus came after the invention of printing and this advance in communications made it certain that the news of the discoveries would be widely and rapidly spread, he pointed out. ``Circa 1492: Art in the Age of Exploration'' will open on Oct. 12, 1991, Columbus Day, and continue Jan. 12, 1992. It will include more than 400 paintings, sculptures, drawings, maps, screens, scrolls, scientific instruments and other objects from the period of his lifetime, borrowed from about 20 countries. The show will be sponsored by the Ameritech regional telephone company, the Republic National Bank of New York and the Nomura Securities Co., Ltd.-Mitsui Taiyo Kobe Bank, Ltd. of Japan. They are contributing $750,000 each, Brown said. He said the total cost of the exhibit would be ``several million dollars.'' Admission is expected to be free, as for other exhibits at the gallery. The gallery is producing a 30-minute film, ``Beyond the Vanishing Point,'' to go with the show. The title refers to the use of perspective in European painting, a practice that became widespread in the period covered by the show. The film is supported by Canon, U.S.A., a subsidiary of the Japanese camera company.

DOC.HEAD: Psychiatrist Testifies Surrogate-Baby Bond Paramount
DOC.TEXT: A surrogate mother established a physical and emotional bond during pregnancy that entitles her to custody of a baby that is genetically unrelated, a psychiatrist testified. ``The natural mother is the woman who gives birth to the child, and that includes whether or not the child is of her genetic origins,'' Dr. Michelle Harrison said Tuesday at a custody hearing over a 3-week-old boy. Ms. Harrison testified on behalf of Anna Johnson in Ms. Johnson's dispute with the baby's genetic parents, Mark and Crispina Calvert. The Superior Court hearing was to continue today. The Calverts had hired Ms. Johnson to carry their baby for $10,000 and supplied the sperm and egg, but Ms. Johnson decided to back out of the deal. The case may set precedent because the surrogate has no genetic link to the baby. The landmark Baby M case in New Jersey involved a surrogate who was also the genetic mother. Attorneys say the California case could result in a ruling on what constitutes parenthood: the genetic link or the act of giving birth. Ms. Johnson has said that she became attached to the baby and that the Calverts neglected her and the pregnancy. The Calverts have accused her of being motivated by money and publicity. They have custody in the meantime. Psychologist David Chamberlain, vice president of the Prenatal and Perinatal Psychology Association of America, also testified for the surrogate. He said ``nothing could be closer than a baby in utero and the birth mother.'' But when asked by the Calverts' attorney, Christian Van Deusen, whether the couple ``have a right to their own offspring,'' he responded yes. Ms. Harrison, a teacher at the Univrsity of Pittsburgh and consultant to the National Coalition Against Surrogacy, counseled Johnson by telephone during her pregnancy. Ms. Harrison, questioned about Ms. Johnson's twice weekly visits with the baby, said Ms. Johnson believes the boy recognizes her by smell, feels safe with her and attempts to nurse. However, Ms. Harrison she could not judge either side's attachment to the child because she has never seen either the surrogate or the Calverts with the boy. Ms. Johnson, who worked with Mrs. Calvert at a Santa Ana hospital, was hired by the couple to bear their child because a hysterectomy prevents Mrs. Calvert from carrying a baby.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese American Internees Get Apologies, $20,000 Checks
DOC.TEXT: Nine Japanese Americans, including six age 100 and older, have received $20,000 checks at a ceremony kicking off a three-year $1.25 billion program to compensate people imprisoned during World War II because of their ancestry. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh knelt as he made the first presentation Tuesday to Rev. Mamoru Eto, 107, the second-oldest survivor of the internment camps. Eto, of Los Angeles, was seated in a wheelchair. In a gesture that symbolized the nation's effort to apologize, Thornburgh also dropped to his knees as he gave checks to five other elderly men and women also seated in wheelchairs. ``By forcing us to reexamine our history, you have made us even stronger and more proud,'' Thornburgh said. ``Your efforts have strengthened this nation's Constitution by reaffirming the inalienability of our civil rights.'' The nine at Tuesday's ceremony also received a letter from President Bush that said, in part: ``A monetary sum and words alone cannot restore lost years or erase painful memories. ... But we can take a clear stand for justice and recognize that serious injustices were done to Japanese Americans during World War II.'' An estimated 65,000 Japanese Americans are expected to receive $20,000 checks over the next three years under an entitlement program enacted by Congress. In 1988, Congress passed legislation apologizing for the internment, stating that it was ``motivated largely by racial prejudice, wartime hysteria, and a failure of political leadership.'' But it was not until this year that lawmakers appropriated money to begin paying compensation, beginning with the oldest and ending with the youngest survivors of the detention. Congress set aside $500 million for the 1991ffiscal year, $500 million for the 1992 fiscal year and an estimated $250 million for the 1993 fiscal year.

DOC.HEAD: Four-Star General Retiring After 37 Years of Service
DOC.TEXT:
Gen. Maxwell Thurman, commander of the U.S. Southern Command and the field commander in charge of the 1989 invasion of Panama, is retiring. The Pentagon announced Tuesday that Thurman, 59, who was diagnosed with leukemia last July, is undergoing chemotherapy treatment at Johns Hopkins Oncology Center in Baltimore. The Pentagon said Lt. Gen. George A. Joulwan, 50, commanding general of the 5th Corps, U.S. Army Europe and the Seventh Army, has been nominated by President Bush to replace Thurman and to be promoted to the rank of general. Thurman has been commander of the U.S. Southern Command, based at Quarry Heights, Panama, since September 1989. He played a central role in drafting the invasion plan for the December 1989 invasion. The four-star general had been scheduled to take mandatory retirement in August 1989 but Defense Secretary Dick Cheney insisted he take over the Southern Command to help with the administration's struggle with Gen. Manuel Noriega's regime in Panama. Cheney also announced Tuesday that Adm. Huntington Hardisty, commander in chief of the U.S. Pacific Command, is retiring after 38 years of active service. He is to be succeeded by Adm. Charles Larson, commander in chief of the U.S. Pacific Fleet.
---
DOC.HEAD: Investigators Call Sexual Harassment Common at Naval Academy
DOC.TEXT:
Sexual harassment of female students at the Naval Academy is widespread, and some victims don't complain openly for fear of reprisal, according to an internal academy report. ``In such a climate it is not surprising that some midshipmen have lost the ability to distinguish a blatant incident of sexual harassment from routine pranks,'' said the report released Tuesday. The report by a seven-member panel of academy faculty, military staff and midshipmen said immediate action is needed to correct the conditions allowing mistreatment of women. ``Most midshipmen readily acknowledge women midshipmen are not accepted as equals in the (academy),'' said the report by the academy's Women Midshipmen Study Group. ``This lack of acceptance has created an environment in which steady, low-level sexual harassment passes as normal operating procedure in many areas and classrooms alike.'' The report was one of several special inquiries prompted by a hazing incident at the academy last December in which a female student was handcuffed by male midshipmen to a urinal as other men jeered and took photographs. The woman, Gwen M. Dreyer, a second-year student, resigned from the academy last May, citing her humiliation and anger at the way the academy responded to it. At the Pentagon, Navy Secretary H. Lawrence Garrett III said ``prompt action will be forthcoming'' to address the concerns raised by the inquiry reports.
---
DOC.HEAD: Group Says Public Health Insurance Far More Efficient Than Private
DOC.TEXT: Sector

Commercial health insurance companies spend 14 times as much on overhead as the federal Medicare program and 11 times as much as the Canadian national health care system, according to a private group. If the private health insurance industry were as efficient as Medicare, about $13 billion could be saved and used to provide insurance to 11 million uninsured people, concluded the report issued Tuesday by Citizen Action. ``Competition in the insurance market is wasteful and expensive,'' said Robert Brandon, vice president of the group. ``In health care, a free market cannot work. What we need is a single-payer system, where the government is the sole insurer.'' The Health Insurance Association of America said Citizen Action's study was misleading because it did not include Blue Cross and Blue Shield plans or plans sponsored by large, self-insured companies. The association also said that private insurers are spending an increasing amount of money to make sure doctors' and hospitals' bills are appropriate. Citizen Action's report showed that in 1988 commercial health insurance companies spent 33.5 cents on administration, marketing, commissions and other overhead expenses for every dollar in claims paid out. By comparison, Medicare's administrative costs were 2.3 cents per dollar in claims paid out. In the Canadian health care system, administrative costs amounted to about 3 cents per dollar in claims paid, the group said. The industry association said that if Blue Cross and Blue Shield and self-insured plans are factored in, the 1988 administrative costs in the private sector drop to 13 cents for each dollar of benefits paid. Private insurance companies, in their efforts to compete for more business, spend money on things that are not necessary when coverage is provided by a single public program, the group said. One of these functions is the internal review required to deny claims. ``Incredibly, the commercial insurance way of paying for health care leaves Americans spending more to deny people coverage than it would cost to provide everyone with coverage,'' the report said. Citizen Action is a nonprofit, consumers rights group with affiliates in 30 states.

DOC.HEAD: Leonard Bernstein Giving Up Conducting
DOC.TEXT: Conductor Leonard Bernstein, the ``West Side Story'' composer who mesmerized audiences with his passion and physical flair at the podium, is giving up the baton because of poor health. The 72-year-old maestro suffers from a lung tumor, emphysema and pulmonary infections and has been told by his doctor to stop conducting and performing on the piano, his spokeswoman said Tuesday. ``Leonard Bernstein will henceforth devote his professional energies to composing, writing and education,'' said Margaret Carson. He last conducted Aug. 19 at the Tanglewood Music Center in western Massachusetts. Bernstein's announcement was met with dismay in the music world, especially at the New York Philharmonic, which he directed from 1958 to 1969. ``I receive this unfortunate news in utter shock,'' said Zubin Mehta, music director. Albert K. Webster, managing director of the Philharmonic, said: ``Leonard Bernstein has BEEN the New York Philharmonic for more than 45 years. We all will be less for the loss of his magic baton.'' Bernstein still hopes to participate in an AIDS benefit at Carnegie Hall on Oct. 28 but canceled all appearances with orchestras in New York, Israel, Vienna and London and with festival orchestras at Tanglewood, Germany and Japan. Bernstein, known for his vigorous style at the podium, once led an orchestra performance at a liberated concentration camp. Last Christmas, he celebrated the tumbling of the Berlin Wall by conducting Beethoven's ``Ninth Symphony.'' In May, he canceled plans to conduct opening night of the Spoleto Festival in Charleston, S.C., citing ``a near brush with pneumonia.'' Carson said Bernstein has had increased difficulty breathing in past weeks. Dr. Kevin M. Cahill attributed the problem to emphysema complicated by a tumor and pulmonary infections. Bernstein was once a heavy smoker. Bernstein is not hospitalized. Carson said the conductor was told that rest offers the best hope for returning to limited activities. She said Bernstein plans to continue work on a new chamber music piece to be performed next spring, a new musical theater work he hopes to finish by summer and several educational, film and recording projects, as well as his memoirs. Bernstein was the wunderkind of American music at a time when all respected conductors in the United States were born and trained in Europe. His first published composition was ``The Clarinet Sonata'' in 1942. He conducted his first symphony, the ``Jeremiah,'' with the Pittsburgh Symphony in 1944. That year his ballet, ``Fancy Free,'' choreographed by Jerome Robbins, opened and became the basis for the Broadway musical ``On the Town.'' After Boston Symphony Orchestra conductor Serge Koussevitzky died in 1951, Bernstein became head of the orchestra and conducting departments at Tanglewood. His first opera, ``Trouble in Tahiti,'' was performed in 1952. He composed ``Candide'' in 1956 and ``West Side Story'' in 1957. In 1969, he retired from the post to concentrate on composing and was appointed the Philharmonic's laureate conductor for life. He has conducted 1,244 New York Philharmonic concerts, more than any other conductor.

DOC.HEAD: Desert Not All That's Hot in Persian Gulf
DOC.TEXT: As if things weren't hot enough in the Saudi desert, soldiers are asking for chiles to spice up their rations. Chile farmer Jo Lytle is sending off packages of dried green chiles and jalapenos for soldiers with a hankering for some picante. The dried chile is a regular item in Lytle's shop, Hatch Chile Express, where she and her husband also sell knickknacks and trinkets with a chile motif. Ms. Lytle said she sent some of the dried chiles to her nephew, who is serving in the Persian Gulf, after he wrote home asking for Tabasco sauce and chile to spice up his meals. Over the weekend, a Nebraska man called and ordered some of the chile for his son, who had lived in New Mexico. ``The word is passing and the moms and dads are calling,'' Ms. Lytle said. ``(The soldiers) put it in their soups and sprinkle it on their food. Of course then the guy in the bunk nearby sees it and says, `Hey, where did you get that?' '' Ms. Lytle and her husband, Jimmy, own 600 acres of farmland and grow 16 varieties of chile. Ms. Lytle said she grinds the dried chile sold in her shop at a large hammer mill on the farm. New Mexico is the nation's No. 1 producer of chile peppers. The Hatch area has a reputation for some of the state's best chile and annually holds a festival celebrating the vegetable.

DOC.HEAD: Rappers' Trial Opens With Calls of Unconstitutional Jury Selection
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Jury selection scheduled to resume 2 p.m. EDT
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto MH4 of Oct. 9
DOC.TEXT: The defense in the 2 Live Crew obscenity trial contends there aren't enough blacks and young people among the prospective jurors. Three of the first 25 potential jurors questioned Monday and Tuesday were black and one was under 25, said Bruce Rogow, attorney for the three members of the black rap group arrested for performing songs from an album pronounced obscene. Jury selection was to continue today. ``You don't have to be a genius to look at this jury pool and see that's not what Broward County looks like,'' Rogow said. The makeup of the jury is particularly important because obscenity cases depend on how the jury defines community standards. In addition, rap music is aimed primarily at a black audience, and the rap group and its defenders have claimed the case smacks of racism. Rogow challenged Broward County's voter-based jury pool as unconstitutional in cases like obscenity that depend on community standards. Judge June Johnson said she wanted to see the whole 70-person pool before ruling on the challenge. Meanwhile, prosecutors Tuesday lost a bid to have the judge removed from the case on grounds that Rogow was her law professor at Nova University 15 years ago. Johnson refused to step down, saying she had lost touch with Rogow since then. Luther Campbell, Chris Wongwon and Mark Ross were charged after they performed songs from ``As Nasty as They Wanna Be'' on June 11 at an adults-only show at a Hollywood club. Days before, a federal judge ruled the album obscene. If convicted, the Miami-based rappers could get up to a year in jail and a $1,000 fine. Rogow also represented Charles Freeman, a black record store owner convicted of obscenity last week by an all-white jury for selling ``As Nasty As They Wanna Be.'' Most obscenity cases are argued on the U.S. Supreme Court's Miller v. California test. It holds that material is obscene if the average person, applying local community standards, would find that it is designed to cause sexual arousal, depicts sex in a patently offensive way, and if, taken as a whole, lacks serious literary, artistic, political or scientific value. ``I need young people and black people,'' Campbell said of the jury pool.

DOC.HEAD: Arthur Schwartz, Prosecutor of Bootleggers, Dead at 86
DOC.TEXT: Arthur Schwartz, a racket-busting federal prosecutor who won a bootlegging conviction against Jack ``Legs'' Diamond, has died at age 86. Schwartz died Monday of congestive heart failure at a community hospital in Dobbs Ferry where he lived. As an assistant U.S. attorney in Manhattan, he captured public attention as chief of the office's bootlegging division. In 1931, he won the conviction of Diamond on charges of conspiracy and violation of the Prohibition law. In 1944, Schwartz was the New York manager of Thomas Dewey's presidential campaign. He also was a counsel to the Republican State Committee and from 1974 to 1976 was chairman of the state Board of Elections. In 1952, he served as a state Supreme Court justice. Schwartz practiced law until his retirement six years ago. A New York native, he attended Columbia College and graduated from its law school at the top of his class in 1926. He is survived by his second wife, Betty; two daughters, and three grandchildren.

DOC.HEAD: Pakistan Tried to Buy Furnaces Similar to Those Iraq Wanted
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Subs last grafs with 2 comments
DOC.TEXT: Pakistan tried three times this year to buy from a New Jersey company high-temperature furnaces useful for making nuclear weapons, a congressional source said Wednesday night. This source confirmed an account in Wednesday editions of The Washington Post, which said it had obtained documents of an unspecified nature given to administration officials and congressional investigators describing Pakistan's attempt to buy the furnaces from Consarc Corp. of Rancocas, N.J. The confirming source had not read the documents, but they had been described to him. He spoke on condition that his name not be used. The newspaper's account said the furnaces were more sophisticated versions of Consarc furnaces whose export to Iraq was approved over the summer. The Iraqi shipment was stopped at the last minute. According to the newspaper, Pakistan tried through its embassy in France, and through intermediaries in France and Switzerland, to buy the Consarc furnaces, either directly or through Consarc's British subsidiary. The inability to obtain export licenses from U.S. or British authorities was said to have prevented the sale. In the Canadian approach, the manufacture of surgical instruments was given as the intended use of the furnaces. A Consarc salesman, Manfred Dickersbach, was quoted as saying in one document that the material to be processed ``appears to be zirconium.'' Zirconium is used to clad uranium fuel in nuclear reactors. Fuel for power reactors comes from suppliers already clad. Irradiated with neutrons in the reactor, the uranium would be transformed into plutonium, from which nuclear weapons may be made more easily than with uranium. Pakistan is believed to have taken steps to make a uranium bomb also. Pakistan has steadfastly denied making nuclear weapons. Congress has required that the Bush administration certify that Pakistan does not possess a nuclear weapon before Pakistan may receive U.S. aid. The administration has approached Congressional leaders on the issue about the possibility of waiving the requirement this fiscal year, which began Oct. 1. Congress is reluctant, and officially, the State Department says no decision has been made on what to do. In Islamabad, a foreign ministry spokesman said reports that Pakistan was trying to buy high-temperature furnaces came as a surprise and questioned their veracity. ``These kinds of stories always come out when we have problems with certification. It's uncanny . . . (and) they are later disproved,'' said a spokesman who could not be identified under usual briefing rules. ``There is no reason why there shouldn't be certification this year,'' said the foreign office spokesman.

DOC.HEAD: F-111 Crashes in Saudi Arabia, Killing Two
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS six grafs of details, background.
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. Air Force F-111 fighter-bomber crashed today in Saudi Arabia, killing both crew members, U.S. military officials reported. It was the fourth American aircraft to crash in three days among those deployed to this kingdom for Operation Desert Shield. Eight Marines are missing in the crash of two helicopters in the northern Arabian Sea on Monday. An Air Force F-4 reconnaissance jet also went down that day, killing both crew members. Lt. Cmdr. J.D. van Sickle, a military spokesman, said the F-111 crashed in the ``southern Arabian peninsula'' while on a training mission and that the incident was under investigation. The names of the flyers were withheld pending notification of next of kin. The aircraft was attached the 48th Tactical Fighter Wing based at RAF Lakenheath Air Base in Britain. The wing was sent to Turkey as U.S. forces massed in the region in response to Iraq's Aug. 2 takeover of Kuwait. Today's crash brought to at least nine the number of Americans killed in the Persian Gulf region since Operation Desert Shield began. The eight Marines aboard the two UH-1 Huey helicopters that vanished Monday are still officially listed as missing. In addition to those killed in Saudi Arabia, 13 other Air Force personnel were killed in a crash of a C-5 jet cargo plane in Germany. That aircraft was ferrying supplies and equipment to the Saudi peninsula. Officials said the F-111 crashed at dawn. The aircraft was an F-model, the latest version of the 23-year-old swing-wing jet that first saw action in Vietnam. The F-model has more powerful engines, and state-of-the-art equipment to operate against enemy targets at night. The plane can carry up to 12 tons of bombs and missiles and has a crew of two, a pilot and a weapons systems officer.

DOC.HEAD: 400 Americans and Foreign Family Members To Return To United States
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Subs first two grafs to fix style on time element
DOC.TEXT: About 400 Americans and foreign-born family members have signed up for another U.S. government-chartered evacuation flight from Iraq. The State Department said Tuesday the flight is scheduled to depart today and arrive in Raleigh-Durham airport in North Carolina on Thursday after an overnight stop in London. Most of the passengers are in Kuwait and will be transported to the airport in the Iraqi city of Basra for the flight. The flight is the first of its kind since Sept. 22. As before, the Americans on board will be limited to women and children and Americans of Arab ancestry. Previous evacuation flights have transported about 1,900 Americans out of Iraq and Kuwait. The most recent State Department estimates indicate there are more than 900 Americans stranded in Kuwait and more than 300 in Iraq. Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said three more American men have been detained by Iraqi authorities, bringing the total to 104. Americans still not in detention are subject to house-to-house searches. Ms. Tutwiler said the Iraqis have not provided U.S. officials with a list of the Americans that they have detained. They also have refused to evacuate any of 69 Americans in need of medical attention, she said.

DOC.HEAD: Visitors Return to National Parks
With PM-Budget, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Visitors once again could touch the Liberty Bell and visit Valley Forge as they trickled back to historic sites around the country that had been shut down by the congressional impasse over the budget. Park ranger Jim Van Dorin led visitors Tuesday on one of the first tours of Independence Hall since it was locked up. Back on display were George Washington's chair and the silver inkstand used by signers of the Declaration of Independence and the Constitution. ``That's what gives us the Congress we have today,'' he said of the Constitution. ``I won't go any farther than that.'' The three-day impasse had locked doors at Independence Hall and other National Park Service sites across the country. David Head of Florence, Ky., said he blamed Congress for not passing budget legislation soon enough to avoid a shutdown. Asked if anyone had won his vote during the budget wrangling, he said, ``Yes, anyone new.'' The government lost its authority to spend money Saturday after Congress rejected a White House spending plan for the fiscal year that began Oct. 1. Non-essential services were halted during the three-day Columbus Day weekend, hitting tourist sites the hardest. The emergency spending bill that President Bush signed Tuesday failed to convince many people the problem had been solved. The bill is effective until Oct. 19. By then, congressional leaders hope to work out a deficit-reducing budget. ``I think we're all pleased to be still employed this morning, but we've only got a 10-day reprieve,'' said Richard G. Ring, superintendent of Delaware Water Gap National Recreation Area near Stroudsburg. ``We're hoping that things sort themselves out on a permanent basis for the coming fiscal year.'' ``It's not the best way to run a park,'' Warren Beach, superintendent of Valley Forge National Historical Park in suburban Philadelphia, said of the temporary bill. People had also been turned away from the Gettysburg battlefield. ``It's just a shame that lots of our visiting people, both from this country and as well from other countries, were really denied the opportunity to see some of our heritage,'' said James C. Roach, the battlefield's chief of interpretation and visitor services. In St. Louis, children on a field trip to the St. Louis Arch got to see what they came for. `If it hadn't been open, the students were going to write President Bush and Congress telling them how it affected their education,'' said Nancy Scargall, a teacher at Wren Hollow School in St. Louis County.

DOC.HEAD: Company: Pakistan Sought Furnaces Useful in Making Nuclear Weapons
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. company says it refused to sell Pakistan high-temperature furnaces that can be used in making nuclear weapons because it was suspicious of the country's intentions. Raymond Robrts, president of Consarc Corp. of Rancocas, said Wednesday the company was approached at least twice by Pakistan. ``The end use that they wished was to produce zirconium, and that's a metal that has principally nuclear end-uses,'' Roberts said in a telephone interview from his home. ``We know that the U.S. government has concerns with Pakistan and nuclear weapons, so we elected not to pursue a potential sale.'' Among other things, the furnaces can also be used to make surgical steel. A government-approved sale of less-sophisticated Consarc furnaces to Iraq this summer was stopped at the last minute. Pakistan approached Consarc and its British subsidiary early this year with a request to buy the arc melting furnaces, which cost about $3 million each, Roberts said. About the same time, a Canadian company made a similar request, leading Consarc to believe that Pakistan was behind that request as well, he said. In Pakistan, a Foreign Ministry spokesman, who could not be identified under the briefing rules, said: ``These kinds of stories always come out when we have problems with certification. It's uncanny . . . (and) they are later disproved.'' Before it grants more aid to Pakistan, the third-largest recipient of U.S. aid, Congress wants the Bush administration to certify that the country does not possess a nuclear weapon. The alleged attempts to purchase the furnaces were first reported in today's Washington Post, which said it had obtained documents describing the incident. According to the newspaper, Pakistan tried through its embassy in France, and through intermediaries in France and Switzerland, to buy furnaces. A Consarc salesman, Manfred Dickersbach, was quoted in one of the documents as saying that the material to be processed appeared to be zirconium, a metallic element used by suppliers to clad uranium fuel for nuclear reactors. Uranium can be transformed in a reactor into plutonium, from which nuclear weapons may be made more readily than with uranium. Pakistan is also believed to have taken steps to make a uranium bomb, the newspaper said.

DOC.HEAD: Assailants Ambush Bus, Six Killed, 27 Injured
DOC.TEXT: Gunmen opened fire with automatic weapons on a bus, killing six blacks and wounding 27 in the second random attack around this Indian Ocean city in less than 24 hours, police said today. Police spokesman Lt. Bala Naidoo said the public bus was traveling just outside Durban late Tuesday when it was attacked by unidentired gunmen. Police said they had no motive for the attack and no one had been arrested. Earlier Tuesday, a group of about 20 knife-wielding blacks stabbed eight whites when they went on a rampage on a street near the beachfront. Seven suspects were arrested, including the alleged leader, who was shot by police. Authorities said the 26-year-old leader appeared to be a religious zealot who had recruited his followers hours earlier at an all-night vigil on the Durban beach. He told the others that 1990 would be the year blacks obtained freedom in South Africa, police added. The gang stole knives from a store speacializing in weapons from the Far East and then began stabbing people along a street near the beach, police and witnesses said. ``We have come to take over this place,'' the alleged leader was quoted as saying by witnesses. Some in the gang wore badges of the Pan Africanist Congress, a militant black opposition group, but the attack was not believed to be politically motivated, police said. Eight whites, ranging in age from 15 to 85, were hospitalized with stab wounds, Barkhuizen said. Law and Order Minister Adriaan Vlok condemned the violence and called for private citizens to refrain from seeking vengeance. Thabo Mbeki, a top official for the African National Congress, said the attack might have been orchestrated by ``somebody trying to provoke a reaction from the white population.'' Despite deep racial divisions and widespread violence in South Africa, there have been few cases of blacks randomly attacking whites. Some 5,000 blacks have been killed in factionalfighting since 1986 in Natal Province, which includes Durban. But the violence has been almost exclusively in black areas, pitting Zulu supporters of the conservative Inkatha movement against Xhosas and other blacks linked to the ANC.

DOC.HEAD: Cardin Retrospective At Victoria And Albert
DOC.TEXT: Pierre Cardin, who invented bubble dresses and revolutionized Paris with the first ready-to-wear collection, is the first of his contemporaries to have a retrospective at the Victoria and Albert Museum. The 68-year-old fashion pioneer returned briefly to the past Tuesday when selections from his 40-year career went on display at the museum, known in part for its extensive clothing collections of various periods. It was ``very emotional,'' he said, to see nearly 100 models dressed in bubble and balloon dresses of the 50s, unisex space-age styles and vinyl minis of the 60s, pagoda-sleeve jackets and asymmetrical skirts of the 70s, and hooped evening mini-dresses and computer-inspired coats of the 80s. But while Cardin was the first of his contemporaries to be so honored at the museum, his mind was very much on the future. He says he wants to expand his empire from 102 countries to the entire world. ``I have very big ambition. ... I don't stop. ... I'd like to prove myself again,'' Cardin said. ``Today my ambition is to work very hard with China, with Russia, with Indonesia and Malaysia. Today, we are looking at ... Vietnam and North Korea.'' Born in Venice and reared in France, Cardin worked with renowned Parisian designers Paquin and Schiaparelli after World War II and then joined Christian Dior in 1947, just after he started his own company. The retrospective includes a suit he said he made as part of Dior's ``New Look.'' In 1950, Cardin started his own house, showing his first collection in 1953 and establishing himself as an important figure in French haute couture. ``My first show, I sold 300,000 of one red coat,'' he recalled. ``It was the beginning of my career.'' But his big breakthrough came in 1959, when he presented a ready-to-wear collection for women and was swiftly expelled by the Chambre Syndicale de la Couture, the select couturiers' club. ``I was looking at ready-to-wear; `why,' I said, `can only the rich people dress with haute couture?', '' Cardin recalled. ``It was the beginning of my fortune in this moment, because my house was the first to offer ready-to-wear and in Germany, in Japan, France and America it was immediately successful.'' After that, Cardin branched out into licensing. Currently, he said, 800 factories employ more than 180,000 people producing Cardin brand name goods ranging from perfume and chocolates to frying pans and shoes. ``Put end to end, the ties I sell every year would go round the globe twice over,'' he was quoted as telling The Observer newspaper. In 1970, he said he bought a theater in Paris ``because when I was young I wanted to be an actor or dancer.'' In 1981, he bought the famous Paris restaurant Maxim's so he could see beautiful men and women dining there in designer clothes. After that, it was hotels. Estimates of retail revenue from Cardin-stamped products range between $1.2 billion and $2 billion annually. Cardin's personal income is estimated at between $20 million and $50 million a year and Forbes magazine calls him the richest designer in the world. ``I love money,'' he was quoted as saying in the Telegraph Weekend Magazine. ``I do not believe there has ever been a name as important as Pierre Cardin in the general history of couture.'' Cardin said he saw fashion partly as designs to be worn today, partly as creations for the future. ``The body is liquid material and I put it in a dress. The body is like a vase and I put the water in it,'' he said, describing his fashion philosophy. ``Other designers follow the body. For me the body doesn't exist. It's the shape that counts.'' The retrospective runs until Jan. 6.

DOC.HEAD: Drizzle in the Northeast; Showers in Florida
DOC.TEXT: The Northeast received drizzle and Florida had showers early today. Tenperatures dipped below freezing in the central Plains and Minnesota. Unseasonably warm weather was again predicted for the East, with highs in the 70s and 80s. Several Eastern cities set records for the date Tuesday, including Washington, D.C.; Newark, N.J., and Charleston, S.C. Rain was expected from Louisiana to the Great Lakes region and up into New England. A tropical disturbance from the Gulf of Mexico was expected to bring showers to the Southeast. Sunshine was forecast for the Middle Atlantic states and clear skies were expcted from the Plains to the West Coast with only Idaho and Oregon looking for showers. Flurries were possible in Montana, where temperatures were expected to reach only the 40s. The Midwest was expecting highs in the 50s and 60s, and most of the West was looking for temperatures in the 80s and 90s. The high temperature for the nation Tuesday was 99 degrees at Monrovia, Calif. DOC.HEAD: Biden's GOP Challenger Dusts Off Plagiarism Controversy in Videotapes
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Joseph Biden's Republican challenger is dusting off videotape on a plagiarism controversy that wrecked Biden's Democratic run for president in 1988. Prosecutor M. Jane Brady, who trails badly, said she is playing the ``character card'' with a 10-minute videotape to be mailed next week to about 40,000 homes. The videotape, including material used against Biden two years ago, shows Biden using lines from the late Robert Kennedy and British Labor Party leader Neil Kinnock. Biden quit the 1988 presidential race after it was revealed that he borrowed from Kinnock and others without attribution, lifted from a law review article for a legal brief while in law school and inflated his standing in his law school class. John Sasso, an aide to Democrat Michael Dukakis during the 1988 presidential campaign, resigned after admitting he leaked a videotape on Biden's Kinnock-like remarks. Biden's campaign staff said Brady broke her word to avoid negative campaigning with use of the videotape, put together by the National Republican Senate Campaign. ``I don't believe that voters who see this again will be concerned because the record has been set straight that I repeatedly quoted Kinnock previously and never intended to appropriate his words without attribution,'' Biden said. The videotape also shows an exchange Biden had with a man at a political function over Biden's claim about his law school class standing. The video, which cost Brady's campaign $75,000, uses material from network television and the public affairs TV channel C-SPAN.

DOC.HEAD: Jane Byrne Plans Another Run for Mayor
DOC.TEXT: Former Mayor Jane Byrne says she will attempt a comeback in 1991 and already is circulating nominating petitions. ``We are absolutely having no difficulty getting signatures,'' she said Tuesday. Byrne was elected mayor in 1979 and lost a re-election bid in the 1983 Democratic primary to Harold Washington, who went on to become the city's first black mayor. She lost a comeback bid to Washington in the 1987 primary. Mayor Richard M. Daley, elected in 1989 after Washington died in office, is expected to seek a full four-year term in 1991. ``Anybody can run for mayor,'' Daley said when asked about Byrne's decision.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. City Rejects Japanese Visit After Race Remarks
DOC.TEXT: The mayor of Trenton, N.J., has rejected a visit by a Japanese group studying garbage disposal methods because of a Cabinet minister's remarks comparing blacks with prostitutes, Japanese news reports said today. The Tokyo Metropolitan Assembly had asked Trenton to accept the visit in late October, but Mayor Douglas Palmer refused because of the remarks last month by Justice Minister Seiroku Kajiyama, Kyodo News Service reported. ``For the city of Trenton, with a large black population and a black mayor, Kajiyama's remarks were unbearable,'' Kyodo quoted Palmer as saying in a letter. Palmer said the visit should wait until anger in Trenton has eased, the news agency added. Officials of the Metropolitan Assembly were not available for comment because of a national holiday in Japan. On Sept. 21, following a police roundup of foreign prostitutes in Tokyo, Kajiyama said such prostitutes ``ruin the atmosphere'' of neighborhoods they move into. ``It's like in America when neighborhoods become mixed because blacks move in and whites are forced out,'' he said. The remarks provoked protests in the United States and Japan. Kajiyama later apologized and retracted them. Otherremarks by Japanese politicians in recent years also have angered American minorities. In 1986, then Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone said, ``On the average, the United States is lower (in intellectual level) because of a considerable number of blacks, Puerto Ricans and Mexicans.'' In 1988, Michio Watanabe, policy chief of the governing Liberal Democratic Party, said American blacks have few qualms about going bankrupt and implied they walk away from their debts. The team from the Tokyo Metropolitan Assembly planned to set out next Monday for a two-week study on environment and housing.

DOC.HEAD: 70 Dead In Storm, 5,000 Fishermen Missing in Bay of Bengal
DOC.TEXT: A storm that has claimed the lives of more than 70 fishermen and left about 5,000 missing in the Bay of Bengal continued to lash the Bangladesh coast today, newspapers reported. The Bengali-language daily Sangram said 350 boats and trawlers had failed to return to port since the storm hit on Monday. Sangram quoted the president of a fishermen's association, Kabir Ahmed Sowdagar, as saying he saw 50 to 60 bodies floating in the bay 60 mile offshore on Tuesday. The newspaper Dainik Bangla said at least 70 fishermen were killed. Sowdagar said more than 100 fishermen were rescued by boats carrying relief goods to the affected areas, but he feared the death toll would rise. A senior official at the seaside resort of Cox's Bazar 190 miles southeast of Dhaka, said organized search operations were being delayed by the weather. The official, speaking by telephone on condition of anonomity, said hundreds of fishermen were already out in the sea looking for their kinsmen. He said speed boats and small launches were ready to start the search as soon as the weather eased. The incessant rains have caused flash floods in most parts of this low-lying country, rendering tens of thousands of people homeless, the English-language Morning Sun reported. The paper, quoting reports from the southern port city of Chittagong, said a tornado whipped up tidal surges, causing extensive damaged on the Sandwip and Urirchar islands. Some areas of Sandwip, 10 miles northwest of Chittagong, have gone under 7 to 8 feet of water and the island's protective embankment has been heavily damaged. Communications with the islands have been disrupted, and they have been cut off from the mainland for three days, the paper said.

DOC.HEAD: Physician Claims `Creation of Adam' Includes Image of Brain
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf to CLARIFY how picture forms image of a brain.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY37 of Oct. 9, LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: Art historians are split over a doctor's theory that Michelangelo's ``Creation of Adam'' on the Sistine Chapel ceiling contains a huge image of a brain, symbolizing God endowing man with intelligence. Dr. Frank Lynn Meshberger contends the fresco has been misunderstood since it was created in 1512. The painting was covered with dirt until a recent restoration, ``so it might have been difficult to visualize a brain,'' he said. The painting shows Adam and God reaching toward one another, arms outstretched, fingers almost touching. God has his arm around Eve, and angels lookon. God and the angels form the shape of the brain, Meshberger said. Meshberger, a gynecologist at St. John's Medical Center in Anderson, Ind., said in today's Journal of the American Medical Association that Michelangelo intended to symbolize God giving man intellect, rather than life, as commonly believed. Kathleen Weil-Garris Brandt, a fine arts professor at New York University and a consultant for Renaissance art at the Vatican Museum, disputed Meshberger's theory as a ``retrofit'' of his own knowledge. ``All the elements in the image have profound traditional roots in the visual culture of the Renaissance and Middle Ages,'' she said. ``God is more than a flying brain.'' Other art historians are reluctant to dismiss the theory, noting that artists and scientists of the time studied sections of the brain. Meshberger said he learned through his research that Michelangelo had deep religious beliefs and dissected cadavers to study the human form for his art. ``The idea of God being equated with the mind is quite attractive,'' said Graham Smith, who specializes in 16th-century art at the University of Michigan in Ann Arbor. Lynn Orr, curator of European art at the Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco, said, ``Anybody can look at artwork and say, `Oh, that means such and such to me,' but that's one of the wonderful things about art.'' ``I guess the thing to do now is for a bunch of people to look at the picture carefully to see if it really does look like a brain,'' she said. Meshberger said the theory came to him after he dissected and drew a brain in medical school in 1969. He said he saw a three-page fold-out photograph of the painting in a magazine and ``had a tremendous sense of deja vu.'' ``I like to think of it as a brainstorm,'' he joked. Meshberger said he waited 20 years to publish an article on it because he was establishing himself as a doctor and had little time to research Michelangelo. Meshberger said that the painting also includes a representation of the vertebral artery, which feeds blood to the brain, and that a cleft-footed angel forms the two lobes of the pituitary gland. For centuries after the fresco was created, art lovers did not have the benefit of clear photography, and artists who would have had access to the painting generally were not skilled in the study of anatomy, the doctor said. ``For someone to make this observation, you would have had to travel to Rome to the Sistine Chapel, stand on the floor and look up at a ceiling about 65 feet away,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Newsletter Says Britons To Be Released By Next Week
DOC.TEXT: Anglican church envoy Terry Waite and other Britons held hostage in Lebanon will be released ``before the end of next week,'' a Lebanese newsletter said today. ``The final arrangements for the release of the British hostages held in Lebanon topped by Anglican church envoy Terry Waite are under way behind the scene,'' Akhbar al-Yom (Today's News) said. The missing Britons are ``expected to be released before the end of next week,'' said the report, attributed to unidentified sources informed about the foreign hostage issue. It did not disclose further details. The privately owned newsletter is close to the Higher Shiite Islamic Council, the highest Shiite Moslem religious authority in Lebanon. The newsletter seldom reports on the foreign hostages, but has been fairly accurate when it does. Most of the 13 Westerners missing in Lebanon - including six Americans - are believed held by Shiite fundamentalists affiliated with the pro-Iranian Hezbollah, or Party of God. It was the latest in a flurry of reports predicting the release soon of British captives now that Iran and Britain agreed to restore diplomatic relations last month after an interruption of 18 months. Waite, 51, disappeared in Moslem west Beirut after leaving his hotel for a meeting with representatives of hostage-holders on Jan. 20, 1987. No group has claimed responsibility for his abduction, but former Irish hostage Brian Keenan, freed in August, said he was held with Waite in the same house for awhile. In addition to Waite, the missing Britons are journalist John McCarthy, World War II flier Jack Mann and writer Alec Collett. McCarthy, 33, of Barnet, North London, was kidnapped April 17, 1986, while driving to Beirut airport to catch a flight to London. Mann, 76, was kidnapped in Moslem west Beirut May 12, 1989. Collett, a New York-based writer on assignment in Lebanon for the U.N. Relief and Works Agency, was kidnapped March 25, 1985. A group calling itself the Revolutionary Organization of Socialist Moslems, believed linked to Palestinian terrorist mastermind Abu Nidal, claimed in April 1986 that it hanged Collett in retaliation for British support for U.S. air raids on Libya earlier that month. A videotape released by the group purportedly showed Collet's body dangling from a scaffold. No body has been produced but British officials believe Collett is dead. American journalist Terry Anderson, 42, of Lorain, Ohio, is the longest-held foreign captive in Lebanon. Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, was kidnapped in west Beirut on March 16, 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Clashes As Police Block Showing Of Banned North Korean Films
DOC.TEXT: Students wielding clubs and firebombs fought with riot police today, who responded with tear gas and stormed two universities to block the screening of banned movies from communist North Korea. Police beefed up security around intelligence offices after radicals firebombed an intelligence office in the southern city of Chonju early today. No serious damage or injuries were reported. Police arrested about 50 dissidents who tried to march toward the police command's headquarters near President Roh Tae-woo's residence to demand that military intelligence be overhauled to end its political operations. Anti-government protests intensified after last week's reports of illegal spying on civilians by the Defense Security Command, a military intelligence unit. As part of their anti-government tactics, radical students tried to screen North Korean movies, which encourage revolution, before police moved in to stop the efforts. In downtown Seoul, about 2,000 riot police were deployed around a Catholic cathedral to block an evening rally by dissidents. Meanwhile, opposition leader Kim Dae-jung's hunger strike continued for a third day at his party headquarters. He was backed up by about 400 supporters who were staging sit-ins in 20 local offices. Kim began fasting Monday to demand dissolution of the security command, economic reform and the scrapping of government plans to change the form of government from presidential to parliamentary. The latest political turmoil began last week after an army private released classified documents he said showed the military intelligence unit illegally spied on more than 1,300 dissidents, intellectuals and opposition legislators. Roh fired his defense minister and the chief of military intelligence Monday, seeking to minimize the impact of the most serious scandal since he took office in early 1988. But opponents joined forces to mount a major campaign against Roh, a former general who once headed the security command after helping former president Chun Doo-hwan seize power in 1980. Roh has vowed to end military intervention in politics. His party gained control of two-thirds of the 299-member National Assembly in January by merging with two minor opposition groups. Roh's opponents contend the merger is a government attempt to prolong power. All opposition legislators resigned from Parliament en masse in August, accusing the government of railroading legislation through the assembly and curtailing democratic reforms.

DOC.HEAD: Tax Bubble Explained
DOC.NOTE: EDs: New throughout to CORRECT that rates apply to taxable income, not adjusted gross income; CORRECTS tax brackets to reflect inflation adjustments; ADDS 1 graf to note that some people do pay an average rate about 28 percent. ^With PM-Budget Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Discussions of higher taxes on the wealthy in exchange for lower taxes on capital gains have focused on an oddity in the law, the so-called ``bubble'' that finds the rate on the top tax bracket lower than in the bracket immediately before it. That means the wealthiest people pay a lower rate on extra dollars of income than do some earning slightly less. Thus, a person with $1 million income can win a $10,000 lottery and owe the government an additional $2,800 - a 28 percent tax rate. But a person with $50,000 income can hit the same lottery and owe $3,300. Currently, single taxpayers face a tax rate of 15 percent on the first $19,450 of taxable income. A 28 percent rate applies to the next segment of inome, between $19,450 and $47,050. Income between $47,050 and $97,620 is taxed at 33 percent. Any taxable income above $97,620 is taxed at 28 percent. But before that lower rate kicks in, a taxpayer will have lost any benefit from a personal exemption and from having some income taxed at the lowest, 15 percent, rate. Similarly, for married taxpayers with no children and filing joint returns, the first $32,450 is taxed at 15 percent; income between $32,450 and $78,400 is taxed at 28 percent; taxable income between $78,400 and $162,770 faces a 33 percent rate. Any income above $162,770 is taxed at 33 percent. The ``bubble'' is not an accident. Congress invented it in 1986 in an effort to prevent any person from paying more than 28 percent of taxable income to the government. Even so, some people can pay more than 29 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Jogger Hurls Bucket of Acid at Two Women
DOC.TEXT: A man hurled a can of acid at two employees of an abortion clinic, critically injuring one, police said. The women had just left work and were walking down the sidewalk in midtown Manhattan Tuesday afternoon when a man ran up, threw a coffee can of acid at them and ran away, police spokeswoman Sgt Tina Mohrmann said. The motive for the attack was unclear. Police spokesman Sgt. Nick Vreeland said it ``does not seem to be connected to their work at the clinic.'' Police were trying to determine whether an estranged husband of one of the women was linked to the attack, he said. Natalie Boston, 29, of Brooklyn, was hit in the face and eyes. She was listed in guarded condition this morning at New York Hospital, administrator Kathleen McGowan said. Digna Rodriguez, 24, was hit in the hand and neck. She was hospitalized in stable condition, McGowan said.

DOC.HEAD: Princeton Eating Club Votes To Ban Women
DOC.TEXT: The last men-only dining club at Princeton University has voted to stay that way despite a state Supreme Court order requiring it to admit female members. The vote Tuesday by undergraduate members of the Tiger Inn also reverses the club's decision earlier this year to admit women and end a 100-year-old tradition. ``We all believe the right to freedom of association is an important and fundamental aspect of life at any age,'' said Stockton S. Williams, undergraduate president of the Tiger Inn. In February, the Tiger Inn voted to admit women. However, club rules say women can be admitted only if undergraduate members vote them in for two consecutive school years. The club said the earlier vote ``was taken under severe pressure with pickets, bonfires, rallies, and other interferences.'' The pressure to admit women began 11 years ago when former Princeton University student Sally Frank sued the all-male Ivy Club as well as the Tiger Inn. In July the state Supreme Court ordered both clubs to admit women. The Ivy Club admitted 15 women two weeks ago after a membership drive. Tiger Inn attorney Russell H. Beatie Jr. says the club cannot be forced to obey the court order because it held no membership drive this fall. Beatie said the club intends to hold a spring membership drive and will ask the U.S. Supreme Court to put the state order on hold if the high court decides to hear the case. Ms. Frank, now a law professor at Drake University in Des Moines, Iowa, said the club ``is fighting tooth and nail to maintain a system of exclusion and discrimination that harms its members and the entire Princeton community.''

DOC.HEAD: TV Documentary Says British Soldiers Trained Khmer Rouge Guerrillas
DOC.TEXT: A television documentary claims British soldiers have been training Cambodia's Khmer Rouge guerrillas, and opposition legislators said they will press for a government explanation. The Foreign Office denied allegations by the documentary broadcast Tuesday that commandos of the Army's elite Special Air Service regiment were involved in helping the Communist group. ``We have never given and will never give aid of any sort to the Khmer Rouge,'' it said in a statement. The TV program's director says the assistance began in 1985, and he claims that Britain helped the guerrillas at the request of the United States. George Foulkes, foreign affairs spokesman for the opposition Labor Party, said the film demonstrated that ``the Foreign Office statement is incorrect. The television evidence seemed well-documented.'' Hundreds of thousands of people died from starvation, execution and disease during the Khmer Rouge's rule in Cambodia from 1975 until Vietnam invaded in late 1978. A civil war involving the guerrillas continues today. The Khmer Rouge is now the largest and strongest organization in a three-faction guerrilla coalition opposed to the Vietnamese-installed government of Prime Minister Hun Sen. The other two groups are non-Communist. The Foreign Office said in July that Britain shared U.S. determination to prevent the Khmer Rouge from taking power. The hourlong TV program, ``Viewpoint 90: Cambodia, the Betrayal,'' was made for Central Television by journalist John Pilger and shown on the Independent Television network. It alleged that Special Air Service men trained Khmer Rouge guerrillas in Malaysia and Thailand. It said Britain's MI6 espionage agency was heavily involved in the covert operation. The director of the program, David Monroe, said in a radio interview with the British Broadcasting Corp. on Tuesday: ``Since 1985 in various forms the British government has supplied military training directly to the Khmer Rouge in guerrilla warfare, basic mines technology and mine-laying techniques. ``From 1985 until about November of last year there were serving SAS officers who were training directly the Khmer Rouge.'' Asked in the BBC interview why Britain would want to train the Khmer Rouge, Monroe claimed the United States was trying to get others to ``do the dirty work for them.'' He said Britain undertook the task to repay U.S. favors during the 1982 Falklands War. He added: ``The idea is to get in place in Phnom Penh a government that is anti-Vietnamese. However, I don't think anybody actually wants to see the Khmer Rouge take power.''

DOC.HEAD: Govt Frees 21 Political Prisoners
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs last graf pvs, `The white-dominated...' with 1 to CORRECT that health services in South Africa no longer segregated. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The government released 21 political prisoners today as part of a pledge to free all activists convicted of anti-apartheid acts. Eighteen men were released in Cape Town and three were freed from prisons in Johannesburg and Pretoria, the Prisons Service said. Most of those released belong to the African National Congress, the largest black opposition movement. They had two to five years remaining on sentences that included convictions for terrorism, sabotage and treason. ``We are very happy to see them come out,'' said ANC official Reggie September. ``Even a short time in prison is too long for anybody.'' More than 100 family members and friends provided an emotional welcome for the men, who arrived from Robben Island prison off Cape Town. The ANC has demanded the release of all political prisoners, estimated at up to 3,000, before it will enter full-scale negotiations with the government on ending apartheid. President F.W. de Klerk's government has promised to free all inmates convicted of political offenses, but has not said how many people fall in that category. Dozens of prisoners have been released in recent months. ANC leader Nelson Mandela on Tuesday visited ANC members held at Robben Island and Pollsmoor prisons near Cape Town to explain the government's plans. Mandela served 27 years in the two prisons for plotting to overthrow the government. He was released in February. ``We have set a date by which all political prisoners will be released and that is the end of April 1991,'' he said. The return of ANC exiles is another major obstacle to negotiations on a new constitution. De Klerk on Monday said ANC exiles could begin applying for amnesty that would clear the way for their return to South Africa. De Klerk says he wants to draw up a new constitution with opposition groups that would allow the 5 million whites and 30 million blacks to share power. The government and the ANC have been holding preliminary talks since May. The ANC is pushing for a one-person, one-vote system. The white-dominated government's apartheid system deprives blacks of a vote in national affairs, controls the economy and maintains separate residential areas and schools.

DOC.HEAD: Judge in Noriega Case Refuses to Separate Trials
DOC.TEXT: Three co-defendants of Manuel Noriega lost bids to be tried separately from the ousted Panamanian leader on drug-trafficking charges. U.S. District Judge William Hoeveler on Tuesday denied separate trials for Luis Del Cid, a former chief aide to Noriega; William Saldarriaga, an alleged drug trafficker from Colombia; and Brian Alden Davidow, an alleged drug dealer in Miami. Some defense lawyers have argued that the huge volume of testimony against Noriega could prejudice jurors against his co-defendants even if it did not apply to them. ``This just happens to be a case where sitting next to Noriega has an atomic effect and Davidow would suffer from the fallout,'' said Richard Sharpstein, attorney for Davidow. ``The evidence is so overwhelming and on such a massive scale that (Davidow) would be severely prejudiced by the spillover.'' Noriega, Del Cid, Saldarriaga and Davidow were among 16 people indicted in Miami in February 1988 on charges of taking part in a conspiracy that made Panama a way station and processing center for Columbia's Medellin drug cartel. The trial is officially scheduled to begin Jan. 28. ``I feel sorry for some guy who should have had a two-to-three week trial and now has a six-to-eight month trial,'' said Noriega attorney Frank Rubino, who noted the co-defendants could also experience the lengthy delays expected in preparation of the general's defense. ``Even if the money became available today, it would be six to nine months before a half-dozen investigators I would have to employ could go through the thousands and thousands of records and documents in Panama that I am told exist,'' he said. Diane Cossin, a spokeswoman for U.S. Attorney Dexter Lehtinen, said prosecutors were pleased with the judge's ruling against separate trials. ``The grand jury returned an indictment against all of the defendants,'' she said. ``We feel they should be tried together.'' Drug pilot Eduardo Pardo, another co-defendant, has already pleaded guilty to flying $800,000 in cocaine profits from Fort Lauderdale to Panama in May 1983. He is awaiting sentencing.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Soldier Kills One Person, Wounds Another
DOC.TEXT: An American soldier opened fire with an automatic rifle in a military dining hall, shooting and killing one soldier, wounding another, then seriously wounding himself, officials said today. The assailant was in critical condition, and officials gave no motive for the shooting incident on Tuesday. Capt. Charles Brunson, spokesman for the U.S. Army 3rd Armored Division, said the attack occurred at the Grafenwoehr military training area in northern Bavaria state, 50 miles east of Nuremberg. He said the shooter was assigned to the 2nd Battalion 67th Armor Regiment. Brunson said the other wounded soldier was in satisfactory condition at a German hospital in the area. The names of all three American soldiers were withheld pending notification of relatives. Brunson said he could not immediately confirm what type of weapon was used in the shootings. Bavarian state police reported that it was a rapid-fire M-16 military rifle. They also said the soldier who did the shooting is 22 years old. The police released no further details.

DOC.HEAD: Arrests Continue in Capital of Rwanda
DOC.TEXT: Authorities in Rwanda have arrested more than 1,500 suspected rebel sympathizers in the nation's capital and continued their house-to-house searches today, sources said. The sweep began when gunbattles broke out in the capital on Friday, five days after Rwandan refugees living in Uganda invaded their country seeking to overthrow its ruler, President Juvenal Habyarimana. The rebels remained dug in the nation's northeastern corner, said sources in Kigali, the capital. They spoke on condition of anonymity. The central African nation of Rwanda has aked the United States for military supplies and the request is being considered, the U.S. State Department said Tuesday. The sources said Kigali was calm today. Rwandan troops patrolled the streets and manned checkpoints, and French and Belgian troops controlled the airport and the road to it from the capital, they said. France and Belgium have sent nearly 1,000 troops to Rwanda to protect their citizens and embassies. France has urged the approximately 300 French citizens still in Rwanda to leave. Rwandan authorities claim Friday's street battles were caused by rebel infiltrators and say they have arrested 500 suspected sympathizers for questioning. The rebel group denies any of its members entered Kigali and says the fighting was between Rwandan army loyalists and soldiers trying to desert to join the insurgency. Sources said the number detained for questioning appeared to be much higher than that cited by the government. One source quoted witnesses who had seen approximately 1,500 detainees held at a sports stadium outside Kigali earlier this week. A Western diplomat said the detainees had been moved to jails in and around Kigali and estimated the number held at about 2,000. The detainees are predominantly Tutsi and include businessmen, intellectuals, senior civil servants and clergymen, the sources said. Most of the rebels are members of the minority Tutsi tribe, which ruled Rwanda until the majority Hutu gained control in the late 1950s. In the early 1960s, the Hutu brutally put down a Tutsi uprising, killing more than 10,000 and forcing hundreds of thousands to flee to neighboring countries. The invaders, calling themselves the Rwandese Patriotic Front, are members or offspring of the more than 250,000 Tutsis who sought safe haven in Uganda. Many are Ugandan army deserters. The government Monday said its forces continued to battle the rebels in the country's northeast and put the number of the invaders at 10,000. The rebels say they want to install a democratic government and repatriate all refugees. They accuse Habyarimana's government of corruption, human rights abuses and dictatorial leadership, and of stalling on the refugee issue. He has ruled since a coup in 1973. The government has said the country of 8 million is too crowded to accomodate the more than 1 million Rwandan refugees in neighboring countries and around the world. Rwanda is among the most crowded nations in the world. An average of more than 566 people live on every square mile, compared with a nationwide average in the United States of 63 per square mile.

DOC.HEAD: Richard Murdoch, British Radio Comedian, Dead at 83
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Waggon in the title ``Band Waggon'' is correct.
DOC.TEXT: Richard Murdoch, one of Britain's best loved radio comedians in the 1930s and 1940s who went on to delight movie, theater and TV audiences into the 1980s, has died. He was 83. Murdoch died Tuesday after collapsing earlier in the day while playing golf at Walton Heath, 20 miles south of London, family members said. The cause of his death was not released. Murdoch, a tall, droll and elegant man who was received his college education at Cambridge University, once said in an interview: ``I've never been in a show where I had to be anyone else but me.'' He often played down his talent as a comedian, once declaring: ``The more you do, the easier this kind of thing becomes.'' He insisted that golf and sailing were his main interests. Murdoch began his show business career in 1927 as a dancer in the chorus of a London stage show, ``The Blue Train,'' but soon branched out into radio comedy. He starred with the late Arthur Askey in a popular radio comedy show, ``Band Waggon,'' launched by the British Broadcasting Corp. in 1938. The weekly half-hour show emptied city streets as millions of Britons hurried home to tune in. Its success was cut short by World War II in 1939. During the war Murdoch joined the Royal Air Force, where he became an intelligence officer at a variety of air bases. His next success on BBC radio was ``Much Binding in the Marsh'' in the 1940s, a weekly comedy about armed forces life set on an air base. Murdoch's movies included ``Band Waggon'' in 1939 and ``The Ghost Train'' in 1941. In the 1980s, he appeared in the popular weekly TV comedy series ``Rumpole of the Bailey'' about life in London's Old Bailey Central Criminal Court. In the series, which was shown on public television in the United States, he played Uncle Tom, the barrister who never gets a brief. Murdoch is survived by his wife, actress Peggy Rawlings, whom he married in 1932, as well as a son and two daughters. Funeral plans have not been announced.

DOC.HEAD: Inmates Alert Deputies to Noisy Escape Attempt
DOC.TEXT: An attempted jailbreak was foiled when the two inmates trying to escape made so much racket that other prisoners complained to guards, who caught the men in a crawl space, officials said. The two were using a piece of metal to chip through an eight-inch concrete wall at the Okanogan County Jail when they woke up other prisoners at about midnight Monday, jailer Dan Slattery said Tuesday. The men removed a ceiling light fixture to get into the crawl space. Sheriff Jim Weed said even if the men had been able to chip through the outside wall, they would have found themselves 80 feet above the ground. Billy Dale Anderson, 22, and David Cabarett, 33, face second-degree attempted escape charges, Slattery said. Both men were booked in September for investigation of burglary, Slattery said.

DOC.HEAD: Discovery Arrives Safely Back Home
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs., EDITS to tighten.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto Staffing
DOC.TEXT: Discovery returned home today, landing safely on a desert lakebed, after a virtually flawless mission that sent a sun probe hurtling through space and lifted morale at NASA. ``Rescue teams glad to have you back, also to have the fastest manmade object in the universe well on its way. Congratulations on a picture-perfect mission,'' Mission Control's Brian Duffy told the five-man crew. Discovery touched down at 6:57 a.m. PDT, shortly after sunrise, precisely as planned. The arrival was preceded by the usual two sonic booms sweeping the desert. More than 5,200 people cheered and applauded as the shuttle landed on a concrete runway on a dry lakebed in the Mojave Desert. The touchdown, like the rest of the flight, was extremely smooth. Discovery circled Earth 66 times during the four-day mission, logging 1,707,445 miles. The flight - the first shuttle mission in nearly six months - has helped rebuild NASA's image, battered in recent months by the flawed Hubble Space Telescope and hydrogen leaks on the two other shuttles. ``This flight is probably as close to perfect as we can get,'' flight director Ron Dittemore said Tuesday. The six-month delay was the longest gap between missions since shuttle flights resumed after the 1986 Challenger accident. Discovery blasted into orbit just a few minutes behind schedule Saturday. Several hours later, the five astronauts deployed the Ulysses solar probe exactly as planned. Ulysses continued to race through space on a 1.86 billion-mile, five-year journey. It will travel to Jupiter to use the planet's gravity to sling it back across the solar system and into an unprecedented orbit around the sun's poles. The $250 million spacecraft is expected to pass over the sun's poles in 1994 and 1995. On Tuesday, the astronauts retracted the shuttle's 50-foot robot arm, which had been extended in an experiment to measure the deteriorating effects of space on an Intelsat satellite that is stuck in a useless low orbit. Material attached to the arm was identical to that used on the satellite's solar panels. Intelsat, an organization of countries that owns the communications satellite, will study the amount of decay and decide whether it is worth sending astronauts on a rescue mission in 1992. Discovery's other crew members are mission specialists Bill Shepherd and Bruce Melnick. Atlantis is due to fly next on a secret military mission in early November. The mission originally was scheduled for July but was delayed by hydrogen leaks. Some repairs still must be completed in Atlantis' engine compartment, which was damaged by a metal beam left there by workers. The 9-foot beam left about 25 dents and dings when it rattled around while the shuttle was hoisted upright.

DOC.HEAD: Bhutto's Husband Arrested on Kidnapping Charge
DOC.TEXT: The husband of ousted Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto was arrested today for allegedly kidnapping a Pakistani-born British citizen and extorting $800,000 from him. Asif Ali Zardari, largely blamed for his wife's legal problems since the Aug. 6 dismissal of her government, was arrested and charged at the Sindh High Court. The army-backed caretaker government had hinted for weeks that the arrest of the 38-year-old Karachi businessman was imminent. Zardari was charged in the April kidnapping of businessman Murtaza Hussain Bukhari and taken for interrogation to the Federal Investigation Agency, comparable to the FBI. He was also charged with extortion. Conviction for kidnapping is punishable by seven years in jail, while extortion carries a 10-year sentence. Authorities said Zardari would not be able to apply for bail, forcing him to spend at least one night in jail. When Bukhari reported the alleged abduction to police and the British Embassy in Islamabad, he implicated Zardari. Bukhari claimed he met Zardari to discuss building a hospital in southern Sindh, Ms. Bhutto's home province. He said that at a second meeting, an associate of Zardari's, Ghulam Hussain Unar, pinned him down, strapped a time bomb to his leg and forced him to cash $800,000 in checks at a Karachi bank. Although Zardari was not present at the second meeting, Bukhari has contended the former prime minister's husband was part of the plot.
