Unar, a former provincial legislator and member of Ms. Bhutto's Pakistan People's Party, was arrested in June. Ms. Bhutto wed Zardari in a highly publicized arranged marriage in December 1987, a year before she became the first woman leader of a modern Moslem nation. President Ghulam Ishaq Khan dismissed her government Aug. 6 on charges of corruption, incompetence and abuse of power. Many supporters and critics have blamed Zardari for her fall from power after only 20 months. Zardari, an avid polo player with a jet-setter reputation, has been accused by the Pakistani media and the caretaker government of demanding commissions for lucrative government contracts. He has vehemently denied the allegations, which earned him the nickname ``Mr. 10 Percent.'' He had been expected to be the key target of the corruption investigations, but the caretaker government instead launched a legal assault on Ms. Bhutto to try to discredit her party and force her to abandon politics. Zardari's father, Hakim Ali Zardari, also has been charged with corruption. The elder Zardari, who headed the committee that oversaw government public spending, was in London when the government was abruptly dissolved.

DOC.HEAD: Diplomatic Corps Hits Roof Over Utility Bills
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS typos in `Nicaragua' in lede and `subsidies' in 7th, `Nicaraguans, however...'
DOC.TEXT: When Nicaragua's new government yanked subsidies for public services, utility bills took off and diplomats hit the roof. But instead of refusing to pay, as many Nicaraguans are doing, the foreign officials organized a protest and their bills were put on hold pending an investigation. ``We pay the light and water (bills) when they are normal, but not when they are exaggerated,'' said Soviet Embassy press attache Vyacheslav Spassky. A diplomatic source said the Soviets were stunned by an electric bill in July for $4,000. Under the Sandinistas, who were voted out of office in February, monthly utility bills rarely exceeded a few hundred dollars. President Violeta Chamorro's economic restructuring program passed the full cost of electric, water and sewer and telephone services to consumers. Central Bank President Francisco Mayorga recently said the government reduced its monthly deficit from $28 million in April, when Mrs. Chamorro took over, to $7 million in September. Nicaraguans, however, have not quickly adapted to the new prices after a decade of Sandinista subsidies. The first effects of the austerity program surfaced in July with food, gas and utility price increases that jolted people in a country where wages of less than $100 a month are common. A government official, who asked that her name not be used, said her mother received an $800 water bill, based on the official exchange rate. The black market rate, once well above the official rate, is now only slightly better than at the banks. ``This goes beyond ridiculous. It is just incredible, it's astounding, it's, it's ... '' the exasperated official said. With electricity, a typical family bill that was $8 a month is now around $117. The diplomatic protest began last month at a dinner when somebody complained about soaring utility bills, said U.S. Embassy spokesman Stedman Howard. Soon, all the 42 accredited foreign missions in Managua confronted the Foreign Ministry, which appointed a committee to look into the complaints and told the embassies to hold off paying bills until meters and consumption were checked. Technicians found broken water pipes at the North Korean Embassy that explained high water bills there, said ministry spokesman David Silva. But the Libyans would not let technicians in to check out the water meters, and Cuban officials complained that meter readers never got close enough to take a reading. Although Howard declined to say how much the U.S. Embassy was being billed, he said his home electric bill went from $200 to $780 in one month. ``That's indicative of the general trend,'' Howard said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush's Approval Rating at Lowest Point
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 4th graf pvs `The previous ...' to ADD highest approval rating
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's job approval rating has fallen to the lowest point of his presidency, a media group said today. The Times Mirror Center for The People & The Press, which monitors public interest in the news each month, said its survey put Bush's rating at 55 percent, 21 points below the rating he was given in early August. Last month, 68 percent of those surveyed said they approved of Bush's handling of the presidency. The previous low - 61 percent - came in February 1989, the month after Bush was inaugurated. Ten days before he took office, Bush's approval rating was 59 percent. The president's highest rating - 80 percent - came in surveys taken in January after the U.S. invasion of Panama. Twenty-eight percent of those in the most recent survey said they disapproved of Bush's job performance and 17 percent said they didn't know. The survey also indicated that the most closely followed stories in the news are the crisis in the Persian Gulf and the resulting increase in gasoline prices. But Americans paid much less attention to the domestic budget crunch. The news industry group said 68 percent of Americans surveyed said the Mideast crisis, which began Aug. 2 when Iraq invaded Kuwait, was the most important news of September. Sixty-three percent said they were following very closely news about the U.S. troop deployment in Saudi Arabia and other developments in the wake of Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. That was the same percentage as did so in August. On the other hand, 62 percent said they paid close attention to stories about rising gasoline prices, compared with 56 percent in the previous month. The percentage of the public who paid close attention to news about hostages held in Iraq and Kuwait declined from 57 percent to 47 percent. Although the poll was taken Oct. 4-7, the period in which budget negotiations broke down and a government shutdown was ordered, only 34 percent said they were closely following news about efforts to resolve the budget impasse. However, 45 percent said they were aware that gasoline tax increases were being considered, 38 percent had heard that cigarette taxes might be raised and 40 percent knew that alcohol tax increases were under consideration. Among people under 30, only 20 percent said they were following the budget news closely. The percentage increased with age and reached 46 percent among people 50 and older. The results were based on telephone interviews of 1,213 adults conducted under the direction of Princeton Survey Research Associates by The Gallup Organization in Lincoln, Neb. The margin of error was plus or minus 3 percentage points.

DOC.HEAD: Party Takes No Action on Economic Reform, Plans to Cut Its Staff
DOC.TEXT: The Communist Party has decided to stay out of the debate over how the country should move to a market economy, and it plans to cut its headquarters' staff nearly in half, officials said today. After a two-day meeting of the party's policy making Central Committee, Deputy General Secretary Vladimir Ivashko told a news conference the Soviet legislature should decide the nation's economic future. ``It would be wrong if the plenary session of the Communist Party Central Committee turned into an affiliate of the Supreme Soviet and started competing on various aspects of a particular program,'' he said. The legislature is considering conflicting plans for the transition from a centrally planned economy to a market one. The Central Committee's restraint is in line with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's attempts to specify more clearly the powers of the party and state and to give the legislature independence. But its failure to endorse an economic plan could be seen by many Soviets as indecision. The committee traditionally has made proposals to the legislature, which then dutifully enacted them. But the current legislature, the Supreme Soviet, was democratically elected in part and is more wary of party proposals. While not committing the party to an economic plan, Ivashko did differ with proposals to privatize industry. He said a nationwide referendum should be held on the question. Gorbachev referred to the difficulties of plotting economic reform in a meeting today with executives of the New York Stock Exchange. ``These days we are deciding the question of how we should move forward. Everybody is facing a lot of questions. We do, and people have even more,'' Gorbachev, the party chief, told the American visitors. In a move that coincides wih declining party membership, the Central Committee will cut its headquarters staff by 40.4 percent, Ivashko announced. He said later in an interview that 580 employees will be laid off, leaving about 800. More than 500 were dismissed last year. The Communist Party has about 18 million members. In a partial concession to demonstrators that have been demanding the party give up property it nationalized, Ivashko said buildings with historical and cultural significance and small churches now in the party's hands will be made into monuments. He said the party would not ask for compensation and would turn over the buildings gradually. The party has valued its property at 4.9 billion rubles, or $8.2 billion at the official rate.

DOC.HEAD: Search Halted for Eight Missing Marines
DOC.TEXT: The Navy has halted its search for eight Marines lost and presumed killed in Monday's crash of two Huey helicopters over the Arabian Sea, officials said today. The search was stopped at 3:30 a.m. EDT on Tuesday. A Marine Corps headquarters statement said the announcement was delayed until today to verify that all next-of-kin had been notified. The statement said Navy search teams found no indications of survivors during an extensive air and water search of the area. Some floating debris, including aircraft parts from each helicopter, were recovered. The statement said the cause of the accident, which occurred at night, is still under investigation. The eight Marines were identified as: Capt. Gary S. Dillon, 29, of Merrimack County, N.H; Capt. William D. Cronin Jr., 29, of Du Page County, Ill.; Capt. Kevin R. Dolvin, 29, of Stark County, Ohio; Capt. William J. Hurley, 27, of Cook County, Ill.; Sgt. Kenneth T. Keller, 26, of Cook County, Ill.; Sgt. John R. Kilkus, 26, of Norfolk County, Mass.; Cpl. Timothy W. Romei, 22, of San Francisco County, Calif.; and Lance Cpl. Thomas R. Adams, 20, of Baton Rouge County, La. The Marine Corps did not release the men's hometowns or other information. All eight were part of a search-and-rescue squadron based at the Marine Corps Air Station at Camp Pendleton, Calif. The helicopter crews were conducting routine night training operations about eight miles from their shipboard base when radar and radio contact was lost at 5:13 a.m. local time Monday, Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams said.

DOC.HEAD: Bennett Sentenced to 12 to 25 Years
DOC.TEXT: A black man once reportedly suspected of killing a pregnant white woman in an apparent hoax by her husband that inflamed Boston's racial tensions has been sentenced to 12 to 25 years in prison for robbery. William Bennett, 40, of Boston was convicted Friday in Barnstable Superior Court of robbing a Brookline video store at gunpoint Oct. 2, 1989. Judge Robert W. Banks sentenced Bennett Tuesday. Bennett reportedly was identified by Charles Stuart as most resembling the person he claimed had shot him and his pregnant wife, Carol, after jumping in their car and robbing them last Oct. 23 in Boston. Mrs. Stuart died hours after the shooting. Her prematurely delivered son died 17 days later. Stuart was hospitalized with a bullet wound. Last January, after Stuart was implicated in the shootings, he apparently committed suicide by jumping from a bridge into the Mystic River. Authorities then said Bennett no longer was considered a suspect. Norfolk County Assistant District Attorney Louis F. Sabadini said at Bennett's sentencing he had a record of 37 convictions, including shooting a police officer, shooting a taxi driver and firing a shotgun at a police cruiser. Bennett's lawyer said he will appeal the verdict. Bennett is also awaiting trial on a charge of armed robbery of a Boston yogurt shop.

DOC.HEAD: Princeton Mayor Barbara Boggs Sigmund Dies
DOC.TEXT: Barbara Boggs Sigmund, the colorful and eloquent mayor who finished second to Gov. Jim Florio in the 1989 Democratic gubernatorial primary, died early today, borough officials said. She was 51. Police Officer Bernard Lenhardt said Mrs. Sigmund died at home. She had been suffering from a recurrence of a cancer. Mrs. Sigmund was the daughter of retiring U.S. Rep. Lindy Boggs, a New Orleans Democrat, and the late Hale Boggs, who was the House majority leader and who was scheduled to become speaker of the House when he was killed in a plane crash in 1972. Mrs. Boggs reportedly made her decision to retire from the the House to spend more time with Mrs. Sigmund. The mayor was first stricken with cancer seven years ago. A malignant melanoma was found behind her left eye and the eye was removed in 1982. Late last year, Mrs. Sigmund announced the melanoma had reappeared and spread. After losing her eye, Mrs. Sigmund made her large collection of fashionable eye patches her trademark, coordinating them with the color of her outfits. As a campaign gimmick during the primary, she distributed eye patches to businessmen, lobbyists and politicians boarding a Chamber of Commerce chartered train to Washington. She was a former Mercer County freeholder and was an unsuccessful candidate for U.S. Senate in 1982. She had been widely expected to run for Congress - following in the footsteps of her mother and father - if Republican Rep. James Courter's bid for the governor's office succeeded and his seat became available. Courter lost. But by the time he announced he would retire from Congress, Mrs. Sigmund was waging a new battle against cancer. Florio today said Mrs. Sigmund ``had no peer ... as a friend, a leader and a source of joy and inspiration.'' Gov. Thomas H. Kean called Mrs. Sigmund ``a woman of remarkable courage, who kept through a difficult time with a sense of perspective and humor.'' Mrs. Sigmund enjoyed writing poetry, and recently published a collection of poetry and prose called ``An Unfinished Life.''

DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 15 grafs to UPDATE with arguments. Picks up 9th graf pvs `At Johnson ...' ^By RICHARD CARELLI
DOC.TEXT: Three Supreme Court justices voiced doubts today about the wisdom or legality of an employer's ``fetal protection'' policy that excludes all women of childbearing age from some hazardous jobs. In a case that could affect millions of working women, Justices John Paul Stevens, Antonin Scalia and Sandra Day O'Connor posed questions seemingly critical of the policy during an hour-long argument session. Stevens questioned Stanley Jaspan, a lawyer for the Milwaukee-based Johnson Controls Inc., about the risks to women working in its battery-making factories. ``Is the slightest risk enough'' to justify banning women from some jobs, Stevens asked. O'Connor and Scalia took issue with Jaspan's interpretation of what burdens Congress placed on employers when it passed the Pregnancy Discrimination Act in 1978. Scalia told Jaspan his suggestion that the 1978 law means employers cannot discriminate against women based on pregnancy except to protect a fetus ``is to make a farce of the Pregnancy Discrimination Act. You're making it a ridiculous piece of legislation.'' Since 1982, Johnson Controls, the nation's largest auto battery manufacturer, has barred women from factory jobs that expose them to unsafe levels of lead, the principal material used in making batteries. The policy was upheld by lower courts. Lead exposure is a health risk for female workers and their fetuses. Lead exposure, of course, also is a health risk for male workers. But the scientific proof that high levels of lead in a man's blood can contribute to fetal harm is sketchy. ``It would violate common sense ... to require an employer to damage unborn children,'' Jaspan argued. He said lead exposure ``poisons the fetus and causes permanent brain damage.'' But San Francisco lawyer Marsha Berzon, representing those who challenged the Johnson Controls policy, said ``the net effect of a policy like this is to sanction the re-segregation of the workplace.'' She said such policies relegate women to stereotypical jobs such as teaching, child care and nursing. The justices must decide by July whether the fetal protection policy amounts to illegal discrimination. One federal appeals court judge, calling the case the most important of its kind since Congress outlawed on-the-job sex bias 26 years ago, said the estimated number of women affected runs as high as 20 million. At Johnson Controls, women who could not prove they were infertile were forced to transfer to other jobs, although their salaries were not cut. Some of the women were in their 60s. Fertile women now hired are ineligible for top-paying jobs at the company's 13 plants, located in California, Delaware, Florida, Illinois, Kentucky, North Carolina, Michigan, Missouri, Ohio, Oregon, Texas, Vermont and Wisconsin. Eight employees and the United Auto Workers union challenged the policy in court, alleging that it violates Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964. It was not the first such challenge. At least 15 major corporations have fetal protection policies, and the American Civil Liberties Union says lawsuits have been filed in behalf of hospital technicians and factory and auto workers. Among the companies with such policies are General Motors, Monsanto and DuPont. U.S. District Judge Robert W. Warren in Milwaukee ruled for Johnson Controls before any trial was held, and the 7th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals voted 7-4 to uphold his ruing. Judge John L. Coffey wrote for the appeals court that the differing treatment of women employees was based on a ``business necessity.'' The appeals court concluded that the policy ``is reasonably necessary to industrial safety.'' Bush administration lawyers told the high court that a fetal protection policy could be legal, but that it should be judged by a standard more stringent than the ``business necessity'' test used by the appeals court. In a strongly worded dissent to the appeals court ruling, Judge Frank Easterbrook called the case the most important Title VII case ever and said such policies could ``consign more women to `women's work' while reserving better-paying but more hazardous jobs for men.'' He noted that lead is only one of many workplace substances that could harm fetuses, and said as many as 20 million jobs could be closed to women if the 7th Circuit court's rationale were adopted nationwide. In action Tuesday, the Supreme Court: -Let stand a ruling in a Pennsylvania case that public schools that allow civic groups and others to rent space cannot refuse the same access to religious organizations. -Agreed to decide in a Florida case whether police without a court warrant may conduct random searches aboard buses and trains. -Left intact an affirmative action program plan for hiring and promoting more minorities and women in San Francisco's fire department. The plan had been challenged as discriminatory against white men. -Revived a $4 billion lawsuit by a millionaire Florida inventor who says an ABC television program falsely portrayed him as a liar and hypocrite.

DOC.HEAD: Economist, Human Rights Lawyer Honored for Social Work
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 13th graf to CORRECT that Ms. Langer teaches at University of Bremen sted the University of Tuebingen; pickup 14th graf pvs, `Bernard Ledea...'
DOC.TEXT: An American economist and an Israeli human rights lawyer were among the winners today of the Right Livelihood Awards, which honor grass-roots work that helps people and solves social problems. A West African peasant leader and a Colombian agricultural workers' organization also won. The awards, often called the alternative Nobel prizes, were founded in 1980 by Jakob von Uexkull, a Swedish-German writer who sold his stamp collection to provide the funding. Von Uexkull wanted to support people and organizations doing practical work. He said the Nobel Prizes hade become too specialized and tend to focus on scientists and other products of Western universities, rather than grass-roots innovators. The awards will be presented in the Swedish Parliament on Dec. 9, the day before the Nobel Prize ceremonies. Alice Tepper Marlin, founder and president of the Council on Economic Priorities in New York, won one award. The international award jury cited her for ``the courage and vision to show the directions in which the Western economy must develop if it is to contribute to - instead of harming - global security and the well-being of humanity.'' The council is an independent research organization that focuses on national security, energy and the environment, and corporate responsibility. It publishes monthly newsletters, studies and books, including the 1988 bestseller ``Shopping for a Better World,'' a guide that rates companies according to ecological and social criteria. Ms. Martin's award was honorary because her organization was deemed large enough to generate funding. The three other winners, however, each received cash awards of $120,000 to help them continue their work. They included human rights lawyer Felicia Langer, 59, who since 1968 has defended Palestinians in military courts in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. The jury cited her ``exemplary courage ... for basic human rights under very difficult circumstances.'' Langer moved to Tuebingen, Germany, in July to teach law at the University of Bremen. Bernard Ledea Ouedraogo of Burkina Faso was honored for establishing the grass-roots organizations NAAM and the Six S Association, which promote peasant self-help movements. Ouedraogo believes that Africa's problems can only be solved by applying traditional African methods, von Uexkull said. The Six S is a federation of peasant organizations that disburses financial aid to local farmers groups. NAAM's activities range from building projects to manufacturing and trade. A Colombian agricultural workers' organization, the Association of Peasant Workers of Carare, won the prize for its efforts to promote peace. Four of its leaders were slain in February. The association is involved in ecological projects in Colombia and the promotion of self-reliance. Since October 1989, it has concentrated on peacemaking by organizing meetings among guerillas and military and paramilitary units.

DOC.HEAD: Fire on Offshore Rig Injures Six
DOC.TEXT: A fire broke out aboard an oil rig in the Gulf of Mexico, injuring six workers. The fire started shortly before midnight Tuesday and burned for about 45 minutes. The cause was under investigation, said Jay Cheatham, vice president and southeastern district manager for Arco Oil & Gas Co. The platform was six miles out from the mouth of the Mississippi River, about 100 miles southeast of New Orleans, the Coast Guard said. Coast Guard and civilian helicopters evacuated the injured crewmen to New Orleans area hospitals. Only one suffered serious burns, the Coast Guard said. Mitchell Ham, 28, has second- and third-degree burns and was in critical condition, said West Jefferson Medical Center spokesman Jim Pittman. A civilian company was hired to do cleanup work, Petty Officer Dennis Schaefer said. ``The boats were shooting water on the fire, and there probably was a little bit of oil that washed over as a result of that, but as far as we know there's no spill coming from the platform at this time,'' Cheatham said.

DOC.HEAD: USDA Keeps Close Eye on Grain Competitors
Also moved for PMs
DOC.TEXT: Trade watchers in the Agriculture Department are straining to see what other countries are doing that could affect the prices American farmers get for wheat, corn and other commodities. In other words, competition is the name of the game, and practically every foreign grain exporter is swinging away. For example, a report by the department's Foreign Agricultural Service included an article about the Canadian Wheat Board and its guaranteed price to farmers in today's competitive world market. ``With the recent precipitous decline in world wheat prices, attention is drawn to the role of export monopolies, such as the Canadian Wheat Board, and the extent to which guaranteed price levels to producers may have been overestimated, possibly requiring government treasuries to cover resulting losses,'' the report said. In many international markets, Canadian wheat must compete with prices established by subsidized wheat from the European Community. Meanwhile, the board's initial payment to wheat farmers for No. 1 Canadian Western Red Spring wheat of 13.5 percent protein was about $117 per metric ton in U.S. dollars. But Canadian wheat on the world market is worth only about $69 per ton. Therefore, the report said, the deficit of $48 per ton presumably would have to be absorbed by the board. ``Any losses being sustained by the Canadian Wheat Board on wheat exports could be offset by profits from sales executed before the recent price declines or by sales to commercial customers who pay premium prices for high-protein wheat,'' the report said. Some other comments about the current grain situation: -Brazil will need to import more wheat in 1990-91 because of reduced domestic plantings, a crop shortfall and growing consumption. Although Brazil has a supply agreement with Argentina, it may have to turn to other suppliers. ``Canada, whose wheat trade agreement with Brazil ended in 1988, has been exporting wheat under an informal agreement,'' the report said. ``Trade sources indicate that Canada has expressed an interest in negotiation a new formal agreement but has insisted that arrearage on past credit sales be paid first.'' -South Korea has been buying competitively priced feed-quality wheat from the European Community. The low-quality wheat from Europe already is displacing corn in the South Korea and could hurt U.S. exports of feed grain to that growing Asian market. -Poland's wheat imports in 1990-91 are expected to drop to the lowest level in more than 20 years, mostly because of a record 1990 harvest, diminished consumer subsidies and reduced livestock feeding. ``Typically, the EC has been the major supplier of wheat to Poland,'' the report said. ``However, lower import needs in Poland could free additional EC supplies for shipments to other markets and could increase competition for the United States.'' -In southern East Europe, greater demand for imports of coarse grain has been spurred by harvest shortfalls in Yugoslavia and Hungary, major corn-producing countries. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Consumer prices for bananas peaked in July because of a strike against Chiquita Brands Inc. by workers in Honduras, according to an Agriculture Department report. The United States imported 2.92 million metric tons of bananas in 1989. A metric ton is about 2,205 pounds. In late June, a strike against Chiquita Brands ``significantly disrupted'' shipments of Honduran bananas in July and August and ``resulted in unseasonably high retail prices in U.S. markets,'' the department's Economic Research Service said. Total imports of bananas were up during the first six months of this year, including the period of the Honduran strike, as imports from Ecuador - the largest supplier - rose 36 percent from a year earlier. Between July 1 and Aug. 18, according to USDA trade figures, shipments of Honduran bananas to the United States dropped 54 percent from a year earlier to only 27,034 tons. The strike ``curtailed Honduran exports of about 108,000 metric tons over its seven-week duration,'' the report said. The United States accounts for more than 60 percent of the country's total banana exports, and Chiquita is the largest handler. Meanwhile, U.S. banana prices, which usually soften with stiffer competition from summer fruits, rose sharply in July as a result of the reduced supply from Honduras, the report said. ``Although the impact was primarily on the East Coast, where the bulk of Honduran banana imports are sold, West Coast retail prices also reflected the market shortage,'' the report said. In July, the U.S. retail banana prices reported by the Labor Department averaged 52.9 cents per pound, up 18 percent from June. But with the end of the strike and more bananas in the market, prices dropped sharply in August, averaging 46.3 cents per pound nationally, a 13 percent drop from July. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Trout farming is sharing in an expanded demand for fish and other seafood, an annual report by the Agriculture Department shows. Growers in 15 major trout-producing states had total sales of fish and eggs of about $76.9 million during the year that ended Aug. 31, according to the report. That was up 7 percent from $71.7 million in 1988-89. The sales included 59.9 million pounds of trout valued at $72.6 million, and 349 million trout eggs worth $4.31 million. An estimated 95 percent of the trout sold were food-size, the report said. The average value was $1.14 per pound, up from $1.08 the previous year. Idaho was the leader in sales at about $33.1 million. Other leading producers included California, $11.1 million; Pennsylvania, $6.14 million; North Carolina, $4.9 million; and Washington, $4.76 million.

DOC.HEAD: Enrollment Triples at Tiny School
Also moved for PMs
LaserPhoto MP1
DOC.TEXT: Enrollment tripled at the Orton School this fall, but there is no risk of overcrowding. Three students now share the school's single classroom. ``Now I have someone to play with at recess,'' said Levi Tibbs, a fifth-grader who was the school's lone student last year. His playmates are sisters Emily Hansen, a second grader, and Sheri Davis, who is in sixth grade. Their attendance at the 1918 schoolhouse has helped stave off its extinction. ``We considered closing it, but if we did, then we'd have to pay to board those kids in town or we'd have to pay mileage for them to be driven to school and home every day,'' said county school Superintendent Jerry Kleinsasser. And that trip is no quick jaunt. The nearest town is Fort Pierre, a long hour's drive down 50 miles of bumpy, winding road that follows the rugged breaks of the Missouri River. Locals call the area starkly beautiful. Outsiders call it desolate. Winters are harsh and snowy on the Dakota prairie, and the wind almost never stills. ``You can hear the coyotes fighting and jabbering all night long,'' said teacher Steve Pickner, 31, who lives with his dog in a rent-free mobile home on the school site. His nearest neighbors are antelope, grouse and rattlesnakes. Pickner is in his first year as a teacher - he graduated from the University of South Dakota in August - and he has his qualms. ``I'd rather teach 50 kids in one class than three in different grades,'' he said. ``That's 21 separate lessons I have to prepare each night, but it does keep me busy and helps pass the time out here.'' It's hard to get used to the quiet after classes. ``I look forward to Tuesdays, Thursdays and Saturdays when the mail comes,'' Pickner said. Occasionally, he helps mend fences at a nearby ranch that raises one of the nation's largest private buffalo herds. Elementary Principal Elsie Baye says teachers rarely stay more than a year at Orton. ``It's isolated,'' she admits, and the free housing is essential to lure teachers to such a rustic outpost. Still, she persists in putting the best face on it: ``Someone who is an artist or wildlife photographer would just love it there.'' And as for the children, ``It's a great educational opportunity. Our rural kids are usually good students. They get a lot of one-on-one.'' Levi Tibb's mother, Loretta, taught at the Orton School; her husband, Wayne, and their three other children all went there. ``They were almost a year ahead of other students when they got to ninth grade,'' she said. In Orton's classroom - big and bright with three desks in the middle - two students sit together while Pickner tutors the third across the room. An outdated computer sits in one corner; a television set that gets only one channel sits in another. The other classroom fixtures include an aging piano, an ant farm, a water fountain and a microwave oven where the kids and teacher heat their lunches. Once a month, a janitor shows up to shine the linoleum floor. Three times a day, the huge bell atop the freshly painted white building tolls. The bell did not toll this year for the Orton School, but its future is not assured. Stanley County rural schools once were full, but fewer ranch families live in the area, Mrs. Tibbs said. ``They couldn't all make a living here anymore because milking cows and a few acres of land just didn't cut it. People sold out to others, and the remaining ranches got bigger. That cut down on families and kids in the area,'' she said. But Orton is not alone in its tininess. Of the three other rural schools in Stanley County, none has more than eight students. Almost one-fourth of the elementary schools in South Dakota still have only one or two teachers. Legally, schools cannot be closed unless enrollment slips to fewer than five. And neither the kids nor their parents seem inclined abandon the small schools. ``It's funner than a big school,'' said Sheri Davis.

DOC.HEAD: Mother Shaves Head for New Kids Tickets
LaserPhoto MI1
DOC.TEXT: When Denice Sprowl learned a radio station would give free New Kids on the Block tickets to parents who would do the craziest things, she made a vow. ``I'd do anything. I'd shave my head,'' she promised. And that's exactly what she did to win two backstage passes, four tickets, a limousine ride to and from the Nov. 11 concert in Milwaukee, plus an evening at an adult fantasy suite in Northbrook, Ill. Her 12-year-old daughter, Anna, had been disappointed her mother couldn't afford tickets to the popular rock group's concert at East Troy last year. Ms. Sprowl, 28, of Lake Geneva, heard about the contest on Kenosha station WJZQ. At the contest Saturday, her 38-year-old sister, Debbie DaSilva, clipped and shaved Ms. Sprowl's hair. ``When she started with the clippers, I was thinking, `What if I do this and I don't win the tickets?''' But the sight of the hair-clipping caused several contestants to drop out, and Ms. Sprowl emerged a bald-headed winner.

DOC.HEAD: More than 40 Dead After Beachings
DOC.TEXT: More than 40 pilot whales have died near New Zealand's Coromandel Pensinsula over the past few days after beaching themselves, officials said Wednesday. Volunteers and conservation officers managed to coax many of the whales back to sea, but some returned to the peninsula on the east coast of New Zealand's North Island or were too exhausted to survive. More than 20 pilot whales died Wednesday on Great Mercury Island, just off the peninsula, after a pod of about 47 was found beached the night before, said Warwick Murray, operations manager for Auckland Conservancy. Local residents and conservation officers were able to steer all but five of the survivors back to sea, but another nine later washed ashore dead. Many of the survivores were still ``groggy'' and might die, Murray said. On Saturday, about 36 whales became stranded or were in trouble in shallow water south of the peninsula. At least a dozen died.

DOC.HEAD: U.N. Sending 30 Million Dollars in Food Aid for Liberians
DOC.TEXT: A U.N. agency said Wednesday it will provide 50,000 tons of food aid worth $30 million for Liberians displaced by the civil war in their West African country. The shipments to Liberia and the neighboring countries of Ivory Coast, Guinea and Sierra Leone will help meet the needs for six months of 710,000 Liberians, said the Rome-based World Food Program. The World Food Program said it will also send 5,000 tons of wheat worth $1.7 million to Ethiopia for 110,000 people whose food supplies are expected to be reduced by drought.

DOC.HEAD: After Decades in East Bloc, Etruscan Treasures Return to Italy
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.HEAD: By MARY BETH SHERIDAN
DOC.TEXT: After decades behind the Iron Curtain, hundreds of Etruscan artifacts have returned to Italy in a major show from museums in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union. The 1,200 artifacts, which were nearly inaccessible to Westerners for decades, have come home to central Italy, where the Etruscan culture flourished until the 1st century B.C. The exhibit is being hailed as a chance for scholars and the public to rediscover Etruscan masterpieces hidden away for decades. It also is seen as a sign of exciting times to come in the art world, as the new democracies of Eastern Europe begin to exchange exhibits with countries that were ideological foes. ``This brings together an extraordinary number of masterpieces that were very little known,'' said Massimo Pallottino, president of the National Institute of Italian Etruscan Studies. ``It's something of exceptional importance.'' The exhibit in a Gothic castle in Viterbo, 50 miles north of Rome, was organized by the State Museums of Berlin. It includes Etruscan artifacts from 26 museums in Poland, Hungary, Czechoslovakia and the former East Germany, as well as the Soviet Union. The Etruscans were a powerful empire that dominated Italy before succumbing to the Roman Empire. They were known for commercial flair, an elaborate religion and a brilliant artisan tradition, which included the finest goldwork in ancient Europe. The Viterbo show brings together a wide range of Etruscan artifacts, ranging from a simple ceramic urn shaped like a house dating from the 9th century B.C., to elaborately carved sarcophagi from the 2nd and 3rd centuries B.C. The highlights include the contents of an 8th century B.C. tomb of a man known as the Warrior of Tarquinia. Among the 104 pieces are engraved bronze shields, weapons, bracelets, rings and even a razor for the afterlife. Another rare item is the ``Tile of Capua,'' a 5th-century B.C. plaque with writing believed to be part of a funeral ritual. It is the second-longest existing piece of Etruscan writing, which scientists have never succeeded in translating. Several carved stone and alabaster sarcophagi with scenes of battles or the trip to the afterlife illustrate the Etruscans' talent for sculpture. On top of a few lies a likeness of the dead person, often propped up on one elbow as if to enjoy a good Etruscan meal. Also in the exhibit is gold jewelry, including tiny earrings etched to resemble shields or bunches of grapes from the 3rd to 5th centuries B.C. Many Etruscan treasures wound up in German and Russian hands in the 19th century, before Italy passed a law limiting exports. Germans, in particular, did much of the early research on the Etruscans and were interested in acquiring the pieces. Many of the items in the exhibit were difficult for Westerners to see during Communist rule in Eastern Europe, due to the difficulty of obtaining tourist visas. ``Even some of our experts hadn't seen them,'' said Carlo Maria Cardoni, director of the exhibit. For the Italian organizers, the novelty of having treasures from Eastern European museums was matched by the novelty of working with museum officials trained under communism. ``Their architect still goes around with a wooden ruler and a pencil,'' said Cardoni, shaking his head. ``Let him see a computer that in 35 minutes lays out the show, and it's like hitting him in the head with a hammer.'' The Germans were also uneasy about the idea of making a videocassette of the exhibit, Cardoni said. ``I just went ahead with it anyway,'' he shrugged. The show, which closes Sunday, has toured Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union and may eventually go to France or Japan, Cardoni said. Art experts say the show is an example of the revolution that is occurring in cultural exchanges now that Communist governments have fallen or become more moderate. ``As curators and scholars, there's always been an international interest in sharing the cultural wealth of one nation with another,'' said Jillian Slonim, public information director of the New York-based American Federation of Arts. ``On the practical level, the circumstances have radically changed in the last short while, along with the changes in the governments.''

DOC.HEAD: Lower-Caste Advocates Set Fire To Train, 47 Killed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with lower number of dead, to 47 from 60; pickup 8th graf pvs, `United News...'
DOC.TEXT: Members of a leftist band that advocates the rights of the underpriviliged doused a moving train car with gasoline and set it on fire, killing 47 people, news reports said today. A survivor said he and other terrified passengers stampeded for the train's exits as the fire swept through the car Tuesday night. Fourteen people were injured in the blaze, according to the news reports. The blaze came just hours after six higher-caste students killed themselves by poisoning, hanging or immolation to protest an affirmative action for the lower casts announced by Prime Minister V.P. Singh, Trust of India reported. Radicals were calling for a strike today in support of the plan, which reserves half of the government's vacancies for low-caste Hindus. The train torching was the worst incident linked to Singh's Aug. 7 announcement of the policy. The deaths Tuesday pushed to more than 150 the number of people killed in related violence. United News of India said 47 people were burned to death when the passenger train car was set ablaze near Hyderabad, 590 miles south of New Delhi. The news agency initially reported that 60 people were killed. It quoted official sources as saying 45 bodies had been recovered and more were trapped in the charred rail car. It was not immediately known how many passengers were aboard when the blaze began. United News and newspapers quoted local officials and witnesses as saying the fire was set by members of the People's War Group. The group is part of the so-called Naxalite movement, which often resorts to kidnappings and violence to press its claim as an advocate of the rights of oppressed peoples. The Hindu, a daily newspaper based in the southern city of Madras, said 10 to 15 members of the People's War Group boarded the train at Cherlapalli and handed out pamphlets protesting a Supreme Court injunction suspending implementation of the plan on which Singh's job proposal is based. The activists then poured gasoline on the floor of a passenger car, ignited it and jumped off the train, The Hindu said. Its report was attributed to a correspondent who visited the site while the car was still burning. The Indian Express, another national newspaper, quoted railroad officials as giving a similar account and saying one or two Naxalites might have died in the fire. The Naxalite movement was founded in 1967, drawing inspiration from the late Chinese leader Mao Tse-tung and advocating armed overthrow of government. The name ``Naxalite'' stems from Naxalbari village in West Bengal state where the movement started. It later spread across eastern and southern India. The Times of India, another national newspaper, quoted witnesses as saying the arsonists sang revolutionary songs before jumping off the 15-car passenger train, which was traveling from Hyderabad to Warangal. Warangal, 80 miles northeast of Hyderabad, is at the core of a rural region where Naxalite agitation is often reported. ``I was sitting in the middle of the compartment,'' The Times quoted passenger Samba Murthy as saying. ``I heard slogans and suddenly there was smoke all around and lights went off. About 20 of us could jump off. There was a stampede.'' Murthy, a contractor from Warangal, added: ``I do not know what happened to my brother and brother-in-law who were traveling with me.'' The Times quoted another passenger, identified only as Narsimha, as saying the arsonists shouted slogans in support of the strike called for today by the Naxalites. Singh wants to reserve an additional 27 percent of federal jobs for low-caste Hindus. Twenty-two percent already are reserved for tribespeople and outcasts, or ``untouchables,'' who are at the very bottom of Indian society. This means fewer upper-caste people would get jobs, even if their academic qualifications are higher than people from the lower social classes. Strikes, marches and rallies have swelled in New Delhi and several states across India as the students pressed their protests by torching buses and stoning government buildings. Police and paramilitary forces have retaliated with tear gas and bullets.

DOC.HEAD: NASA Plans One, Maybe Two More Launches in 1990
With AM-Space Shuttle, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Buoyed by a nearly flawless flight of its fleet leader, NASA headed with renewed confidence toward the next shuttle sendoff, next month's launch of Atlantis. ``The fact that it flew and they had such a textbook mission really makes us feel good,'' Conrad Nagel, a NASA official in charge of Atlantis' prelaunch operations, said of the Discovery mission. Atlantis' secret military mission will be the fifth and final shuttle flight for 1990 - four fewer than planned - unless Columbia's hydrogen leaks can be repaired in time for a late November or December launch. Safety rather than flight qutas will dictate when Columbia goes up, said launch director Bob Sieck. ``The bottom line is we've got to have safe and successful missions, and that's always been our goal,'' Sieck said. The way to restore NASA's credibility, Sieck said, is to ``set realistic launch dates given our capabilities and meet the objectives as close as we can.'' The National Aeronautics and Space Administration met both those criteria preparing for Discovery's four-day mission, which ended Wednesday with a smooth landing at Edwards Air Force Base, Calif. Discovery's liftoff Saturday was just a day later than planned and was followed by the release of its cargo, the Ulysses sun probe. It was Discovery's 11th flight, a shuttle record, and ended the second-longest grounding of the fleet, caused by dangerous hydrogen leaks. Discovery had flown the last mission before that, in April. Columbia, the oldest spaceship, has logged nine trips, Atlantis six. Challenger's last journey, which ended in disaster in January 1986, was its 10th. Atlantis, like Columbia, has had more than its share of trouble this year. A tanking test on Atlantis in June uncovered hydrogen leaks in plumbing between the orbiter and external tank, and its July Pentagon flight was put on hold. Similar leaks had been found in Columbia in May. NASA replaced Atlantis' external tank and attached plumbing, as well as seals in liquid hydrogen valves on the orbiter side of the vehicle. The repairs were completed Sept. 28. Five days later, a metal beam from a work platform banged around the engine compartment as the orbiter was being hoisted into an upright position. Workers forgot to remove the 9-foot-long, bright yellow beam. Nagel said the space agency is ``extremely fortunate'' the beam did not cause more damage. About 25 dings and dents were reported, the worst being a cracked purge duct and a smashed 1-inch section of an overboard vent line for liquid oxygen. NASA planned to move Atlantis from the assembly building to the launch pad this week. A tanking test to check for hydrogen leaks is planned for later this month. ``We feel like we're going to come through the tanking test with flying colors,'' Nagel said. Columbia, which has endured four failed countdowns since May, was moved from the pad back to the assembly building Tuesday because of potentially severe weather. It will be transported early next week to the other launch pad where it, too, will undergo a tanking test this month. A nine-member investigative team is working seven days a week on Columbia's leak problem, which appears to be confined to the engine compartment. Each investigator received a one-way ticket to Florida and was told he cannot go home until all the leaks are found. ``We're going to finally capture this diabolical leak in Columbia and we're going to get it back in the air, hopefully before the end of the year,'' Sieck said. Sieck doesn't expect this to be the last time a shuttle is grounded by a mysterious problem that crops up during the countdown. ``We hope they're minimum, but I wouldn't say there never will be one again,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Crude Oil Hits Record High on Saddam Threats
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs with today's record oil prices, Picks up 4th graf pvs., `Crude oil...' A version also moved on financial wires.
DOC.TEXT: War jitters from the Middle East helped push crude oil to more than $41 a barrel during one spurt of feverish buying today, its highest level since the 1979 Iranian revolution. That's nearly double the price before Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. In early trading today, light sweet crude, the U.S. benchmark grade, was as high as $41.15 per barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange, the highest price ever for an oil futures contract, before falling back to $40.88. That was 48 cents above Tuesday's record close of $40.40 for November delivery. Crude oil futures contracts, which promise delivery at a certain date at a set price, have traded on the New York Mercantile Exchange since 1983. Crude oil last fetched more than $40 a barrel after the 1979 Iranian revolution. But crude would have to hit about $57 in 1990 dollars to equal the real cost of oil from a decade ago, experts have said. Traders said the slayings of 19 Palestinians in a clash with police in Jerusalem on Monday, Saddam's threat of retaliation and the approach of winter in the United States - which increases demand for oil - pushed the price up. ``Everybody's worst possible nightmare is fighting breaking out in the Middle East and another cold winter in the United States,'' said Peter Beutel, an oil analyst at Pegasus Econometric Group Inc. in Hoboken, N.J. Saddam appeared to use the slayings in Jerusalem to lash out at Israel and the United States. In a statement, he said Iraq has a new long-range missile that could be launched against Israel and the U.S.-led forces in Saudi Arabia. The benchmark U.S. grade was $22.10 a barrel the day before the Iraqi invasion. The main reason for the increase has been the possibility that war will disrupt production, making oil more scarce and more expensive. While futures prices do not directly affect the price of gasoline at the pump, self-serve unleaded gasoline nationwide rose 2.4 cents in the last week to $1.37 per gallon, the American Automobile Association said Tuesday. The AAA said unleaded gasoline has risen 29.5 cents since Aug. 1.

DOC.HEAD: Israel Names Panel to Investigate Shooting at Temple Mount
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To ADD last time such a panel was appointed, INSERT new 10th graf; pickup 10th pvs, `Membes of...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY7
DOC.TEXT: The Israeli government today named a three-man panel led by a former chief of the Mossad secret service to investigate the killing of 19 Palestinian rioters on the Temple Mount. The investigation was ordered by Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir before the U.N. Security Council was to begin debate on condemning Israel for using police force against rioters. The Security Council also was expected to order a U.N. inquiry into Monday's bloodbath. ``It will now be investigated by ourselves. We don't need a probe by international factors,'' said Yossi Ahimeir, Shamir's spokesman. ``The marginal point of whether it was excessive force or not is to be investigated.'' Israeli security forces killed 19 Arabs and wounded 140 in Monday's clash outside the Al-Aqsa mosque, Islam's third-holiest site. It was the bloodiest confrontation of the 34-month-old Palestinian uprising against Israeli occupation, and it raised an immediate world outcry. The panel was ordered to investigate events leading to the riot and the conduct of paramilitary border police in opening fire with live ammunition. Asked what powers the committee would have, Ahimeir said it could make ``every recommendation they see fit and the prime minister will decide what to do with it.'' However, Israel radio reported that it will not have the power to subpoena reluctant witnesses and its recommendations will not be binding. Ahimeir said the investigation would be headed by reserve Maj. Gen. Zvi Zamir, who was head of the Mossad from 1968 to 1974. The other members will be Yaacov Neeman, a prominent attorney, and Chaim Kubersky, a former director of the Interior Ministry. Ahimeir said the committee would report ``as soon as possible.'' When asked whether its hearings would be public, he replied that they ``involve security and operational details so, if necessary, discussions will be subject to the usual security laws.'' The last time such a panel was appointed was in 1985 to examine the deaths of two Palestinian bus hijackers while in custody of the Shin Bet security service. Members of the U.N. Security Council on Tuesday debated a resolution condemning the shootings and calling for a U.N. investigation. The United States was prepared to cast a rare vote against its ally. President Bush criticized Israeli forces for not acting ``with more restraint.'' Today, China, Zimbabwe and Kuwait's government-in-exile added their voices to those condemning Israel for the violence. In the occupied territories, soldiers kept more than a million Palestinians under curfew for a third day to contain unrest triggered by the violence at the Old City site, which is holy to both Jews and Moslems. In a leaflet issued Tuesday, the PLO-backed leaders of the Palestinian uprising urged revenge attacks on soldiers and Jewish settlers. The government published a full-page ad in leading dailies urging Israelis to respond to Monday's riots by showing up at the Wailing Wall for Simchat Torah holiday celebrations Thursday night. The holiday, which means Joy of Torah, marks the end of the eight-day Sukkot, or Feast of Tabernacles. Police Chief Yaacov Turner denied reports in Israeli newspapers that suggested his troops had failed to heed intelligence information to expect Monday's riot, and to deploy accordingly. The riot began when Palestinians hurled rocks at Jewish worshippers at the Western Wall, Judaism's holiest site and just below the Al-Aqsa mosque. Twenty-eight Jews were injured by rocks. Police then charged at the rioters on the Temple Mount, initially firing tear gas. According to Israeli officials, the troops, heavily outnumbered, only later opened fire with live ammunition. The attack was provoked by rumors that Jewish zealots planned to march on the Temple Mount - which both Moslems and Jews consider sacred - and reclaim it for Judaism, Palestinians said. The site of the violence is the most emotionally charged in the lands Israel captured in the 1967 Middle East War. The left-of-center Labor Party published a statement accusing the government of ``a lax in security that endangered the lives of Jews at the Wailing Wall.'' The Western Wall is also known as the Wailing Wall. The conservative daily Maariv in a full-page story today, said some policemen apparently panicked over rumors that colleagues were trapped in a burning police station on the Mount during the riot. ``The opening of fire was not done in planned fashion or by command, but rather independently based on decisions by isolated policemen or a small force when they felt their lives were endangered,'' the newspaper said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Campaigning for GOP in North Carolina, Georgia, Florida
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 10th graf, bgng, The president ... with 3 new grafs to UPDATE with later comments; edits at end to tighten
DOC.TEXT: RALEIGH, N.C. AP) - President Bush, treading carefully on the tax issue as he campaigned for conservative Sen. Jesse Helms, promised today to work to ``put together a better package'' to match the $500 billion in deficit cuts of his rejected plan. It was Bush's first test of his professed goodwill toward Republicans who disagree with him on the budget. Helms opposed the package Bush crafted with congressional leaders, and which was rejected last week by the House, calling it ``a turkey.'' He also has criticized Bush's decision to abandon his ``no new taxes'' campaign pledge. ``Of course there are going to be differences,'' Bush told the fund-raising breakfast in Raleigh's Civic Center. Bush steered completely clear of the issue of higher taxes, and didn't mention them when he ticked off a list of features that the new budget pact should include. The campaign appearances came a day after Bush hinted he might agree to higher taxes on wealthy Americans in exchange to lower capital gains tax rates, then abruptly withdrew the offer under pressure from Republican senators. Helms is seeking a fourth term in a heated race against Harvey Gantt, the liberal, black former mayor of Charlotte. Polls show the two locked in a dead heat. Helms avoided areas of disagreement with the president completely, calling Bush ``evenhanded'' in all matters. ``He's evenhanded. He's always the same: a thoroughbred gentleman who is recognized around this world, who is recognized as a courageous and brave leader. Later, in St. Petersburg, Fla., Bush told a fund-raising rally for Republican Gov. Bob Martinez that Democratic control of both houses of Congress ``is all the more reason for Republicans to stand for the best possible budget.'' Bush also defended his decision to shut down the government over the Columbus Day weekend rather than approve the first version of a temporary spending bill. ``I did it to keep the pressure on,'' he said in prepared remarks. The president was to wind up his three-state swing through the South tonight at a GOP reception in Atlanta for Georgia gubernatorial candidate Johnny Isakson. At his Raleigh stop, Bush said, ``My objective now is to put together a better package, one that meets our target of $500 billion deficit reduction over the next five years.'' ``I can't confine my support to somebody who agrees with me on a deficit deal today or some bill tomorrow,'' Bush said Tuesday when asked whether he would have trouble campaigning for Helms. In today's remarks, Bush made no mention of the divisive issue of higher taxes for wealthy Americans. The president on Tuesday did a flip-flop on the issue, first suggesting at a morning news conference that he was open to a compromise that would trade higher tax rates for affluent Americans for a cut in the capital-gains tax. Then, later in the day, Republican leaders said Bush had reversed his position on the issue. The budget package rejected by the House, which called for higher taxes on gasoline, cigarettes and alcohol and cuts in Medicare and farm programs, ``was not the one I would have written alone,'' Bush said. ``And it's not one Jesse would have written either. But as president, I don't control the Congress and so we had to compromise - because the future of the country is at stake.'' He said he worked for the bipartisan agreement because it was ``the best plan possible.'' And, said Bush, ``I will continue now to press hard for a budget that fulfills the spirit of that bipartisan plan and proves to the American people once and for all that we can deal with this deficit. Like many conservative Republicans, Helms was a critic of the $500 billion, five-year package of new taxes and spending cuts crafted by Bush and congressional leaders but rejected last week in the House. Among its many features, the plan would have raised taxes on cigarettes - extremely unpopular in tobacco states like North Carolina. Helms even voted against a vague budget outline approved late Monday in the Senate with Bush's endorsement - an outline that didn't specify what would be taxed. Still, it was Bush's second campaign appearance for Helms. He also helped him raise money for his campaign in June. ``I would be talking about the common themes,'' Bush said. ``We're talking about the broad principles that unite us.''

DOC.HEAD: One Marine Missing After Training Mission Accident
DOC.TEXT: A Marine parachutist was killed and five others were injured in a jump during a night training mission, officials said. The accident occurred Tuesday night when the Marines jumped out of a helicopter into a wooded area at the Oak Grove Training Facility in Jones County in eastern North Carolina. The training center is part of Camp Lejeune, based in neighboring Onslow County. The body of the dead parachutist was discovered today in the Trent River, base spokesman Lt. Colleen Ryan said. He was assigned to the 2nd Air Naval Gunfire Liaison Company, 2nd Surveillance, Reconnaissance and Intelligence Group at Camp Lejeune. His name was not released pending notification of relatives, Ryan said. Three of the injured Marines were treated for minor cuts and scrapes and released. Two others were being kept for observation. In the Persian Gulf, a sudden spate of air crashes has left four dead and eight missing. Many of the aircraft mishaps involving American forces in Saudi Arabia have occurred in darkness, underscoring that U.S. forces are stressing training for night fighting. But base officials said the accident Tuesday was unrelated to the preparations in the Middle East. ``This is normal, routine training,'' said Staff Sgt. Rick Lynch. ``We've been doing it since people have been jumping out of airplanes. It has absolutely nothing to do with the Gulf.''

Here are excerpts from recent editorials in newspapers in the United States and abroad. --- Oct. 8 San Antonio Light on the federal budget: What a way to run a government! Millions of Americans who have to handle family and business budgets undoubtedly have been shaking their heads and uttering that comment. ... Tourists who have planned vacations for months and traveled thousands of miles only to find the national parks or government museums padlocked shut undoubtedly have been saying worse. Government employees who literally don't know from day to day whether to report for work can hardly be expected to bring high morale to the work place. Few can sympathize with a Congress that has known for months that such tough decisions loomed. With an election one month away, members of Congress now stand truly accountable before voters - and those voters are not in a tolerant mood. ... This form of government eventually could be at stake if such antics persists. --- Oct. 8 Courier-Post, Hannibal, Mo., on the federal budget: House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., summed up the crisis situation at the end of the House debate on the revised budget: ``With all my heart, I believe the country is at stake. These deficits cannot go on.'' We believe that Gephardt is right on target with this budget message. Our country's economic future is at stake. It is time to stop catering to the needs of special-interest groups and concentrate instead on the good of the nation. We believe ... lawmakers must commit themselves to reducing the federal deficit. Additional taxes may be needed to accomplish this goal. But more importantly, spending must be reduced. This country is in financial peril, and we cannot continue to be the saviors of the world. Voters must put pressure on lawmakers to act in the best interests of America as a whole. Perhaps this election-eve financial crisis is what it will take to get lawmakers to concentrate on reducing the deficit - and building an economically stable world for the next generation. --- Oct. 3 Argus Observer, Ontario, Ore., on politicians: Politicians should have gotten the message by now. Election years, for some time now, have shown decreasing numbers of the electorate turning out to vote. From the complaints we hear, it isn't that the voters are satisfied with the status quo. More and more we begin to think that the voter is discouraged with those whom we send to Washington. ... The political bickering is hardly something to instill faith in the system. Neither of the major parties has really drafted policy which will cut into the horrendous deficit. A few bright legislators can see the handwriting on the wall and realize that this deficit must be curbed - but they are too few. Others go blissfully on, voting large raises for themselves and constituents, handing out dollars for pet projects where their greatest poitical support is, and not enacting any really meaningful reform for both social and economic issues. The inability of these elected solons to stand up to the issues is appalling. ... Right now it is hard to determine just what they are doing to earn salaries four or five (or more) times what most of us earn, not to mention the ``perks'' which few if any taxpayers can claim. --- Oct. 6 The Providence (R.I.) Journal-Bulletin on nuclear plants and cancer: The National Cancer Institute examined all deaths from 16 types of cancer occurring from 1950 to 1984 in 107 counties that are in close proximity to 62 commercial and defense-related nuclear facilities across the country. According to John Boice, chief of the institute's radiation epidemiology branch, the study indicates there is no evidence of increased risk of cancer among people living near nuclear power plants. These results confirm what most scientific and medical specialists in the field of nuclear radiation have been saying all along. While acknowledging that nuclear plants release some radiation into the atmosphere during operation, they have pointed out that the amounts are extremely small - less than 5 percent of the background radiation that people are habitually exposed to from the natural environment. ... The National Cancer Institute is not famous for its pro-nuclear bias. And no proponent of nuclear energy - within the government or without - can ever underestimate the primary importance of the strictest safety standards. So Americans may take some heart from this report, especially since it comes on the heels of the massive Columbia University-Audubon Society study that found no evidence of increased cancer rates attributable to the 1979 accident at the Three Mile Island nuclear plant. --- Oct. 8 The Charlotte (N.C.) Observer on cigarette ads: When Surgeon General Antonia Novello said ... the tobacco industry must stop its ``death dealing'' to women and children, tobacco industry officials huffily said she was wrong to try to keep cigarette ads away from women. ... But the tobacco industry does not target its ads to women like Antonia Novello. Many cigarette ads are aimed at young, relatively uneducated women - the women most likely to make uninformed decisions about smoking and a group still of child-bearing age. Lung cancer now kills more women than any other type of cancer. Although health officials say cigarette smoking is harmful to the fetus, about 25 percent of the nation's pregnant women smoke throughout their pregnancies. That smoking causes 4,000 babies to be born dead each year, the surgeon general said. ... People do have the right to decide for themselves whether they want to smoke cigarettes, but tobacco companies behave like pushers when they try to exploit the least informed. ---
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Democrats Delay Action After Bush Flip-Flops on Tax Package
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 3 grafs after 7th graf pvs `Dole denied ...' to UPDATE with administration portrayal. Picks up 8th graf pvs `Other Republicans ...'
DOC.TEXT: Democrats delayed Senate Finance Committee consideration of a deficit-reduction plan today after President Bush backed away from his endorsement of higher taxes on the rich to pay for a cut in taxes on capital gains. ``In view of the apparent reversal of position by the president last evening, we will now have to reconsider what the appropriate course of action will be,'' Senate Majority Leader George J. Mitchell told reporters. ``It's obviously a difficult circumstance for all concerned,'' Mitchell said. The Finance Committee postponed a morning session scheduled to begin work on a plan that was to have included the capital-gains cut long favored by Bush. To meet Democratic demands, the plan also included higher income tax rates on the wealthy, who would benefit most from the capital-gains reduction. ``We thought until last night that the ... (Finance Committee plan) would be acceptable,'' Mitchell said. Senate Republican Leader Bob Dole said in a Senate speech that news organizations are unfairly portraying Republicans as favoring the rich. ``Some Democrats are now trying to force us to take capital gains in order to get more money (to spend) by raising tax rates,'' Dole said. Dole denied that Bush had made any decision Tuesday to drop support of a deal that would include capital gains and higher rates. ``He listened to us,'' Dole said, referring to a group of Republican senators. ``He didn't announce his position at all. He didn't acquiesce in what we said.'' But a senior administration official who briefed reporters after the meeting portrayed it differently. The members of Congress, the official said, told Bush that he wasn't going to get the kind of capital gains he wants, meaning Congress would not accept a cut in the capital gains tax that would be low enough to satisfy Bush and would insist on unacceptable increases in taxes on the rich. ``The conclusion was to forget all of it,'' said the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``He said, `Fine, we don't need either one of them.''' Other Republicans who attended the session gave yet another slant. ``Our uniform position was that we will not go up on the rates, no matter what,'' Sen. Bob Packwood of Oregon said after he and other GOP lawmakers met with Bush on Tuesday. The president agreed with that consensus, added Packwood, the senior Republican on the Senate Finance Committee. ``Stop trying to buy us off with capital gains,'' Sen. Ted Stevens, R-Alaska, cautioned Democrats. The presidential flip-flop - only a few hours after he publicly said that higher rates on the wealthy would be fine in exchange for a capital gains cut - clouded attempts to write a $500 billion deficit-reduction plan. Packwood announced Bush's turnabout, which was confirmed by senior administration officials, at about the time Congress' two top tax-writers were signaling they were ready to accept the capital gains bargain as part of a deficit agreement. Under terms of a stopgap spending bill that Bush signed Tuesday, Congress has until Oct. 19 to agree on a deficit plan. Tax-writing committees in the House and Senate are considering packages that include increased taxes on gasoline, tobacco and alcohol, a capital gains cut and higher taxes on the rich. Republican senators apparently convinced the president that the capital gains cut offered by Sen. Lloyd Bentsen, D-Texas, was not good enough to justify the upper-income tax rate increase that Bentsen wanted. Bush's demand to cut taxes on capital gains - the profits from the sale of investments - has been a bone of contention with Congress since the 1988 presidential campaign. The president says the reduction is necessary to stimulate investment and create jobs. Democratic leaders have resisted by arguing there is no evidence the economy would benefit and by hammering away at the fact that 80 percent of the tax cut would go to those with incomes over $100,000 a year. At a news conference Tuesday morning, Bush said for the first time that he could accept higher tax rates on the rich to win a capital gains reduction. Several Republican lawmakers then arranged a meeting with the president, and ``we all put up our hands and said, `No deal on rates at all,''' Packwood recounted. ``He just acquiesced in it.'' Bush asked the GOP lawmakers if they would hold fast to such a position, Packwood said. ``And to the man, in the room, every single person said we will support that.'' Capital gains are fully taxed at the same rates that apply to wages and other income - 15 percent, 28 percent and 33 percent. Bentsen's proposal would result in a top rate of 23.1 percent on capital gains realized by the wealthiest Americans. In return, the plan would require those highest-income people to pay a top tax rate of 33 percent, up from the present 28 percent. The plan also would raise a special levy called the alternative minimum tax, which is designed to ensure that high-income people pay a fair amount of tax regardless of how many legitimate deductions they have. The quick shift of positions by the president and lawmakers from both parties highlighted the difficulty of giving a special tax break to one group and trying to pay for it by changing another tax provision. In this case, the problem arises from the fact that fewer than half of the nation's wealthiest people reported any capital gains on tax returns filed last year. As congressional budget negotiators resumed work on the deficit-reduction plan Tuesday, lawmakers predicted that a two-penny tax on home heating oil and a delay in unemployment benefits - both of which drew widespread objections to the earlier proposal - are likely to be dropped. The impact on Medicare recipients likely will be cushioned, lawmakers said, but taxes on gasoline, tobacco and alcohol almost certainly will rise under the new $500 billion plan.

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: least informed.
DOC.TEXT: Oct. 4 The Arizona Republic, Phoenix, on the Persian Gulf: Predicting the future is a job best left to prophets and gypsy fortune-tellers. It is a risky business in any circumstance, and is even more so in the Byzantine world of the Middle East. All sorts of fanciful scenarios are being concocted by so-called ``military analysts'' as to how a U.S.-Iraq battle would unfold. They all end with the U.S. winning a decisive victory with minimal loss of life. The scenarios are all very neat. The good guys win and the bad guys lose. But, of all human activities, war is perhaps the least predictable. There never was a war that conformed to expectations. If war breaks out in Kuwait, this much is certain: it will develop in directions that are utterly unpredictable. It will not be neat or surgical or sanitary. It will be what war has always been: ugly and vicious and more deadly than anyone can imagine. No one should be fooled by the glitzy video-game scenarios being spun by armchair generals and sunshine soldiers. War in the Persian Gulf would not be a Tom Clancy novel or a Clint Eastwood movie. William Tecumseh Sherman said ``War is hell'' because that is precisely what it is. --- Oct. 5 The State, Columbia, S.C., on linking Israel to the Persian Gulf: When world leaders go upon a world stage such as the U. N. General Assembly, they do not as a rule, speak lightly or intentionally misspeak. As he joined the parade of presidents and potentates who kicked off the current session of the world body's General Assembly, George Bush quite naturally concentrated on Iraq's Aug. 2 takeover of Kuwait and its subsequent refusal to leave, even though much of the world, operating largely with U.N. sanction, has made it absolutely clear that the Iraqi action is totally unacceptable conduct that must be reversed. During his address, President Bush made this observation: ``In the aftermath of Iraq's unconditional departure from Kuwait, I truly believe there may be differences permanently, for the states of the (Persian) Gulf themselves to build new arrangements for stability and for all the states and peoples of the region to settle the conflict that divides the Arabs from Israel.'' Earlier at the United Nations, French President Francois Mitterand said if Iraq would ``declare its determination to withdraw from Kuwait and free the hostages ... all things might be possible.'' That got a rise out of Iraqi despot Saddam Hussein, who has been demanding that the Arab-Israeli dispute and the complex Lebanon question be put on the table with the kidnapping and rape of Kuwait. It does sound like both ... Bush and ... Mitterand might be willing to make such a linkage one day, and that surely sends shivers down the spine of Israel. The Arab-Israeli set-to is 42 years old, and the Israeli occupation of Arab territories populated by Palestinians goes back to the 1967 Six-Day War. The civil war in Lebanon that has led to partial occupation by Syria dates back to the mid-1970s. Those issues have defied solution despite endless efforts, and Israel's security concerns are bound up in both. The rape of Kuwait is a matter of the moment, an international crime of a most egregious variety that demands solution right now. It was a mistake to link these matters, even with the ambiguous words of diplomacy used by the French and American presidents. --- Oct. 8 Argus Leader, Sioux Falls, S.D., on the purpose of textbooks: For three years, small bands of critics across the United States have been attacking the textbook series ``Impressions.'' ... The books are interesting and colorfully illustrated, and they challenge students. Tey are a big improvement from the days of Dick, Jane and Spot and boring reading programs. ``Impressions'' appears far more likely than older books to encourage pupils to learn to read and think. The intent does not appear to be instilling negative values, as some critics might have you believe. Critics cite passages they claim promote witchcraft, mysticism and other evils. ... Yes, there is fantasy, even tales that could be interpreted as rebellious or violent. But children's literature has dealt with such subjects for generations in, for example, ``Little Red Riding Hood'' and ``Huckleberry Finn.'' ... Textbooks should not instill values; that's the responsibility of parents and churches. Textbooks should instill a sense of wonder and curiosity. ``Impressions'' has the potential to do that job well. --- Oct. 5 The Meridian (Miss.) Star on education in Japan: The Japanese ... feel they have much to learn from the American education system, but in view of the much-heralded performance of Japanese students, what can we learn from them? The cultural diversity that is one of our strengths also presents challenges to American educators that the Japanese don't have to worry about. Secondly, Japan has no American-style tradition of individualism. The individual is subordinate to the group in Japanese culture, which makes group learning easier. There are other qualities of Japanese culture we could learn from. Foremost is the absolute priority that is placed on education. Japanese children go to school more hours a week and many more days a year than U.S. children. Japanese teachers are paid on the average 60 percent higher than U.S. teachers. Honor the profession in tangible ways and it will attract bright and committed people. Ingrained in Japanese parents is the principle that education matters more than anything else for their children. Family-imposed standards of educational discipline, as well as heavy parental involvement in schools, are the norm. Widespread emulation of that aspect of Japanese culture would probably do more than anything else to improve U.S. student performance. ---
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: student performance.
DOC.TEXT: Oct. 5 The Record, Hackensack, N.J., on U.S. military aid to El Salvador: President Alfredo Christiani of El Salvador did his best to convince on-the-fence members of Congress recently that he is indeed calling the shots in his war-torn country, and that progress is being made in the case of the murder of six Jesuit priests last year. Fortunately, it looks like no one was fooled. ... Cristiani was hoping to convince the lawmakers to reject a measure that would cut military aid to El Salvador in half.
