Since the civil war began, the United States has sent El Salvador more than $4.5 billion in military and economic aid. Yet the war continues to drag on. More than 73,000 people have died. And the military has been as brazen as ever. There must be a better way. --- Oct. 5 The Milwaukee Journal on female sportswriters: A female reporter, Denise Tom, was denied access to the Cincinnati Bengals' locker room by coach Sam Wyche after a Monday night game in Seattle. This episode came amidst a furor over a complaint by Lisa Olson, a Boston sports reporter, that several naked New England Patriots surrounded her in the team locker room Sept. 17 and made lewd comments to her while she was conducting interviews. Let it be understood that reporters - male or female - do not go into locker rooms because they want to, but because that is their job. Postgame interviews with players and coaches are necessary to the reporters' stories. But some athletes seem to treat locker rooms as personal playpens. Their immaturity perhaps is understandable, maybe inevitable. Management pays them millions; groupies and other fans lionize them; agents pamper them. They spend much of their lives shielded from responsibility. They need a spanking, in the form of a major fine or suspension, or both. An athlete who exposes himself is guilty not only of childish behavior, but possibly of an illegality as well. As for Wyche, his excuse that he didn't want a woman in a locker room full of naked men is beside the point. Can't a quarterback or linebacker put on a towel or a bathrobe for a few minutes and be interviewed before heading into the shower room? Can't a room be set aside for post-game interviews? No one expects an athlete, physically and mentally exhausted after a tough game, to show impeccable manners while being peppered with sometimes tough questions. But no one is demanding perfect behavior, just common courtesy. If athletes and coaches aren't capable of that, then they aren't entitled to call themselves professionals, and they shouldn't be in the NFL with the real men. --- Oct. 9 Financial Times, London, on the U.S. budget and economy: U.S. budget-making has become a lamentable shambles. Nine months of negotiation ended in rejection by the Congress last Friday. True, the proposed $40 billion package of tax increases and spending cuts was little more than a token gesture. But it was better than nothing. Even so a hint of higher taxes and reduced entitlements were too much for nervous congressmen to countenance in the run-up to November's elections. ... The United States may be moving into an era of disappointingly slow increases in living standards and unpredictable exchange rate crises. The unprecedented decline of the value of the dollar during a major international crisis is thus a harbinger of instability to come. Higher national savings are essential if this difficult period is to be short-lived, a goal to which the elimination of the structural budget deficit would make a valuable contribution. This is a vicious circle: voters expect little of politicians and politicians respond to their cynicism by confirming it. If no one can break the circle, the voters themselves will pay the price. --- Oct. 5 The Bangkok (Thailand) Post on the reunification of Germany: There is one Germany again and it seems like the world will be a better place for it. ... The vows of the German leaders to stay a nation at peace sound more sincere and believable than those of earlier this century. A world which fought two world wars against the European power has decided to give the German people a chance once again to decide and direct their destiny. And quite rightly so. Sins of the fathers may not properly be avenged upon the sons and daughters. The Germany of today is so far different from that of the past that the field marshals and Hitler are no doubt spinning in their unmarked graves. It is affluent, independent and its people are dedicated far more to democracy than to proving German superiority. ... Naturally there are some voices of trepidation among the congratulations. ... But the lessons of history are for learning not for enduring. ... The evidence of the past 45 years indicates that Germans learned these lessons. Despite the terrors of those two wars and the memories of some, the true ``danger'' is not of a resurgence of Hitlerian stupidity. It is like the ``danger'' of Japan, the enormous economic power of a vital hard-working nation fuelled by a committed work force. ... The world will be watching to see how much added responsibility Germany is willing to shoulder as the price of its unity. The first test comes quickly. European economic unity comes in 1992, and Germany must move fast even before that event, to show its neighbors and the rest of the world that it will assume intelligent responsibility as a price for its economic dominance of Europe. ... Much of the world already views European unity as a license to protectionism. Germany would do well to help ease those fears, and the sooner the better. ---
DOC.HEAD: End Editorial Roundup

DOC.BYLINE: German Economy Will Continue to Boom, Despite Unification Costs ^By KEVIN COSTELLOE
DOC.TEXT: The German economy will keep picking up steam as industrial growth slows in other leading nations, the country's central bank chief said Wednesday. However, Bundesbank president Karl Otto Poehl acknowledged the Persian Gulf crisis and the costs of unification present formidable challenges for the economic powerhouse. During a speech Wednesday, Poehl outlined how the recently united country of nearly 78 million people has become ``the locomotive of growth for the world economy.'' ``And this role will be further strengthened,'' Poehl added during his speech to international banking supervisors from about 100 nations. He said economic expansion in Germany, which has Europe's strongest industrial base, comes during ``a situation of clearly weakening growth in a whole series of important industrialized nations.'' Poehl did not name any other countries during his speech in Frankfurt's St. Paul's Church. The area of what was once West Germany is expected to have a 3.9 percent growth in its gross national product this year, the same as last year. Reliable figures for the ravaged economy in the former East Germany are not available. By way of comparison, the United States expects a growth rate of only 1.3 percent this year, leading to fears of a recession. Last year's growth rate was 2.5 percent. West Germany's growth rate last year was 2.2 trillion marks ($1.4 trillion at current rates), trailing only the United States and Japan. Also last year, the West German trade surplus was 140 billion marks ($90 billion at current rates), the highest in the world. Poehl sounded several notes of caution Wednesday, including the enormous expense involved in bringing East Germany's industry up to Westernstandards. Those expenses will add to the national debt, according to Poehl. Poehl said the gulf crisis, which is driving up oil costs, presents another challenge, but added that inflation in Germany would stay below 3 percent this year. Germans remain extremely wary of inflation, mindful that skyrocketing prices and the resulting instability led to the rise of Adolf Hitler's Third Reich. Inflationary dangers led West German officials in the late 1980s to resist U.S. calls to become the world's economic engine, the very role that Poehl has established for the merged nation. Also in the late 1980s, officials in Bonn worried that overly rapid growth would undercut the strength of the West German mark. Germany, formally united last week, faces other economic challenges beyond the gulf crisis and keeping inflation at bay. Foreigners have shown a reluctance to invest in what was East Germany, where problems of land ownership and bloated work forces have compounded ordinary risks. In addition, many of the businesses are literally falling apart. Nearly 450,000 workers in what was East Germany are out of jobs and another 1.8 million put in short hours in what amount to make-work jobs. Chancellor Helmut Kohl has said the need to keep the German mark stable and strong will curb financial outlays to rebuild the economy in the East. Elmar Pieroth, an economics expert from Kohl's Christian Democratic Union, says it may take $775 billion in private investment and public financing over the next five years.

DOC.HEAD: Bhutto Says Arrest of Husband Meant to Force Her From Race
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Police arrested the husband of Benazir Bhutto on kidnapping charges Wednesday, and the ousted prime minister called the arrest another effort by the army-backed government to force her from politics. Asif Ali Zardari had been expected to be the main target of the corruption investigations against Ms. Bhutto's government, which was ousted in August after just 20 months in power. Police arrested Zardari for kidnapping a Pakistani-born British citizen and extorting $800,000 from him. He was taken into custody and charged with kidnapping and extortion. At a news conference later Wednesday at her home, Ms. Bhutto said she ``will not be intimiated and blackmailed by these gutter politicians.'' ``A few days ago, a federal minister in the caretaker government came to see me and told me that I should not contest the (Oct. 24 parliamentary) election. If I did, then I would be disqualified and Asif imprisoned,'' Ms. Bhutto said. Zardari was charged in the April kidnapping of businessman Murtaza Hussain Bukhari of England. Zardari was taken for interrogation to the Federal Investigation Agency, which is comparable to the FBI. Authorities said he would not be able to apply for bail until Thursday. ``I fear for his safety and his life,'' Ms. Bhutto told reporters. ``I knew they would do something ... I had warned Asif. He told me to be brave and continue the struggle.'' When Bukhari reported the alleged abduction to police and the British Embassy in Islamabad, he implicated Zardari. He also sent letters detailing the alleged events to Ms. Bhutto and to President Ghulam Ishaq Khan. Both Zardari and Ms. Bhutto contend the case was fabricated. Ms. Bhutto wed Zardari in a highly publicized arranged marriage in December 1987, exactly a year before she became the first woman leader of a modern Moslem nation. They have a 2-year-old son and a 9-month-old daughter. The president dismissed her government Aug. 6, accusing officials of corruption, incompetence and abuse of power. Supporters and critics alike have blamed Zardari for Ms. Bhutto's downfall. Zardari, an avid polo player with a jet-setter reputation, has been accused by the Pakistani media and the army-backed caretaker government of demanding commissions of lucrative government contracts and using the state-owned banks as his personal fund, ordering huge loans for friends with little or no collateral and putting the institutions on the verge of bankruptcy. He has vehemently denied the allegations, which earned him the nickname ``Mr. 10 Percent.'' Ms. Bhutto is being tried by special one-judge tribunals in Lahore and Karachi on four charges of misconduct and abuse of power. She has called the charges a political vendetta aimed at discrediting her left-leaning Pakistan People's Party and forcing her to quit politics.

DOC.NOTE: EDs: Members who used a0698, AM-Defense Spending transmitted Oct. 9 under a Washington dateline, are asked to use the following story.
DOC.TEXT: The Associated Press erroneously reported on Tuesday that the defense bill approved by the House Appropriations Committee totaled $297 billion. The correct figure is $268 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Fad Bracelet Toy Banned From Schools As Potentially Dangerous
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS new 4th graf, `In Connecticut ...' and ADDS 3 grafs at end with Walgreens' Connecticut stores pulling slap bracelets from 16 stores.
DOC.TEXT: Slap bracelets may be a new fashion necessity for chic children but they won't be seen in elementary schools here since educators decided the fabric-covered steel ornaments are dangerous. The 9-inch bracelets come in wild patterns and bright colors. They coil around the wrist when slapped against it. If the fabric covering comes off, the sharp steel edge could cut hands and arms, says Joseph Longobardi, principal of the Colonial and Siwanoy elementary schools. He ordered the ban last week. Principals at the two other grade schools in this New York City suburb said they will announce a ban in their school newsletters. ``I have four kids of my own,'' Longobardi said. ``I know how popular these things are. ... But the possibility of injury does exist because of that sharp cutting edge.'' In Connecticut, Walgreens pulled slap bracelets from the shelves of 16 stores Tuesday after a 4-year-old girl was reportedly cut by one. Gene Murtha, president of Main Street Toy of Simsbury, Conn., which makes ``The Original Slap Wrap'' and sells it for $2.49, said his product causes no injuries. The culprits, he said, are cheap imitations made in Taiwan and sold illegally in this country for as little as 99 cents. ``The metal is inferior, low-grade caliber steel with poor quality fabric,'' he said of the knockoffs. ``The sealing is also inferior. The steel can either break through or snap through and cause injury.'' His product, which took a year to develop, is made of high-grade steel with rounded edges and covered by double-knit fabric that is tightly sealed, he said. ``We haven't had any consumer complaints,'' he said. Longobardi said he banned the toy after hearing of an injury in the West Orchard Elementary School in Chappaqua. Officials there said an elementary school student who had removed the material covering needed three stitches on her hand after she was cut by an exposed bracelet edge. Main Street Toy has shipped nearly 1 million of ``The Original Slap Wraps'' since the fad started this summer. The company is now shipping about 200,000 of the toys each week. A parent's call to Walgreens in Wallingford, Conn., prompted the district manager to order bracelets that were foreign copies of the Slap Wrap pulled from all Connecticut stores, said Maryellen Thielen, corporate spokeswoman for Walgreens in Deerfield, Ill. ``We're an extremely conservative company and we do react. Simply as a precaution, we did remove them from the shelves,'' she said. Nicole Tomaso cut her finger two hours after picking out her 99-cent bracelet at Walgreens, according to Joseph Tomaso, her father. Tomaso said the metal protruded from the bracelet's sewn end.

DOC.HEAD: Klaus Gone, But Tropical Storm Marco Forms off the Keys
DOC.TEXT: Florida faced whipping winds, possible lowland flooding and up to 3 inches of rain today as a new tropical storm formed off the Keys, replacing Tropical Storm Klaus. Marco, the 13th named tropical storm of the Atlantic hurricane season that runs from June 1 to Nov. 30., formed west of Key West early today, the National Hurricane Center said. A tropical storm watch was in effect in the Florida Keys from Dry Tortugas to Key Largo and for the southwest Florida coast from Key Largo northward to Longboat Key. Small craft in the area were warned to stay in port. A coastal flood warning remained in effect for all the Florida Keys, and along Florida's Atlantic coast from Daytona Beach to Jupiter Inlet. A coastal flood watch also was in effect for the rest of Florida's east coast and the Georgia coast, the National Weather Service reported. ``You're going to continue to have strong, gusty winds,'' said Martin Nelson, a meteorologist with the hurricane center in suburban Coral Gables. ``But the center (of Marco) is forecast to stay out over the Gulf of Mexico and turn more to the north within the next day.'' Marco was expected to gain strength over the next 24 hours, ``but we're not forecasting it to become a hurricane,'' he said. At noon EDT, Marco was centered 180 miles south of Tampa, the hurricane center said. Marco had top sustained winds of 40 mph and was headed northwest at near 12 mph. Marco formed less than a day after Tropical Storm Klaus petered out over Cuba, leaving behind heavy rains and high seas. Klaus left six dead and more than 1,500 homeless on the island of Martinique on its trek through the Caribbean.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Pop impresario George Martin said Wednesday the Beatles might not have become superstars had they started out in the 1990s. He was speaking after presenting the John Lennon songwriting awards to three students at Salford College of Technology near Manchester, the day after what would have been Lennon's 50th birthday. ``John was not all that keen on education,'' said Martin, who was Lennon's producer. ``If he had been around now I don't think the Beatles would have broken through.'' Martin described Lennon as ``a rebel who did not want to be bothered with small details like music and reading and writing. He wanted to get down to the real nub of things.'' ``John could not read or write music and I think if he had tried to get this award in 1990 he would not have stood a chance.'' --- NASHVILLE, Tenn. (AP) - Singer-songwriter Paul Overstreet has been named country music songwriter of the year by Broadcast Music Inc. for the fourth straight year. His compositions during the year included ``Houston Solution,'' ``My Arms Stay Open All Night,'' ``All the Fun,'' ``Love Helps Those'' and ``Sowin' Love.'' ``Houston Solution'' was recorded by Ronnie Milsap and ``My Arms Stay Open All Night'' was a hit by Tanya Tucker. Overstreet himself recorded the latter three songs. ``Lots of good things have happened,'' he said Tuesday at the annual BMI awards dinner. BMI licenses music and collects royalties for songwriters. Don Everly, one-half of the Everly Brothers rock 'n' roll duo, was honored for writing ``Cathy's Clown,'' which was the most performed BMI country song of the year. The 1960 song was redone last year by Reba McEntire. --- LONDON (AP) - Princess Anne flew to New York on Wednesday to meet with United Nations Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar. The princess, president of the Save the Children charity, will discuss the outcome of last month's U.N. World Summit for Children with de Cuellar on Thursday. Anne will then make official visits to Barbados on Oct. 12-13, Trinidad on Oct. 14-17, and Jamaica on Oct. 17-19 to inspect Save the Children projects. --- LOS ANGELES (AP) - Former NBC-TV chief Grant Tinker says television has lost its magic and most people simply regard it as furniture. ``There is nothing wrong with (television) particularly. There is too much of it. Maybe that is part of what's wrong with it,'' Tinker said in an interview for Thursday's syndicated show ``Personalities.'' ``There are so many viewing alternatives that there just aren't enough creative people to supply the software just to feed the hardware,'' Tinker said. ``I also think we are now living among people who mostly have never been without television and for whom it is furniture. ``When I was a kid and television arrived, it was magic.'' Tinker, a TV producer whose company gave viewers ``The Mary Tyler Moore Show,'' ``Lou Grant'' and ``St. Elsewhere,'' is working on a CBS-TV dramatic series called ``WIOU.'' He was the NBC programming chief from 1981 to 1986. ---
DOC.NOTE: Eds: A longer version moved on the sports wire.
DOC.TEXT: New York Yankees outfielder Mel Hall is due in court Oct. 30 on charges of possessing a potentially dangerous animal - two cougar cubs - and importing a wild animal without a permit. State officials acting on an anonymous tip seized the cubs from Hall's suburban home in July. Hall was arrested Saturday and given the court date in Bridgeport Superior Court, said Sgt. Thomas Daniels of the state Department of Environmental Protection's Law Enforcement Bureau. The year-old male and female cougars were taken to a West Hartford children's museum, where they were reported in good condition and gaining weight. Adult cougars, also known as pumas or mountain lions, grow to 8 feet long from nose to tip of tail. The cubs had been bred in captivity in Florida. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Financial reporter Dan Dorfman is leaving CNN to join CNBC, and Fortune magazine editor Marshall Loeb will join Financial News Network as a commentator, the two cable networks said Monday. Both will start their new jobs on Oct. 15. Loeb, who previously did financial commentary for the CBS Radio Network, will continue at Fortune. In his new FNN job, he will do a daily 60-second commentary called ``Managing Today.'' Dorfman, who will continue a twice-weekly financial column for USA Today newspaper, signed a multiyear contract to report for CNBC, a 24-hour consumer and business news cable service co-owned by NBC.

DOC.HEAD: Former Communist Politburo Accused of Corruption Cover-Up
DOC.TEXT: The top body of Poland's former Communist government learned of a theft and corruption ring in the security service in 1984 but suspended a criminal investigation, the government said Wednesday. Interior Minister Krzysztof Kozlowski, a former Roman Catholic journalist who took over the law enforcement department in July, said there was no proof of individual guilt in the apparent cover-up, but investigations continue. At that time, President Wojciech Jaruzelski was the head of the then-ruling body, the Communist Party Politburo. The disclosures came at a rare news conference held by top Interior Ministry officials. Most Communist officials have left the agency in the year since the non-Communist Solidarity government took power. Former Interior Minister Miroslaw Milewski and six former associates were arrested Saturday on charges they were involved in the corruption ring. Milewski, a hard-liner, was a Communist Party Politburo member and Central Committee secretary in charge of internal affairs in the early 1980s. The case will be the first major prosecution of a Communist official by the country's new authorities. Also Saturday, two former police generals were arrested on charges of directing the murder of the Rev. Jerzy Popieluszko, a pro-Solidarity priest beaten and drowned by secret police in October 1984. The Milewski case, code-named The Iron Affair, involved people of Polish origin establishing companies in the West, said Andrzej Milczanowski, chief of the State Protection Office. Through insurance fraud, break-ins and thefts carried out in the unidentified Western countries, the companies accumulated gold, precious stones, jewelery and other valuables that would be shipped back to Poland by intelligence agents, he said. Milczanowski said the crimes began in 1968. At a minimum the perpetrators gathered 143 pounds of gold, he said. That would be about 2,090 troy ounces, worth $820,000 at today's prices. Milewski was accused of accepting gold and jewelry stolen by the ring. The arrest of Milewski and his associates, whose names have not been disclosed, stems from a 1984 investigation into the affair by an internal Interior Ministry commission, Milczanowski said. The commission assembled a report of several dozen pages and said the case should be prosecuted, he said. However, the country's then ``highest decision-making body'' decided to suspend the case, and no further action was taken. Milewski soon retired. Kozlowski said the suspension of criminal proceedings was a decision of the Communist Party politburo, but that there was no evidence to link any individual with a cover-up. ``Those involved, people who were under very serious accusations, received party reprimands and ... Milewski ended his political career a few months later,'' Kozlowski said. Jaruzelski, who is due to step down in December after the country's first popular presidential vote, headed the Politburo from 1981 until assuming the presidency in July 1989. Milczanowski said he was not at liberty to release the names of the others arrested with Milewski without the prosecutor general's permission. However, he said, no one from current political life was recommended for prosecution.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Releases Text of Settlement Assurances
With AM-Israel, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III on Wednesday released assurances from Israel that it would not settle Soviet Jewish refugees on land won in the 1967 Mideast war. The assurances were in a letter Baker worked out with Israeli Foreign Minister David Levy to end weeks of negotiations between the two governments over a $400 million U.S. housing loan guarantee. Baker, in announcing the agreement he had reached with Levy, said last Week that the foreign minister had offered assurances ``considerably beyond'' Israel's longstanding commitment not to use the U.S.-backed loans to house Soviet Jews in the territories. But the letter did not appear to break new ground, and Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir said Sunday that the assurances did not cover Jerusalem. He announced, meanwhile, that a new Jewish neighborhood will be built in the part of the city Jordan held from 1948 until 1967 and termed by President Bush as ``occupied territory.'' The Bush administration considers settlement of Soviet refugees or any other Jews on the West Bank, in Gaza and in East Jerusalem to be an obstacle to peace. The administration supports the Arab demand that most or all of the territory be relinquished by Israel. Shamir has offered to negotiate the territory's future after five years of limited self-rule by the Palestinian Arabs who make up most of the population of the West Bank and Gaza. But he does not consider the capital to be occupied territory and said Sunday that ``Jerusalem is an integral part of Israel, and the building of the city will continue unhampered.'' A strong Jewish presence on the West Bank and in Gaza could make surrender of the land more difficult. However, former Israeli Prime Minister Menachem Begin agreed in 1978 to the elimination of all Jewish settlements in Sinai as part of a peace treaty with Egypt. Levy in the letter states ``the government of Israel's policy is not to direct or settle Soviet Jews beyond the green line,'' which delineates the boundaries of Israel before the 1967 war. The foreign minister does not specifically mention East Jerusalem, which was not part of Israel before the war. The two other main assurances: -The housing loan guarantees will be restricted to the geographic areas administered by Israel before the war. -No special incentives are given to encourage Soviet Jews to settle in territories captured during the war. The State Department spokeswoman, Margaret D. Tutwiler, said Tuesday that Baker and Levy had agreed in their negotiations that the letter would be made public. She declined to take questions Wednesday on the contents. About 90,000 Jews now live among the 1.5 million Arabs on the West Bank and in Gaza. Only a tiny percentage, 1 to 2 percent, of Soviet Jewish refugees are among them.

DOC.HEAD: Minnie The Cow Mooooves to Disney World
LaserPhoto SI1
DOC.TEXT: Minnie the Cow is trading her quiet southwestern Minnesota barnyard for stardom at Walt Disney World, all because she was born with markings that resemble a certain famous rodent. ``The whole thing is nothing but foolishness - a cow with Mickey Mouse on the side,'' said owner Melvin Brockberg, 65. ``She's going to live the luxurious life,'' said Brockberg, who has owned the cow with his wife, Dorothy, and son Bill. ``I understand she'll be visited by 30,000 plus people a day.'' Minnie leaves Sunday for the Orlando, Fla., amusement park. Disney World spokeswoman Jenne Hess said the cow will be among the featured animals at the park's petting zoo. Minnie is a Holstein whose big black markings on her otherwise all-white left side resemble Mickey Mouse's head and ears. Two years ago, Melvin and Dorothy Brockberg's niece, Jody Kline of Minneapolis, started a letter-writing campaign and sent pictures of Minnie to both Disney World and Disneyland in Anaheim, Calif. Last month, Disney World officials contacted Kline about buying Minnie. Brockberg would say only the family got a good deal. The markings on Minnie, now 4 years old, were visible at birth. ``That was just one of those things that happens - a phenomenon,'' said Brockberg. ``I've seen thousands of cows in my live - that's the only one I've seen like that.'' The markings have always proved lucky for Minnie. ``She's not a top producer'' of milk, Brockberg said. ``At different times we've talked about hauling her off to market, but she'd turn around and we see the spots. The spots saved her.''

DOC.HEAD: University Wants to Burn Radioactive Dog Carcasses
DOC.TEXT: For years, University of Iowa researchers have injected hundreds of dogs with radioactive isotopes in the quest to improve human health. Now it's time to dispose of the carcasses because storage capacity is full. A plan to use a refurbished, 25-year-old incinerator to burn 900 barrels of the slightly radioactive carcasses has angered environmental groups. They want a public hearing to assess the risks that may be associated with spewing radioactive ash into the Iowa countryside. ``It is the best way right now to do this. We can't think of a better, safer way to do it,'' said William Twaler. He is director of the university's Health Protection Office and will oversee the incineration. ``We anticipate most of the radioactive material will stay in the ash, probably about 85 percent and maybe even 100 percent. It's not very precise,'' said Twaler. ``We don't anticipate the majority of it going up the smoke stack in the first place. ... But if you're asking me if there's a zero percent risk, I'd have to say I don't know.'' Environmental Advocates and Iowans for Animal Rights want a hearing before any of the more than 1,000 carcasses are incinerated. Their request in a letter Sept. 28 to university president Hunter Rawlings has gone unanswered. ``Our main concern is that the public is not involved in the whole process. There's been no public discussion about the operation. We have questions about the ash disposal, how radioactive will this ash be?'' said Joe Bolkcom of Iowa City, a spokesman for Environmental Advocates. Twaler said he has had no word from university officials about a hearing and plans to start incinerating about eight barrels a day later this week on the Oakdale campus, a few miles northwest of the downtown campus. He would not give the exact ay, saying he feared protests. The state-run university has received the necessary permits to operate the incinerator from the Iowa Department of Health and the Iowa Department of Natural Resources. Paul Connett, professor of chemistry at St. Lawrence University in Canton, N.Y., and author of a weekly newsletter called, ``Waste Not,'' said he fears any radioactive ash released from the incinerator would enter the food chain, settling on plants fed to cows and contaminating their milk. He was in Iowa City last weekend for a medical waste management conference. ``It's a stupid idea. It never ceases to amaze me how incinerator advocates resemble the Medieval alchemists in their ideas that you could somehow burn something and make it disappear,'' said Brian Lipsett, a research analyst for the Citizens Clearinghouse for Hazardous Waste in Arlington, Va. ``Radioactive materials aren't destroyed by incineration and in fact will be dispersed throughout the community,'' Lipsett said. Paul Cooper, university veterinarian in charge of animal care, said live dogs were injected with tiny pellets, or microspheres, containing low-level radioactive materials. The microspheres are primarily used as tracers in the dogs' blood streams for cardiovascular research designed to improve human health, he said. After the dogs died, the school planned to store their carcasses until the radioactive isotopes decayed in non-radioactive elements, in about three years. However, researchers have begun using new isotopes that take longer to decay and the university is out of storage space. ``The quantity of the radioactive material is very, very low to begin with,'' said Don Flater, chief of the radiological bureau of the Iowa Health Department. ``Nature has already taken its course. Most of the radioactive isotopes have decayed and are mostly gone.'' A better alternative to incineration would be burying the barrels, but Flater said that is illegal in Iowa. The university could avoid the controversy by shipping the carcasses to one of the nation's three radioactive waste dumps, in Washington state, Nevada or South Carolina, Twaler said. ``That would be cost prohibitive. It would be something like $1,000 per drum. That gets very expensive,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: World's Coastal Cities Face Catastrophic Flooding, Storms
DOC.TEXT: Miami is living on borrowed time, New Orleans' future looks bleak and the world's coastal cities face a growing risk of catastrophic storms and floods as sea levels rise from global warming, a report warned Wednesday. Global warming is projected to cause sea levels to rise 12 inches to more than 3 feet over the next century, according to scientists with the U.N. Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change. But even without global warming, many of the world's most beautiful and populous cities face an increasing threat of flooding, according to ``Cities at Risk,'' prepared by three scientists at the University of East Anglia. ``This report puts a whole lot of things together that have been done on an isolated or ad hoc basis,'' said Allen Miller, executive director for the Center for Global Change at the University of Maryland. About 500 million people around the world could be affected, according to the paper, which looked at the future of Miami, New Orleans, Alexandria, Bangkok, Dhaka, Hamburg, Leningrad, London, Shanghai, Sydney and Thessalonika. ``A variety of human activities are exacerbating existing problems and increasing the vulnerablity of cities to the future impact of global warming,'' said Dr. Mick Kelly, who wrote the report with Dr. R.K. Turner and R.C. Kay. Global warming, otherwise known as the greenhouse effect, occurs as rising levels of carbon dioxide and other pollutants trap the sun's heat in the atmosphere. Inappropriate development and ill-considered flood control programs contribute to the problems faced by coastal cities. In addition, land levels are sinking because of erosion or the extraction of underground water. Sea levels, meanwhile, are rising for reasons not fully understood. An increase of one degree has caused the oceans to expand, scientists say, while melting glaciers and possibly melting polar ice-caps have added to the problem. Miami faces both erosion and runaway development, much of which has taken place since the last major storm hit the city in 1966, the report said. Kelly said the city is overdue for a storm and the hazard will increase substantially in the future as global warming heats the oceans, which give energy to tropical storms. ``These people are living on borrowed time,'' Kelly said. ``Miami has to face not only the possiblity of natural hurricane activity, but also an increase due to global warming.'' The report notes that five of Miami's seven bridges to the mainland are subject to flooding. It suggests that Miami and other coastal cities pay more attention to emergency planning. Miami Beach, built on a barrier island-lagoon, is eroding. So is an estimated 90 percent of the sandy shoreline of the United States, the report said. Miami already has spent more than $68 million rebuilding the beach and more money will be needed to save the dozens of hotels and condominiums built on the ocean front, it said. New Orleans is suffering from construction of a different sort - a half century of flood control projects by the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers that have done more harm than good, the report said. Levees, reservoirs, floodgates and enlarged channels have been built to solve specific problems, but together they have exacerbated flooding. The levees killed the deltas by blocking the flow of mud that replaced soil washed away in the river. The projects helped destroy the salt marshes that serve as a buffer between the city and the sea. The marshes are dying at a rate of 40 square miles a year, according to Jim Titus of the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency. The report warned: ``Some parts of New Orleans are now nine meters (yards) below peak river flow. A disaster is waiting to happen.'' Bangladesh, meanwhile, is considering a $10 billion flood control system financed by the World Bank, which environmentalists fear could create more problems than it solves. ``There is a growing body of opinion that this sort of engineering offers only a short-term respite,'' Kelly said. ``Ultimately the thing we should be doing is limiting greenhouse gases. But in the short-term, we will need to improve our coastal defenses. And we need to start now.'' Basic protection of cities at greatest risk would cost more than $100 billion, while $500 billion may be required for coastal defense and flood protection works worldwide, the report said. The report was published by the Bureau of National Affairs International, a subsidiary of the Washington-based Bureau of National Affairs, Inc., a publisher of environmental, business and regulatory information.

DOC.HEAD: NASA `Elated' as Discovery Ends Flight in California
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 6-8, `The astronauts ...'' with 4 grafs to UPDATE with astronauts' departure, Richards' comment; picks up 9th graf pvs, `Six hours ...'; Denis and Valeri are cq.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto EAB1
With AM-Shuttle-What's Next
DOC.TEXT: Shuttle Discovery sailed out of orbit and landed Wednesday after a four-day flight that boosted NASA's confidence and sent a spacecraft on a five-year mission to explore the sun's poles. ``If you criticize our mistakes, then you must also acknowledge our successes,'' space shuttle director and former astronaut Robert Crippen said after completion of the first shuttle flight in nearly six months. ``I'm elated,'' he added. ``It's been a long hot summer, I'll tell you that. It's nice to be back flying again. It is a high day for us.'' About 5,500 spectators cheered as Discovery touched down at 6:57 a.m. PDT, just seconds before the sun rose over hills to the east. It was the third smallest crowd for any shuttle landing open to public viewing. ``Congratulations on a picture-perfect mission,'' Mission Control's Brian Duffy told the five astronauts. The astronauts stepped out of the shuttle into sunshine an hour after the landing. About four hours later, shuttle commander Dick Richards was given a small gold model of Ulysses. Then Richards, pilot Robert Cabana and mission specialists Bill Shepherd, Bruce Melnick and Tom Akers boarded two jets to take them home to Houston. Discovery's 1.7 million-mile flight was the first since April - the longest gap between shuttle missions since they resumed after the 1986 explosion that destroyed Challenger and killed seven crew members. The latest flight helped bolster morale at the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, which has been plagued by hydrogen fuel leaks in the shuttles Columbia and Atlantis and by a flawed mirror that severely impaired the $1.5 billion Hubble Space Telescope. ``Like any great team, occasionally there's losing streaks,'' Richards said before flying to Houston. ``Today is a day we can say this losing streak is over and we're going on to great things in the future.'' Six hours after they lifted off from Cape Canaveral, Fla., on Saturday, Discovery's astronauts deployed the Ulysses spacecraft on its 1.86-billion-mile mission to study the sun's high latitudes and poles. Ulysses ``seems to be working perfectly well,'' said Roger Bonnet, director of scientific programs for the European Space Agency, which operates the $250 million solar explorer in a joint mission with NASA. Bonnet praised the $750 million mission as ``a symbol of future cooperation between Europe and the United States.'' About an hour before touchdown, Discovery's twin braking rockets fired, allowing the shuttle to plunge out of orbit and dash through Earth's atmosphere. The shuttle's twin sonic booms cracked loudly, waking Santa Barbara and Ventura residents as Discovery crossed the coast and descended toward the 15,000-foot-long concrete runway 22 on Rogers Dry Lake in the Mojave Desert. ``I thought someone was rattling the walls in the next room,'' said Ventura County fire dispatcher Denis Miller. ``That's gorgeous!'' spectator Valeri Leahey, 29, of Camarillo, said as sunlight glistened off the descending shuttle. Discovery touched down on pavement so NASA could test its brakes - a test aimed at eventually having shuttles land at Cape Canaveral. Crippen said Discovery's brakes apparently performed well, only the second test for the new carbon brakes, but he won't decide until spring when to have shuttles land in Florida. Discovery sustained only a few ``dings'' to its heat-shielding tiles, he added. Ulysses was 3.1 million miles from Earth on Wednesday, speeding at 25,451 mph toward a February 1992 swing past Jupiter, said Don Meyer, NASA's operations manager for Ulysses at Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Pasadena. The spacecraft will use the solar system's largest planet as a ``gravity slingshot'' to become the first spacecraft to fly perpendicular to the plane in which the planets orbit the sun. That will allow Ulysses to pass over the sun's south pole in 1994 and north pole in 1995, gathering information about the sun, its magnetic field and the solar wind - all of which affect Earth's climate. Bonnet said Ulysses left Earth's orbit at a faster speed - about 34,000 mph - than any other spacecraft. But it will not become the fastest spacecraft ever until it reaches Jupiter, where it will accelerate to about 89,500 mph. Voyager 2 zoomed past the outer planets at speeds exceeding 80,000 mph. The next shuttle flight is scheduled for early November, when Atlantis will conduct a secret mission for the Pentagon. The flight had been scheduled for July, but was delayed by hydrogen leaks. In addition to deploying Ulysses, Discovery's astronauts tested a voice-activated camera system and started a small fire inside a sealed aluminum container so safety managers could observe how fire acts in the absence of gravity. They also extended Discovery's 50-foot-long robot arm to test the amount of decay on two pieces of material identical to that used on the solar panels of a communications satellite stranded in a uselessly low orbit. Intelsat, an organization of countries that owns the communications satellite, will study the amount of decay and decide whether it is worth sending astronauts on a rescue mission in 1992.

DOC.HEAD: Plane Carrying Troops for Mideast Drives off Detroit Metropolitan Runway
DOC.TEXT: An American Airlines DC-10 carrying about 250 Middle East-bound soldiers taxied off the runway at Detroit Metropolitan Airport after stopping for repairs, a spokesman said Wednesday. Al Becker, a spokesman at the airline's Dallas headquarters, said the plane got stuck in mud after one wheel went off the taxiway Tuesday night. No injuries were reported. Becker said the soldiers and their equipment were transferred to another plane, which took off early Wednesday. The plane, chartered by the Civil Reserve Air Fleet, landed at the suburban Detroit airport after a mechanical problem was detected in flight, said Becker. He wouldn't identify the problem. Becker also wouldn't say where the flight originated or where the troops were from. Becker said the plane had been repaired and was taxiing for takeoff when the accident occurred. The cause was under investigation.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Warplane Crashes in Saudi Arabia; Americans to Leave Iraq
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with four grafs to UPDATE with U.S. flight has not yet left Basra, details. Picks up 4th graf pvs, `And on...'
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. Air Force jet crashed today in Saudi Arabia, killing both crew members. It was the third accident involving American military aircraft in the Persian Gulf region in three days. In Iraq, meanwhile, 400 Americans and other foreign captives signed up for the first U.S.-chartered evacuation flight from Iraq and Kuwait since Sept. 22. The U.S. flight had been scheduled to leave from Baghdad later today. Most of the 400 were evacuated from Kuwait and were taken by bus to the Iraqi port of Basra. From there, they had been scheduled to leave on an Iraqi Airways Boeing-747 for the Iraqi capital. While officials in Baghdad said they had departed Basra, in Washington the State Department said without elaboration late this afternoon that the plane had not yet left Basra. And on the New York Exchange, the Middle East crisis helped push oil prices briefly to a record $41.15 a barrel today, before falling back to $40.88 in early trading. That was 48 cents above Tuesday's close of $40.40, and higher than the previous record close of $39.54 per barrel on Sept. 27. The upward trend has been caused in part by the slayings Monday of 19 Palestinians in a clash with police in Jerusalem, and Saddam Hussein's threat to retaliate against Israel. On Tuesday, Saddam announced that Iraq had added another missile to its arsenal, and he said it could be launched ``against the targets of evil when the day of reckoning comes.'' He made it clear he was referring to Israel and the U.S.-led forces sent to Saudi Arabia after Iraqi invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. About 170,000 U.S. forces are deployed in the Persian Gulf region. Saddam has repeatedly tried to link the status of Palestinians in the Israeli-occupied territories with his annexation of Kuwait, indicating he might withdraw from the emirate if Israel pulls out of Arab lands seized in 1967. Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir was quoted today by a German newspaper in Berlin as saying that the nations in the Persian Gulf will collapse like ``houses of cards'' if Saddam stays in power. In an interview with the Berliner Morgenpost newspaper, Shamir was also quoted as saying that the Israelis do not want war, but are prepared to retaliate if attacked by Iraq. Lt. Cmdr. J.D. van Sickle, a U.S. military spokesman, said the F-111 fighter plane crashed in the ``southern Arabian peninsula'' today while on a training mission and that the incident was under investigation. The names of the two flyers were withheld pending notification of relatives. Eight Marines are missing in the crash of two helicopters in the Northern Arabian Sea on Monday. An Air Force F-4 reconnaissance jet also went down that day, killing both crew members. Today, the Navy said that search teams had found no indication that any of the eight Marines had survived and it halted its search. In addition to those killed in Saudi Arabia, 13 other Air Force personnel were killed Aug. 29 in a crash of a C-5 jet cargo plane in Germany. That aircraft was ferrying supplies and equipment to the Saudi peninsula. U.S. officials said, however, that the overall safety record of U.S. forces in the gulf remains at least as good as it would be for forces of the same size in the United States. In Washington, the State Department said more Americans stranded in Iraq and Kuwait would be evacuated today. The flight is to arrive in Raleigh-Durham airport in North Carolina on Thursday after an overnight stop in London. As before, the Americans on board will be limited to women and children and Americans of Arab ancestry. It was the first U.S.-organized charter out of the region since Sept. 22, when the State Department said it would organize no further evacuation flights. Previous evacuation flights have transported about 1,900 Americans out of Iraq and Kuwait. Recent State Department estimates indicate there are more than 600 Americans stranded in Kuwait and more than 300 in Iraq. American and other Western men are being held in Iraq and Kuwait, many at strategic Iraqi installations to prevent an attack by the multinational forces in the Persian Gulf region. On Tuesday, State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said three more American men were recently detained by Iraqi authorities - two in Iraq and one in Kuwait. Many Westerners are believed still in hiding to avoid detention, primarily in Kuwait, which Iraq invaded in a dispute over land, oil and money. Besides the Westerners caught in Iraq and Kuwait, thousands of foreign workers of mostly Arab and Asian descent are stranded in squalid desert camps along the Jordanian and Turkish borders.

DOC.HEAD: Engineer Killed, Three Hurt in Train-Truck Crash
DOC.TEXT: An Amtrak train collided with a tractor-trailer rig at a rural crossing Wednesday, killing the engineer and injuring at least three other people on the train, officials said. Thirty-seven passengers were aboard the Houston-to-Dallas train when the accident occurred near Waller, about 40 miles northwest of Houston, Southern Pacific Railroad spokesman Jim Johnson said. The train did not derail. The fireman aboard the single-engine train and two passengers were hurt, Johnson said. The remaining passengers were taken to Dallas by bus. The condition of the truck driver was not immediately known.

DOC.HEAD: List of Fatalities in Operation Desert Shield
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: As Operation Desert Shield goes on the number of deaths grows of American serviceman taking part. Here is a breakdown of the 24 military personnel killed and eight missing: --- Oct. 10 - A U.S. Air Force F-111 fighter-bomber crashed in Saudi Arabia, killing both crew members. The aircraft was attached the 48th Tactical Fighter Wing based at RAF Lakenheath Air Base in Britain. Oct. 8 - In Saudi Arabia two U.S. pilots died in the crash of a RF4C Phantom reconnaisance jet belonging to a unit of the Alabama Air National Guard. Two UH-1 helicopters, carrying eight Marines, vanished during a training flight Monday. Rescuers searching for the missing helicopters reported finding debris in the north Arabian Sea but no bodies. Sept. 30 - Two Air Force pilots were killed Sunday when their F-15 fighter plane crashed during an exercise in Saudi Arabia. Sept. 26 - A Marine Corps staff sergeant from the 3rd Marine Aircraft Wing in Saudi Arabia died of a self-inflicted gunshot wound. Sept. 20 - An Army specialist from the 82nd Airborne was killed in a vehicle accident in Saudi Arabia. Sept. 14 - An officer from the U.S. Army's 24th Infantry Division was killed when his vehicle left the roadway and crashed in Saudi Arabia's Eastern Province. Aug. 29 - A giant C-5A transport aircraft loaded with supplies for U.S. forces in the Persian Gulf crashed and burned shortly after takeoff, killing 13 crew members. Aug. 21 - An electrician's mate aboard the USS Antietam, was electrocuted in an accident during maintenance of the ship's ventilation system. Aug. 12 - An Air Force Staff sergeant died when he was hit by a military truck on a darkened runway in Saudi Arabia.

DOC.HEAD: Safety Board Draws Up List Of 18 `Most Wanted' Safety Improvements
DOC.TEXT: Declaring that the time for foot dragging has ended, federal safety officials issued Wednesday a list of 18 ``most wanted'' safety improvements in air, sea and land transportation. The proposed improvements range from development of an air-collision avoidance system to adoption of state laws permitting uniformed police officers to confiscate drivers' licenses on the spot when drivers fail or refuse tests to detect alcohol. The National Transportation Safety Board list seeks to spur movement by regulatory agencies, industries, and state and local governments to implement recommendations made by the board over the last two decades. ``It's a call to action,'' said Chairman James L. Kolstad. ``Our most wanted list of recommendations represents some of the biggest areas for life saving. It is a tool that the safety board is using to help us get our job done.'' ``I think on some issues there has been foot dragging,'' he said, noting that federal rule-making procedures can delay implementation for five years or more. ``We need action now. We hope that everyone will agree that the issues we have chosen to include in our most wanted list have a great potential to prevent accidents and save lives.'' The safety board has no actual enforcement power. It can only identify possible safety improvements and recommend they be implemented. Kolstad said he believes the highest priority item on the list is the recommendation for the passage of laws in all states to permit police officers to seize licenses of drivers who fail or refuse to take alcohol tests. ``That is the single most important way to get drunk drivers off the road,'' he said. Air accidents can be reduced, he said, by developing and requiring an airborne collision avoidance system - a recommendation first made in 1969 - and requiring a runway incursion system to prevent ground accidents. The board's other most wanted safety improvements include: -Legislation to allow alcohol testing if an operator of a recreational boat is suspected of being intoxicated. -Implementation of a recommendation first issued in 1970 to require railroads to install signal and control systems to keep trains separated and prevent collisions. -Require commuter aircraft to carry ground proximity warning devices. -Make sweeping improvements in fishing vessel safety, including legislative authority to require the licensing of captains and the installation of basic lifesaving gear, including exposure suits in cold waters, flooding detection and fire detection alarms, Coast Guard-approved lifeboats or rafts, and emergency radios with an independent power source. -Require the screening of all commercial pilots to identify convicted alcohol and drug abusers, require periodic reviews of pilots' driver history records, and require airlines to report pilots convicted as drug and alcohol abusers to the Federal Aviation Administration for medical evaluation. -Require improvements in railway tank car safety. -Consider requiring adjustable seat belts in new cars to make them suitable and safe for children. -Speed up research to learn the effects of fatigue, sleepiness and sleep disorders on safety in all areas of transportation. -Adopt new standards to incorporate materials in new school buses which will slow the spread of fire. -Improve fire safety standards on passenger vessels, including automatic devices to close doors when smoke detectors are activated. -Adopt uniform regulations for drug and alcohol testing of all transportation employees responsible for operations and safety. -Require wear limits for airplane wheel brakes. -Improve the safety of heavy commercial trucks by detecting and preventing drug and alcohol abuse, imposing medical standards and dealing with driver fatigue. -Encourage the installation of excess flow valves in natural gas service lines to prevent explosions. -Require that all new turbojet transport planes receive full scale structural testing. The safety board has made 8,200 accident-prevention recommendations since it was founded in 1968. Kolstad said 81 percent have been adopted, but 1,800, including some of the most troublesome safety issues before the board, have not.

DOC.HEAD: Small But Enthusiastic Audience for Discovery's Return from Space
With AM-Space Shuttle, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A small crowd of space enthusiasts, bundled against the numbing desert chill, cheered the first space shuttle landing in nearly six months. Discovery's dawn touchdown Wednesday drew about 5,500 spectators, the third-smallest crowd for a landing open to the public. But those who braved the 38-degree cold were determined, some visiting from as far as England. The smallest crowd for a public shuttle landing at Edwards was 2,200 when Columbia landed Jan. 20, 1990. Top attendance was 500,000 when Columbia landed on July 4, 1982. Some landings have been closed to the public. Scattered shouts of ``It's here!'' and ``There it is!'' were heard as the signature twin sonic booms broke the silence of the Mojave Desert morning. Gasps were heard on the east shore of Rogers Dry Lake as the sunrise glinted behind the descending shuttle. ``That's gorgeous,'' said Valeri Leahey, 29, of Camarillo, who said it was her ninth shuttle landing. ``I wanted to come out and see this myself. It's my once in a lifetime chance,'' said Bruce McLean, 23, of Essex, England. Scattered applause and whoops rose into the air when the shuttle curved over the crowd and gently set down at 6:57 a.m. Air Force spokeswoman Michelle Orosco said the crowd may have been small because it was a early morning, midweek landing. Teacher Mark Walker brought 33 of his sixth-grade, gifted-class pupils from Briggs Fundamental School in Chino. They camped in sleeping bags and lawn chairs overnight. ``We wanted to be here to see the shuttle have a safe landing, but most important is to see our space program continue,'' Walker said. ``It's important that even in the midst of financial crisis and crisis in the Persian Gulf to see the program continue, and continue to promise for these kids.'' There also were skeptics, including Barry Dugan, on vacation with wife and two daughters from Williamsburg, Va. ``Nothing's going to get it on the right track until they make it an adventure again like the Chuck Yeager (first supersonic flight), when they did it for the sheer fun of it. Now it's just big money and big bureaucracy,'' he said. Discovery carried the European Space Agency's $250 million Ulysses spacecraft into orbit and launched it on a five-year journey to explore the sun's poles.

DOC.HEAD: Jane Byrne Plans Another Run for Mayor
DOC.TEXT: Former Mayor Jane Byrne says she'll hit the campaign trail again in 1991 for another run for City Hall. Byrne said Tuesday that she has begun circulating nominating petitions. ``We are absolutely having no difficulty getting signatures,'' she said. Byrne was elected mayor in 1979 but lost a re-election bid in the 1983 Democratic primary to Harold Washington. Washington, the city's first black mayor, also foiled Byrne's comeback bid in the 1987 primary. Mayor Richard M. Daley, elected in 1989 after Washington died, is expected to seek a full four-year term in 1991. ``Anybody can run for mayor,'' Daley said of Byrne's decision.

DOC.HEAD: Stand Firm Behind Budget Deal, Bush Urges Republicans
With AM-Budget-Taxes, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note grafs 13-16, In Atlanta, FOR RELEASE 7:05 p.m. EDT.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush urged Republicans to ``stand firm for the best budget deal possible'' as he campaigned for Southern GOP candidates Wednesday, dismissing differences with one of them on that very issue. The president said he wielded the appropriations veto that led to a partial government shutdown because Congress would otherwise have taken last weekend off. ``I kept the pressure on, and to make the point - no more business as usual,'' Bush told a rally for Florida Gov. Bob Martinez at a sweltering waterfront park. Bush left a mixed message on taxes as he went in quest of votes for Republican candidates. He had said Tuesday that he'd consider an increase in the highest income tax rates in exchange for a capital gains tax cut, then met withRepublican senators who said he'd dropped that idea. But, on Wednesday, Bush's spokesman said the president had only listened to the senators and hadn't told them anything. The budget message was a theme of his three-stop swing. ``Let's get the job done, members of Congress,'' he said in St. Petersburg. ``I didn't come down here to assign blame, but you know, I've seen these surveys. The American people are pretty smart. They know where the action is. And they know that Congress has the responsibility to pass a budget. And it's about time that they met that responsibility.'' Bush said in Raleigh, N.C., that if the rest of Congress were as careful with federal spending as Sen. Jesse Helms, there wouldn't be a budget crisis to begin with. Helms denounced one budget deal Bush endorsed and voted against a temporary settlement the Senate finally approved to avert a government shutdown Tuesday. ``Of course there are going to be differences,'' Bush said at a campaign breakfast for Helms, who is seeking a fourth Senate term against former Charlotte Mayor Harvey Gantt in a race the pollsters now see as a tossup. The president said differences with Helms ``on one issue or another'' were beside the point. ``The point is that if we had more senators like him, we wouldn't be trying to solve some of these problems that should have been solved months ago, years ago,'' Bush said. Republican defections, especially in the House, have been a major problem for the president and congressional leaders in trying to strike a budget deal to cut the deficit by $40 billion this year and by a total of $500 billion over the next five years. Bush's final campaign stop of the day was in Atlanta, home territory of Rep. Newt Gingrich, the leader of conservatives who rebelled against the budget deal. The president was appearing there to raise campaign funds for Johnny Isakson, the Republican candidate for governor of Georgia. He is rated a long shot against Democratic Lt. Gov. Zell Miller.
DOC.HEAD: Following 4 grafs FOR RELEASE 7:05 p.m. EDT
DOC.TEXT: In Atlanta, Bush again discussed the budget at a fund-raising reception for Isakson. ``Right now, the federal budget process is like a huge Rube Goldberg machine, out of control - producing noise, smoke, heat and no light,'' Bush said. ``Sucking up more and more tax dollars on one end and churning them into spending programs without end.'' But he said he is confident Congress can pass a sound budget. ``We've had a few days now for the smoke to clear,'' Bush said. ``Now it's time to move forward.''
DOC.HEAD: Preceding 4 grafs FOR RELEASE 7:05 p.m. EDT
DOC.TEXT: In St. Petersburg, Bush sought money and votes for Martinez, bidding for reelection in a close contest with Democrat Lawton Chiles, a former senator looking for a comeback. It was the president's first campaign foray since the budget crisis that led to a partial shutdown of federal facilities and threatened more, a standoff resolved temporarily with government spending authority extended until Oct. 19. Bush demanded that the Democratic Congress ``make the hard choices and real reductions'' in spending that would produce a permanent settlement he'd accept. ``I will continue now to press hard for a budget that fulfills the spirit of that bipartisan plan and proves to the American people once and for all that we can deal with this deficit,'' he said. ``We've got to turn it around now.'' He said he is dead serious about the deadline 10 days away.

DOC.HEAD: Condoms Tossed On Street In Anti-Government Protest
Laserphoto MOSB2
DOC.TEXT: With a smirk on her face, a lone Soviet activist nearly caused a riot a block from the Kremlin on Wednesday by tossing hard-to-find condoms into the air and demanding that prostitution be legalized. ``We want to draw attention to the problem of prostitutes, because they have no legal protection and because they are the objects of sexual abuse,'' declared Yevgenia Debryanskaya, a member of the fledgling Libertarian Party. ``Nor are they protected medically,'' she said. Many in the crowd of more than 100 people, including many Soviet journalists, shrieked and grabbed for the hundreds of American-made condoms she scattered on the ground in front of the Intourist Hotel, one of Moscow's best-known workplaces for prostitutes. Passers-by stopped in amazement and several joined in the scramble on one of Moscow's main thoroughfares. Defying the usually prudish Soviet attitude toward sex, Ms. Debryanskaya also tossed a stack of English-language manuals on safe sex into the air, and the wind swept them across the sidewalk in the direction of the Kremlin. Condoms, like many consumer goods, have never been plentiful in the Soviet Union. Soviet-made condoms are notorious for their poor quality and undependability. Western condoms sell for as much as the equivalent of $8 on the black market. Wednesday's protest also demonstrated the length to which groups will go to stand out among the growing number of Soviet political organizations, and the extent to which once-banned activities are now tolerated. Although a half-dozen police were present at the unauthorized protest, they made no effort to intervene other than keeping the sidewalk clear. Ms. Debyranskaya said the Liberation Party wanted the repeal of a law that punishes prostitution with fines as well as free medical care for prostitutes. She said prostitutes ``do not even have the most elementary contraception devices - condoms. And in the age when AIDS is spreading, they are particularly liable to infection.'' At one point, two other protesters unfurled a hand-written banner depicting a submarine and reading: ``One nuclear submarine equals (the cost of) 5 billion condoms.'' Another sign read: ``A sexual blockade on members of the Communist Party.'' Soviet officials have been slow to acknowledge the spread of AIDS, which can be transmitted through sexual contact, intravenous drug use or passed from an infected mother to her fetus. In 1989, several cases were reported of babies being infected with AIDS through the use of contaminated hypodermic needles in Soviet hospitals. Although Soviet health officials have begun publicly discussing ways to treat those infected with AIDS, statistics for the number of infected Soviets are not available. There are also no official figures on the number of Soviet prostitutes, although they do a brisk trade at hotels catering to foreigners and at train stations.

DOC.HEAD: J.S. Bell, Noted British Physicist, Dead at 62
DOC.TEXT: John Stewart Bell, a British theorhetical scientist who pointed to an answer to one of the basic questions of his science, has died. He was 62. He died last week at a Geneva hospital after suffering a stroke, the European Laboratory for Particle Physics said. Bell, born in Belfast, Northern Ireland, had worked since 1960 at the 15-nation lab, located outside this Swiss city and known by its former French acronym CERN. The lab's director, Nobel laureate Carlo Rubbia of Italy, cited Bell's ``imposing contribution to physics'' which he said ``did much ... to unravel the paradoxes which riddle quantum theory ....'' Quantum physics is based on the theory that energy is transmitted in definable units rather than constant streams. Bell was best known for 1964 research in which he postulated how simultaneous measurements on separate physical systems can be linked. Testing of ``Bell's Theorem'' or ``Bell's Inequality'' seems to have shown that the apparent coordination of particles that have flown too far apart for normal communication arises from the action of the measurement. The tests appear to have resolved a basic question of physics: Is there a message within the basic particles that determines their behavior? Bell is survived by his wife Mary, who collaborated on some of his research and also works at the lab.

DOC.HEAD: Candidate Fires Ad Agency He Says Was Too Negative
DOC.TEXT: Republican gubernatorial candidate Dave Frohnmayer says he fired his advertising agency because his campaign had gotten too negative. Frohnmayer, the state attorney general, also offered to hold a fifth public debate with Democrat Barbara Roberts, who has pulled even with Frohnmayer in the polls. Roberts, the secretary of state, dismissed the moves as desperation tactics by a candidate who is ``running scared.'' Frohnmayer's debate offer came as he and Roberts held what was supposed to be their fourth and final debate Tuesday night. Earlier, Frohnmayer's campaign announced it had fired an ad agency because its campaign ads were too negative. Frohnmayer said he felt he wasn't coming across well. ``The ads were accurate, but there was a certain amount of stridency,'' he said. Frohnmayer said future ads would be upbeat and focus on his record. ``Let's look for the higher ground,'' he said. ``That's my plan for the next 28 days.'' Roberts said Frohnmayer's call for a more positive campaign was ironic in view of the negative ads he's been running, portraying her as soft on crime. ``He's been running negative ads all summer. It's a little late for the high ground,'' Roberts said.
DOC.HEAD: Pence Calls Sharp `Environmental Hypocrite' in Possible Farm Sale
DOC.TEXT: Rep. Phil Sharp says he has no role in the proposed sale of his family's Illinois farm as a planned nuclear waste dump. The Indiana Democrat was criticized as ``an environmental hypocrite'' by Republican Mike Pence, who is trying to unseat Sharp in the November election. ``For Phil Sharp to decry my commitment to the family farms of this district, and at the same time to sell his family farm for a nuclear waste site, is just unbelievable,'' Pence said. The Illinois Department of Nuclear Safety wants to put a low-level nuclear waste dump near Martinsville, Ill. The Sharp family farm is one of several parcels Illinois wants to buy to create the dump. Sharp said Tuesday that he has no say in selling the farm. ``That is just ridiculous. I am not an owner of the property,'' he said. ``I'm neither trying to accelerate the sale or stop it. I am staying away from it, as I should.'' The 175-acre farm belonged to Sharp's father, Riley Sharp, who died in 1985. In his will, Riley Sharp named his wife, Martha Sharp, and Phil Reeds, who leases the property from her, as the property's trustees.
DOC.HEAD: Mississippi Governor Gearing Up For 1991 Re-Election Race
DOC.TEXT: Democratic Gov. Ray Mabus plans a series of campaign fund-raisers over the next two months to prepare for his 1991 re-election race. Jere Nash, who left Mabus' staff to run the governor's campaign, said Mabus has about $350,000 in campaign funds. ``It's going to be increased, dramatically, when we get finished,'' Nash said Tuesday. Mabus spent more than $3 million to win the 1987 governor's race. No opponent has materialized to challenge the 41-year-old Mabus.
DOC.HEAD: Idaho's Gov Andrus Begins 100-City Re-Election Campaign Tour
DOC.TEXT: Democratic Gov. Cecil Andrus began the first leg of a 100-city re-election campaign tour in northern Idaho on Wednesday. Andrus was stumping on the progress Idaho has made in the past four years as he moved north through the day. Andrus is the odds-on favorite to win an unprecedented fourth term over GOP long-shot Roger Fairchild. ``I'm going to be taking nothing for granted,'' Andrus said. ``I'm going out campaigning among the people of Idaho.''

DOC.HEAD: Oil-Eating Bacteria Called Promising, Some Express Doubts About Safety
DOC.TEXT: Oil-eating bacteria worked when sprayed on a sensitive marsh fouled by a July oil spill, proponents say, but some scientists say they're still worried about the safety of the cleanup technique. Speaking at a symposium on bioremediation at Lamar University in Beaumont, proponents of the technique reported that microbe-treated areas of Morrow Marsh, on Galveston Bay, were largely free of oil a month after the spill. Franz Hiebert, director of geoscience programs for Alpha Environmental Inc., said researchers ``found a wide variety of fishes swimming in and out of the marsh'' in the northern reaches of the bay near Cedar Bayou. Hiebert's company sprayed the oil-eating bacteria in the marsh and other areas of Galveston Bay fouled by 700,000 gallons of oil that spilled when a tanker collided with oil barges in the Houston Ship Channel. The bacteria also were used in June, after the supertanker Mega Borg exploded 57 miles off Galveston. Not everyone at Tuesday's conference rallied behind bioremediation, which has been used for years to treat sewage and hazardous waste and only recently was used on oil spills. Although studies done so far have been ``very encouraging,'' there ``is plenty of research yet to be done,'' said Sarah Liehr of the Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering at the University of Houston. Among the issues to be resolved is whether phosphorus, nitrogen and other nutrients mixed with the bacteria to stimulate their growth will cause algae to bloom or reproduce explosively. Algae blooms can deplete oxygen in the water. Norm Novick, of Mobil Oil Corp.'s Toxicology Department, said the process clearly works on contaminated soils, sludges and groundwater. He said it has limited usefulness in cleaning up heavier petroleum products. Novick maintained that in most oil spills ``the organisms you need (to eat the oil) are already there.'' Evidence suggests that indigenous bacteria only need stimulation by nutrients to degrade spilled oil and that additional bacteria aren't needed, he said. Texas Water Commission Chairman Buck Wynne III said that during two recent spills ``the one thing we did show was that (bioremediation) didn't hurt anything.'' It cost the state about $90,000 to treat the June and July spills, he said. Wynne expressed doubts that bacteria will be used routinely on spills until the technology wins the support of the federal government.

DOC.HEAD: Former U.S. Rep. William Henry Harrison, Descendant of Presidents
DOC.TEXT: Former U.S. Rep. William Henry Harrison, a descendant of two presidents and an opponent of excessive federal power, has died at age 94. Harrison died Monday of heart failure at Palms of Pasadena Hospital in St. Petersburg, Fla., his winter ome. He will be buried here Saturday. A five-term Republican congressman from Wyoming, Harrison campaigned in the early 1960s by opposing Kennedy administration policies. He saw Washington taking more control and direction over American life and he didn't like it. ``This is, in my opinion, a serious detriment and threat to local and state initiative and control which are at the very foundation of our freedom and liberty and our free enterprise system,'' he said in April 1962. Politics ran on both sides of his family. He was a grandson of President Benjamin Harrison and a great-great grandson of President William Henry Harrison. His great-great-great grandfather was another Benjamin Harrison; that one signed the Declaration of Independence. On his mother's side, Harrison was a grandson of Alvin Saunders, Nebraska's territorial governor during the Civil War and later a U.S. senator. Harrison was born in Terre Haute, Ind., on Aug. 10, 1896. After earning a law degree he served in the Indiana Legislature, then moved to Wyoming and eventually won election as a lawmaker here. He was first elected to Congress in 1950. In 1969, President Richard Nixon appointed Harrison to the U.S. Renegotiation Board, an independent agency that examined contracts relating to the defense and aerospace programs in an effort to stop excessive profits. Harrison resigned from the board at age 75 and returned to Wyoming. He is survived by his wife, Dorothy, a daughter and a son.

DOC.HEAD: Teamsters President McCarthy Won't Run for Re-Election
DOC.TEXT: Teamsters Union President William J. McCarthy, citing personal reasons, announced Wednesday he will not run for re-election in next year's government-supervised elections, the first in which union leaders will be elected directly by the rank and file. A majority of the union's 21-member board quickly backed R.V. Durham of North Carolina, a Teamsters vice president, to replace McCarthy. But Jack Cox of Los Angeles, a board member who withheld his endorsement of Durham, said he may run for the union's presidency. McCarthy, 71, has had a minor stroke and open-heart surgery. He made the announcement at a union board meeting in West Palm Beach, Fla. A brief statement released by the union's headquarters in Washington said McCarthy, who succeeded the late Jackie Presser two years ago, ``has decided for personal reasons not to seek re-election to the post.'' Sources within the union, speaking on the condition of anonymity, said there were deep political divisions on the board, with some factions opposed to McCarthy's running again. Cox said he thought that ``more people were beginning to tell him (McCarthy) the truth, which was that he was losing the touch and losing control.'' Durham, a 40-year union veteran from Greensboro, N.C., was named by 15 of the 21 board members to head the board's slate for next year's elections, the union said. Weldon Mathis, who now has the No. 2 job of secretary-treasurer, was selected by the board to again run for that post. The December 1991 elections, agreed to by the union board last year as part of the settlement of a massive civil racketeering suit brought by the Justice Department, will be the first direct, secret-ballot elections in the Teamsters' 87-year history. In past elections, top officers were elected at a convention by delegates handpicked at the local level. Next year, the 1.6 million rank-and-file Teamsters will cast secret ballots. Ron Carey, a local president in New York who is mounting an independent campaign for the presidency, is running on a pledge to clean up the union. He has won the endorsement of the Teamsters for a Democratic Union, a dissident group that has pushed for union reform for a decade. Ken Paff, a spokesman for the dissident group, said that Durham is ``not very well known,'' and added that ``in this election, being well-known is going to work against you.'' Durham, a former director of the Teamsters' safety and health department, is the union's freight director. He oversees operations and negotiations in the freight area, such as contracts covering union truckers. Cox said he would decide by the end of the week whether to endorse someone else as McCarthy's replacement or run himself. ``I might decide to go for the top spot myself,'' Cox said, adding, ``I listen to people.''

DOC.HEAD: Cavazos Testifies About Student Loan Problems
DOC.TEXT: Education Secretary Lauro Cavazos told a Senate panel Wednesday his department is moving aggressively to halt fraud, waste and abuse and recover an estimated $7.8 billion in defaults in the federal student loan program. Cavazos said the government collected a record $722.3 million in defaulted student loans in fiscal year 1990, an increase of about $79 million over 1989. He told a subcommittee of the Senate that ``tough, but fair-minded'' regulations have recently been implemented. ``They go as far as we felt we could go under the law at the time,'' Cavazos said. ``They are working, but they are not enough. We need more statutory authority.'' Cavazos's testimony before the Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations brought to a close a yearlong examination of problems in federal student financial aid programs. Chairman Sam Nunn, D-Ga., said the legislative initiatives were welcome, ``but here's tremendous authority in the Department of Education that's not been utilized.'' He pointed to numerous times the department ignored warnings from its Inspector General's Office of problems within the loan program. ``In brief, it is not an exaggeration to say that we have heard no testimony or seen any documents that suggest the department has done even an adequate job in managing and overseeing its student loan program responsibilities,'' Nunn said. Nunn asked Cavazos and officials accompanying him why it has taken years to correct flaws in the program and to update the agency's computer system so that questionable activities from unscrupulous trade schools can be detected. As an example, Nunn showed documents of a trade school that had lost accreditation from two licensing agencies. When the same owners changed the institution's name and moved its location, he said the department recently approved the accreditation by a third agency. ``The program seems to be just a joke, isn't it?'' Nunn said. Sen. Edward Kennedy, D-Mass., said, ``It is clear that the current system does not protect students, and it does not protect taxpayers either.
