Total federal insurance costs to cover defaults have increased from $239 million in 1980 to $2.4 billion in 1990. ``There will always be some defaults in any loan guarantee programs. But the amount we are spending now on student loan defaults is unacceptable.'' However, Kennedy acknowledged Cavazos had initiated some improvements. Cavazos said the agency has ``dramatically increased'' the number of on-site reviews of higher education institutions to determine compliance with student aid regulations. He said 372 were conducted in fiscal year 1987 but more than 1,200 were carried out in fiscal year 1990 ending in September. Cavazos said the department's successful debt collection activity includes using private collection agencies, offsetting federal income tax refunds and collecting from the salaries of federally employed defaulters. Default collections from tax refunds totaled $261 million in fiscal 1990, with more than 439,000 defaulters paying an average $610 from federal tax refunds.

DOC.HEAD: At Least 4 Killed, 200 Injured in Clashes with Police
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE death toll to 4, 200 cars damaged, details. ADDS material on storms. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Police fired shotguns and used nightsticks to break up an opposition demonstration Wednesday and at least four people died and 200 were injured, police said. The demonstrators set ablaze or damaged more than 100 vehicles, including eight belonging to the United States Information Service, witnesses said. Opposition leaders said up to six people died in the clashes. After listening to speeches against President Hussain Muhammad Ershad, slogan-shouting followers burned an effigy of the president and marched toward the headquarters of Ershad's Jatiya Party in the Motijheel financial district, the United News of Bangladesh news agency said. Police fired tear gas and used their batons to suppress the stone-throwing demonstrators. When that failed to stop them, police opened fire with shotguns, witnesses said. At least 15 people, including a news photographer, suffered bullet wounds. Opposition leader Khaleda Zia said up to six died in the demonstrations. She showed reporters large bruises on her hands that she said were the result of police attacks. The ``police attack on me and my supporters was absolutely unprovoked,'' Mrs. Zia said. ``This country is being run by the worst dictaor in the world.'' At a separate news conference, another opposition leader, Sheikh Hasina, said five people were killed in the ``unprovoked firing.'' Mrs. Zia, head of the Bangladesh Nationalist Party, called for a half-day nationwide general strike to condemn the police action. Ershad, who took power in a coup eight years ago and subsequently was elected president, has said he would allow elections if the opposition agrees not to boycott the vote. The opposition wants Ershad to step down and allow a caretaker government to hold the elections. In a speech before the demonstration, Mrs. Zia pledged the opposition would not rest until the government was ousted and a free election held in the country. Meanwhile, a storm that has claimed the lives of more than 70 fishermen and left about 5,000 missing in the Bay of Bengal continued to lash the Bangladesh coast Wednesday. The Bengali-language daily newspaper Sangram said 350 boats and trawlers had failed to return to port since the storm hit on Monday. Incessant rains have caused flash floods in much of low-lying Bangladesh, rendering tens of thousands of people homeless.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Responds to Boycott by Ordering Parades
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev on Wednesday ordered all major Soviet cities to hold parades Nov. 7 marking the 1917 Bolshevik Revolution, apparently trying to squelch a boycott called by liberals. The presidential decree was Gorbachev's first public response to the liberal mayors of Moscow and Leningrad, who last month called for abandoning the traditional Revolution Day celebrations because the dismal economic situation gave Soviets nothing to celebrate. Other groups since have supported their call. The anniversary of the 1917 revolution is one of the major holidays on the Soviet calendar, a day usually devoted to praising the glories of communism. While the official ideology has fallen from its sacred position in politics in recent years, many conservatives remain committed to upholding the old system. Using his broad executive powers, Gorbachev issued the decree ordering the date to be observed with military parades in Moscow, the capitals of the 14 other republics and in other cities where army or naval fleets are based, the official Tass news agency said. Gorbachev also instructed Defense Minister Dimitri Yazov to review the parade in Red Square in Moscow. The parades usually include tanks and rockets, followed by a ``people's demonstration'' of the city's residents. May Day, another major Soviet holiday, was marked this year by counter-demonstrations involving tens of thousands of people in Moscow. As they passed through Red Square, many shouted ``Resign!'' and jeered at Gorbachev, who suffered the embarrassment stoically for 20 minutes and then left the reviewing stand.

DOC.HEAD: Seneca-Salamanca Lease Bill Passes House
DOC.TEXT: The House passed a bill Wednesday authorizing the federal government to pay $35 million to the Seneca Nation to make amends for a century of unfair land leases to the city of Salamanca, N.Y. The legislation passed the House on a voice vote and was headed to the Senate, where it could be considered before week's end. ``We're facing up to reality,'' Rep. Amo Houghton, R-N.Y. and the bill's sponsor, said on the House floor. ``This nation was badly treated. Something ought to be done.'' The measure would ratify an agreement reached by Salamanca and the Seneca Nation to replace a 99-year lease accord that expires Feb. 19, 1991. About 85 percent of the city of Salamanca is leased from the Senecas, at rents that were frozen at rates as low as $1 per year. Under the bill, the federal government would pay $35 million to the tribe to make up for some of its financial losses. The state of New York must pay $25 million, which will require state legislation. The Bush administration has said it opposes the bill because of the cost. But Houghton spokesman Mike Hyland says the congressman has discussed the problem with Interior Secretary Manual Lujan and believes the bill's chances are good.

DOC.HEAD: Man Pleads Guilty to Attempted Extortion of Malcolm Forbes
DOC.TEXT: A man has pleaded guilty to trying to extort $30,000 from the late Malcolm Forbes by threatening to harm his reputation. George Kenneth Warnock, 25, of the Bronx, had been charged in July with mailing two threatening letters to Forbes last August and September and a similar letter to Forbes' son, Malcolm Jr., after the millionaire publisher died Feb. 24. Warnock, in an agreement with prosecutors, pleaded guilty on Friday to one count of using the mail in an extortion attempt. The plea was made public Wednesday. He faces up to two years in prison and a $250,000 fine when sentenced Dec. 14 by U.S. District Judge Lawrence M. McKenna. The indictment didn't describe the nature of the threats. At last week's hearing, Warnock said he sent the first letter in August asking Forbes to ``give me money or something in return for the favors, and I think I sent it in a threatening way.'' He said he never caused or intended to cause any physical harm to Forbes. At the time of the indictment, Forbes magazine attorney Donald Shaw said in a prepared statement that Warnock had made ``fabricated allegations.'' Shaw said the family had looked into Warnock's claims and ``our investigation found that Mr. Warnock ... never even met the late Malcolm Forbes.'' Assistant U.S. Attorney Nancy Northup said Warnock admitted to a Forbes employee that he had written the letter and asked for $30,000 in exchange for withholding information that could damage Forbes' reputation. Northup said the Forbes employee, who was not identified, would have testified had the case gone to trial.

DOC.HEAD: Chess Notation Explained
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf to add dropped word
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Chess Showdown
DOC.TEXT: Chess players have long used systems of notation to record the moves of their games and to replay and study games. The U.S. Chess Federation says it's necessary to know notation to play rated chess in tournaments. A written record proves a player made the required number of moves within the specified time limit. The system known as algebraic notation is most widely used. In algebraic notation, the ``ranks'' are the horizontal rows of squares. The ranks take numbers, 1 to 8, beginning on white's side of the board. The ``files'' are the vertical rows of squares. They take letters, a through h, beginning on white's left. Thus, each square is identified by its file letter and rank number. In the starting position, white's queen knight stands on b1, the queen on d1, the king on e1; black's queen knight stands on b8, the queen on d8, the king on e8, and so on. Other features of the system follow: -DESIGNATION OF PIECES: The major pieces are shown by a capital letter: K for king, Q for queen, R for rook, B for bishop and N for knight. No symbol is used for the pawn. -MOVES BY PIECES: Shown by the letter of the piece (except for the pawn) and the destination square. For instance, Bb5 means the bishop moves to square b5. -MOVES BY PAWNS: Since only one pawn can move to a given square at any time, pawn moves are designated only by the name of the destination square. Thus, e4 means the pawn on the e file moves to e4. -CASTLING: It is written as 0-0 for the kingside and 0-0-0 for the queenside. Kingside is the side of the board (right half from white's point of view, left half from black's), on which each player's king starts. The other half is queenside. -CAPTURES BY PIECES: A capture is recorded using an ``x'' after the letter for the capturing piece. For instance, if white's bishop captures the black pawn, it is written Bxf6. -CAPTURES BY PAWNS: When a pawn captures something, the players name the file the pawn was on and the square where it made the capture. If white's pawn on a g file captured black's pawn, the move would be gxf6. If black's pawn on an f file captured white's, it would be fxg5. -CHECK: The symbol for check is a plus sign. -AMBIGUITY: If more than one piece of the same type can move to a square, the rank number or file letter of the origination square is added. Thus, if a rook on d1 were to move to d4, but another rook also could move there, instead of Rd4 the move would be given as R1d4 (pronounced ``rook at 1 to d4.'') If there are black knights on c6 and e6, and the one on e6 moves to d4, the move is given as Ned4 (``knight at e to d4.'')

DOC.HEAD: One Marine Killed In Training Mission Accident
DOC.TEXT: One Marine was killed when he landed in a river on a night parachute training exercise, and three other Marines were injured, a base spokesman said Wednesday. The body was found Wednesday in the Trent River. The cause of the accident Tuesday night hasn't been determined. ``There are so many factors involved in this type of training,'' said Capt. Michael Imsick. ``They have to examine all those factors: gear, environmental conditions, individual Marines involved, the flight, the location, all those factors.'' Three other Marines suffered minor injuries when they landed in woods at a training area that is part of Camp Lejeune, but separate from the main base, Imsick said. The training wasn't in preparation for duty in Saudi Arabia, another spokesman said. The men were among six who jumped from a CH-53 Delta Sea Stallion helicopter. They were part of the 2nd Air Naval Gunfire Liaison Company, 2nd Surveillance, Reconnaissance and Intelligence Group at Camp Lejeune, Imsick said. One of the injured was in intensive care Wednesday at the Naval Hospital at Camp Lejeune with burns suffered when he touched power lines. Another remained hospitalized with ``minor orthopedic injuries,'' Imsick said. The names of the victims were withheld.

DOC.HEAD: `Sacred' Japanese Rice Harvested for Coronation Ceremony
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf `The hourlong' to CORRECT Akita's location to northeast sted northwest. Picks up 6th pvs, `Having the...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto TOK6
DOC.TEXT: Just as a few chosen farmers have done for more than 1,000 years, Susumu Anai on Wednesday harvested ``sacred'' rice for his emperor to offer the gods in a mystical ritual of enthronement. The harvest, conducted under heavy security, completed the gathering of rice that Emperor Akihito is to offer to the gods of Shinto, Japan's native religion, next month. But, unlike in times of old when Japan's monarchs were revered as living gods and Shinto was the national religion, questions have been raised about the rite's constitutionality and whether it should be performed. Palace and local government officials looked on silently as Anai, clad in white cotton robes and wearing the type of tall black hat worn by religious and court officials centuries ago, entered a talisman-ringed paddy and cut several plants to place on a wooden altar. The hourlong ritual on Japan's southwestern island of Kyushu followed a similar harvest two weeks ago in Akita, in the northeast. By tradition, one paddy must be to the west and one to the east of Kyoto, Japan's former capital. ``Having the paddy of my ancestors chosen makes me feel both honor and the weight of responsibility,'' said Yoichiro Ito, the Akita farmer whose paddy was used for the rice. ``It was rice that I had just grown like the rest,'' Ito said in a telephone interview. ``As a farmer this is a great honor.'' Emperor Akihito will offer the rice and several other kinds of food to the gods in the mystical Daijosai, or ``Great Food Offering Ritual,'' on Nov. 22-23 after his Nov. 12 coronation. Akihito ascended the throne after his father, Hirohito, died in January last year. His formal enthronement, however, had to await a one-year mourning period and the growing of rice for the Daijosai. After communing with the gods in two halls at the Tokyo Imperial Palace, Akihito is to sleep with the spirit of the sun goddess Amaterasu, from whom the imperial line is said to have descended. The Daijosai was largely ignored in the 15th and 17th centuries, but otherwise has been performed regularly for at least 1,200 years. Because Akihito will be the first monarch to be enthroned under Japan's post-World War II constitution, his coronation is under particularly close scrutiny. Nearly 1,000 people are suing Japan's conservative-led government over plans to provide state funds for the rite, which is opposed by Christian, Buddhist and intellectual groups. Before Japan's surrender to the Allies in 1945, a nationalistic brand of Shinto had state backing and was used by the government to rally the people behind the war effort. Hirohito renounced the concept of imperial divinity soon after the war and a new constitution written mainly by U.S. occupation forces banned government backing of Shinto or any other religion. In defending the decision to provide funds, officials have acknowledged the religious significance of the rite, but stated its importance as an imperial tradition should take precedence. In February, imperial ritualists selected the location of the two sacred paddies by heating turtle shells over charcoal until they cracked, and then using the cracks to divine where the proper paddies would be found. Only the names of the states were announced because radical leftist groups, who oppose the monarchy, have threatened violence to disrupt ceremonies related to the coronation. Radicals claimed responsibility for a fire in July that razed a shrine in Akita and were suspected of setting a fire earlier this week in a buidling formerly used as a train station for the imperial family. But no incidents were reported at either harvest ceremony. Ito said he was not told by local agricultural officials that his paddy had been chosen until one month before the harvest, and that the palace had not approached him until one week before the rice was to be cut. ``The first I heard about it was on the night of Aug. 23,'' he said. ``It was a very unexpected thing, and I was quite shocked.''

DOC.HEAD: U.N. Sending Human Rights Expert to Burma
DOC.TEXT: The United Nations is sending a human rights expert to Burma to check on claims of torture and the failure to investigate the 1988 killing of thousands of pro-democracy demonstrators, U.N. officials said Wednesday. The leader of Burma's opposition, Aung San Suu Kyi, has been under house arrest for more than a year. Her National League for Democracy won a majority of seats in May's parliamentary elections, but the military government has not yet turned over power. The entire leadership of the National League for Democracy has been detained. Last month, the acting head of the opposition party, his deputy and four regional party leaders were arrested and charged with breaking the official secrets act. The government says it must resolve some challenged election results and write a new constitution before stepping down. The U.N. Commission on Human Rights is sending an investigator to Burma who will give the Geneva-based commission a private report in February, said U.N. spokeswoman Nadia Younes. Burma's deputy foreign minister, U Ohn Gyaw, said that his government ``has agreed to, and indeed welcomes the visit to our country of Prof. Sadako Ogata, an independent expert appointed by the Commission on Human Rights.'' ``She will shortly be arriving in our country to carry out her mandate,'' he said. ``Questions have been raised in certain quarters concerning the restraint placed on certain individuals in my country,'' he added. ``Legal action has been taken against these persons not for their political activities but for their infringement of the existing laws of the land,'' he said. In 1988, government troops fired on pro-democracy demonstrators, killing thousands of them, in Rangoon, the Burmese capital. Amnesty International says that many hundreds, perhaps thousands of suspected government opponents were detained without charge or trial or sentenced to prison terms after unfair trials before military tribunals. At least 100 people have been sentenced to death, although it is not known if any sentences have been carried out, said Amnesty. The government has never investigated the orders to the troops to fire on the protesters. Torture and arbitrary executions by soldiers trying to put down insurgences were widely reported, Amnesty said.

DOC.HEAD: Attorneys Debate Court Role in Labor Disputes
With AM-Scotus-Sex Bias, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Fired employees have a right to sue if the company's grievance procedure does not get them rehired, an attorney for two Michigan workers argued Wednesday in the Supreme Court. The attorney, Laurence Gold, asked the court to overturn lower court rulings that the workers were bound by the result of the in-house grievance procedure. But Terence V. Page, attorney for the Ferndale Fastener Division of Ring Screw Works in the Detroit suburb of Ferndale, Mich., argued that the lower courts ruled correctly since the employees' contract did not explicitly grant the right to sue. ``This court has never allowed people to run the gamut'' of company appeals and then go to court ``for a second bite of the apple,'' Page said. The key question the case raises is whether employees may take labor disputes to court when their collective bargaining agreements neither grant nor rule out a lawsuit. Ring Screw Works and its employees have operated under a collective bargaining agree since the early 1950s with Local 771 of the United Auto Workers union. The agreement sets out a four-step grievance procedure for settling disputes, including outside mediators if agreeable to both sides. If the talks produce deadlock, the union could strike and the company could lock out the workers. The contract says nothing about the possibility of lawsuits. Gold said in an interview he was not involved in drafting the agreement and did not know why the subject wasn't addressed. ``It just looks like it never surfaced as an issue,'' he said. Most union contracts, but not all, do say whether lawsuits may be filed. In 1985, Ring Screw Works fired Arthur Groves on the grounds of excessive absenteeism and Bobby J. Evans for allegedly falsifying company records. Both tried to get their jobs back through the normal grievance procedure, but failed. The company declined to submit to arbitration but the union decided not to strike. The employees then sued, claiming the company breached the collective bargaining agreement by firing the workers without just cause. The U.S. District Court in Detroit threw out the suits, saying the employees could not sue unless there was evidence the union had not given them effective representation. The workers made no such allegation. A federal appeals court upheld the decision. Gold told the justices he doubted the employees would have agreed to the contract if they thought it would prevent them from going to court as a last resort. ``We believe ... collective bargaining agreements should not be construed to preclude judicial enforcement unless that is clearly and unmistakably the parties' intent,'' he said. Page said that by providing for strikes and lockouts as a last resort, the two sides signaled an intent to resolve their disputes among themselves without involving the courts. Associate Justice Byron White expressed skepticism that strikes and lockouts are effective means of resolving disputes. The winner of such showdowns is stronger or more patient but not necessarily the correct side, he said. Page disagreed, saying the value of strikes and lockouts is in prodding workers and management to resume negotiations. The courts' proper role is not to settle labor disputes but to act as umpires and ``make sure you play by the rules,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Read My Flips, Say the Nation's Headlines
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS 20th graf, ``Bush Fickle, to make it Arkansas Gazette sted Arkansas Democrat
DOC.TEXT: Across America, newspapers printed the headline politicians least like to see. President Bush was portrayed as having reversed himself on taxes and Wednesday's papers called him indecisive. In Houston, headlines said Bush ``Pulls Fast Reverse'' and in Hot Springs, Ark. he ``Recants.'' In Omaha, Neb., and Portland, Ore., he says ``Yes, Then No.'' In Hudson County, N. J., he ``Blinks.'' He is ``Fickle'' in Little Rock, Ark., ``Backs Off'' in Sioux Falls, S.D., and ``Waffles'' in Albany, N.Y. All because of an apparent change of heart. On Tuesday morning, Bush told a news conference he could accept higher tax rates for the richest of Americans in exchange for lower tax rates on capital gains. In the afternoon, he met with protesting Republican senators. They carried out word that he had changed his stance. Politicians hate to be seen as contradicting themselves, and Bush's spokesman said Wednesday that the president had merely listened to the senators, not blatantly reversed himself. But headline writers everywhere in America had already had their field day. Bush might have recalled what John F. Kennedy said about newspapers after he moved into the White House. He said he was ``reading them more and enjoying it less.'' Before leaving town on a campaign trip Wednesday, Bush could have gotten an idea about what kind of a day it was to be from the front page of The Washington Times: Bush
Hems,
Haws
On Tax

But generally the verbs of choice were flip and flop: ``Bush Flips, Then Flops on Tax Rates for Rich,'' said The Evening Sun of Baltimore. ``Bush Flip-Flops on Tax Swap,'' said The Gazette of Cedar Rapids, Iowa. ``President Flip-Flops on Tax Deal'' said The Herald-Leader of Lexington, Ky. ``Bush Flips on Taxes'' said the Philadelphia Daily News. A smattering of other read-my-flip headlines from the Wednesday's papers: -``Bush Fickle on Raising Taxes on Rich.'' (Arkansas Gazette of Little Rock). -``Bush Zigzags on Higher Taxes for Wealthy.'' (The American-Statesman of Austin, Texas). -``President Agrees to Tax Wealthy - Then Backs Off.'' (The Seattle Post-Intelligencer). ``Bush Switches Sides on Tax Tradeoff - Twice.'' (The Kansas City Star). -``Bush Hastily Retreats on Income Tax-Capital Gains Deal.'' (The Des Moines Register.) -``Bush Leaves 'Em Guessing on Tax Hike.'' (The Atlanta Journal). -``Bush Backs Away from Tax on Rich'' (The Wyoming Eagle of Cheyenne.) -``Bush Wavers on Higher Tax for Wealthy'' (The Sun-Sentinel of Fort Lauderdale, Fla.) -``Prez Is Yes-&-No on Tax Hike'' (The New York Daily News). No one, of course, knows what was in the president's mind. But maybe, just maybe, he composed a headline of his own: Tomorrow Is
Another Day

DOC.HEAD: Police Officer Starts Somber Reading of List of Crash Victims
DOC.TEXT: A police sergeant on Wednesday began the somber roll call of the 270 people who died in the terrorist bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 over Scotland. In a silent courtroom virtually empty of spectators, Sgt. David Johnston began listing in alphabetical order the fate of each victim and where their bodies were found as documented by investigators and pathologists. All 259 people aboard the Boeing 747 died when it exploded over the nearby town of Lockerbie on Dec. 21, 1988. Eleven people in that Scottish town were also killed in the crash. Johnston, of Strathclyde police, told the first public hearing into the crash that he arrived in Lockerbie on Christmas Day to work with a unit collating information on the dead. The first name on his roll call was John Michael Gerard Ahearn, 26, a government bonds broker who lived in Rockville Center, N.Y. In a process lasting six minutes, Johnston told the court how the young American had been sitting in seat 30C in the economy class area. His body was found the day after the crash on the Lockerbie golf course. A postmortem exam put the cause of death as multiple injuries. Johnston said Ahearn was identified by dental records. The sergeant then continued with the list. The roll call is expected to take several days. Earlier, Johnston told how 17 victims, 10 passengers and seven Lockerbie residents, were officially registered as ``missing presumed dead.'' Most of the missing passengers were sitting in the fuel-laden wing section that crashed in a fireball in the Sherwood Crescent section of town, damaging or destroying about 20 homes. The missing local residents were from those homes. Several dozen bags of unidentified human remains and two bodies that could not be identified were cremated, police said. Johnston said for each casualty, a ``victim pack'' was compiled, listing all documentary material relating to their death. The officer also produced maps showing the location of each body and described how the victims were identified by several means, mainly dental records and fingerprints. Some were identified by distinctive features like tattoos. Two victims were identified by next of kin who were members of the medical profession. The officer described how police obtained proof that those missing had joined the doomed flight, in some cases recovering personal documents like driving licenses from the debris. The inquiry is focusing on the causes of death and airport security, but not criminal responsibility. Scottish police say they are investigating several radical Palestinian groups and Fraser has said he believes the bombers will be caught.

DOC.HEAD: United Nations Launches Big Aid Program to Help Angolans
DOC.TEXT: The United Nations is launching a relief program this month to feed more than 1 million Angolans suffering from drought and a debilitating civil war, the U.N. coordinator in Luanda said Wednesday. It is the first time the United Nations has gotten clearance to distribute food throughout the country from Angola's Marxist government and from the rebel army that has been fighting for 15 years, said U.N. Luanda coordinator Otto Esseien. The United Nations plans to distribute about $60 million in food, clothing, drinking water and vaccines to Angola the next six months, he said. Official estimates of Angolans in need of disaster relief vary from 500,000 by official count to 2 million, according to international organizations. Angola's population is 10.5 million. A severe drought has affected the country since last year. Aid initiatives have been stymied by government fears that food convoys would be used to smuggle arms to the rebels of the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola. UNITA, as the rebel force is known by its Portuguese acronym, was concerned the government would block shipments to the areas it controls, mostly in the southern and eastern parts of the country. Government and rebel delegations met last month in Portugal, with U.S. and Soviet observers, to negotiate a cease-fire. The two sides agreed to further peace talks later this month. Both sides have withdrawn their objections to the relief deliveries and vowed not to attack aid convoys, Esseien said. But he acknowledged, ``The whole operation is costly, complex and risky.'' The aid shipments will reach Angola through the port of Lobito, in the southern province of Benguela, and through two points on the Namibian border. The convoys will have no military escort. The rebels dominate most of Cuando Cubango, a southeastern province bordering Namibia, where the threat of starvation is said to be gravest. Government officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, say more than 30,000 people have died of starvation this year in Angola. UNITA has been fighting the Soviet-backed government since it took power in 1975 after the war of independence with Portugal. The war has left this resource-rich country in a state of ruin. It has claimed more than 340,000 lives, left 50,000 people maimed and hundreds of thousands homeless, according to official figures. The relief program will be one of the largest the United Nations has undertaken in Africa since its aid to hunger-stricken Ethiopia in the early 1980s, Esseien said. Unrest over food shortages has mounted in Luanda, the capital, since the government last month imposed an economic austerity package. The package replaced Angola's currency with a new unit, the New Kwanza, devalued it 50 percent and froze most cash in circulation. The government promised to fill official stores with food but supplies have been slow to arrive. Tension peaked Tuesday when 3,000 shipyard workers in Luanda refused to work all morning to protest the reforms, which left them without coins and small bank notes for shopping.

DOC.HEAD: Tropical Storm Hits Florida, Snow and Rain From Wisconsin to Illinois
DOC.TEXT: Record low temperatures hit parts of Texas on Wednesday, snow fell around the Great Lakes and a tropical storm raked southern Florida with wind-driven rain. Snow mixed with rain and occasional thunderstorms fell during the afternoon from Wisconsin across northern Illinois, and central lower Michigan. About 2 inches of wet snow broke tree limbs and power lines near Freeport, Ill., the National Weather Service said. Two inches of snow fell at Madison, Wis. Snow accumulated during the morning in Montana on a highway between Marias Pass and Shelby, and advisories were posted for hazardous driving conditions caused by snow on a highway north of Browning, Mont. Chilly air spilled southward across the Plains and record lows in Texas were 45 at Austin, a tie; 42 at Bryan-College Station; 38 at Midland; 36 at San Angelo; 43 at San Antonio, a tie; and 38 at Wichita Falls, a tie. Record lows elsewhere were 21 at Duluth, Minn.; 32, a tie, at Kansas City, Mo.; 37, tie, at Pueblo, Colo.; and 44, tie, at Redding, Calif. Florida Gulf Coast residents kept a wary eye on a weak Tropical Storm Marco as it moved up the edge of the Florida peninsula with 40 mph wind, heavy rain and erosive tides. By early afternoon, Miami already had 4.5 inches from Marco and the Atlantic remnants of Tropical Storm Klaus, which was absorbed when its much stronger cousin formed Wednesday north of Cuba. Elsewhere, rain and thunderstorms extended across southern Michigan, parts of Indiana, Ohio, central Kentucky, central Tennessee, North Carolina, South Carolina and Georgia. Heavier rainfall during the six hours up to 2 p.m. EDT included 1.06 inches at Waycross, Ga.; 1.40 at Columbia, S.C.; 1.03 at Atlanta; 1.30 at Savannah, Ga.; 1.26 at Fort Stewart, Ga.; 1.25 at Sumter, S.C.; 1.20 at Brunswick, Ga.; 1.14 at Charleston, S.C.; and 1.14 at Valdosta, Ga. Wednesday low for the Lower 48 states was 16 at Gunnison, Colo. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 33 at Wausau, Wis., to 94 at San Diego, Calif.

DOC.HEAD: Senate OKs German Unification Pact
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 10th graf, bgng: Senate Minority xxx to CORRECT Dole quote; SUBS 14th graf, bgng: Aside from xxx to reflect unification of Germany.
DOC.TEXT: The Senate on Wednesday overwhelmingly approved a treaty formally ending the post-World War II division of Germany, with wary members suppressing concerns about yesteryear's aggressor in the interest of advancing the cause of European democracy. ``We welcome the German people, as a whole, back to the fraternity of civilized nations,'' exclaimed Sen. John Heinz, R-Pa. Voting a week after unification, senators also made clear that nothing in the treaty's ratification should be construed as tacit U.S. acceptance of the Soviet Union's postwar annexation of the Baltic nations of Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania. The treaty, signed in Moscow Sept. 12 by Britain, France, the Soviet Union, the United States and East and West Germany, now goes to President Bush for his signature. It relinquishes all American rights and responsibilities over Germany and lifts Soviet, French and British controls over the country as well. ``A unified Germany is something I look at with some concern,'' said Sen. Rudy Boschwitz, R-Minn., who fled Berlin during his childhood. ``I intend to vote for this resolution. Nothing should stand in its way. But a sense of the history of Central Europe and a sense of the history of the world should be stated on the Senate floor ... so that Germany will remember that we will be watchful.'' ``The millennium has not yet come,'' said Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., echoing several senators' statements of concern about the peaceful intentions of a unified Germany. Sen. Paul Simon, D-Ill., said he supported the treaty and said he had been assured by Secretary of State James A. Baker III that it was understood the accord did not override longstanding U.S. policy against recognizing the Soviet annexation of the Baltic states. ``We must now focus our attention and our energy on the challenges of the future, not the legacy of the past,'' said Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine. ``This treaty is of historic importance,'' he said. ``It marks the end of an era. It puts behind a century of conflict or potential conflict at the center of the earth - a century that witnessed the ravages of two wars.'' Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., said the treaty ``does not exact the price of German sovereignty for German unification. ... All freedom-loving people of the world have won.'' The treaty was approved 98-0, with Sens. Mark Hatfield, R-Ore., and Pete Wilson, R-Calif., not voting. The ``Big Four'' powers already had agreed to suspend their rights Oct. 1, in time for the reunification to go forward. After the defeat of Nazi Germany, the four allies divided the country and its capital into four occupation zones, which became East and West Germany and East and West Berlin. Aside from ending the division of the country, the treaty calls on the Soviet Union to complete the withdrawal of its estimated 370,000 troops from what was East Germany by 1994. U.S., British and French troops will remain in Berlin during the interim. In sending the treaty to the Senate, President Bush had said it ``clears the way to achievement of the goal we Americans have long shared with the German people: a united, democratic and sovereign Germany.''

DOC.HEAD: Barbara Boggs Sigmund, Mayor of Princeton, Dies At 51
DOC.TEXT: Barbara Boggs Sigmund, the colorful and eloquent Princeton mayor who lost to Gov. Jim Florio in last Democratic gubernatorial primary, died Wednesday at age 51. Mrs. Sigmund was the daughter of U.S. Rep. Lindy Boggs, a Democrat from New Orleans, and the late Hale Boggs, who was the House majority leader and had been slated to become speaker when he was killed in a 1972 plane crash. Mrs. Sigmund, who died at home, had been suffering from a recurrence of a cancer that first struck her in the early 1980s. That cancer, a malignant melanoma, forced the removal of her left eye in 1982. After the loss of her eye, Mrs. Sigmund made a trademark of her collection of fashionable eye patches, which were always coordinated with the color of her outfits or of holiday symbols. As a campaign gimmick during the primary, she distributed eye patches to businessmen, lobbyists and politicians. Late last year, she announced the melanoma had reappeared and had spread. Mrs. Sigmund ran unsuccessfully U.S. Senate in 1982 and was elected mayor of the hometown of Princeton University in 1984. She was expected to run for Congress if Republican Rep. James Courter's bid for governor was successful and his seat became available. Courter lost but by the time he announced that he would retire from Congress, she was again battling cancer. ``Her death marks the end of a life that was dedicated to excellence and compassion,'' Florio said. ``She used her many gifts to the fullest. And in doing so, she touched many hearts and made her home in Princeton, as well as this state, a better place for everyone.'' Former Gov. Thomas H. Kean called Mrs. Sigmund ``a woman of remarkable courage, who kept through a difficult time with a sense of perspective and humor.'' U.S. Sen. Frank Lautenburg, who defeated Mrs. Sigmund in the 1982 Democratic primary, read a tribute into the Congressional Record on Wednesday. ``Everyone who knew Barbara was enriched by their association with her,'' said Lautenburg. ``She was a unique individual who had an abundance of wit, knowledge, charm and character.'' Mrs. Sigmund was born in New Orleans on May 27, 1939. At age 12, she proclaimed that her lifelong ambition was to run for Congress. Nine years later, she was president of the student body at Manhattanville College in New York, where she received a degree in governmental studies. Her gubernatorial primary campaign was short on cash, but Mrs. Sigmund charmed crowds with her wit, saying she wanted to be New Jersey's first ``governess.'' Of Florio, who at the time was a congressman, Mrs. Sigmund said: ``It's always good to have a man around the house. Let's keep him there.'' She finished a surprising second in the three-candidate race. Mrs. Sigmund pushed for social programs, including low-income housing, and criticized what she said was a lack of planning in many of the state's corporate park sprawls. She is survived by her husband, Paul, a professor of Latin American studies at Princeton University and three sons. She also is survived by a sister, Cokie Roberts a correspondent for National Public Radio and ABC News, and a brother, Thomas Hale Boggs, a Washington lawyer. Funeral services were scheduled for Saturday at the Princeton Universty Chapel.

DOC.HEAD: Portugal Confirms It Sold Uranium to Iraq
DOC.TEXT: The government said Wednesday that Portugal had sold Iraq uranium concentrate, a material that could be used to produce nuclear weapons. The Ministry for Industry and Energy said the government sold 252 tons of the concentrate to the Iraqi Atomic Energy Commission from 1980 to 1982. It said no sales were made after 1983. Under the contract, Iraq agreed to use the uranium for purely peaceful ends and abide by the nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty, the ministry said in a statement. A ministry spokesman said the concentrate sold to Iraq was not the enriched variety that can be used directly in nuclear weapons. The government was responding to a report in a Spanish newspaper that said Portugal had exported 1,189 tons of uranium from 1980 to 1988. The report said much of the uranium was purchased by Iraq. It suggested Iraq could have used the material to produce nuclear weapons.

DOC.HEAD: Government to Arm Citizenry in Case of Israeli Attack
With AM-Israel, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Jordan is discussing plans to arm and train a civil guard to help the army fight any potential Israeli attack, Parliament Speaker Suleiman Arar said Wednesday. Arar told 3,000 demonstrators gathered to protest the Monday killings of 19 Palestinians in Israeli-occupied east Jerusalem that Prime Minister Mudar Badran has accepted a request from Parliament to arm a citizen's militia. An official in the Prime Minister's office said the government would meet next Tuesday to discuss the implementation of the plan. Yaqoub Qirrish, a member of Parliament, said the plan would probably involve storing weapons at local police stations for use by civilians in emergencies. Moslem fundamentalists as well as left-wing political parties and Palestinian factions have been asking the government for 20 years to train and arm citizens as a second line of defense against Israel. The groups have expressed increased fears that Israel might attack Jordan and expel Palestinians in the occupied West Bank to Jordan to create an alternative Palestinian homeland. Palestinians comprise about half of Jordan's population of 3.4 million. ``We have met the Prime Minister and convinced him of the need to arm people. He agreed and said the decision will take effect in three days,'' Arar told the protesters outside his Parliament office. ``The government has promised to respond to the armament request, but it is going to be within limited and narrow limits,'' said an official in Badran's office, who did not elaborate. ``Our financial situation does not permit us to buy arms for all the people of Jordan,'' he said, citing the country's $8.3 billion foreign debt. The official, insisting on anonymity, said Badran and Parliament agreed to ``meet Tuesday to put forward a plan crystalizing these armament ideas.'' He said King Hussein might preside over the closed-door meeting. In 1970, an estimated 20,000 Palestinian were killed during a civil war that pitted King Hussein's largely Bedouin army against Palestinian factions. Since the fighting the government has refused requests to arm citizens. Israel seized the West Bank from Jordan in the 1967 Middle East war, prompting a mass flight of refugees to Jordan.

DOC.HEAD: Fire on Offshore Rig Injures Six
DOC.TEXT: Workers surveyed damage Wednesday on the offshore oil production platform that caught fire overnight and injured six of the 84 people aboard. ``We have made an inspection and are trying to piece together exactly what happened,'' said Jay Cheatham, vice president and southeastern district manager for Arco Oil & Gas Co. He said it was too soon to know what caused the 45-minute fire, and he offered no timetable for resuming production. The platform, owned by Arco and producing 15,000 barrels of crude a day, sits six miles out in the Gulf of Mexico, near the mouth of the Mississippi River, about 100 miles southeast of New Orleans. Workers escaped in a life raft and an emergency capsule, said Earl Simms, an Arco spokesman in Dallas. He said none had to jump into the sea. Five of the six injured men were admitted to hospitals, where all but one were listed in stable to good condition. Mitchell Ham, 28, of Columbia, Miss., was in critical condition with second and third-degree burns, said West Jefferson Medical Center spokesman Jim Pittman. A ivilian company was handling pollution cleanup, Coast Guard Petty Officer Dennis Schaefer said. ``The boats were shooting water on the fire, and probably there was a little bit of oil that washed over as a result of that, but as far as we know there's no spill coming from the platform,'' Cheatham said.

DOC.HEAD: Parisian Freezes to Death While Meditating in the Nude
DOC.TEXT: A music teacher from Paris froze to death on Mont Blanc while meditating in the nude, police said Wednesday. The body of Ghislaine Sanchez, 37, was found Sunday near a glacier at 6,000 feet that had been whipped by rain and strong winds, police said. A mountain patrol had encountered Ms. Sanchez meditating nude on the mountain on Sept. 23, police said. She was brought down to the resort town of Chamonix for treatment of hypothermia. Doctors in Chamonix said Ms. Sanchez apparently was practicing one of the forms of meditation originating in Japan and Tibet that involve exposure to extreme cold. She was the 40th person to die this year on the 15,781-foot Mount Blanc, the highest mountain in the Alps.

DOC.HEAD: Party Retreats Further from Its Leading Role
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with Gorbachev quotes, moves to fight black market, details. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said Wednesday he wants to crack down on the black marketeering that has spread rapidly as the Soviet leadership hesitates between a centrally planned and a market economy. In his speech at the closing session of a Communist Party Central Committee meeting, Gorbachev, the party leader as well as president, signaled a strong assertion of his enhanced executive powers. He also emphasized that economic reform plans would not call for a ``restoration of capitalism,'' indicating a possible step away from the radical steps at which central Communist authorities have balked over the past year. The party itself retreated further from its vanguard role by announcing it was cutting its headquarters staff from 1,493 to 536 people and refraining from making key decisions on national economy. The actions appeared in line with Gorbachev's proclaimed intention of transferring power to elected legislative and executive bodies. The Soviet Union seems to be sinking into chaos, however. The party - which with 18 million members is by far the largest organization in the country - is deeply divided over Gorbachev's policy of perestroika. The legislature has been unable to agree on a plan to move the nation to a market economy. Two weeks ago it gave Gorbachev sweeping powers to carry out reforms. Gorbachev told the meeting Wednesday that by week's end, he will propose to the Supreme Soviet legislature ``tough measures that will represent a powerful weapon in the hands of law enforcers and authorities.'' His proclaimed ``allegiance to the socialist idea'' and call for a war on speculation and black marketeering appeared to reflect a conservative backlash against the halting steps authorities have taken toward a market economy. Law enforcement officials have complained the state businesses that dominate the economy have not been fulfilling their obligatory delivery quotas to other state enterprises, and that the goods are being sold instead on the black market. Gorbachev issued a decree on Oct. 4 authorizing fines against businesses that fail to fulfill state orders. His new proposals would enforce that decree. He said a reform package he is assembling will include a mixture of state and privately owned businesses, and rental of some government-owned properties to entrepreneurs. ``I resolutely reject efforts to proclaim the transition to the market as a restoration of capitalism,'' he said. He predicted the people will support his tough measures against trade outside the state sphere. Under his supervision, a parliamentary commission is trying to meld radical and moderate proposals to move toward a market economy, private industry and decollectivized agriculture. A party source, speaking on condition of anonymity, predicted Gorbachev would take steps ``to control democracy in order to preserve the democratic reforms'' he has taken. Deputy party chief Vladimir Ivashko told reporters Wednesday the 400 Central Committee members were ceding economic responsibility to the Supreme Soviet, saying: ``It would be wrong if the plenary session of the Communist Party Central Committee turned into an affiliate of the Supreme Soviet and started competing on various aspects of a particular program. Our task is to determine political aspects of this very difficult process.'' The situation has been complicated by shortages of food and other basics and by resolutions by nearly all 15 Soviet republics, including the Russian Federation, declaring various forms of independence and sovereignty. If radical economic reforms take place, the secretariat staff reduction could foreshadow sharp reductions in the number of employees in the central ministries which now own nearly all Soviet businesses. Last year, the secretariat let go about 500 workers. Western diplomats and experts have predicted that sudden displacement of an elite that once ran the country could add momentum to a possible conservative backlash. The state news agency Tass carried excerpts of Gorbachev's remarks, which Pravda editor Ivan Frolov told reporters would be carried by the party newspaper Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Nine Countries, including Libya, Forge Mediterranean Grouping
DOC.TEXT: Nine Western European and North African countries, including Libya, forged a regional grouping Wednesday to promote stability and economic development in the Mediterranean region. They agreed to develop close political, economic and cultural ties with the aim of turning the Western Mediterranean into ``an area of peace, cooperation and stability.'' They also pledged to work toward the convening of an international conference on peace and security in the region. The initiative was launched by Italy, France, Spain, Portugal, Libya, Algeria, Tunisia, Morocco and Mauritania. Libya has often been accused of supporting international terrorism. The New York Times reported Wednesday that Libyan intelligence agents may have played a role in the 1988 bombing of a Pan Am flight over Lockerbie, Scotland. An Italian Foreign Ministry spokesman said the issue of terrorism was not raised Wednesday. In a joint declaration, the nine countries said their initiative was designed to prevent ``marginalization'' of the Arab nations on the Mediterranean's southern shore. ``The great current divide between the level of development in the north and south of the Mediterranean has introduced imbalances causing grave dangers for the stability and well-being of the whole region,'' it said. The nine backed in principal a proposal launched last month by Spain and Italy for a Conference on Security and Cooperation in the Mediterranean.

DOC.HEAD: Wrong Computer Instructions Were Given to Discovery Before Liftoff
With AM-Space Shuttle, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Space shuttle Discovery was launched with incorrect instructions for how it should operate some of its computer programs, a NASA official said Wednesday. The mistake never posed a threat to the shuttle or its five-man crew, said Milt Heflin, lead flight director for the mission. ``This was serious,'' Heflin said. ``But it didn't hurt anything.'' The crew noticed the error on a computer display screen about one hour after Discovery was launched Saturday from Cape Canaveral, Fla., and quickly corrected it, Heflin said by phone from Johnson Space Center in Texas. Even if the crew hadn't discovered the error, automatic safeguards on Discovery would have prevented any problem, he added. Nevertheless, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration will write an ``anomaly report'' on the incident and investigate to determine the cause of the error and to prevent it from happening again, Heflin said. Discovery landed safely in California on Wednesday after a four-day flight highlighted by the launch of the Ulysses space probe, which will study the sun's polar regions in 1994 and 1995. Heflin said the error was made before launch, but was discovered when the five astronauts were converting the shuttle's five onboard computers from launch operations to orbital operations. To do that, the astronauts call up pre-loaded instructions on computer screens. After checking the instructions, they give a command that has each computer follow the instructions. As planned, computers No. 3 and 5 were shut off and computers No. 1 and 2 followed instructions that made them guide, navigate and control the shuttle. Computer No. 4 is used for ``housekeeping'' tasks, including monitoring Discovery's propulsion, electrical and life-support systems, including temperature and pressure. But Heflin said that when the astronauts called up the computerized display showing the instructions for computer No. 4, they found the display screen had been incorrectly loaded with instructions intended for computer No. 2. Because of built-in safeguards, the wrong instructions ``wouldn't have gone anywhere,'' he added. Heflin said the computer program for the shuttle's housekeeping functions started operating when the astronauts fixed the error, but would have automatically done so anyway because the wrong instructions would have been rejected. The mistake is considered serious, Heflin said, because ``if we erred in some procedures on the ground, why did we not catch it?''

DOC.HEAD: Irene Mayer Selznick Dies at 83
DOC.TEXT: Irene Mayer Selznick, who spent half her life as a member of two film dynasties before creating her own legend as Broadway producer of ``A Streetcar Named Desire'' died Wednesday. She was 83. Mrs. Selznick died at the Pierre Hotel, where she had an apartment overlooking Central Park, said William Hartgrave, night manager of the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel. Mrs. Selznick, who was born in New York City and spent part of her childhood in Boston, was the daughter of the powerful and tyrannical movie mogul Louis B. Mayer. As head of production at Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Mayer was the most important filmmaker in Hollywood during the 1920s and 1930s. When she met the young studio executive David O. Selznick at age 19, she found a man who matched her father in strength, power and influence. She married Selznick, who went on to become one of the most successful film producers of his time, producing such classics as ``Gone with the Wind.'' As a child, she was taught to prepare for life as a conventional wife and mother, according to her 1983 memoirs, ``A Private View.'' ``I'd pick up a book,'' she said during a 1983 interview, ``and my father would say `she knows too much already.''' As the mother of two boys, Mrs. Selznick led a traditional life with David Selznick until the marriage broke up in 1948. The split came in part because of Selznick's affair with actress Jennifer Jones, whom he later married. Selznick died in 1965. After the divorce, Mrs. Selznick moved back to New York and became a Broadway producer, beginning with ``A Streetcar Named Desire.'' In a battle with the play's director, Elia Kazan, she once yelled, ``I've survived Louis B. Mayer and I've survived David O. Selznick. It's no use. You better lay off.'' Kazan did. Mrs. Selznick also produced a string of Broadway hits such as ``Bell, Book and Candle,'' ``The Complaisant Lover,'' and ``The Chalk Garden.'' Survivors are sons Lewis and Daniel Selznick. Funeral arrangements were pending.

DOC.HEAD: Supreme Court Won't Hear Keating Appeal
DOC.TEXT: The California Supreme Court declined Wednesday to hear an appeal by jailed financier Charles H. Keating Jr. who seeks reduction of his $5 million bail on fraud charges. Keating's lawyers sought a hearing from the San Francisco-based high court after a state appeals cour rejected a request for bail reduction. Keating, 66, an Arizona developer and chairman of American Continental Corp., the parent of Irvine-based Lincoln Savings & Loan, has been jailed in Los Angeles since his indictment last month. He is accused of fraud in selling American Continental junk bonds to investors at branches of Lincoln Savings, misleading investors about their security. Keating contends he can't adequately defend himself if he remains jailed. At a hearing last week, Keating declared he was ``absolutely not guilty'' of the charges against him. A pretrial hearing is scheduled Monday. Stephen C. Neal, Keating's main attorney, has said he would pursue every avenue to get Keating out of jail. The next appeal would be to a federal court. Neal didn't immediately return telephone calls Wednesday after the state Supreme Court issued its decision. Keating and three co-defendants surrendered to face a 42-count state grand jury indictment on Sept. 18. Superior Court Judge Gary Klausner set Keating's bail at $5 million and held the other defendants on $1 million bail. The judge later reduced the co-defendants' bail to $100,000 or $200,000 and they were released. Klausner refused to lower Keating's bail, saying the possibility of 10 years in prison made him a flight risk. Sandi Gibbons, spokeswoman for District Attorney Ira Reiner, said the Supreme Court's ruling was ``not unexpected to us.'' Reiner has acknowledged the $5 million bail was unusually high, but has said he believes Keating might try to flee the jurisdiction if released on bail.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Bans Wheat for Sudan Until Relief Goes to Rebels
DOC.TEXT: No more U.S. wheat will go to war-torn Sudan until the government lets relief move to areas held by rebels, the U.S. Agency for International Development said Wednesday. ``Several weeks ago the Sudanese government imposed a freeze on all food grain within the country,'' said John Metelsky, an agency spokesman. ``This prevented the moving of 35,000 tons of relief grain already in Sudan. ``The United States can send no more wheat until relief can move freely throughout the country and other obstacles for the distribution of relief can be overcome.'' Relief centers had been bombed and relief flights grounded, he added. Last Saturday United Nations officials in New York said Sudan had lifted its ban on relief flights to rebels in the southern part of the country. Last month, U.S. officials accused Sudanese president Omar el-Bashir of ordering an air raid on a grain barge at the same time he was seeking $150 million in additional U.S. food aid. Metelsky said 45,000 tons of wheat from the United States intended for commercial sale in Sudan had been stopped but that famine aid had not been cut off. He emphasized that the U.S. agreement to deliver $20 million worth of wheat had not been cancelled. ``We are ready to reschedule delivery when Sudan meets the conditions of the agreement,'' he said. He noted that the United States had supplied $51.3 million worth of disaster aid to Sudan in the year that ended Sept. 30. About 5 million people have been hit by drought in the Sudan and 3 to 4 million displaced by civil strife, he said. U.N. officials have predicted that drought could kill a million Sudanese. Civil war has afflicted the country much of the time since it became independent from joint British-Egyptian rule in 1956. ``The message we want to convey is that it will be impossible to meet Sudan's needs unless the government makes and carries through a firm commitment to facilitate the movement of relief food throughout the country,'' including rebel-held areas, Metelsky said.

DOC.HEAD: Ann Richards: Clayton Williams Should Discuss Drug Money Probe
DOC.TEXT: Democratic gubernatorial candidate Ann Richards sought Wednesday to link Republican opponent Clayton Williams to a federal investigation into alleged drug money laundering. Williams press secretary Gordon Hensley accused Richards of ``dealing with unfounded rumors, allegations and innuendos, many of which she generated herself. ... She seems to be losing it by lashing out at Mr. Williams in an irrational manner.'' At a news conference, Richards cited a Houston Chronicle report that said federal agents were investigating allegations against a Houston loan broker, Lloyd G. Williams Jr., who also has done business with ClayDesta National Bank, the Midland bank owned by the GOP nominee. ``I think it is incumbent on Clayton Williams to cooperate with the investigation and tell the voters of Texas what his relationship was with Lloyd Williams,'' Richards said. Hensley said Clayton Williams ``has answered questions in a very forthright manner. He said he does not know the man (Lloyd Williams).'' Lloyd Williams, no relation to the GOP candidate, said Wednesday he had nothing to do with alleged money laundering and that he was puzzled by the inquiry. He also said he didn't know Clayton Williams and only met him once, at a fund-raising event last spring. Lloyd Williams told the Chronicle he had acted as an FBI ``operative'' for more than 10 years. ``Why they are now coming at me, I don't know,'' he said. Richards suggested that the investigation may be why Williams won't debate her. ``I think it is very likely, considering the recent press we've seen, that there are questions he doesn't want to be asked, that he doesn't want to discuss on television,'' Richards said. Hensley rejected the contention. ``That's not even a factor. Clayton Williams has said he'd be happy to debate Ann Richards if she will go along and pledge to the voters of Texas that she will refrain from additional negative TV advertising,'' he said. The Chronicle reported this week that Lloyd Williams' primary source of income comes from working with auto dealers to arrange financing for car buyers with credit problems. Last June, Lloyd Williams began arranging such loans through ClayDesta National, the newspaper reported. The Chronicle said investigators are looking into alleged laundering of drug proceeds through Fallbrook National Bank and Columbia Savings, both closed last year by federal regulators. Richards said ``the question remains'' whether the alleged laundering extended to ClayDesta and may have tainted Clayton Williams' campaign money. Laundering is the process in which large amounts of cash generated by illegal activities are passed through legitimate transactions to make it hard to trace or confiscate. Banks willing to risk taking large cash deposits without asking too many questions can profit if they invest or lend the money at higher interest rates than they pay the depositors. Richards aide Bill Cryer said Lloyd Williams had done some $13 million worth of business through ClayDesta. ``The bank was losing money until Lloyd Williams started his loan scheme,'' Cryer said. Hensley insisted the Richards campaign was engaged in ``gutter'' politics and there were no improprieties on the part of Clayton Williams. ``He knew that ClayDesta Bank was involved in loaning money for homes and cars, as all banks are,'' Hensley said. But a bank's owner isn't always familiar ``with specific individuals involved tangentially in setting up loans,'' Hensley said.

DOC.HEAD: Democrats Say Bush's Stance on Taxes Clouds Budget Deal Prospects
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS new grafs 21-22: ``Dole said,'' with Dole saying package should exclude capital gains cut
DOC.TEXT: Confusion over President Bush's position on higher taxes slowed congressional efforts Wednesday to start work in earnest on a new budget agreement. Bush showed no inclination to clarify matters, saying, ``Let Congress clear it up.'' Congressional Democrats complained that an apparent Bush rejection of higher taxes on the wealthiest Americans - a reversal of the position he took at his news conference Tuesday - would make it tougher to forge a budget compromise. But there was no shortage of options, as both Republicans and Democrats began floating new versions of tax and spending plans on Capitol Hill. Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., and other lawmakers who met with the president Tuesday night said he had not ruled out the tax boost at that private meeting, as reported by Sen. Bob Packwood, R-Ore. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater told reporters that Bush ``listened to'' the GOP lawmakers rather than stating a position. Bush, on a campaign trip in the South, was asked repeatedly about the matter, but turned away the questions with wisecracks. He was asked as he jogged during a break in St. Petersburg, Fla., if he would care to clear up the confusion. ``Confusion?'' he responded. Was he giving up on his long-sought capital gains tax rate cut, the item the Democrats supposedly were to trade for his support of higher income taxes on rich people? ``Read my hips,'' he said, pointing, as he jogged by. Could he clear up his position? ``Let Congress clear it up.'' The Senate Finance Committee indefinitely postponed a meeting at which it was to discuss a budget package written by its chairman, Texas Democrat Lloyd Bentsen, generally in line with the tax trade Bush endorsed at his news conference. ``I had the deal all worked out until the president changes his position on taxes,'' said Bentsen. Across the Capitol, the House Ways and Means Committee adopted a plan on a voice vote written by its chairman, Rep. Dan Rostenkowski, D-Ill. The package was similar to the measure Bentsen's panel had readied, although it would add restrictions on tax deductions available to people earning more than $100,000 annually. It also would add private planes worth more than $100,000 to the list of luxury items subject to a new 10 percent tax, and place a 2-cent-per-gallon tax on petroleum products, excluding home-heating oil. Rostenkowski's measure contained neither higher tax rates on the rich nor a lower capital gains tax. But lawmakers said those items might be added by amendments on the House floor. Facing an Oct. 19 deadline, congressional committees must work out tax and spending details adding up to a $500 billion reduction in the federal deficit over the next five years. Medicare spending is expected to be cut, though not as much as in the budget package rejected by the House last week, and taxes are expected to be increased on such consumer items as gasoline, tobacco and alcohol. Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, said, ``I had hoped for agreement on tax proposals along the lines Sen. Bentsen had indicated a intention to offer and ... the president had indicated an intention to accept. The president's reversal of that position last evening ... requires us to reconsider and attempt to determine how best to proceed.'' Dole said that because of the political uproar they were causing, both a lower capital gains tax and higher rates on the wealthy should be excluded from the package. ``They've become sort of a tar baby,'' he said. ``Let's get this done and get back to deficit reduction.'' The confusion was also exposing rifts among Republican lawmakers. A group of conservative House Republicans put together a deficit-slashing plan of their own, raising the income tax rate on the wealthiest Americans from 28 to 31 percent. It would drop the rate on people who are almost as well-to-do from 33 percent to 31 percent, and not increase the gasoline tax. ``We're delighted to have White House input,'' said Rep. Mickey Edwards, R-Okla., the leader of the group. ``We're not looking to the White House for leadership.'' At day's end Tuesday, GOP senators had visited Bush to tell him they opposed raising taxes on the wealthy even if Democrats would agree to capital gains rate cuts. ``He just acquiesced in it,'' Packwood told reporters afterward. ``I got the impression the president thought that was fine, but I can't point to a definite fact where he said, all right, this is it,'' said Sen. John Chafee, R-R.I. Dole seemed certain: ``He didn't announce his position at all. He didn't acquiesce.'' Sen. John Danforth, D-Mo., suggested, ``Sometimes people hear what they want to hear.'' The visit itself was yet another example of Republican lawmakers' unrest concerning proposed budget deals. A majority of GOP House members went against Bush last week as that chamber voted down the budget agreement worked out by the White House and congressional leaders of both parties. The turmoil on Wednesday was hardly encouraging to efforts to fill in the details of the $500 billion budget package over the next few days and head off a repeat of last weekend's government shutdown. Bush's reported refusal to raise taxes on the rich garnered headlines across the country and struck a nerve among lawmakers. The wealthiest Americans now pay taxes at a 28 percent rate on their top dollar. People who earn slightly less pay 33 percent. Democrats want to boost the top rate to 33 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Letters of Kidnapped Premier Found in Former Terrorist Hideout
DOC.TEXT: Workers restoring an apartment used by the Red Brigades during the 1970s found what appear to be letters written by former Premier Aldo Moro when he was a captive of the terrorists, police said Wednesday. The former Italian premier and president of the Christian Democratic Party was slain May 1978 by his kidnappers in probably the most spectacular action of the once-feared left-wing terrorist group, which has all but disappeared. The letters, two guns and $50,000 in cash had been hidden in a hole in the wall that police missed when they raided the downtown Milan apartment and arrested three Red Brigades members in 1978. Lauro Azzolini, Franco Bonisoli and Laura Mantovani - the three captured at the Via Montenevoso hideout - were among the terrorists who kidnapped Moro in Rome in March 1978, according to trial records. During his captivity, Moro sent numerous letters to his party, his family and leading political figures asking them to negotiate an exchange of ``political prisoners'' with the Red Brigades. Several leaders of the gang were in jail at the time. The government at the time rejected any negotations or prisoner swap. Moro was slain and left in the trunk of a car in Rome. Police chief Achille Serra said 418 sheets of papers, including letters and photocopies, were found in the former Red Brigades hideout, along with a pistol, a submachine gun, 30 detonators and the cash. Serra said some of the letters ``could be attributed to Aldo Moro.'' He didn't elaborate.

DOC.HEAD: Charlotte Rae Plays Beckett's `Happy Days'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: No PMs Planned.
DOC.TEXT: Charlotte Rae doesn't turn Samuel Beckett's ``Happy Days'' into a joke, but in the revival which opened Wednesday at off-Broadway's CSC Theater, she does make the play much funnier than usual. Rae, best known for her work on the television series ``The Facts of Life,'' has a face with seemingly unlimited expressions. When it brightens in expectation and then falls in chagrin or disappointment, it reminds a viewer of the quick, unstudied responses of childhood. One laughs in remembered recognition. ``Happy Days,'' in which the leading character Winnie is buried to her waist in a big clay mound in Act 1 and up to her neck in Act 2, can be seen to mean different things at different viewings. Winnie has a bell for morning wakeup and a bell for night sleep. In between, she isn't striving for major accomplishment. She reaches into a large purse, puts on pink lipstick, squeezes a flat toothpaste tube and brushes her teeth with a ragged brush. The woman proclaims that little things such as an occasional grunt from her old husband, played by Bill Moor, make it a happy day. In this production, a viewer is reminded of a life in retirement. There's a repetition of the daily rituals that promote health and well-being and pass time. There's also a determined effort to keep oneself cheerful. Actresses often play Winnie with gallantry. Rae doesn't stress that; she plays the situation as humorous. And she lets Winnie appreciate some of the humor. Remembering her first kiss, she laughs, then ostentatiously pulls back from the laugh, her mouth turning down. With her clown face, Rae's expressions allow the audience to see even more of the humor of the whole situation than Winnie does. ``Happy Days,'' directed here by Carey Perloff, can become one-dimensional. Rae does not let that happen. She has extraordinary range as an actress and extraordinary dynamic range, making her voice shrill to tender to harsh, frivolously high to wisely deep. ``Mustn't complain. So much to be thankful for,'' she says briskly, curling her voice into a faintly false upbeat tone. She ends Act 1 on a serious note, her eyes amazed and shocked when she has told herself, ``Pray your prayer, Winnie,'' and finds herself unable to pray. In Act 2, moving her mouth and eyes but not swiveling her neck, Winnie's smile is now a frozen grin. She tells a story and frightens herself with it. She shows feelings she didn't exhibit in Act 1 and becomes sarcastic, frustrated, cynical and rueful. More importantly, it takes a greater effort to cheer herself up. Despite the laughs that Rae is able to get out of ``Happy Days,'' Beckett's view of the human condition doesn't make a happy play.

DOC.HEAD: DOT Finishes Work on New Side Crash Standards
DOC.TEXT: The Transportation Department has sent a draft of new auto side impact standards to the White House, a spokesman said Wednesday. The spokesman, Bob Marks, said he had no details on how the standards would work. In any case, the department would make them public only after the Office of Management and Budget finished its review, he said. Marks confirmed a report broadcast by NBC News that the department had finished drafting the new standards. The network said necessary changes in door manufacture could cost an average of $50 per car, or half a billion dollars a year for domestic and import manufacturers, when fully in effect in 1996. The current side impact standard requires doors to be manufactured with guard beams inside, but requires no test. The proposed standard would requires a test for side impact. Cars now must pass a frontal barrier impact test, scored according to notional ``injuries'' received by test dummies in the front seat.

DOC.HEAD: U.N. Approves Poll Watchers for Haiti
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with Haitian officials welcome U.N. action, Communist chief gets presidential nomination, vandalism reported. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: The General Assembly on Wednesday unanimously approved a plan to send poll watchers to Haiti, the first time the world body has agreed to verify an election at the invitation of a member state. Elections for president, the legislature and mayors are set for Dec. 16 in the impoverished Caribbean nation of 5.6 million residents, which long has been plagued by political violence. About 50 U.N. observers will go to Haiti immediately. A second group will follow, bringing the total to ``a few hundred'' poll watchers. In addition, security advisers will help Haitian authorities organize safe and peaceful balloting, according to the resolution, approved by acclamation by the 159 assembly members. The Organization of American States and a group led by former President Jimmy Carter are providing other poll watchers. Since Haiti's independence from France in 1804, dictators have usually ruled. The last attempt at free elections collapsed in November 1987 when ruffians supported by the army shot and hacked to death at least 34 voters. Following December elections, the new president is to be sworn in on Feb. 7, 1991, fifth anniversary of the overthrow of the Jean-Claude ``Baby Doc'' Duvalier dictatorship. Figures linked to the Duvalier dynasty have returned to Haiti in recent months, and were linked to murders there. President Ertha Pascal-Trouillot wrote to Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar on Sept. 14, specifying she did not want peacekeeping soldiers sent and that none of the U.N. advisers would carry firearms. Diplomats, speaking on condition of anonymity, commented that many Haitians regard armed security men as oppressors. Perez de Cuellar says he intends to send 87 U.N. staff members to fill administrative posts, and up to 150 security advisers. During the election he will add 80 election monitors and 100 more staff members. The U.N. operation will be known as ONUVEH, signifying the Spanish phrase for U.N. Observer Group for the Verification of Elections in Haiti. The assembly budgetary committee authorized $6.5 million for the mission. Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot was named provisional president in Haiti on March 13, after military ruler Lt. Gen. Prosper Avril fled during a popular uprising. Political violence has terrorized the population since then. In six days last March, nearly 40 people were killed and dozens wounded in strife said to be provoked by foes of democracy and Avril supporters. Officials in Port-au-Prince, Haiti's capital, welcomed the U.N. action. ``I am very satisfied. This will help enormously to guarantee the credibility of the election process in Haiti,'' said Jean Casimir, secretary-general of the Council of State, a quasi-legislative body that shares power with the provisional president. Although nobody has officially filed, more than 20 presidential aspirants have declared their candidacy. They have until Oct. 16. Communist Party leader Rene Theodore was nominated for president on Wednesday by the leftist Movement for National Reconstruction, an influential organization of public figures. Radio Haiti-Inter reported that vandals broke into two voter registration bureaus and the home of an municipal electoral official Wednesday in Grand Goave. It said the premises were smeared with human excrement. The incident occurred while 28 OAS observers are in Haiti to monitor voter registration, which began Oct. 6 and runs until Oct. 16. On Saturday, vandals used the same tactic on two other registration bureaus in Gonaives, Haiti's second largest city.

DOC.HEAD: ABC, British Agency To Send News to Japanese Network
DOC.TEXT: ABC News and Worldwide Television News said Wednesday they've signed an agreement to provide domestic and international news reports to Fuji TV, Japan's largest commercial network. The deal is the second in two months between U.S. and Japanese networks. CBS and the Tokyo Broadcasting System last month agreed to combine resources and technology for worldwide newsgathering. The CBS contract is exclusive and gives Tokyo Broadcasting the right to air in Japan such programs as ``CBS Evening News'' and ``60 Minutes.'' The ABC-WTN contract with Fuji is non-exclusive, said a spokesman for WTN, a London-based agency serving 1,000 clients worldwide, including CBS and Cable News Network. The Fuji deal doesn't provide for sharing facilities overseas, either, nor give the Japanese company rights to air ABC's regularly scheduled news programs, said Scott Michaelis, WTN's regional executive for North America. Fuji will, however, be allowed to excerpt news reports broadcast on ABC's ``World News Tonight,'' he said. Fuji also will get all of WTN's international news reports under the agreement. ABC, which owns 45 percent of WTN, recently agreed in principle to raise its stake in the company to 80 percent. London-based Independent Television News and Australia's Nine Network would share the remaining percentage.

DOC.HEAD: Poll Shows Lenihan Leading Irish Presidential Campaign
DOC.TEXT: Deputy Prime Minister Brian Lenihan is favored to become Ireland's next president in the Nov. 7 election, according to an opinion poll published Wednesday. The survey shows Lenihan with support of 49 percent of those interviewed. If no candidate wins 50 percent a second round of voting will be held for the largely ceremonial office. Lenihan, 59, is the candidate of Prime Minister Charles Haughey's Fianna Fail Party. Leftist candidate Mary Robinson had 32 percent. Austin Currie of the main Fine Gael opposition party was third with 19 percent. The poll conducted by Market Research Bureau of Ireland for Dublin's Irish Times newspaper surveyed 1,000 voters across the country on Oct. 5-6. The newspaper gave no margin of error.
