It is the first presidential election in 17 years. In previous years, the country's three main political parties agreed on the presidency of Dr. Patrick Hillery, a former finance minister. Hillery is stepping down after 14 years, the maximum term under Irish law.

DOC.HEAD: END HOUSE TEXTILE ROLL CALL - 3 TAKES
Kuwaiti Ambassador Accuses Iraq Of Plunder, Human Rights Abuses
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS grafs 11-12: ``At a,'' comment from Iraqi ambassador
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi soldiers have turned to looting food from Kuwaiti homes and now bar citizens from hospitals, restricting medical care to military personnel, Kuwait's ambassador to the United States said Wednesday. At the same time, Iraqis are stripping the invaded country like a stolen car, removing hospital equipment and even traffic lights and shipping them to Iraq, witnesses said at a hearing of the House Human Rights Caucus. ``Anything which is not nailed down has been taken away,'' as well as some things that are nailed down, said Saud Nasir Al-Sabah, the ambassador. Public buildings, schools and hospitals all have been gutted, he said. But of greater concern are continuing human rights abuses in the country, including torture or summary execution of anyone suspected of sympathizing with Kuwait's exiled leadership, said Al-Sabah and others who have fled the emirate. Al-Sabah also predicted that international sanctions imposed on Iraq after its Aug. 2 invasion will fail because Saddam Hussein's economy is self-sufficient in food. ``I don't believe Iraq in the short or long run will be adversely affected by the sanctions,'' he told the caucus, a loose organization of lawmakers interested in human rights issues. Iraq's border with Jordan remains open to truck traffic, thwarting the trade embargo. And aircraft still land in Amman and transfer their cargos to trucks, a leak in the new United Nations air embargo, the ambassador said. ``Sanctions will not bring Iraq down to its knees and force it out of Kuwait,'' he said. But Al-Sabah declined to publicly state whether he believes the United States should take military action, saying only: ``you can reach your own conclusions.'' He said the embargo was being further undermined by the central banks in other countries who are providing credit lines to Iraq, although he declined to name the countries in a public hearing. ``Saddam Hussein's policy now is to sit tight ... to strengthen his grip on Kuwait and to outlast the patience of the multinational forces,'' Al-Sabah said. ``He hopes to break the alliance, and he believes time is on his side.'' At a news conference in Cambridge, Mass., Iraq's ambassador to the United States said allegations of atrocities in Kuwait were ``a pack of lies.'' The Iraqi ambassador, Mohammed Mashat, said the United States was being influenced by ``Israeli expansionist interests.'' Meanwhile, the leader of the Gulf Cooperation Council, a grouping of oil-rich countries including Kuwait and Saudi Arabia, appealed to U.S. officials on Wednesday to attack Saddam before Kuwait is dismantled. The United States, however, wants a political rather than a military solution to the crisis, said Abdulla Bishara after meeting with Undersecretary of Defense Paul Wolfowitz. ``I appealed to the administration to speed up'' its diplomatic activity, Bishara said in an interview. If diplomacy fails, as it probably will, the United States and its allies should use force against Saddam. ``We demand the liberation of Kuwait at any cost - there should be no compromise with Saddam, no reward.'' Others who have escaped Kuwait since the invasion described to the caucus horrors they had witnessed. Deborah Hadi, an American who is married to a Kuwaiti, said she took a cousin who was in labor to a maternity hospital and encountered a Kuwaiti woman, also in labor, screaming at the front door because she was not allowed to enter. ``When she continued to scream, they put a bayonet through her stomach, pinning her to the wall,'' Hadi testified. Rep. Tom Lantos, D-Calif., said there are reports that Saddam is displacing Kuwait families and moving Iraqi families into their homes with the intent of later holding a plebiscite to legitimize his occupation of the country. ``We all know it might lead to such phony procedures,'' Al-Sabah responded.

DOC.HEAD: State Supreme Court Orders Review of Release of Menendez Tapes
DOC.TEXT: Two brothers charged with murdering their millionaire parents for the inheritance money Wednesday won a rehearing on prosecutors' attempts to use taped conversations the young men had with a psychologist. The state Supreme Court ordered the state Court of Appeal in Los Angeles to review a decision that prosecutors could listen to the tapes and use them as evidence against Eric and Joseph Menendez. The brothers are accused of killing Jose Menendez, 45, and Mary Kitty Menendez, 44, with a shotgun at their Beverly Hills mansion in order to inherit $14 million. Eric, 19, and Joseph, 22, maintain someone else killed their parents on Aug. 20, 1989. Los Angeles Superior Court Judge James Albrecht ruled Aug. 6 that the prosecution was entitled to recordings of the brothers' October and November 1989 sessions with psychologist L. Jerome Oziel. Conversations between patients and therapists during treatment normally are confidential, but can be disclosed in some circumstances when a patient has threatened another person. The prosecution argued that the tapes could be released because Oziel had concluded that the brothers were dangerous and had disclosed disclosed the brothers' statements to others. Lawyers for the brothers argue that Oziel's limited disclosures had taken care of any danger that existed. Leslie Abramson, the attorney for Erik Menendez, said the Supreme Court ruling was gratifying. ``We're not celebrating, but we are relieved that we are getting a full day in court on this issue,'' she said in Los Angeles. The tapes were to have been released to prosecutors and the public Sept. 4, but were sealed last month while the Supreme Court decided whether to grant a new hearing. Psychologists and psychiatrists from as far away as New York had called to get information on the ruling because of the case's potential impact on the issue of medical privacy, Abramson said.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING a0756 to restore writethru designation. ^Racist Defendant in Civil Lawsuit Alleges Government Persecution
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 3 grafs after 18th graf pvs, `Metzger said...,' to UPDATE with more testimony. Note language in 13th graf.
DOC.TEXT: A white supremacist accused of inciting the fatal beating of a black man told jurors Wednesday the $10 million wrongful-death lawsuit against him is government persecution. ``This is a stacked deck. There's no doubt about it,'' Tom Metzger, who is handling his own defense, said during opening arguments. ``Understand that I am a radical figure and I've had to fight the government from the get-go.'' Metzger, 52, of Fallbrook, Calif., is the leader of White Aryan Resistance and a former Ku Klux Klan grand dragon. The lawsuit was filed by Engedaw Berhanu, the uncle of an African man slain by neo-Nazi ``skinheads'' in November 1988. It alleges that Metzger incited the slaying by sending a representative to Portland to preach hate and violence. ``It doesn't have that much to do with Mr. Berhanu,'' Metzger said of the trial. ``This is an insult to my intelligence.'' But attorney Morris Dees, of the Southern Poverty Law Center in Montgomery, Ala., told the Multnomah County circuit jury evidence would link Metzger to the slaying of Mulugeta Seraw. He described Metzger as a ``pathetic'' man whose business is hate and whose agenda is to ``set about training these young skinheads to go out and do violence.'' ``In America, we have the right to hate, but we don't have the right to hurt,'' Dees said. ``We're going to ask you to return a verdict so big, that on the south border of the state of Oregon there's going to be a wall $10 million high that's going to stop Tom Metzger from coming back to this good state.'' Dees said a vice president of White Aryan Resistance met with Portland skinheads minutes before they attacked Seraw, 27, of Ethiopia. In their meeting with WAR Youth vice president Dave Mazzella, the skinheads learned techniques to use in assaulting blacks, Dees said. The three - Kenneth Mieske, Kyle Brewster and Steven Strasser - later pleaded guilty to the attack. Seraw was returning home from a party about the time the meeting ended. ``The three walked out ... and stood on the corner about 100 feet away. Kyle Brewster looked up the street and said, `Hey, I see a nigger. Let's go over there and mess with him,''' Dees said. ``They drove directly up in front of Seraw and his friends. They drove so close these Ethiopians could not go around them. Then they did what they had been taught,'' he said. Seraw was beaten to death with a baseball bat, which ``came down on his head with such force ... it just took the whole top of his head off.'' Metzger said his views are radical, but he denied advocating violence and said his police recor is clean. ``They may not like his views, but they've never ever found Tom Metzger going over the line,'' he said. Metzger said he would not call witnesses to refute the plaintiff's contention that he commands legions because he has no legions. Mieske, who admitting beating Seraw with a baseball bat, testified Wednesday that Mazzella visited him and made a telephone call to Metzger a month before Seraw's slaying. He said he kicked Seraw in the head with a pair of steel-toed boots he bought from another WAR member. Mieske also said that he telephoned Metzger the day he was arrested and spoke to an associate of Metzger several times after he was imprisoned. Also named as defendants in the lawsuit are Metzger's son John, 22, Mieske and Brewster. Mieske was sentenced to life with a 20-year minimum, Brewster to 10 to 20 years and Strasser, who was convicted of beating one of the other Ethiopians, to 20 years.

DOC.HEAD: Kent State President When Students Were Killed Dies at 81
DOC.TEXT: Robert L. White, president of Kent State University when National Guardsmen killed four students during an anti-war protest there in 1970, died Wednesday at age 81. White died at Robinson Memorial Hospital in Ravenna. White was president of Kent State from 1963 to 1971. He was a teacher or administrator there for 44 years until his retirement in 1975. By 1970, five years after U.S. combat troops joined the Vietnam War, anti-war demonstrations were mounting on the nation's campuses. At a protest at Kent State on May 4 of that year, Guardsmen called in by Kent Mayor Leroy Satrom opened fire on demonstrators, killing four and wounding nine. The shootings stunned the nation. A photograph of an anguished 14-year-old girl kneeling over one of the victims came to symbolize the era. White urged protesters and their critics to remain calm. ``I hear lunacy on the one side and frightening repressions on the other and I don't hear from that traditional center position that says, `Let us discuss fully and without limits and let us come to a decision and conclusion within orderly processes which are in themselves subject to orderly change,''' he said at the time. White named a 28-member campus panel to review the shootings and to recommend ways to avoid more violence. He also urged President Nixon to appoint a national panel to look into the causes of unrest at Kent State and other colleges. Nixon did so a month later. White, born in Elgin, Ill., received bachelor of philosophy, master of arts and doctor of philosophy degrees from the University of Chicago and was a member of Phi Beta Kappa, the academic honor society. He taught elementary school in Thornton, Ill., and high school in Chicago and was a principal in Orland Park, Ill., and a visiting associate professor at the University of Chicago. He joined the Kent State staff as dean of the college of education and later became a vice president.

DOC.HEAD: Tories Demand Return of Death Penalty
DOC.TEXT: Delegates to the governing Conservative Party's annual conference, angered by a new IRA offensive and by government failure to stem rising crime, on Wednesday demanded the return of the death penalty. But Home Secretary David Waddington instead promised life sentences that ``in the worst cases will mean life.' Like Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, Waddington supports capital punishment but is regularly outvoted in Parliament. ``This government will not flag in its determination to see that the monstrous evil of the IRA does not prevail,'' Waddington told the 5,000 delegates on the second day of the party's four-day conference in this south England resort. The delegates met under unprecedented security following Irish Republican Army attacks this year which included a July 30 car bomb that killed legislator Ian Gow, a close political aide of Mrs. Thatcher. An attempt was foiled last month to kill a government minister by planting a bomb at a London conference. Mrs. Thatcher, seated alongside Waddington, applauded delegates who urged restoration of capital punishment and demanded tougher anti-crime measures. Britain and most other Western European nations abolished capital punishment in the mid-60s. Attempts to restore it have been regularly defeated in the House of Commons. It is an issue on which legislators are allowed to ``free'' vote - according to conscience and not on party lines. Besides the IRA's bomb and bullet campaign against British rule in Northern Ireland, the issue of civil law and order is among the most sensitive for the Conservatives. Mrs. Thatcher came to power 11 years ago on a platform that included pledges to crack down on crime. But despite a 60 percent increase in spending on police forces, crime rates has risen, including a 17 percent increase in reported crime in the last four months. Riots have also hit British prisons, among the most overcrowded in Europe. Waddington said the government would introduce a 10-year maximum jail sentence for prison mutiny, reduce remissions and parole, and introduce electronic tagging to keep track of people on parole or doing community service sentences.

DOC.HEAD: Boats Hauled in as Storm Climbs Gulf Coast
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with storm picking up strength, expected to hit coast by morning. Pick up 9th graf pvs, `Storm warnings...
DOC.TEXT: Tropical Storm Marco thundered toward Florida's Gulf Coast with increased strength Wednesday evening. Forecasters said the storm could crash ashore by morning. By 10 p.m. EDT, Marco's top winds had increased to 65 mph and the storm had picked up speed, charging north across the Gulf of Mexico at 10 mph, twice as fast as two hours earlier. That could put landfall somewhere in the area between Fort Myers and Sarasota before dawn Thursday, Zimmer said. ``We're prepared, as prepared as we're going to be,'' Sanibel Marina owner Myton Ireland said after hauling nine boats, all 40 feet or longer, onto land. ``If we wait too late and then it blows hard, we're in trouble.'' At 10 p.m., Marco's center was located near 26.2 north latitude, 82.4 west longitude, about 45 miles southwest of Fort Myers. Forecasters said they expected it to maintain its direction. Marco's winds weren't expected to reach the hurricane threshold of 74 mph, said forecaster Bob Case. ``Coastal flooding and beach erosion will probably be the main problem that it will produce,'' he said. ``The further north the system goes, the closer it will get to the coast.'' Marco's southwest winds were expected to push tides 1 to 3 feet above normal, scour the coast's sandy beaches and dump 3 or more inches of rain in some sections. Storm warnings were in effect from the Dry Tortugas through Key Largo, including Florida Bay, and northward along the Southwest Florida coast to Cedar Key at the southern edge of the Big Bend region. All Red Cross chapters on the Gulf Coast from the Keys to Panhandle were on alert and ready to open shelters, said state disaster specialist Karen Wescott. Emergency management planner Don Reed said two shelters were already being opened in Bradenton to house voluntary evacuees from low-lying areas. Marco's wind was expected to push tides 1 to 3 feet above normal, scour the coast's sandy beaches and dump 3 or more inches of rain in some sections. By early afternoon, Miami already had 4.5 inches from Marco and the Atlantic remnants of Tropical Storm Klaus, which was absorbed when its much stronger cousin formed Wednesday north of Cuba, Case said. A houseboat broke its mooring in Miami's blustery Biscayne Bay. It was lassoed at a private dock but broke loose again and the wind pushed it ashore. In the Keys, trucks and vans were advised to stay off the bridges connecting the islands because of gusts. Key West reported wind gusting to 38 mph, and 36-mph gusts were recorded on the reefs off Marathon. Pinellas County, with the county seat in coastal Clearwater, activated its emergency operations center as a precaution because of past experience with unpredictable tropical storms. The state Division of Emergency Management followed suit at its Tallahassee center. Meanwhile, Tropical Storm Lili was racing west across the central north Atlantic at nearly 21 mph, forecasters said. At 6 p.m., the storm had wind up to 65 mph and was centered about 600 miles east of Bermuda, near 31.3 north latitude and 54.5 west longitude. Marco is the 13th named storm of Atlantic season, which runs from June through November. Five have built into hurricanes.

DOC.HEAD: Kansas' First Black Official Honored in Ceremony
DOC.TEXT: The state resurrected the memory of the first black to win a statewide election in Kansas by hanging a portait of Edward P. McCabe in the Capitol Wednesday on the 140th anniversary of his birth. About 500 people gathered in the rotunda as Lt. Gov. Jack Walker hung a portrait of McCabe, who served as state auditor in 1883-87. McCabe is the first black to have his portait among the many that hang in the Kansas Capitol. ``I see how far as black Americans we have to go,'' said Horace Peterson III, the executive director of the Black Archives of Mid-America in Kansas City, Mo. ``We're going to keep on erecting great paintings and statues to our leaders.'' A local activist, Sonny Scroggins, organized the ceremony, which included more than two hours of speeches and music. McCabe, who was born in Troy, N.Y., settled in northwest Kansas in 1878 and was prominent in efforts to bring blacks west. Angela Bates, president of the Nicodemus Historical Society, said McCabe was a strong man who refused to be daunted by prejudice. McCabe ran successfully as a Republican for auditor in 1882, then won re-election in 1884. He later moved to Oklahoma and started a movement to persuade blacks to move west to make it a black state. Although the movement failed, it led to the establishment of several black towns, including Langston, Okla., where historically black Langston University is located. McCabe died in Chicago in 1920.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqis Complain to U.N. about U.S. Actions
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraq complained to the United Nations on Wednesday that Washington has frozen its bank accounts, barred special aircraft flights by its foreign minister, and restricted the movements of Iraqi envoys. Iraqi envoy Adnan Malik did not mention during his appearance before the Committee on Relations with the Host County that the Security Council has denounced Baghdad for violating international law on hostage-taking and for violating the immunity of diplomatic compounds. The U.S. delegate on the committee, James Wilkinson, called the complaints ``misguided and misdirected.'' Malik said the Bush adminstration barred Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz from flying to New York on his special Iraqi Airways plane. He said the flight was needed for security reasons. Wilkinson said U.S. restrictions on Iraqi flights stemmed from the Security Council's economic embargo on Iraq and occupied Kuwait. He said Aziz could have come to New York on any commercial flight, as did 90 other foreign ministers. ``It is ironic that Iraqi should cite security threats as a reason for special arrangements, especially since Iraq increasingly sponsors terrorist groups and their use of the public media,'' Wilkinson said. He said limiting Iraqi diplomats to a 25-mile radius of New York City was appropriate ``in view of the Iraqi government's action not to allow the unrestricted travel of foreign nationals in Iraq.'' Baghdad holds hundreds of Western hostages at strategic sites as ``human shields'' to prevent any U.S. attack in Iraq. Malik said U.S. freezing of Iraqi assets and banks accounts is hindering the work of its U.N. Mission. Wilkinson said Washington would try to work out necessary steps so the Iraqi Mission could continue to function at the United Nations.

Two weeks from the end of its two-year term, the 101st Congress has little to brag about and much to do. The preoccupation with getting a budget has backed up other important legislation on subjects ranging from clean air and housing to civil rights and child care. With anti-incumbent sentiment running high across the country, no member of Congress wants to face voters having done little more than approve job protection rights for the disabled, an inadequate savings and loan bailout and a congressional pay raise. ``It's been a thin session so far, there's no question about it,'' said Thomas Mann, who studies Congress for the Brookings Institution, a Washington think tank. ---= JERUSALEM (AP) - Israel's police minister says he wants an independent probe of the Temple Mount killings, in which troops have been accused of using excessive force in trying to quell a riot by rock-throwing Palestinians. Israel radio said Tuesday night that Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir had agreed to appoint such an investigation team. Israeli security forces killed 19 Arabs and wounded 140 in Monday's clash outside the Al-Aqsa mosque, Islam's third holiest site. It was the bloodiest of a 34-month old Palestinian uprising against Israeli occupation and raised an immediate world outcry. The U.N. Security Council on Tuesday debated a resolution condemning the shootings and President Bush criticized Israeli forces for not acting ``with more restraint.'' ---= WASHINGTON (AP) - The Supreme Court, a day after welcoming Justice David H. Souter to the bench, is taking up a sex bias dispute that could affect millions of working women. The justices were to hear arguments today over the legality of a ``fetal protection'' policy under which an employer excludes all women of childbearing age from some hazardous jobs. The court, expected to be closely divided on the issue, will decide by July whether the policy amounts to illegal sex discrimination. Souter, who sat silently through four cases argued before the court Tuesday, could find himself a pivotal vote in this one. ---= ANCHORAGE, Alaska (AP) - Thousands of bargain hunters snatched up everything from all-terrain vehicles to animal shampoo on the first day of an Alaska-size garage sale offering gear from the Exxon Valdez cleanup. Locals grumbled that out-of-town businessmen with plenty of money in their pockets and a need to justify their jaunts to Alaska helped drive up prices Tuesday. ``It's a feeding frenzy,'' said Butch Johnson, a fisherman in search of nets who lives in the Prince William Sound fishing community of Cordova. Everything on the opening-day block was sold, including a plane, mobile homes, TV sets and cat box filler, used to provide traction on oily beaches. ---= LINCOLN, Neb. (AP) - Republican Gov. Kay Orr and President Bush face the same problem. Both promised they would oppose tax increases, and both went back on their word. In Mrs. Orr's case, the issue could cost her the November election to Democratic challenger Ben Nelson, who has been leading in the polls. After giving voters a no-new-taxes pledge, Mrs. Orr became the first woman governor in Nebraska history and the first Republican woman ever elected to a governorship. Following her 1986 election, she endorsed a 1987 overhaul of the state's income tax system. She then denied for 18 months that it had resulted in a tax increase.

After two months in which military officials marveled at the low rate of accidents among American forces in Saudi Arabia, a sudden spate of air crashes has left four dead and eight missing. The official death toll for Operation Desert Shield rose to 24 on Wednesday when an Air Force F-111 fighter-bomber crashed on a training mission in the Arabian Peninsula, killing both crew members, U.S. military spokesmen said. The plane was the fourth U.S. military aircraft involved an accident in three days. But an Air Force spokesman, Capt. Jack Giese, said there was no single factor linking the crashes. A summary issued by the U.S. Command on Wednesday said 23 Americans had been killed in accidents and one Marine died of a self-inflicted wound since the deployment began following Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. ---= JERUSALEM (AP) - Israel on Wednesday appointed a panel headed by a former spy chief to investigate the killing of 19 Palestinians in a riot on the Temple Mount. It also rejected U.S. charges that police used excessive force. Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's government urged Jews to gather at the Wailing Wall at the end of the religious festival of Sukkot on Thursday in a show of defiance of the Arab stoning attack that prompted the bloodbath. To block further violence, the army kept more than 1 million Palestinians in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip confined to their homes by curfews. In Jerusalem, police fired tear gas to break up at least five protests by Palestinians. In Jordan, protests by thousands of Jordanian and Palestinian university students continued for the third day Wednesday. ---= EDWARDS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif. (AP) - Shuttle Discovery sailed out of orbit and landed Wednesday after a four-day flight that boosted NASA's confidence and sent a spacecraft on a five-year mission to explore the sun's poles. ``If you criticize our mistakes, then you must also acknowledge our successes,'' space shuttle director and former astronaut Robert Crippen said after completion of the first shuttle flight in nearly six months. Discovery's 1.7 million-mile flight was the first since April - the longest gap between shuttle missions since they resumed after the 1986 explosion that destroyed Challenger and killed seven crew members. ---= WASHINGTON (AP) - Three of the Supreme Court's nine justices gave a chilly reception Wednesday to an employer's ``fetal protection'' policy that excludes women of childbearing age from some hazardous jobs. In a case that could affect millions of working women, Justices John Paul Stevens, Sandra Day O'Connor and Antonin Scalia voiced doubts about the wisdom and legality of such a policy. The court is expected to decide by July whether the policy amounts to illegal sex discrimination. The three justices, along with Justice Anthony M. Kennedy, dominated an hourlong argument session. They posed numerous questions to the two lawyers before them, firing their most biting inquiries at Stanley Jaspan, who represented the Milwaukee-based Johnson Controls Inc. ---= BOSTON (AP) - Sit back and enjoy another cup of full-powered, extra-kick caffeinated coffee. A major new study concludes your morning brew is almost certainly harmless to your heart. Decaf, though, may be another story. Contrary to the fears of many doctors and coffee lovers, coffee with a get-you-going jolt of caffeine seems to be perfectly safe, as far as the heart is concerned. However, the study found troubling hints that people who drink lots of decaffeinated coffee may somewhat increase their risk of heart trouble. ``This study means that if there is a hazard with drinking caffeinated coffee, it's going to be very small, and there may be none at all,'' said Dr. Walter Willett, who directed the study at the Harvard School of Public Health. While the wisdom of very high coffee consumption is questionable, several experts agree that three or four cups a day of typical American coffee are safe for virtually everybody, even those with heart disease. ---= WASHINGTON (AP) - Declaring that the time for foot dragging has ended, federal safety officials issued Wednesday a list of 18 ``most wanted'' safety improvements in air, sea and land transportation. The proposed improvements range from development of an air-collision avoidance system to adoption of state laws permitting uniformed police officers to confiscate drivers' licenses on the spot when drivers fail or refuse tests to detect alcohol. The National Transportation Safety Board list seeks to spur movement by regulatory agencies, industries, and state and local governments to implement recommendations made by the board over the last two decades. The safety board has no actual enforcement power. It can only identify possible safety improvements and recommend they be implemented.

DOC.HEAD: Elections Expected to be Costly for Economy
DOC.TEXT: Whether democracy wins or not, this month's elections will be costly for an economy already weakened by higher oil prices, analysts and economists say. ``The losses to the economy may run into billions of rupees in terms of wasteful campaign expenditure and lost business,'' said economist Hussain Mullick. Campaign spending has been estimated at up to $1.35 billion and conducting the elections will cost the government about $15 million. Elections for the National Assembly, the lawmaking lower house of Parliament, are scheduled for Oct. 24. Provincial legislatures in Punjab, Sindh, Baluchistan and Northwest Frontier provinces will be chosen three days later. President Ghulam Ishaq Khan dismissed Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto and dissolved the National Asesembly on Aug. 6. He accusaed Ms. Bhutto's government of plundering the treasury and abusing its constitutional and administrative powers during 20 months in office. The 37-year-old former prime minister and several of her Cabinet ministers face charges before special tribunals. Prime Minister Ghulam Mustafa Jatoi's caretaker government accuses Ms. Bhutto of allowing 20 billion rupees ($900 million) in bank loans to relatives and friends, as political patronage, with little or no collateral. It alleges the Bhutto government spent $30 million for what Ishaq Khan called ``horse-trading,'' to insure victory in a November 1989 no-confidence vote. Ms. Bhutto's Pakistan People's Party and its main opponent, the Islamic Democratic Alliance, are contending for 217 seats in the National Assembly and 483 in the provincial legislatures. ``You need money to throw all around to win a seat, be it money from gun-runners, heroin barons or smugglers,'' said Afzal Sindhu, a leader of her party and a former National Assembly member. He estimated each candidate spent about $114,000 in the 1988 election in addition to money donated by friends and relatives. Most political observers and candidates estimate the cost per candidate this time at about $180,000. The campaign can pump an extra 2.5 billion rupees ($1.15 million) into the economy in less than four weeks, and ``that is a lot of money to push prices up in an economy of a trillion rupees,'' Mullick said. Finance Minister Sartaj Aziz said Pakistan's annual inflation rate was in double digits, and independent economists put it at more than 15 percent. Factories and farms, transport and telecommunications, trade and industry either halt or slow dramatically when millions of workers become preoccupied with rallies and campaigns. Pakistan's economy already suffers from the higher oil prices caused by the Persian Gulf crisis. Aziz said Pakistan uses 180,000 barrels of oil a day, 120,000 of it imported, and ``our oil bill may go up by $900 milllion a year.'' He said Pakistan also was losing $300 million a year from Pakistanis working in Kuwait and Iraq and $100 million in trade. About 85,000 Pakistanis worked in Kuwait and 10,000 in Iraq until the Iraqi invasion of the Persian Gulf emirate on Aug. 2. Nearly 60,000 have been repatriated so far.

DOC.HEAD: Swiss Women Face Prejudice in Army and Jobs
DOC.TEXT: Fifty years after the first women joined Switzerland's army, some old guard commanders still order them to make coffee. The 3,000 women doing military service also risk criticism from family and friends, and prejudice from employers unwilling to give them paid leave for regular refresher training. Brig. Gen. Eugenie Pollack puts discrimination and male chauvinism high on the list of obstacles she has encountered since becoming chief of the Women's Military Service last year. She is a soft-spoken, determined woman who raised eyebrows in conservative army circles this summer by marrying her long-time companion. He is a lawyer who works for environmental causes, she said in an interview at her headquarters in the Swiss capital. Women's reluctance to take the army seriously is more significant than the sexist comments and attitudes, Pollack said, and blamed it for the persistent shortage of women volunteers. If the brigadier had her way, national service would be compulsory for all women in this neutral country, with military and civilian options. ``Every woman should have a certain training,'' she said. ``For example, we should all know how to move into an air raid shelter and how to cope in a disaster. I do not agree that only men should have such education.'' Female volunteers are committed to 117 days of service - four weeks of basic training and refresher courses of two or three weeks over several years. Basic training for male conscripts in the 625,000-man reserve force lasts 17 weeks and overall service totals one year. Women do not receive weapons training, but the government is expected to allow them to carry pistols in the near future for self-defense. Pollack said she favors arming women on a voluntary basis and estimated 50 percent to 70 percent of her volunteers would choose to carry weapons. She added, however, that women never would be used in combat because it would be politically unacceptable and ``there is no need.'' In the past, women soldiers have been confined to medical, clerical or transport jobs, but now they can work in the intelligence service, as trainers of rescue dogs and as chaplains. Male commanders do not always let women fill positions for which they are trained, Pollack said. ``We have had real problems with some commanders who merely sent women to make coffee,'' she explained, and described the attitude as reflective of society in general. Switzerland did not give women the vote until 1971. Much can be learned from other armies, the brigadier said, and she has invited participants from 11 countries to a three-day seminar on integrating women into the armed forces. They include the United States, Canada, Australia, Sweden and Poland. Only about 100 women have volunteered for the army this year, she said, leaving it nearly 1,000 short of the goal of 3,900. The East-West thaw has caused interest to flag and the Persian Gulf crisis seems too distant to have an impact, Pollack said, and added: ``The irony of the whole business is that you almost have to wish for a crisis to attract enough people.'' Switzerland first accepted women into the army in 1940, when it was a neutral island in German-occupied Europe, and there always has been a shortage of volunteers. If the commander had her way, the women's corps ultimately would disappear, because ``being utopian, I would like to see women so integrated that a special female army no longer exists.''

DOC.HEAD: Gambling Sets Utah-Nevada Border Towns Far Apart
DOC.TEXT: A white line across the highway is all that officially comes between Wendover, Utah, and Wendover, Nev. But the neighboring towns are worlds apart - divided by the contrary philosophies of hell-raising Nevada and God-fearing Utah. One Wendover an improbable cluster of watered lawns and neon lights shouting in the lonely sagebrush. Outside the State Line casino, a 64-foot cowboy named ``Wendover Will'' waves his mechanical arms, beckoning travelers to a gambler's paradise. The travelers - most of them from Utah, where gambling is illegal - drop enough dollars in Wendover's six casinos to make the town blossom like a desert rose. Despite Wendover's isolation (Salt Lake City is 120 miles east, Reno 400 miles west), business is booming, population is growing, and new homes are sprouting around the town's new 18-hole golf course. There's little new in Utah's Wendover. Its chief attraction is an abandoned World War II air base with broken windows and empty, echoing hangars. Junk cars rust along gravel side streets, and paint peels from dilapidated cottages. When the wind howls in from the salt flats, the town seems ready to shrivel up and blow away like a tumbleweed. ``We're just like a ghetto,'' said Richard Dixon, a grocer on the Utah side. ``It's the difference between East Berlin and West Berlin - only the wall has neer gone down between Wendover, Utah, and Wendover, Nevada.'' Since 1988, Dixon and other businessmen in Wendover, Utah, (pop. 1,300) have tried to tear down that wall by lobbying for a local exemption from Utah's constitutional ban on gambling. Without gambling, they say, Wendover will die. Since 1985, nearly 200 families have moved to a more prosperous life just over the white line, Dixon said. In the Nevada Wendover (pop. 2,000), schools are better-funded, and there are no state taxes on food or personal income. It's easy to see why a town living in the shadow of ``Wendover Will'' would want a cut of the gambling take. But it's also no surprise that the rest of Utah is cool to the idea. Utah and Nevada share a 340-mile border, an arid climate, political conservatism - and some great differences. Some disparities can be traced to their frontier heritage - to hard-bitten miners who settled Nevada in 1859, lusting after the mother lode; to Mormons who arrived in Utah in 1847, seeking to practice their religion in peace. Nevada celebrates the reckless frontier spirit in casinos and bars that never close. No-wait weddings help produce the highest marriage rate - and highest divorce rate - in the country. Prostitution is legal in 11 counties. Family oriented Utah channels its sexual energies differently, though no less vigorously. It has the nation's highest birth rate, lowest abortion rate, largest median family size, and youngest population. Nevadans say they have more fun, but Utahns live longer. Average life expectancy in Utah is 75.7 years, or three years longer than in Nevada. An insurance company recently ranked the health of states based on levels of smoking, accidents, violent crime, and disease. The results were hardly surprising: Utah was No. 1 for healthy lifestyles; Nevada was 49th. Religion lies at the root of the differences. Utah has more churchgoers per capita than any state, while Nevada ranks 45th. More than two-thirds of Utah residents belong to the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, commonly known as the Mormon Church. Mormon theology considers gambling a forbidden vice, and the state constitution follows suit, banning all games of chance involving money. It is a gauge of Wendover businessmen's determination, then, that their gambling proposal went as far as it did. They won supporting resolutions from city and county authorities in 1988 and even found two state senators - both Mormons - to back a constitutional amendment. That woke up Utah's Mormon-dominated political scene. The church-owned Deseret News, Utah's second-largest newspaper, editorialized against the amendment, and early last year, the bill was unanimously tabled into oblivion by the Senate Business and Labor Committee. ``It's a matter of principle,'' says state Sen. Richard Tempest, who opposed the amendment. ``Nevada has whorehouses. Do we need whorehouses to make a living? Somewhere you have to draw the line. I don't like gambling. It's demeaning and degrading to the human spirit.'' Wendover businessmen promise to keep fighting. They point at the Utah cars streaming across the notorious white line and say SOMEBODY in Utah obviously likes to gamble. But even some gaming Utahns believe that gambling, like a slot-machine handle, is best kept at arm's length. ``I'd just as soon not have gambling in Utah,'' said Mrs. B. Johnson, 65, of Ogden. She was clutching a cupful of nickels in front of a poker-slot machine in the State Line casino. ``I just feel gambling brings a different element into the state.'' Mrs. Johnson wouldn't give her full name. ``I probably shouldn't be here,'' she said. ``I'm a Mormon.'' Glancing around at others feeding the slots, she added, ``But then, I think a lot of them are Mormons, too.'' ---= EDITOR'S NOTE - David Foster is the AP Northwest regional reporter, based in Seattle. End Adv PM Tues Oct. 16

DOC.HEAD: So Many Yuppies, So Few Nannies
DOC.TEXT: You can stamp your feet if you want. You can cry, sulk, even hold your breath until you turn blue. It won't help. There is a nanny shortage afoot, and no amount of parental petulance will ensure that you can hire a nursemaid for your children. ``We can't possibly fill the demand,'' said Cathie Robertson, president of the International Nanny Association and a nanny-training instructor at Grossmont Community College near San Diego. For each trained nanny, 25 to 250 families want one, said Robertson, whose group fields 15 queries daily from parents seeking more than a sitter or day care. ``People are more willing to pay for excellent child care,'' she said. They certainly do pay. Terri Eurich, founder of the National Academy of Nannies Inc. in Denver, last month placed one graduate with a Connecticut family that pays $1,400 monthly. Plus major medical coverage. Including vacation provisions. Also, travel opportunities. ``Those jobs are out there,'' Eurich said. Nationally, average pay ranges from $200 to $300 weekly for trained, live-in nannies hired by couples who, between the two of them, earn at least $80,000 yearly, said Donna Dixon, an associate dean at the Moraine Park Technical College in Fond du Lac, Wis. Nanny educators and placement-agency operators are hardly surprised by the dearth of trained nannies. More than 3.2 million mothers work outside their homes now. The U.S. Labor Department predicts that by 1995, 80 percent of women ages 22 to 44 will work outside the home, representing almost 15 million preschoolers. ``There are lots of babies. There are older, wealthier, dual-income people having babies,'' said Eric Miller, editor of Research Alert, a Long Island magazine devoted to spotting and analyzing trends. ``Yuppies, as they've aged, buy service almost more than anything else. They don't like the paltry child care available. It's a recipe for a nanny,'' Miller said. Susan Elsea, a suburban Detroit sales executive for American Express, considered a day-care center when she was pregnant. She envisioned wondering: ``Are her diapers changed? Is she by herself in a corner?'' By the time Carolyn was born seven months ago, she had decided to hire a nanny. ``Day care - absolutely not. I just will not take her out of the house on those cold, blustery mornings. I wanted her here,'' she said. Fortunately, she said, she earns enough to pay for it. Elsea used an agency rather than a classified ad to find her nanny. ``The finder's fee is well worth it. The $1,000 was a drop in the bucket. Time is money. We couldn't have come up with her on our own,'' she said. Agencies and schools, private and public, stress that nannies must be trained. A textbook is being written now for the fledgling field, and groups like the International Nanny Association are pushing standardized courses. Training varies from 100-hour courses to two-year college associate degrees, but experts agree that nannies must know nutrition, child-care basics like when babies switch to solid foods, psychological and physical development, safety, telephone and table etiquette, and how to handle emergencies. Robertson said there are at least 68 nanny programs at community colleges, like hers, and 20 of them are just a year old. There are at least 15 private schools like Eurich's. At least 75,000 nannies have been placed in homes nationwide by schools or agencies, not including illegal aliens or nannies without any classroom or practical experience, Robertson said. ``I would insist on training, but some families get so desperate that they don't,'' said Dixon, whose state school has a one-year program and also offers an associate's degree. Linda Hice-Guastella quit law school to open her Nanny Network Inc. placement agency four years ago. Her applicant screening includes reference and police checks. ``We've come up with drunk driving and disorderly conduct, but nothing more serious. You have to screen,'' she said. Her clients tend to be people worried about abuse or neglect at day-care centers where wages are low, turnover is high and training is often minimal. Nannies placed by her metro Detroit agency earn at least $200 weekly to live in, and up to $450 if they have a nursing background. ``Women can have a `wife' too. They don't have to choose between their families and jobs,'' Hice-Guastella said. The cost isn't necessarily much higher than a day-care center. A year of full-day preschool costs $4,200 per child, and up to $9,000 or more for infants, according to a General Accounting Office survey of 1988 average costs, the most recent available. For infant care or nannies shared by families, the cost is comparable, said Barbara Willer of the National Association for the Education of the Young, a Washington, D.C., advocacy and professional association for child-care workers. Barbara Taylor, president of the National Association for Family Day Care in Washington, D.C., makes the case for organized day care: Children in day care ``get structure and the stimulation of playmates,'' she said. Day-care workers generally earn less than live-in nannies, whose compensation includes room and board. Yet people aren't flooding the field. Eurich says some prospective nannies are worried that they'll end up being maids, or by publicized cases in which child-care workers are accused of abusing their charges. Carol Emrich, the coordinator of Delta College's nanny training program, receives about 100 inquiries monthly from families seeking nannies. The two-semester program has eight students, although she expects more in the winter term. ``It's just real important to stress the opportunities.'' ``It's hard to recruit students. We have 30 to 40 (jobs) for every graduate,'' Dixon said.

DOC.HEAD: Warning Cry Found Stirring Churches Toward Recovery
LaserPhoto planned
DOC.TEXT: Alongside a chapel at Louisville Presbyterian Theological Seminary in Kentucky stands a brass sculpture of a crowing rooster - an ancient Christian symbol of warning. Some say it is relevant for today's mainline Protestantism. A repeated cock's crow signaled the apostle Peter's denial of the arrested Jesus before his crucifixion, and a new study says ``the rooster's poignant cry of caution'' now echoes in some church conditions. But the study also detected signs of surmounting the difficulties. The situation in historic Protestantism is described as ``decline, malaise, division and demise,'' a weakening that has toppled the old mainline churches from holding sway over American culture. Involved is ``an epochal change in American religion that has occurred during the 20th century,'' says the first volume of the planned seven-volume study of the problem and responses to it. Old-line denominations - Presbyterians, Episcopalians, Methodists, Congregationalists (now United Church), Disciples and American Baptists - are said to ``have been displaced - religiously and culturally - to a significant degree.'' All have suffered severe membership losses and serious theological strains, while all have shifted emphasis from devotionalism toward social justice and struggled over institutional organization, sapping energies, the study says. It adds that nevertheless, ``they remain influential voices in the spectrum of American religion and retain an enduring vitality in the face of a massive reconfiguration of American religious life.'' More than 60 researchers at seminaries, colleges and universities throughout the country took part in the study. Financed by the Lilly Endowment, it focused on the Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.) as a case study. The ``developments within one tradition - American Presbyterianism - are mirrored in other denominations as well,'' says the first volume, ``The Presbyterian Predicament,'' published by Westminster-John Knox Press. The Rev. John M. Mulder, Louisville Presbyterian Theological Seminary president, who heads the project, said it was the most extensive research ever into any Protestant body. He said the study turned up developing processes in mainstream ``religious life that make this one of the most interesting and exciting periods in American religious history.'' ``We're at a point where the church is beginning to define itself in a new situation in which it has new competitors both in society and in non-Christian alternative religions,'' Mulder said. ``It's very clear that American culture no longer supports and reinforces the church. But in facing new competitors, it is finding new resources. The church is being called back to its basic identity, to what it believes, to the difference it makes in lives.'' Terming this an ``important turning point'' for the churches, he added in an interview: ``Today churches have lost their cultural recognition. They now are being challenged to be the church, to be Christian, to define their identity over against secularity, to be religious in the best sense of the word.'' The seven-volume series is being publishes under the general title of ``The Presbyterian Presence: The 20th Century Experience.'' Two more volumes, ``The Mainstream Protestant `Decline' '' and ``The Confessional Mosaic,'' are coming out this fall. Two additional volumes are due next spring and two next fall. Mulder said the findings point both to the causes of the languishing of mainline denominations and to means for overcoming it. He said the findings also indicate such a recovery is under way. ``There's a resurgence of the moderate center, the huge majority of church people who are tired of denominational policy being determined by extreme groups, left or right,'' he said. This is dispelling past factional polarization that has afflicted churches, retrieving vitality expended in those fights, he said. ``The people who have remained silent in controvery have finally begun to assert themselves.'' He cited these other positive signs: - New church development, a lack of which has been a major factor in a quarter century of denominational decline, is being re-emphasized with a surge of new congregations in the old Protestant bodies. - Baby boomers, born in the decade after World War II, are beginning to return to church participation, after generally shunning it in the 1970s and early 1980s. - Congregations that suffered severe declines, particularly in urban areas, are showing a ``kind of elasticity and vitality that almost defies destruction. Congregations once considered dead are coming back to life.'' Mulder said mainstream denominations also now see a need for each to ``forge a theological identity that is persuasive and distinctive,'' that characterizes each denomination's special contributions to the ``larger Christian family.'' ``They are all committed to ecumenism,'' he said. They recognize the fuller Christian totality, he added, but now are clarifying their particular ``vision and insights'' in it, rather than diluting those values.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Fri PMs, Oct. 12

DOC.TEXT: The Church of the Brethren, one of the historic peace churches, has urged people to observe an ``oil-free Sunday'' on Oct. 21 to focus attention on the nation's dependence on foreign oil. Alternate means of transportation to fuel-powered vehicles were recommended - walking, bicycling or using mass transit. The Persian Gulf crisis is over oil resources, and ``in this case it is clear that our nation is willing to go to war to keep the oil flowing,'' said David Radcliff, the church's peace consultant. ``From a Brethren point of view, all war is wrong. In this particular case, we are committed to making whatever lifestyle sacrifices are necessary to stop the country from going to war.'' --- NEW YORK (AP) - Cardinal John O'Connor told worshippers at St. Patrick's Cathedral on Oct. 7 that Roman Catholicism is ``absolutely, uncategorically and unconditionally against membership in the Ku Klux Klan.'' He referred to media reports of a rise in ultraright groups in New York. --- CHANTILLY, France (AP) - An assembly of the World Student Christian Federation says it rejoices at the end of the Cold War and the ``new possibilities for humankind to tackle the scourge of hunger, illiteracy and poverty.'' But the students from many lands added that ``a new wall seems to begin to be erected between those rich countries which control and dilapidate a disproportionate share of the planet's resources and wealth, and those poor countries that have in common their powerlessness and poverty.'' The message terms the ecumenical movement a ``new and miraculous gift of God'' in which his spirit is ``driving us to work for the reunion of our churches.'' --- WILSON, N.C. (AP) - Atlantic Christian College has been renamed Barton College, partly to keep it from being considered as strictly a religious institution. The new namesake, Barton W. Stone, was a 19th century founder of the Christian Church (Disciples of Christ), which started the college in 1902. The college said that ``to envision this private, four-year liberal arts college as a church-controlled, ultraconservative Bible college is wrong,'' but the new name still preserves the church antecedants. --- OSLO, Norway (AP) - The recently adopted Oslo Declaration says that ``because hatred is willed by man, God himself is unable to stop it.'' This ``ancient scourge, whose origins remain hidden in darkness,'' strikes all races, religions, political systems and classes, says the declaration of political and moral leaders who met about modern currents of hate. Czechoslovakia's president, Vaclav Havel, said that ``in the subconscious of the haters there slumbers a perverse feeling that they alone are the true possessors of truth.'' --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Praising the new Soviet legislation providing for freedom of religion, B'nai B'rith Internatinal says it will now ``redouble its efforts to bring Jewish cultural activity and nourishment to our brethren in every corner of the Soviet Union.'' --- ATLANTA (AP) - Former Atlanta Archbishop Eugene A. Marino, who resigned after Roman Catholic officials learned of his two-year sexual relationship with a woman, is in ``a structured program of psychological and spiritual renewal'' in the Midwest, family members say. Six of Marino's siblings gave their report on the former archbishop in a letter addressed to Atlanta Catholics in the Georgia Bulletin, the archdiocesan newspaper. The letter says he will remain in the Midwestern program ``until he is ready to accept a new assignment.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Fri PMs, Oct. 12

DOC.HEAD: The Man Behind the Beatific Look of ``Avalon''
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: When immigrant Sam Krichinsky arrived in Baltimore in 1914, he says at the opening of the movie ``Avalon,'' it was the most beautiful place he had ever seen. If audiences share Krichinsky's memory, they can thank Allen Daviau. As the film's director of photography, Daviau was charged with transforming director Barry Levinson's rich script into equally evocative images. Perhaps no scene in ``Avalon'' reveals Daviau's artistry more than that first scene in which Krichinsky (Armin Mueller-Stahl portraying Levinson as a young man) lands in Electric Park, a 1914 exposition re-created for the film by production designer Norman Reynolds. As the first reel unspools, something looks off. As Krichinsky moves through Electric Park, decorated with 18,000 lights, his body movements are slightly jumpy and the colors overly rich. He walks at normal speed, and yet it is clear we are not watching his actual arrival. It is instead Krichinsky's recollection of it. ``This is a very abstract, stylized, idealized memory he's having of brilliant lights,'' said Daviau, whose cinematography won Academy Award nominations for Steven Spielberg's ``E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial,'' ``The Color Purple'' and ``Empire of the Sun.'' ``One of the things Barry said was, `We have to find a way to distance the past sequences from the present of 1948,' '' Daviau said. To avoid cinematic cliches, he declined to use filtration or sepia toning. What Daviau (pronounced Dav'-ee-ow) did instead was film at 18 frames per second, as opposed to the standard 24 frames. He then ``stretch-printed'' the film, using every other frame twice. ``It's missing a third of the information that our 24-frame-per second mind is used to seeing, and it's being restored in an artificial way,'' Daviau said. ``We've seen stretch printing in silent films for many, many years. The difference is, you haven't seen it in color.'' Daviau first used the technique making a bank commercial several years ago. He still alternates between commercials and feature films. ``It's the best mixture in the world,'' he said, ``because commercials keep you busy, they keep you in practice, they make you a lot of money and you meet a lot of directors who are on their way to doing pictures. ``Working in commercials allows you to be choosy about what movies you do. . . . What I was really looking to do happened when `Avalon' came along. ``I really am fascinated with the '40s,'' Daviau said. ``I got to deal with a period that I remember quite well.'' The movie spans 50 years, detailing the lives of the Krinchinskys - Levinson's famil - and the world in which they live. Daviau started as a still photographer, photo lab technician and theatrical lighting designer. During the mid-1960s, he photographed rock promotional films with Jimi Hendrix, Aretha Franklin and The Who. Other feature credits include ``The Falcon and the Snowman'' and ``Defending Your Life.'' In 1988, the American Society of Cinematographers voted him best cinematographer in feature films. Levinson and Spielberg both are visual directors, Daviau said, but have different styles. ``Steven is much more interested in the design of the shot; the graphics are very, very important to him,'' Daviau said. ``Barry is a visual director, by all means, but it's a different emphasis. He loves the compositions.'' The cinematographer's job is a curious one. ``It's really a case of choosing to make your presence known. And you pick a look for a film and then you're out to make that look fit,'' Daviau said. ``There are certain things that general audiences may notice about photography that are not the things you do. A lot of times, we're credited with scenery. The things we really do are things that people rarely notice. Most of our work is lighting, color, texture. ``One of the greatest things that you do in cinematography is you guide the audiences's eye to where it should be. You're giving emphasis where it's desired. ``I don't think I would ever want to be known as every film I have looking the same or somebody saying, `Oh! Daviau did that for sure.' I'd much rather shape the look to the individual film.'' In ``Avalon,'' he said, certain details demanded to be examined closely. ``I looked at Armin Mueller-Stahl's face and in a second I saw those eyes. This is one of the most remarkable faces I've ever been given to photograph.'' For the Thanksgiving dinner scenes in ``Avalon,'' Daviau bathed the interiors with warm, comfortable light; pouring in from outside windows is cold, blue light. Near the film's end, Sam Krichinsky settles into a chair to read a newspaper. A few seconds later, when he arises, he's aged 10 years. The framing of both shots is identical. There is no jump in the image, even though the two scenes were done more than a week apart. So seamless is the transition that some in the audience don't notice for several moments that Krichinsky's grown old. And that, for Daviau, is photography at its best.

DOC.HEAD: Foreign Actors Help Norwegians Come to Terms With Ibsen
DOC.TEXT: The national theater has imported talent from as far away as New Zealand to get Norwegians to stop ignoring Henrik Ibsen, their country's greatest writer. Theater director Stein Winge said this month's first international Ibsen festival was a belated attempt to make up for Norway's ``scandalous neglect'' of the 19th-century dramatist. Actors from New Zealand, Ireland, England, Sweden and Norway have been helping to reconcile Norwegians with Ibsen, 84 years after the playwright's death in Oslo. There is nothing new in Norwegians neglecting Ibsen, often called modern theater's most influential figure. His early plays were ignored or met with such hostility in Norway that Ibsen fled to Italy and then Germany, for 27 years of self-imposed exile. ``Ibsen didn't especially like Norway,'' said Winge. But he wrote in Norwegian and said that to understand his work, one had to know his country's severe beauty, isolation and introspective people. Ibsen's socially realistic dramas examined such themes as venereal disease, alcoholism, incest and insanity, all shocking and forbidden topics in his era. When Sigmund Freud, the Austrian father of psychoanalysis, was a 9-year-old, Ibsen was already exploring the human psyche in plays later described as psychoanalysis in dramatic form. Shock has faded into apathy among modern Norway's liberal, easygoing people, said Winge. Oslo's Aftenposten nwwspaper said most consider reading Ibsen a drudgery to endure as a student. His fans, a minority, are so awed by Ibsen that they are timid in exploring his work, said Winge. ``We have made him a museum piece. . . . We experience what we expect Ibsen to be. We need to be presented with what other cultures see in our poet to open the door and get him out of the museum.'' A recent festival brought outsiders to Oslo's National Theater to help blow off the dust from Ibsen. Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis, who wants to lead his Baltic republic out of the Soviet Union, attended the opening ceremony and said, ``I connect Ibsen's name, his work and his ideas with strong thoughts of freedom which have reached a deep meaning for people in Lithuania.'' Winge said he did not know why the National Theater waited nearly a century to arrange the festival. The theater claims to be Ibsen's home, because he invested in it and attended its 1899 opening. ``It should have been done a long time ago,'' said Winge. His first act after being appointed theater director in January was to establish the annual festival. Modern Norwegians may have been shocked by New Zealand's Downstage Theater setting the 1890 play, ``Hedda Gabler,'' in the 1950s. One Oslo newspaper grumbled at a Harley Davidson motorcycle being on the stage. Purists probably raised their eyebrows over ``Peer Gynt'' being performed as a ballet by London's ABC dance company or by masked actors in a fairy tale version by the Kalmar, Sweden, city theater. Winge, however, was pleased by such experimentation. ``I think Ibsen would have approved,'' he said. The theater groups performed 11 plays, many in English, from Ibsen's three periods. From his first period, the festival offered a performance of the 1866 tragedy ``Brand,'' and three versions of ``Peer Gynt'' from 1867. His best-known period, when Ibsen rebelled against social conventions, was illustrated at the festival with such plays as ``Hedda Gabler,'' ``A Doll's House'' and ``Ghosts,'' performed by the Belfast, Northern Ireland's Lyric Theater. Finally, he wrote strongly symbolic plays. ``Ever since `A Doll's House' had its breakthrough on the European stage, Ibsen was more successful abroad (than at home). It's a tradition we have maintained until the present,'' said Vigdis Ystad, a Norwegian university professor and Ibsen scholar. Ystad, attending a two-day Ibsen symposium, said many foreigners know more than Norwegians about Ibsen's ability to illustrate life's big issues through simple human conflicts. ``We owe it to our writer, country and the world to be the best in Ibsen research,'' said Ystad in a newspaper interview. She urged parliament to fund an Ibsen center in Norway. Ibsen's star may finally be rising in Norway. Oslo newspapers extensively covered the festival, and demand for tickets surprised even Winge, who added extra shows. ``It's late, but not too late,'' wrote an Aftenposten editorialist about the surge in interest. ``Excuse me, if I find it a little strange - to put it mildly - that any country suddenly discovers Ibsen, especially when that country just happens to be Ibsen's homeland.''

DOC.HEAD: Gallows Humor in the Budget Trenches
A AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Flying back to Washington to vote on the budget mess, a Democratic senator told the fellow in the next seat who he was. Bad move. Sen. David Pryor of Arkansas told colleagues that the passenger beside him asked whether he worked for the government. ``I said, `As a matter of fact, I do. I'm a United States senator.' He said, `Well, if you don't mind, I don't want to sit with you.''' And changed seats. A Democratic House member is said to have mused aloud that he's glad to be unopposed in next month's election because he'd probably vote for the challenger if there was one. That sort of gallows political humor reflects the bleak outlook as Congress struggles into the next round on the budget, a no-win issue there and at the White House. The government's trying to deal in days with decisions that were supposed to be made months ago. Lawmakers need to figure out how to trim the annual deficit by $500 billion over five years. Sen. William L. Armstrong, R-Colo., said people won't see anyone in Congress as a hero - they will all look like jerks. And there's no guarantee that the process won't grind into another shut-down-the-government deadline, with spending authority extended only until Oct. 19. That date does come with an extra inducement - it's the day Congress had hoped to adjourn for the year. The settlement that avoided the full-scale shutdown threatened for Tuesday ``merely enables us to get to first base,'' said Sen. George J. Mitchell, D-Maine, the majority leader. It doesn't cut the deficit by one dollar. It does set guidelines - $40 billion in revenues and spending cuts to reduce a steadily increasing deficit anticipated this year, $500 billion over five years - and assigns the regular House and Senate committees to draft specific legislation to meet those goals. Those were the overall numbers of the budget agreement President Bush tried to push through Congress with late but intense personal lobbying. The House rejected that plan last Friday. In the process, conservative House Republicans rebelled over the tax increases that were part of the settlement. That could happen next time, too, since taxes will be central to the new plan. Bush acknowledged that his 1988 campaign vow against new taxes ``makes it more difficult for people'' who echoed him to vote for an increase now. But he said he doesn't regret his pledge ``because what I do is take a look at - at the situation at the time, see the changed economics, and say I've got to - got to, you know, go forward here.'' He'd already conceded that his tax philosophy ``runs out of gas in terms of votes'' in Congress. As vice president, then as candidate and president, Bush held the no-new-taxes line for nearly 10 years. He spent 10 minutes on national television on Oct. 2 trying to turn it around and get the first budget deal approved. ``Tell your congressmen and senators you support this deficit-reduction agreement,'' he urged the voters. By most accounts, the message that got back to Congress was the opposite, although Bush maintains that the agreement had wide support from the American people. But nobody bothered in advance to prepare the voters who pay the taxes and use the programs for the surprise package that was supposed to hit on both sides of that ledger. The problem was turned over to congressional leaders and administration negotiators to be handled in protracted, secret bargaining. The result was a last-minute proposition with no constituency in Congress, let alone the country. In part, that was a product of political maneuvering, in whch the Democratic Congress and the Republican White House each tried to get the other to go first in publicly advocating steps that were bound to be unpopular with voters. Bush had said people worried about the election impact of the first budget deal should recall the tax increases that were enacted when Ronald Reagan was president. ``And there wasn't a political fallout because I think the country understands when the president concludes that a deal is necessary,'' Bush said. ``They incline to give him the benefit of the doubt.'' Sometimes. --- EDITOR'S NOTE - Walter R. Mears, vice president and columnist for The Associated Press, has reported on Washington and national politics for more than 25 years.

DOC.HEAD: Hey Dude, Hey Cos, Bart's Back
DOC.TEXT: The bad news about ``The Simpsons'' is that despite a big build-up by Fox Broadcasting, tonight's second-season premiere doesn't reveal who killed Laura Palmer. The good news: Such can happen in Matt Groening's quirky cartoon series about a typical American family full of love, overbite, a proudly underachieving son named Bart and a dog named Santa's Little Helper. Tonight's premiere, however, has young Bart finally realizing the terrible cost of not studying. He could be held back in the fourth grade for another year, and maybe even for life. This will please teachers everywhere, particularly those at three elementary schools who last April banned the wearing of Bart's ``Underachiever: And Proud of It'' T-shirt. Despite such pecksniffs, ``The Simpsons'' was a hit in its first year, a series whose bug-eyed, sweetly weirdo clan took the tradition of shows like ``Father Knows Best,'' made it blue-collar and put it somewhere in the neighborhood of reality. With Bart baying ``Don't have a cow, man!,'' the show rose as high as fourth in the Nielsens. Its success ignited a megabuck merchandising blitz of Simpsons products. But that was when it was on Sunday nights. Then Fox, in a burst of dim that had Groening groaning, shifted the show this season to Thursday, opposite NBC's top-rated ``The Cosby Show.'' Fox also delayed the second-season premiere until tonight. All this has put ``The Simpsons'' so low in the Nielsens that divers must be dispatched each each week to get the results. Many analysts feel that this will continue, no matter what Groening & Co. do. They could be wrong. It may just be that frequent attacks of warmth, decency and goodness by NBC's family Huxtable finally have taken their toll on viewers. There is such a thing as too much warmth, decency and goodness. But it also helps that ``The Simpsons'' is off to a fine re-start tonight with a very funny show. Written by David M. Stern, it brilliantly brings back those chilling childhood memories of facing a major test at school when one's mind is in the state of Nobody Home. And bless its heart, the show also takes some quick, sly digs at the pervasive, mind-numbing influence of video games and television on kids. Bart's class crisis begins when he's called on to give a book report on ``Treasure Island.'' As is his custom, he hasn't read it. As is his custom, he tries to wing it, glancing at the book cover for inspiration: ``It's about these pirates, pirates with patches over their eyes . . . and green birds on their shoulders.'' But of course he winds up at the blackboard, writing ``I will not fake my way through life'' 100 times. Berated by the teacher, facing a major history test the next day, he knows he must study. But first, to the video arcade. There, he plays your basic video game - where a tyke shoots a granny who wants to kiss him. At home, well, just a bit of TV before dinner. He sits with his smart younger sister, Lisa, and Maggie, their pacifier-sucking infant sister, watching a violent cat-chases-mouse cartoon, ``Let Them Eat Scratchy.'' (They chortle when one character winds up in a guillotine; he shrugs his shoulders, and with good reason.) After dinner, Homer the patriarch insists that Bart join him watching a gorilla movie on TV. After that, Bart finally tries to study about the Pilgrims. But he falls asleep over his book. Marge, America's only mother with a blue beevive hairdo, notes that her son tries so hard. But why, she asks, does he keep failing in school? ``Just a little dim, I guess,'' Homer says. Poor Bart faces even more woes, including twin meanies on the school bus the next day. He seeks their help in cramming for the coming test. They advise him that the Pilgrims came to America on ``The Spirit of St. Louis.'' But in time, he does learn one of life's most valuable lessons - that dimness can be overcome, sort of. ``The Simpsons'' is different, all right, and not just because coming episodes feature a Tony Bennett appearance, Danny DeVito as the voice of Homer's separated-at-birth brother, and Homer getting a male secretary - voice by ``Torch Song Trilogy'' author Harvey Fierstein - who proves to be gay. The show also has good writing, attention to life's any oddities, and craftsmanship. That may not be enough to beat The Cos. But it's worth a look. ---

Elsewhere in television .. GOOD MORNING PBS: David Hartman, the original host of ABC's ``Good Morning America,'' will be back on TV on Oct. 21 as host of a five-part public TV series, ``Seasons of Life.'' The series examines Americans in five stages, from conception to old age. End Adv PM Thurs Oct. 11

DOC.HEAD: Trying Money Funds On For Size
DOC.TEXT: When you compare the relative attractions of money market mutual funds, big can be beautiful. To any student of the art of mutual-fund investing, that may sound like a surprising idea. Traditionally, in arenas such as the stock market, small funds are often considered to have an edge on their larger competitors, in part because they can be more flexible and maneuverable. But in the $400 billion-plus money-fund business, which engages in a different battle waged in a different marketplace, analysts who have studied the subject say just the opposite principle applies. ``Large money funds have a tendency to yield more to their shareholders than small money funds,'' says the investment advisory letter Income & Safety, published by the Institute for Econometric Research in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. Income & Safety arrived at this conclusion by examining the field of money funds it monitors, grouped by where they ranked in the service's system for forecasting fund yields. The funds with above-average yield forecasts, it turned out, had an average of $3.7 billion in assets; those with average yield forecasts, $2.3 billion, and those with below-average yield forecasts, $600 million. In other words, pointed out Norman Fosback, the institute's president, ``taxable money funds with above-average yields had, on average, an asset base six times as large as funds with below-average yields.'' Fosback cited several reasons why this correlation appeared to be more than coincidental: ``First, large funds experience some economies of scale in their day-to-day operating expenses. As these relatively fixed costs are spread over a larger asset base, expenses per dollar of assets fall, and lower expense ratios equal higher yields.'' Secondly, Fosback said, sponsors of large funds tend to collect smaller percentages from the funds' assets for their annual management fees. ``In part,'' he observes, ``this reflects the fact that many management companies scale back their fees as fund size increases. ``Third, very large money funds can sometimes obtain slightly better returns by purchasing commercial paper (short-term IOUs issued by corporations and other entities) and certificates of deposit in huge denominations. ``Finally,'' Fosback added, ``the market for money funds is quite efficient. Investors are attracted to funds with superior yields and avoid those with below-average returns. This helps the best-yielding funds to grow still larger.'' Fosback and other observers caution that size should not be the first criterion used in trying to gauge any fund's merits. The prime questions are usually relative yield and safety, as reflected in the kinds and maturities of investments a fund has in its portfolio. There also may be special factors to consider as well. The Dreyfus Worldwide Dollar Money Market Fund, for instance, has used an aggressive marketing strategy to help promote its rapid rise to the ranks of both the biggest and highest-yielding funds. For more than a year and a half since the fund was established, the sponsoring Dreyfus Corp. has picked up all the fund's operating expenses and collected no management fee. It has promised that it will continue to forgo the management fee until at least next June 30. But starting Oct. 1 it began charging part of the operating costs to the fund. But with all those caveats, Fosback observes, ``size does matter.'' A stock mutual fund can, in theory at least, fall victim to its own success, attracting more money than it can put to work in the strategies that have won it acclaim. By contrast, in a money-market fund popularity apparently can be a blessing rather than a bane.
