DOC.HEAD: Some Budget Comments You Might Not Have Seen
DOC.TEXT: If Uncle Sam's economic statistics had been kept properly, there would have been no budget crisis and fewer strains between Congress and the White House. That view of the budget crisis is one you probably haven't heard before, even though you may have been one of those who swore that everything that could have been said had been said and that you didn't want to hear anymore. Albert Sindlinger is an economic researcher who gathers his own information and produces his own analyses for corporate, academic and governmental clients. His data comes from telephone calls his staffers make to households. Those calls, he says, reveal to him that there are probably two million fewer workers in the American economy than are being reported officially by the Bureau of Labor Statistics. He claims the disparity lies in errors in BLS's methodology, including its revisions and its tendency to count one person working two jobs as two people working two jobs, with two full incomes rather than perhaps one and one-quarter. But that's for the statisticians to argue about, and Sindlinger's argument consumes 49 typewritten pages of compilations, charts and graphs. More to the point, his budget commentary is that if the BLS removed those two million workers it would reduce gross national product and show the economy to be in recession, as he has had it for nearly a year. While the BLS has found the economy to be weakening, it still has it skirting recession, due largely to those ``extra'' workers. Worker wages and salaries, he says, account for nearly half of gross national product. If BLS figures agreed with his, concludes Sindlinger, implementation of the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings Act would have been automatically deferred, there being a provision to that effect when two straight near-recession quarters occur. He concludes: ``With a truthful GNP, the act would have been scrapped and the current charade of blamemanship would not be amplifying the growing voter revolt.'' Economist Roger Brinner has another somewhat offbeat comment about the budget scene. Oddly, he says, Congress hasn't yet caught on to the revenue opportunities presented by the Strategic Petroleum Reserve. Brinner, whose analysis are made for DRI-McGraw-Hill Inc., part of Standard & Poor's Corp., reasons that by selling perhaps 200 million barrels of the reserve at $37.50 a barrel could close $7.5 billion of the budget deficit. Then, he continues, ``If war doesn't break out the reserves could be later rebuilt at two-thirds the selling price,'' since he believes prices will fall if peace is achieved. ``I cynically expected this to be part of the $50 billion first-year budget adjustment,'' he says. Instead, he says, negotiators took a more difficult course of scaledowns, program cuts, tax increases and other maneuvers. Another commentary: To J. Marc Wheat of the Citizens For A Sound Economy Foundation, a non-profit research group, the budget negotiators somehow missed the point that Americans wanted spending cut rather than taxes raised. ``More dollars flow into federal coffers than ever before,'' says Wheat, the foundation's director of tax and budget policy, and he has the figures to prove it. He points out that revenue to the federal government has grown every year since 1983, increasing from $600.6 billion to an estimated $1.073 trillion in 1990, a 79 percent increase. That being so, he concludes that overspending rather than lack of revenue has caused our deficit problems, and that ``Congress should not be trusted to cut spending in future years.''

DOC.HEAD: Moslems Begin Edging Into Interreligious Mainstream
LaserPhoto planned
DOC.TEXT: Moslems, long isolated from America's religious mainstream, have started edging into it. An initial step into working collaboration with Christians and Jews came last week as national Islamic representatives joined a major interfaith operation, Religion in American Life. Dawud Assad, president of the Council of Mosques of the United States, said that in taking the step, ``we look forward to some good cooperation in the future'' with ``our brothers and sisters.'' ``We're at a new stage at which we cease to be a religion on the margins, but a religion of American people related to American life,'' said Gutbi E. Ahmed, director of the Moslem World League. ``We're now ready to interact with the rest of American people, particularly in relation to its religious communities.'' Leaders of other faiths, Protestant, Roman Catholic, Eastern Orthodox and Jewish welcomed the Moslem entry into the organization, which works to encourage regular worship and community service. ``This is an historic moment for RIAL and, I daresay, for America,'' said Rabbi Joseph B. Glaser, chairman of the group and executive vice president of the Central Conference of American Rabbis. ``It could be a turning point for our nation,'' he added. ``We have broken a major barrier, and, who knows, the beneficial effect may well ripple to other shores.'' Religion in American Life was founded in 1949 and initially involved only Protestant denominations. It later included Roman Catholicism, making it inter-Christian, and subsequently enlisted Jews, making it a interreligious. ``Now, with the entry of Islam, we become a holy organization,'' Glaser said. ``Holiness is inclusive - it knows not fences. Holiness is trust and is caring beyond one's parochial boundaries. ``Holiness is knowing that we are all God's children - and in knowing that knowing God.'' Moslems previously have been involved in interfaith theological dialogues, but not in interreligious activity on a national basis. ``We had not been willing to join before because we would be drowned,'' Assad said. But, he said, Moslems now have organizational maturity and strength to facilitate interreligious cooperation. The council Assad heads includes 195 mosques, worshipping centers in most major cities. He said there also are now more than 1,000 Moslem community organizations, some worshipping in basements or other makeshift places. Noting Islamic roots in Judaism and Christianity, he said, ``We who work together all are of the Abrahamic faith.'' He said Moslem Scriptures, the Koran, ``demands dialogue with people of the book (the Bible),'' meaning Jews and Christians. ``We also believe in all the book, the prophets, the gospel,'' he said. No Islamic membership count has been made in this country, but estimates generally put the figure between 4 million and 6 milion, although some estimates range considerably above that. The Rev. Nicholas B. van Dyck, a Presbyterian and president of Religion in American Life, said starting Islamic participation shows what ``may be news to many Americans'' - that most Moslems support interfaith cooperation. The group coordinates interfaith research and public information activities, including provision of worship directories in hotels. It also works to increase weekly worship, backed by public service advertising campaigns. The current drive, under the slogan ``Invite a Friend,'' involves projects in thousands of congregations. For years, Islam in this country has been regarded a ``foreign religion,'' and consequently Moslem immigrants ``learned to live in their own substructure,'' Ahmed said. However, he said the taking root in America of indigenous, black Moslems, of which he is one, and the presence of a second generation of younger American-born Moslems opened the way for cooperation with other faiths. ``The big difference is that we have had a wall around our lives in a Moslem ghetto, and now we see we are part of this society, that our future is here,'' he said. ``This has never been faced by Moslems before.'' The Islamic representatives said most American Moslems support international efforts to get Iraqi forces out of Kuwait but hope for a peaceful solution. They also ``understand the presence'' of Western forces in Saudi Arabia, but some have misgivings about it, Ahmed said in summarizing conclusions of 700 Moslem leaders last month at a Continental Council of Mosques. Both Ahmed and Assad also said there had been few signs of antagonism toward American Moslems as a result of the Middle East crisis. ``Not much of it, only a few incidents,'' Assad said. Ahmed noted a few scrawls on mosques and a few telephone hate calls. But, he added, compared to the anti-Moslem feelings stirred by Iran's holding of American hostages in 1979, this time ``it has been minimal.''

DOC.HEAD: Pricey Menus And Glitz Are Out; Restaurants Adapt to Hard Times
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Huberts used to sell caviar and truffles. Its tables were set with fish forks and fish spoons. Waiters wore designer uniforms. And ties and jackets were required of the customers. A dinner for two cost $165. Today there is no caviar and the fish forks are stored away. Waiters wear their own slacks and shirts. There are more tables, pushed closer together. The price for two is about $100 - a hefty sum for most people, but a dramatic cut for the Upper East Side restaurant. ``I felt we were in a vastly changing world and that I needed to keep up,'' says Len Allison, chef-owner of Huberts. This is the year of rude awakenings for restaurant owners in New York City. The economic downturn - triggered by the stock market crash in 1987 - has hit them hard, especially proprietors of second-tier luxury establishments. At credit-card restaurants, sales were down 15 percent to 20 percent in June, compared to the same month last year, while nationally they dropped between 12 percent and 14 percent, says restaurant consultant Michael Whiteman. A Gallup poll for the National Restaurant Association in Washington, D.C., showed 22 percent of adults ate lunch out on any given day in July, compared with 30 percent in June. The polls were of 1,000 people and had a margin of error of 3.5 points. Expensive restaurants are hardest hit. ``People will trade down for lunch,'' said George Rice, a spokesman for Consumer Reports on Eating Share Trends, which tracks restaurant industry data. ``It's Chez Paul's to Bennigan's and Bennigan's to Denny's and then Denny's to McDonald's. That's been going on for a few years and it will accelerate.'' Restaurant owners from San Francisco, Los Angeles, Detroit and Boston say they, too, are adjusting to a newly cost-conscious dining public. But their outlook is brighter than that of their New York City counterparts. ``I think we are going through the same thing. But it's harder in New York,'' said Jasper White, chef-owner of Jasper's, an upscale restaurant in an old molasses warehouse in Boston. New York City is bigger, it is tied more closely to the fortunes of the financial community, and it has more restaurants competing for survival, he said. Moreover, the dining public has more to revolt against in the Big Apple since restaurant prices are by far the highest in the country. The average price of dinner for one in New York City - three courses, one drink and tip in the 20 most popular restaurants according the popular Zagat survey of eateries - is $61. In Los Angeles, the city with the second most expensive meal prices, the average is $43. ``I think the restaurants that were popular in the '80s had a shiny armor,'' says Adam Tihany, co-owner of Remi, a new and popular trattoria in midtown Manhattan, where dinner costs about $35 a person. The places that are successful in the 1990s, he says, will be run by people who truly care and ``turn out a product that ... gives you value for what you are spending.'' Indeed, mid-priced bistros where the atmosphere is casual and the food is simple are thriving in New York City, says Tim Zagat, publisher of the surveys. ``People want to eat well because they are used to that but they don't want to spend as much time or as much money as they used to,'' says Jimmy Schmidt, chef-owner of the Rattlesnake Club in Detroit. His successful restaurant on the Detroit River features midwestern cooking in a light, airy environment filled with contemporary art. About 80 percent of the main courses are priced under $20. Picey restaurants that do not have four-star reputations for food and service are revamping their menus and decor to appeal to the spontaneous, cost-conscious diner. The glitterati used to pack Melrose, a basement restaurant in New York's Greenwich Village where they could dine on small portions of California food served on big white plates for $55 a person. But when the trend setters moved on, Melrose emptied. Owner Lee Friedman realized neighborhood people ``weren't going to come in for three slices of rare-charred tuna for $25.'' Earlier this year, he renamed Melrose the Barrow Street Bistro, cut prices about 40 percent, toned down the austere decor and changed the menu to include heartier bistro cooking. Business has picked up and more than half of Friedman's customers are from the neighborhood. In Boston, Jasper's was hit hard by the stock market crash. Overnight it lost many of its expense account clients. ``We reacted immediately,'' says White, the chef-owner. The menu was expanded to include lower-priced items like fish cakes and pot roasts. And the waiters donned white aprons instead of tuxedos. The average dinner price for one person dropped from $70 to $55. Joyce Goldstein, a San Francisco chef, says she expects to see fewer luxury restaurants in the coming years but not fewer people eating out. ``It's not, `Uh, oh! We're in a recession. Let's start cooking little chicken things at home,''' says the owner of Square One, where dinner averages $35 a person and the atmosphere is warm and friendly. ``People are working just as hard, twice as hard as ever before. The last thing we need after work is to go to the supermarket and cook.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Weds AMs, Oct. 10

For Release Sunday, Oct. 14, and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: A Year Later, the Bay Area Still Shakes
With BC-Earthquake Anniversary
DOC.TEXT: When the earthquake shook the San Francisco Bay area at 5:04 p.m. last Oct. 17, it seemed to many that the end of the world was at hand. It wasn't. A year later, their lives go on. Some residents have moved; others stayed put. Regardless, their lives have been remade. --- Cathryn Green is the first in line at roller coaster rides, but refuses to cross the Bay Bridge since the earthquake. She moved in with her parents to avoid the bridge. She confines her social life to cities east of the span, crippled for one month when a section of the upper deck collapsed. She wasn't on the bridge when the quake struck, but she's scared anyway, and has only been on it one time since. ``I found myself flying across at 60 or 70 mph just to get it over with. ... By the time I got across, I had a headache. I was in no mood to go to school or do my field work,'' said Green, a graduate student at the University of California-Berkeley. She once detoured 40 miles south to San Jose rather than cross the bridge to a dinner south of San Francisco. ``I called and said, `I'll be there. I may be a little late. I'm taking the long way,' '' Green said. --- Puth Suon, 20, came to the city from Cambodia in 1984 with six other family members, after surviving years in refugee camps in his war-torn country. But the quake, he said, was too much for his mother. ``My family was kind of afraid and they just started looking for a lower apartment,'' Suon said. ``We were on the sixth floor and it felt like we were on a boat and the water hit and we were shaking. My mom was really afraid. She's a little old.'' Three weeks after the quake, the family left their $430-a-month studio apartment in the Tenderloin. They moved to Modesto, a mid-size city 100 miles southeast of San Francisco, and rented a larger place for $387. Ten percent to 20 percent of the Cambodian families in the city's Tenderloin district left after the quake, driven by fear and superstition, said Silen Nhok, refugee coordinator for the International Institute of San Francisco. ``There was a lack of information in the community. They thought of a dragon throwing his tail to cause an earthquake,'' Nhok said. --- Adele Bertaud said she might come unfastened when the next big earthquake hits, but her belongings won't. Calling herself a ``converted scared person,'' Bertaud's extensive preparations since the quake include battening down her VCR, stereo and other possessions with industrial strength Velcro ``Quake Grip.'' She founded an earthquake rescue team in her 119-unit condominium complex. The team, one of dozens organized by the city of Oakland, is training in firefighting, search and rescue and first aid in preparation for the ``Really Big One.'' Bertaud, 53, a political worker, designated a command post in her building and outfitted her office with water, food and giant Velcro to hold down computer terminals. ``I'm scared. I'm really scared. If I won the lottery, I'd be out of here in a hot minute,'' she said. --- Bernardo Arellan will spend the night of Oct. 17 sleeping in Callahan Park in Watsonville, as his family did for weeks after the quake destroyed their apartment. The six Arellan children and their parents, all born in Mexico, want to remember and be thankful for their trailer home, paid for with federal relief money. ``We were together and we were alive,'' said Arellan, whose parents are trying to buy the trailer they still live in one year later. Their apartment was renovated, but they couldn't afford the higher rent. The Callahan Park event is planned as part of the anniversary of the quake, which devastated sections of Watsonville, about 100 south of San Francisco. ``We will stay the night and remember, and to be more prepared for it because we are waiting for another big one. I'm not scared because I know it's going to happen,'' Arellan said. --- A page in Robert Hansen's sketchbook contains a crawled inscription: ``Have you hugged your dad lately? - Nightmare. Damn it.'' The sketches are drafts of artworks Hansen created since his father's death in the collapse of Oakland's Cypress freeway during the earthquake. ``He was at the interchange on the end; five seconds more and he would have escaped. If two guys had grabbed him and shook hands and said, `Enjoy the (World) Series,' that was enough,'' said Hansen, 33. ``Angels Come in Many Colors'' is a tribute to his father and 41 others who died on the freeway. The oil collage using news photos of the victims is displayed with dozens of other works in ``Beyond Fragments: After the Earthquake,'' at the Pro-Arts Gallery in Oakland. ``I'm embracing my dad in paintings,'' Hansen said. --- Bob Miguel no longer takes his wife dancing at San Francisco's Top of the Mark or for drinks up in the clouds at Bank of America's 52nd-story bar. The quake brought them back to earth. ``I won't go over the seventh floor in anything for anything,'' said Miguel, a real estate broker who lives in suburban Contra Costa County. Miguel and his wife, Joyce, celebrated her birthday at a high-quality but low-elevation restaurant in the suburbs. They were visiting a lawyer in an eighth-floor Oakland office last year when the floor rippled like ribbon candy and the staircase crashed to the lobby. Miguel wrote messages on cardboard boxes and tossed them out the window to firefighters who couldn't hear his cries. The Miguels climbed down an eight-story fire ladder, the longest made. ``I asked what would have happened had we been on the 12th floor. They said they would have to lower you inside on ladders and ropes. So if you want to give me $10,000 to go to the 54th floor, you can keep your money.'' --- One year after the earthquake miracle of Buck Helm's survival on the collapsed Cypress freeway and the tragedy of his death, his former wife, Lorrie Helm Montgomery, sits beside his grave and quietly talks to him. ``We were married 16 years and we talked about everything. ... I ask him how he would handle a family problem ... what he would suggest doing,'' she said. The 240-pound longshoreman was rescued after 89 hours in his little Chevrolet Sprint, which was crushed to a height of three feet. He had a fractured skull and ribs and only enough room to wiggle the fingers of his left hand. He lived 28 days before a hidden heart disease and the trauma to his body took his life. He was 58 years old. Dozens of movie and book offers were withdrawn after he died, Lorrie Helm Montgomery said. She recently sold the movie rights for what she said was a small sum. For the quake anniversary, she will publish a tribute to Helm in her town paper, including words he wrote to his children during a creative writing class at a junior college: ``I am who you are or will become. You are my immortality - as you remember me, I live past the allotted time given me.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Sunday, Oct 14
$Adv14
For Release Sunday, Oct 14, and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Emotional Aftershocks Plague Quake Victims a Year Later
With BC-Earthquake-Anniversary
DOC.TEXT: For Connie Bishop, a simple thing like changing lanes is enough to jolt her back to Oct. 17, 1989. ``I still don't like those little reflector bumps someone sold to the highway. You hear that thump thump when you change lanes, and you try to catch your breath,'' Bishop said. She was driving on the upper tier of Highway 880's Cypress structure when it crumbled in the earthquake, killing 42 people. She felt what she thought was a flat tire, then saw the freeway sway and a huge section yards in front of her sink to the bottom deck. Uninjured, Bishop put her experience to work. ``It was probably the biggest rush of adrenaline I've had in 37 years,'' she recalled. ``I kind of went into my old staff nurse mode. After about a minute or two, I was checking out people's injuries. It's second nature.'' A year after the shaking stopped, Bishop says she's still feeling the emotional aftershocks of the 15-second temblor. Quake nightmares and sudden bursts of fear of the Really Big One persist for many Northern Californians. Those who experienced the quake's worst devastation still may suffer severe, on-going stress and anger. As the chief administrator of Alta Bates-Herrick Hospital's mental health ward, Bishop is familiar with post-quake symptoms. As a survivor, she's experienced the sleeplessness and anxiety herself. For many, she predicts, the anniversary will bring out unresolved grief. ``We celebrate anniversaries - marriages, divorces. They are rituals around significant life events,'' Bishop said. People also have negative anniversary date reactions. ``They feel bad. Just like if you've lost a parent or a loved one. It's a loss.'' In neighborhoods near the Cypress structure, where residents scaled the crumbled concrete to save victims, heightened fear and anger linger. ``There are lots of crises - marital, relationship, child-parent. Many have been trying to get back on track with their lives and haven't been able to,'' said Ken Davis, a psychologist with the West Oakland Mental Health Center. Robert ``Raven'' Majors, 37, was among the rescuers. He still dreams about a woman who died as he promised her she would be all right. ``I kept telling her, `You'll be all right.' The side of her head was crushed and she was mumbling. Her legs were broken. ... I recall her saying, `Am I gonna be OK?' I said, `Yes.' And then she died,'' he said. A teetotaler before the disaster, Majors began drinking and took time off work as a security guard. A fear of bridges he overcame before the quake is back stronger than ever, and he pulls his van to the side before crossing the San Francisco-Oakland Bay Bridge. Majors, a raggae guitarist, never regained full use of his thumb, broken as he saved the life of a woman dangling from the smoldering ruin 25 feet above the ground. ``The black smoke was choking her. I said, `You're gonna die if you stay there. I'll try to break your fall,' '' he said. The woman fell on Majors, who flagged down a motorist to take her to the hospital. Pat and John Abduljammie live with daily reminders of the quake. Their West Oakland home, just a few yards from what used to be the Cypress structure, never was fully repaired. A sewer line remains broken, and one of the showers doesn't work. The house, cracked and broken, leans to the east because the quake jolted it off its foundation. The couple tries to cope with the anger they feel at what they view as government neglect. Damage to their home was estimated at $35,000 to $40,000, and they received $10,080 in grants. The house shakes incessantly because it is not anchored, and John Abduljammie wonders how he will be able to afford to fix it. ``It's as if you've been accosted by someone. They took your money, robbed you at gunpoint,'' said Abduljammie, an artist who works at home. He, too, was one of the West Oakland rescuers. ``The feeling I have when it shakes is anger. This is shaking from the past earthquake. It's just constant,'' his wife said.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Sunday, Oct 14

For release Sunday, Oct. 14, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Temblor Shook Loose Sales Tax Hike, Insurance, Other Laws
With BC-Earthquake Anniversary
DOC.TEXT: Last year's earthquake resulted in dozens of new California laws, including a temporary sales tax hike expected to raise $800 million and a statewide home quake insurance program. In a special session called after the Oct. 17 quake and in this year's regular session, the Legislature passed a total of 102 quake-related bills, far more than in previous years. The new laws are spreading the quake's effects into the state's distant corners, far from the San Andreas Fault. All California consumers have been paying an extra quarter-cent sales tax since Dec. 1. And all 6.5 million of the state's homeowners, even those living on absolute bedrock, next year will begin paying $12 to $60 extra annually for home insurance to cover potential quake damage. The tax increase raises the state's 6 percent sales tax for a 13-month period, from Dec. 1, 1989, through Dec. 31, 1990. The money raised will be added to the state earthquake fund, used for state and local costs such as the disaster response and the repair of state buildings, highways and roads, said Cindy Katz, spokeswoman for the state Department of Finance. The quake insurance bill creates a state insurance fund that will pay the first $15,000 of residential damage caused by an earthquake. All homeowners will pay a yearly surcharge of $12 to $60, depending on the risk where they live, beginning next July 1. One finding of the quake was that most homeowners didn't have quake insurance because premiums and deductibles, usually 10 percent of the insured value, were too high. Most of the 25,000 homes damaged by the quake suffered less than $15,000 damage - less than most deductibles. The new program would cover such damage and pay the deductible for homeowners who choose to buy full earthquake insurance. Also passed were: -A set of bills creating an $80 million statewide program to inspect all publicly owned bridges for seismic safety and fix them by Dec. 31, 1991. -A pair of bills establishing an emergency, fast-track claims process for families of people killed in the collapse of the Interstate 880 Cypress structure and the San Francisco-Oakland Bay Bridge. The bills provided $25,000 to $50,000 for claims, with a maximum of $200,000 per family. -Two quake-related measures to be put before voters this year. In June, voters approved $300 million in bonds to be used to rebuild or repair seismic problems in state and local government buildings. Voters in November will decide on Proposition 127, which would allow property owners to make seismic repairs or improvements without having the property reassessed for higher property tax rates.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Sunday, Oct. 14

DOC.TEXT: UAL Corp.'s board of directors rejected two employee buyout offers, marking the fourth failed takeover bid of the parent of United Airlines in 3{ years. The Chicago-based company also said Tuesday it would seek to quickly reach new contracts with its pilots, mechanics and flight attendants unions, which led the buyout effort. James Hanson, a spokesman for the pilots union, said the unions had not given up on buying the airline. He did not say when another proposal might be prepared. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Crude oil futures prices hit an all-time high of $40.40 a barrel as angry rhetoric from Iraqi President Saddam Hussein escalated Middle East war fears. Traders said the deaths of 19 Palestinians in Jerusalem on Monday and Saddam's threat of retaliation fed a buying spree that has nearly doubled oil prices on the futures market since Iraq invaded Kuwait Aug. 2. The price of light sweet crude - the key grade of U.S. oil - closed up $1.45 at $40.40 per 42-gallon barrel for November delivery Tuesday after gaining nearly $1 on Monday. --- NEW YORK (AP) - The average price of self-serve unleaded gasoline nationwide rose 2.4 cents in the last week to $1.37 per gallon, the American Automobile Association said. The average retail price of self-serve unleaded is up 29.5 cents, or 27.4 percent, from Aug. 1, the day before Iraq invaded Kuwait and triggered the Middle East crisis. Prices rose in all parts of the country, with largest increase in the West and the smallest in the Midwest, AAA said Tuesday. --- ANCHORAGE, Alaska (AP) - Six oil giants operating the nation's largest oilfield at Prudhoe Bay announced they are investing $1.1 billion to increase natural gas handling capacity and boost declining oil production. Bitish Petroleum, Atlantic Richfield, Exxon, Phillips, Mobil and Chevron will build and install a huge centralized natural gas handling facility that will help boost oil production. Los Angeles-based ARCO will operate the facility. The project, to be completed by 1995, is expected to increase oil production by 100,000 barrels a day, officials said Tuesday. --- CINCINNATI (AP) - Procter & Gamble Co. shareholders rejected a resolution that urged the company to stop buying coffee from El Salvador until that nation ends its civil war, with more than 97 percent voting against it. James Gamble of Amherst, Mass., great-great grandson of the company's co-founder was one of the resolution's sponsors. P&G's board of directors had recommended shareholders reject the proposal, which was voted on Tuesday. The maker of Folgers coffee refuses to say how much Salvadoran coffee it buys annually, but says the amount is less than 2 percent. P&G buys coffee from 30 countries. --- CINCINNATI (AP) - Procter & Gamble Co. said it will spend $20 million to encourage construction of waste composting plants, and is developing a disposable diaper that breaks down totally in such plants. A company official said Tuesday P&G's main interest in the project is providing initiative to help resolve the problem of mounting garbage and limited landfill space. Bans or taxes on disposable diapers were considered in as many as 20 states this year. Nebraska, for one, has effectively banned the sale of non-degradable diapers starting in 1993. --- BAGHDAD, Iraq (AP) - Iraq produced more than 3 million metric tons of grain this year, and plans to produce at least 38 percent more next season to beat United Nations sanctions on trade, the government newspaper said. The increase will help Iraq achieve food self-sufficiency in the face of the U.N. embargo imposed after its Aug. 2 invasion and subsequent annexation of neighboring Kuwait, the newspaper, al-Jumhouriya said Tuesday. --- DEARBORN, Mich. (AP) - With the focus of auto union talks shifting to Chrysler Corp., Chairman Lee Iacocca plans to argue that his company can't afford to be as generous with its workers as Ford and GM. But United Auto Workers Vice President Stan Marshall said it would be pretty hard for Iacocca to plead poverty since he has made so much money in the last five years. --- TOKYO (AP) - A former chairman of Japan's largest company was convicted Tuesday of bribery in the widespread influence-buying Recruit scandal, which had played a role in bringing down two prime ministers. The Tokyo District Court ordered a two-year suspended prison term and a $175,000 fine for Hisashi Shinto, 80, for accepting an offer of prelisted stock that seemed certain to rise in value, court officials said. The non-jury trial has been closely watched in Japan as a court test of what constitutes a bribe in this country, where gift-giving is a common practice in business and politics. ---

Stocks fell sharply Tuesday. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials tumbled 78.22 points, or 3.1 percent, to close at 2,445.54. It was the Dow average's 11th worst point drop, after the fall of 86.61 points on Sept. 11, 1986. The dollar weakened against most major currencies. Gold prices tumbled after rising overseas. Grains and soybeans were mixed; meat and livestock futures were slightly higher; and energy futures rose sharply. Precious metals plummeted. Bond prices fell sharply on concern about rising oil prices and interest rates.

DOC.HEAD: UAL Unions Say Employee Ownership Still Their Goal
DOC.TEXT: United Airlines' pilots say they'll keep pushing for employee ownership, but they're making contract talks their top priority after UAL Corp.'s board rejected their latest buyout bid. ``We're not about to stop buying the airline,'' said James Hanson, a spokesman for the United chapter of the Air Line Pilots Association. United's flight attendants and mechanics also are committed to employee ownership of the nation's biggest airline, said Gerald Greenwald, chairman of the three-union group that mounted the acquisition attempt. But until the group's advisers evaluate their options, ``I don't think you even assume there will be another bid,'' said Hank Krakowski, a spokesman for the buyout group. UAL's board of directors rejected the labor bid Tuesday, marking the fourth failed takeover of the Chicago-based company in 3{ years. The last previous attempt, which also involved the pilots, collapsed almost one year ago. Tuesday was the deadline for employees to arrange financing for a $201-per-share, $4.38 billion offer that the board accepted in principle in April. Despite a lack of bank financing, the buyout group presented the board with two offers. Both were rejected. UAL said it wants to reach new contracts quickly with the unions and will proceed with plans to place a large aircraft order it had postponed at the labor group's request. The rejection stirred speculation that UAL's largest shareholder, Coniston Partners, would revive an effort to oust UAL's board and senior management, including Chairman Stephen M. Wolf. Coniston said it was exploring its options. UAL's stock fell $4 a share Tuesday to $88 on the New York Stock Exchange. The union workers, representing about two-thirds of UAL's 71,000 employees, are working under expired contracts. ``We're going to knuckle down and work on contract negotiations full steam,'' Krakowski said. Greenwald's statement said the labor proposals, which include employee concessions, would remain on the table briefly. He did not return telephone calls to elaborate. The pilots, who launched their first acquisition effort in 1987, vowed last month to confront UAL's management with everything up to and including a strike if the board rejected the latest offer. In a statement, the three unions said Tuesday they would ``pursue all means necessary'' to gain substantial improvements in wages and benefits. Greenwald said the buyout group presented two proposals: a $4.47 billion offer for $205 a share including $70 in cash and $135 in securities, and a $4.43 billion offer for $203 a share with no cash component. UAL said it would proceed with plans to place an aircraft order that Wolf said in the spring would be the largest ever placed for wide-bodied jetliners. In July, the board bowed to employees' request to postpone the aircraft purchase until the buyout effort was resolved. ``This is a time of unique opportunity to continue to build United Airlines,'' Wolf said in a statement. UAL said it had asked the National Mediation Board to resume expedited mediation immediately in hopes of reaching labor pacts with the pilots, whose contract expired in April 1988, and the flight attendants, whose contract expired in November 1987. The company said it also was prepared to resume negotiations with the Machinists union, whose contract with UAL expired in November.

DOC.HEAD: Standard & Poor's Places City's Bond Rating on Credit Watch
DOC.TEXT: A tentative agreement to give teachers a 5.5 percent raise and New York City's worsening economy prompted a major bond rating agency to begin reviewing the city's ability to repay debt. The move by Standard & Poors Corp. Tuesday to put the city's $13 billion in outstanding general obligation bonds on ``credit watch'' means the agency could decide to downgrade the debt. Such a move would force the city to pay higher yields to investors who demand higher returns for the risk. S&P stopped short of lowering the city's rating of A-minus but said it sees a need ``to revise the city's financial plan and to evaluate its payroll burden in line with the realities'' of a slipping economy. ``I'm confident we are going to satisfy them that we are in control,'' Mayor David Dinkins said. ``We have a plan. We are going to meet that gap.'' The mayor has projected a $1.4 billion budget deficit for the next year. ``The city is not on the verge of an economic disaster,'' State Comptroller Edward Regan said. ``It's a cyclical downturn with an erosion of revenue, but that can be handled. The problem is that this year's budget was too large to begin with.'' Regan said there is plenty of room for Dinkins to cut the $28 billion budget for the fiscal year that began July 1, starting with some 8,500 new city hires built into the budget. An A-rating from S&P means the agency believes the city has a strong ability to pay interest and principal on the bonds, although that ability is more susceptible to economic downswings. A plus or minus sign on a rating shows its relative standing within the catagory. The next step lower is BBB, which signifies that adverse conditions make it more likely the city will have trouble paying interest and principal. The other major rating agency, Moody's Investors Service, does not have the city's rating under formal review, managing director Jeffrey Rizzo said. Gov. Mario Cuomo, who was in New York City on Tuesday, said the city does not face a replay of the fiscal crisis of 1975 because mechanisms created then will prevent such a slide now. Saving the city from bankruptcy in 1975 ``wasn't done by sending them money,'' Cuomo said. ``It was done by giving them a mechanism called MAC (Municipal Assistance Corporation) and guidance through the Financial Control Board. ``Those are still in place, and the market knows that,'' Cuomo said.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Giants' Plan May Cut Jobs
DOC.TEXT: Six oil giants' plan to spend $1.1 billion boosting oil production in Prudhoe Bay may cost some Alaska oil workers their jobs as the companies consolidate the work, executives said. British Petroleum Co., Atlantic Richfield Co., Exxon Corp., Phillips Petroleum Co., Mobil Corp. and Chevron Corp. announced an agreement Tuesday to build and install a huge centralized natural gas handling facility to help boost declining oil production at Prudhoe Bay, the nation's largest oil field. ARCO will operate the facility. The project, expected to be completed by 1995, would increase oil production by 100,000 barrels a day, company officials said. It will add an estimated 330 million to 450 million barrels of oil to reserves at the field, they said. BP and ARCO, the two operating partners at Prudhoe Bay, also agreed to reduce overlapping services, including staff and contract jobs, on the North Slope and in Anchorage by the end of 1991. The number of jobs cut won't be known until next year, officials said, but they promised a ``gradual process.'' BP and ARCO together employ about 4,600 workers at Prudhoe Bay. ``At a time of American concern about long-term oil supplies, this project will make a welcome contribution and shows Alaska's potential to add significant domestic reserves,'' BP Chairman Robert Horton and ARCO Chairman Lodwrick M. Cook said in a prepared statement. The oil companies' announcement follows resolution of their longstanding disputes over how much natural gas is available at the wells and who owns it, said Julian Darley, president of BP Exploration (Alaska) Inc. Prudhoe Bay accounts for roughly 20 percent of domestic oil production. The field began producing in 1977, and in 1988 reached its peak at 1.6 million barrels a day. The oilfield's production has started to decline, however. Production now averages 1.4 million barrels a day, said ARCO spokesman Albert Greenstein in Los Angeles. Average 1990 production will be about 1.35 million barrels a day, he said. BP Exploration (Alaska) Inc., a 50 percent owner in the field, estimates production will decline 10 percent to 12 percent annually through the end of the century. As the oilfield ages, oil coming from its wells is mixed with increasing amounts of natural gas and water, officials said. The new facility would allow producers to separate gas from oil and reinject the gas into the wells. Reinjection increases pressure which increases oil flow. Dubbed ``GHX-2,'' the new gas expansion project will go on line in two stages. The first huge gas-handling module will be shipped by barge to Prudhoe Bay in 1993. A second module will follow in 1994, officials said. Last summer, the companies began installing the first major gas facility expansion - GHX-1. It is set to go on line later this year and will boost daily gas handling capacity from the current 3.8 billion cubic feet to 5.2 billion cubic feet. After the new modules begin operation in 1995, gas handling capacity is expected to increase to 7.5 billion cubic feet per day. ARCO Alaska spokeswoman Susan Andrews said the project will create a significant number of new jobs, mostly short- and medium-term construction jobs, but that it was too early to nail down local employment figures.

DOC.HEAD: Government: Boesky Unlikely To Be Called as Witness
DOC.TEXT: Junk bond financier Michael Milken probably won't get a chance to face his main accuser, Ivan Boesky, before sentencing. Federal prosecutors said Tuesday they do not plan to call the inside trader to testify against Milken at a pre-sentencing hearing. Assistant U.S. Attorney John Carroll also said the government was dropping one of four alleged illegal transactions against Milken on which it planned to present evidence and testimony at the planned two-week hearing. The move not to include Boesky in the unusual hearing, scheduled to begin Thursday, was not a great surprise. Boesky was the main source of information against Milken but also was susceptible to attack from defense lawyers. Milken has pleaded guilty to six felony counts and has agreed to pay $600 million in penalties in connection with the biggest government probe of Wall Street fraud. He faces up to 28 years in prison when sentenced by U.S. District Judge Kimba Wood. Sentencing was delayed for the hearing into uncharged allegations against Milken raised by the government in its lengthy pre-sentencing memorandum. Wood has said the hearing is designed to shed light on Milken's character. In a telephone conference with the judge and Milken's attorneys, Carroll said the government was unlikely to call Boesky to the witness stand. But they did not rule out the possibility altogether, he said. Carroll also said to save time the government was dropping from its presentation an inside trading allegation involving Milken and Boesky in securities of MGM-UA Entertainment Co. Boesky also was a central player in two of the other transactions being aired - stock manipulation charges in Wickes Cos. securities in 1985 and a web of alleged wrongdoing in the 1985 takeover of Storer Communications Inc. The third alleges insider trading in Caesar's World Inc. securities in 1983. The Caesar's and Storer transactions involve new charges against Milken not contained in the government's original 98-count indictment last year or earlier Securities and Exchange Commission charges. Wood has given each side a total of 20 hours to present eestimony and cross-examine witnesses at the hearing. The burden of proof on the government is lower than at a trial, though. Boesky, who was sentenced to three years in prison and paid $100 million in penalties to settle insider trading charges, is widely reviled on Wall Street and would have given Milken attorney Arthur Liman a broad target to discredit. Boesky was not regarded as a successful witness when he testified earlier this year against former stock speculator John A. Mulheren Jr. Boesky was perceived as combative on the stand and was forced to admit a litany of serious lawbreaking. Instead, Carroll said the government's first three witnesses on the Wickes transaction would be former Boesky head trader Michael Davidoff and former Drexel employees Cary Maultasch and Peter Gardiner, who worked under Milken in Drexel's Beverly Hills, Calif., high-yield bond department. Carroll said the Wickes testimony would be followed by testimony on Storer and then Caesar's. The prosecutor also disclosed that former Drexel trader James Dahl and mutual fund manager Prescott Crocker were among about 10 planned witnesses on the Caesar's deal. The witnesses for the Storer transactions were not disclosed. Prosecutors last week gave defense lawyers a list of 17 possible witnesses and Wood has ordered the government to say in what order it would call them, to help the defense prepare its case. The witness list also includes former Drexel chairman Frederick Joseph. Liman indicated during the conference call that Milken would be present at the hearing in Manhattan federal court.

DOC.HEAD: NCR Pins Strategy on Software Launch
DOC.TEXT: NCR Corp., a company known for electronic cash registers and automated teller machines, has launched a software system that marks a sharp departure from its traditional sales strongholds, analysts said. The ``Cooperation'' software, unveiled Tuesday at a glitzy press conference in Manhattan's theater district, employs visual on-screen aids and other features to let users obtain information from data bases, route documents and talk electronically with other employees. The announcement comes three weeks after the company said it would replace its entire computer line with industry-standard machines that all could communicate with each other. Based on the open system, the new software launch is designed to help a company's computer users communicate with each other - even if they are working on non-NCR computers. ``Nobody can call NCR dull anymore,'' said NCR Chairman and CEO Charles E. Exley Jr. at the press conference, as he slipped on a pair of bright red sunglasses outfitted with flashing lights. The fifth largest U.S. computer maker, based in Dayton, Ohio, dominates the slow-growing banking and retail-automation markets but is considered a runner-up in mainstream business computers. The new software targets all types of companies from 50 employees and up. ``What you're seeing is NCR coming out of their shell with this product,'' said Bob Vautrain, senior research analyst at Gartner Group Inc. ``They're trying to take an obscure $6 billion company from the Midwest and take it into general-purpose computing.'' Relying on Hewlett-Packard Co.'s New Wave visual computer technology, Cooperation is the first software product released under NCR's new ``open'' computing architecture. The product, unveiled at the Lunt-Fontanne Theatre, was backed by an extravagant stage show of colorful lights, screens aglow with changing images of the product in use, and a demonstration by two computer operators using the software product at actual on-stage work stations. The extravaganza was intended to build excitement among software manufacturers and encourage them to write programs that can run on the NCR system, analysts said. ``Now that you have this great interface, you have to get software manufacturers to write for it,'' said Vautrain. ``I think there's a possibility it will happen.'' Exley said that Cooperation is far more comprehensive than equivalent systems on the market, with the ability to integrate thousands of standard software packages. ``There is nothing announced at this point - much less in the form of product - anywhere as near as comprehensive,'' Exley said in an interview following the announcement. The software modules range from $1,700-$2,500 per user for a 24-user company, but the total cost of operating the system when the workstations are included comes to $10,000-$12,000 per user, Exley said, noting that the cost for a 100-station company would total $1 million. The first release of Cooperation is scheduled for next month. The product is expected to be more generally available in March. NCR is backing the launch of its open system products with a $12 million advertising campaign, starting with an ad in Wednesday's Wall Street Journal, NCR officials said. Other ads will appear in industry trade publications. Next week NCR is expected to elaborate how companies can employ NCR's new software.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Generally Higher in Europe, Gold Lower
DOC.NOTE: Eds: version also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. dollar rose slightly against most other major currencies in European trading late this morning. Gold prices staged a partial recovery from their sharp dive in New York late Tuesday but were still down from Tuesday's late bids in Europe. Dealers said the dollar was holding steady above its historic lows against the German mark. The ongoing U.S. budget stalemate this week highlighted the debate over a potential easing of U.S. interest rates, sending the dollar on a new downward course, dealers said. Renewed Middle East tensions and a rally in oil prices on Tuesday restrained potential dollar sellers, one Frankfurt dealer said. ``But the general direction is still lower.'' In Tokyo, banks and markets were closed for Sports Day, a national holiday. In London, the dollar was quoted at 130.35 yen, up from 129.95 yen in Tokyo late Tuesday. In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.9675, cheaper for buyers than $1.9705 late Tuesday. Other dollar rates at midmorning in Europe, compared with late Tuesday's rates included: 1.5256 German marks, up from 1.5245; 1.2777 Swiss francs, up from 1.2765; 5.1083 French francs, up from 5.1005; 1.7160 Dutch guilders, down from 1.7185; 1,143.60 Italian lire, up from 1,143.25, and 1.1503 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1507. The pound had spurted earlier today on rumors that U.S. forces were mobilized in the Persian Gulf, which were denied by the Pentagon. London's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended gold price of $392.20 per ounce at midmorning, down from $396.25 bid per ounce late Tuesday. In Zurich, the bid price was $391.90, down from $395.50. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell $2.10 to close at a bid $392.27. Silver traded in London at a bid price of $4.63 a troy ounce, down from Tuesday's $4.68.

DOC.HEAD: Bargain Hunters Throng Oil-Spill Auction, Drive Up Prices
LaserPhoto AG1
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of bargain hunters snatched up everything from all-terrain vehicles to animal shampoo on the first day of an Alaska-size garage sale offering gear from the Exxon Valdez cleanup. Locals grumbled that out-of-town businessmen with plenty of money in their pockets and a need to justify their jaunts to Alaska helped drive up prices Tuesday. ``It's a feeding frenzy,'' said Butch Johnson, a fisherman in search of nets who lives in the Prince William Sound fishing community of Cordova. Everything on the opening-day block was sold, including a plane, mobile homes, TV sets and cat box filler, used to provide traction on oily beaches. Ritchie Bros. Auctioneers International of Vancouver, British Columbia, bought the leftover equipment from Exxon Corp. last month for untold millions. The auction company won't say how much it expects to make, but officials said they collected $3.8 million Tuesday. Many items were grouped in lots, about 5,000 of them. ``A sale like this only comes around once in a lifetime,'' said Rod Meeks, an Anchorage aviation mechanic who bought two outboard motors for $3,250. ``You really realize the size of the spill by all th garbage that came out of it.'' The four-day sale continues through Friday at various sites. The items up for sale today include 10 cars, 51 trucks, six buses, heavy equipment such as forklifts and more marine supplies. Many in the crowd complained prices were too high. Some people were upset about having to buy in lots. Microwave ovens were clumped with animal shampoo, for example. Anchorage businessman Brian Watson, looking for equipment for his water purification company, expressed awe at sky-high pallets around him. ``The magnitude of this - and all because one ship blew it big,'' he said. The Exxon Valdez ran aground in Prince William Sound in March 1989 and spewed nearly 11 million gallons of crude in the nation's biggest oil spill. Exxon crews worked two summers to clean up the mess and plan to return next spring for a shoreline survey. Exxon officials said they didn't sell any equipment that could be used for additional cleanup. Parked cars lined the roads for miles in all directions and Ritchie Bros. ran shuttle buses to the auction. An auctioneer in a booth atop a truck sold rows of all-terrain vehicles and aluminum skiffs, pallet after pallet of brand-new fishing nets and such things as life jackets, tables and chairs. There was more inside a hangar, including outdoor thermometers and clothing. A 1966 DeHaviland Beaver seaplane with an old Esso tiger painted on its tail and uncertain salt-water wear sold for $435,000. New, the plane would cost about $700,000, said several air-taxi company officials in the crowd. Four used, nothing-special TV sets sold for a total of $2,000. Exxon used the TVs and videocassette recorders, also for sale, to show training tapes. ``Prices are way out of line. The people we know - the fishermen - aren't buying anything. They're just shaking their heads,'' said a Kodiak fisherman who wouldn't give his name.

DOC.HEAD: London Shares Down at Midday
DOC.TEXT: Share prices were lower at midday Wednesday, hit by rumors of U.S. troop movements in the Middle East. The late morning rumor knocked the main index down about 10 points, traders said. Since then, a U.S. Pentagon official has denied any U.S. troop movements in the region. ``The market fell like a lead duck,'' one trader said, underscoring how susceptible the market is to Middle East developments. The increased tensions Tuesday and the rumor Wednesday have once again scared investors away from the market, traders said. At midday, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was down 20.4 points, or 1 percent, at 2,113.7. Volume was 258.8 million shares.

DOC.HEAD: MGM-UA Settles $200 Million Lawsuit For $35 Million
DOC.TEXT: MGM-UA settled a $200 million shareholders' lawsuit for $35 million, and the troubled entertainment firm said it would file suit against insurers who it said forced MGM-UA into the settlement. ``The settlement was forced on the company by a bad faith settlement by its insurers,'' attorney Terry Christensen said Tuesday. He represents billionaire Kirk Kerkorian, the sole defendant in the class action suit. The action charged that Kerkorian's purchase of United Artists from Turner Broadcasting in 1986 robbed shareholders of profits. In the deal, Turner got the MGM and RKO Warner film libraries. The suit alleged Kerkorian, the controlling stockholder, undervalued United Artists when he sold MGM-UA Entertainment to Turner, then bought back UA. MGM-UA was sold for $1.5 billion, while Kerkorian bought back UA for $470 million. The suit claimed Kerkorian failed to get the highest possible price for the MGM-UA stock. Kerkorian retained UA's film library, which includes such perennial stock as the ``Rocky'' and ``James Bond'' movies. Christensen claimed that the bad faith actions were taken by Harbor Insurance Co., Forum Insurance Co., Associated International Insurance Co., and National Union Fire Insurance Co. Late calls made to the insurers' Los Angeles offices rang unanswered. MGM-UA is suing to recover the $35 million settlement amount plus punitive damages, Christensen said. ``Although we steadfastly deny any wrongdoing on MGM-UA's part, we were compelled to reach this settlement,'' Christensen said. ``It is outrageous that any insurance company would take such actions without a client's knowledge and consent and in total disregard of its interests,'' he said. ``Their attempts to partially settle the suit completely undermined our efforts to defend it.'' Class-action attorney Michael Hennigan said the settlement was given preliminary approval Tuesday. Final approval is expected Nov. 19. He said the money will be divided among thousands who held MGM-UA stock between 1985 and 1986.

DOC.BYLINE: China Plans Partial Return to Collective Farming
DOC.TEXT: Chinese leaders are cautiously planning a partial return to collective farming in hopes of raising productivity, according to an official newspaper report Wednesday. Ten years after land was distributed to individual farming households, Communist Party and government officials recently decided that ``household contracted lands should be redistributed ... and production conducted under a unified plan,'' the English-language China Daily said. China's reformist leaders dismantled the commune system a decade ago, allowing the rural economy to return to a family farming system that allowed farmers to sell some crops on the free market. As a result, grain production jumped by one-third and rural incomes tripled. But that growth has stagnated. China's farmable land is shrinking annually because of industrial development, and plots worked by individual farmers, averaging 1.5 acres, are too small for efficient mechanized farming. At the recent national meeting, party and government officials decided that ``conglomerates in charge of supply, production and sales'' would be established to make large-scale mechanized farming possible, the China Daily reported. It did not say what incentives farmers would have to join the conglomerates or give details about how the conglomerates would be set up. Supporters of such a system have carefully avoided calling the collectives ``communes,'' which evoke unpleasant memories of extreme poverty and the leadership's ``leftist mistakes.'' Aware that the change is likely to be unpopular among China's 80 million peasant population, officials stressed the household contract system was not being abandoned. Rather, it would be incorporated into a ``two-tier rural economy'' along with the collective sector. Redistribution will be done with the consent of the majority of local farmers, the report said. Calls have been heard for several years for a return to large-scale farming. Experts say the family farmer who brought prosperity to many rural areas has outlived his usefulness and must make way for large-scale mechanized farming.

DOC.HEAD: Court Boosts Bid by Baby Bells
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court has boosted a bid by the nation's seven regional telephone companies to enter the multibillion dollar industry of providing electronic information services to homes and businesses. The court, without comment, rejected an appeal Tuesday aimed at making it harder for the companies to enter the developing industry. The underlying issue is whether the companies, so-called Baby Bells, should be allowed to use their phone lines to sell such information as stock market quotes and ``electronic Yellow Pages'' with home-shopping and classified advertising. The U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals here handed the Baby Bells a crucial victory in April. The appeals court threw out part of a 1987 ruling by U.S. District Court Judge Harold Greene, who has overseen the breakup of the AT&T phone monopoly for more than a decade. The appeals court said Greene was too strict in barring the regional companies from selling the information services. It sent the case back to him with instructions to use a more lenient test - whether lifting the ban would be in the public interest. Asking the Supreme Court for help was a coalition of consumer groups, long-distance phone companies, equipment manufacturers, data-processing businesses and newspapers that want to enter the at-home information market. The coalition, including the American Newspaper Publishers Association, said the appeals court ruling could restore the bottleneck that once blocked competition to Ma Bell. The appeals court ruling jeopardizes the vigorous economic growth spawned by the breakup of AT&T in 1984, the coalition said. But the phone companies said their opponents are trying to kill legitimate competition and that most Americans will be slow in getting information services unless the Baby Bells participate. The Bush administration sided with the phone companies in urging the Supreme Court to leave the appeals court ruling undisturbed. The Justice Department defended the public-interest standard in the appeals court decision and said any high court review now would be premature. Greene's 1987 decision loosened the information services restrictions somewhat to let phone companies set up local numbers that customers could call to connect to many different computer data bases. But it upheld the core restriction that the phone companies can convey only other parties' data but not originate data themselves. The phone companies also have been backing legislation in Congress to remove Green's authority and many of the restrictions he imposed. The case is MCI Communications vs. U.S., 90-9.

DOC.HEAD: American Airlines To Lay Off 1,000
DOC.NOTE: EDS: grafs 2-3 NEW to ADD quote that most will be thru attrition; uppicks 3rd graf pvs: The Fort . . .
DOC.TEXT: Rising fuel prices and a weakening economy have forced American Airlines to send layoff notices to 40 workers as part of a plan to eliminate 1,000 jobs from its payroll. American spokesman Al Becker said today that ``almost all'' of the laid off employees will be ``absorbed into other positions in the company. We want to eliminate those jobs mainly through attrition.'' The Fort Worth-based airlines, which employs more than 90,400 workers, took the action ``to reduce costs,'' he said. ``The (cost-cutting) plan isn't completed yet and won't be for several more weeks.'' Airline officials had said this past summer that American planned to trim costs sharply, and a surprise hike in the price of jet fuel last winter contributed to a first-quarter loss of $19.3 million. An unexpected decline in domestic air travel followed, helping to slash second-quarter profits by 27 percent, to $129.2 million when compared to the year-ago period. American officials had planned to reduce costs by implementing a ``head-count freeze'' in management and clerical ranks. The company said it planned to eliminate about 1,000 jobs primarily through attrition, but did not rule out layoffs if necessary. Becker said several American workers at Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport, the largest of the carrier's seven connecting hubs, were included in the layoffs. He did not know the specific number. The American workers affected at D-FW, where the airline has more than 12,000 workers, primarily are fleet service clerks, a group that includes airplane cleaners and baggage handlers. American currently operates 541 aircraft.

DOC.HEAD: Government Clings to Austral But People Prefer Dollar
DOC.TEXT: The government insists it won't change the austral as Argentina's official currency - its fifth in 20 years. But many Argentines already have. Most every good and service in this Latin nation now is priced in U.S. dollars as well as the devalued austral, making Argentina one of the few countries in the world with two working currencies. Blue, purple and red bills mingle in wallets and purses with the U.S. money that Argentines call ``greenbacks.'' Hotels, restaurants, department stores and shops selling everything from furs to eyeglasses accept either as cash. Doctors, dentists, lawyers, architects and other professionals set fees in dollars, payable in dollars or australs at the exchange rate of the day. So do insurance agents, plumbers, handymen and even housemaids. Sonia Repetto, owner of a women's clothing store, explains why: ``I had my prices in australs when March hyperinflation took me by surprise. When I went to restock the merchandise I had sold, I found I could buy only 10 percent of what I needed.'' The cost of living in March soared by 95 percent, eroding her savings, purchasing power and confidence. ``I don't want to even see an austral,'' Ms. Repetto said. Until last year, it was illegal to sell, rent, bank or borrow in currency other than the austral. Regulations rarely were enforced, bt people who skirted controls were regarded as black marketeers and subject to fines and jail. Thousands of Argentines beset by inflation that topped 100 percent in 15 of the past 16 years took their chances. They bought dollars and stashed $5 billion at home ``under the mattress,'' and shipped perhaps 10 times that amount out of the country. Runs on the austral, introduced in mid-1985 at a value of $1.20 apiece, became common as speculators relentlessly bid against it by buying dollars. The central bank almost went broke in early 1989 trying to prop up the national currency. Inflation and devaluation knocked out the peso in 1970, the peso ley in 1983 and the peso Argentino two years later. They also and have put the austral on the ropes. The money supply is a tiny 4 percent of gross domestic product partly because no one wants the austral. Its exchange value vs. the dollar fell to the current 5,700-to-1 from a rate of 17-to-1 in early 1989. A big banknote then was 100 australs. The biggest today: 500,000. Central Bank President Javier Gonzalez Fraga admits, ``The majority of Argentines have their savings in dollars.'' President Carlos Menem bowed to reality when he took office 15 months ago. He removed exchange controls and authorized savings accounts, certificates of deposit and bonds in dollars. Concerned about inflation's effect on investment and relative prices, the government now is considering offering mortgages, loans and checking accounts in dollars. Car dealers raised eyebrows earlier this year when they refused to accept payment in australs, which were losing value by the hour. Now, prices on the grain exchange are quoted in dollars. So are hamburgers and sodas by a street vendor at Constitution Station. Commuters can buy one of each for a buck. ``All my suppliers bill me for wood in dollars, so I sell my doors, shelves and everything else in dollars,'' said Carmelo Gremoni, a 60-year-old carpenter. Alberto Testa collects premiums for an insurance company that shifted bills from australs to dollars during an inflationary outburst, and last month tried to resume billing in australs. ``They had to redo everything because the customers complained,'' Testa said. ``They got used to paying in dollars.'' The ``dollarization'' of the economy provoked panic when the government hinted last December it intended to link wages and fiscal expenditures to the U.S. currency to restrict state spending. On New Year's weekend, speculators bid up the dollar to 6,000-to-1 - three times the free market rate at the time. Hoarding and shortages occurred. Opponents said the proposal meant a loss of sovereignty. The government backed off, but the dollar's influence expanded anyway as the exchange rate held steady at slightly above 5,200-to-1 since April while the cost of living in australs continued to rise by 11 percent or more per month. Now, the dollar seems cheap as well as stable, and there are fewer political and social objections to the widespread use of a foreign currency. Bankers say the use of two currencies seems irreversible. Argentines' savings in dollars amounts to more than the entire money supply in australs, and more than central bank reserves. And most of it is outside the banking system and unavailable for lending. Partly as a result, interest rates are high, investment is low and no end is in sight for Argentina's deepest recession this century.

DOC.HEAD: End of Rains, Recession Fears Push Futures Lower
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures drifted lower in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade. Overall, the market is being pressured by forecasts the rains of the past few days will be ending. That will allow farmers to get on with the harvest. Fears of a recession also are worrying the market and pushing prices lower, said Victor Lespinasse, an analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. in Chicago. Prices also are pressured lower by anticipation of the U.S. Agriculture Department's October crop estimate, due out Wednesday. The report is expected to put the estimated soybean crop at 1.832 billion bushels, and the corn crop at 8.060 billion bushels, Lespinasse said. Corn futures are being pressured by the Soviet Union's denial of rumors that it purchased U.S. corn overnight. And sluggish export sales of soybeans are pushing those futures lower. In early trading, wheat was 1 cent to 1} cents lower with the contract for delivery in December at $2.77 a bushel; corn was a { cent to 1 cent lower with December at $2.33\ a bushel; oats were a \ cent to 1 cent lower with December at $1.21\ a bushel; soybeans were 1 cent to 6\ cents lower with November at $6.28{ cents a bushel. Livestock and pork futures were lower in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Selling was prompted by Tuesday's deep decline on the New York Stock Exchange, which reinforced belief the U.S. economy is entering a recession. Live cattle were .15 cent to .75 cent lower with October at 79 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .17 cent to .82 cent lower with October at 87.70 cents a pound; hogs were .15 cent to .37 cent lower with October at 56.55 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .10 cent to .55 cents lower with February at 63.90 cents a pound. Livestock and pork futures settled higher in Tuesday's trading.
