DOC.HEAD: Justices Voice Doubts Over Employer Policy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: longer version on general news wires as PM-Scotus Rdp.
DOC.TEXT: Three Supreme Court justices voiced doubts today about the wisdom or legality of an employer's ``fetal protection'' policy that excludes all women of childbearing age from some hazardous jobs. In a case that could affect millions of working women, Justices John Paul Stevens, Antonin Scalia and Sandra Day O'Connor posed questions seemingly critical of the policy during an hour-long argument session. Stevens questioned Stanley Jaspan, a lawyer for the Milwaukee-based Johnson Controls Inc., about the risks to women working in its battery-making factories. ``Is the slightest risk enough'' to justify banning women from some jobs, Stevens asked. O'Connor and Scalia took issue with Jaspan's interpretation of what burdens Congress placed on employers when it passed the Pregnancy Discrimination Act in 1978. Scalia told Jaspan his suggestion that the 1978 law means employers cannot discriminate against women based on pregnancy except to protect a fetus ``is to make a farce of the Pregnancy Discrimination Act. You're making it a ridiculous piece of legislation.'' Since 1982, Johnson Controls, the nation's largest auto battery manufacturer, has barred women from factory jobs that expose them to unsafe levels of lead, the principal material used in making batteries. The policy was upheld by lower courts. Lead exposure is a health risk for female workers and their fetuses. Lead exposure, of course, also is a health risk for male workers. But the scientific proof that high levels of lead in a man's blood can contribute to fetal harm is sketchy. ``It would violate common sense ... to require an employer to damage unborn children,'' Jaspan argued. He said lead exposure ``poisons the fetus and causes permanent brain damage.'' But San Francisco lawyer Marsha Berzon, representing those who challenged the Johnson Controls policy, said ``the net effect of a policy like this is to sanction the re-segregation of the workplace.'' She said such policies relegate women to stereotypical jobs such as teaching, child care and nursing. The justices must decide by July whether the fetal protection policy amounts to illegal discrimination. One federal appeals court judge, calling the case the most important of its kind since Congress outlawed on-the-job sex bias 26 years ago, said the estimated number of women affected runs as high as 20 million. At Johnson Controls, women who could not prove they were infertile were forced to transfer to other jobs, although their salaries were not cut. Some of the women were in their 60s. Fertile women now hired are ineligible for top-paying jobs at the company's 13 plants, located in California, Delaware, Florida, Illinois, Kentucky, North Carolina, Michigan, Missouri, Ohio, Oregon, Texas, Vermont and Wisconsin. Eight employees and the United Auto Workers union challenged the policy in court, alleging that it violates Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964. It was not the first such challenge. At least 15 major corporations have fetal protection policies, and the American Civil Liberties Union says lawsuits have been filed in behalf of hospital technicians and factory and auto workers. Among the companies with such policies are General Motors, Monsanto and DuPont. U.S. District Judge Robert W. Warren in Milwaukee ruled for Johnson Controls before any trial was held, and the 7th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals voted 7-4 to uphold his ruling. Judge John L. Coffey wrote for the appeals court that the differing treatment of women employees was based on a ``business necessity.'' The appeals court concluded that the policy ``is reasonably necessary to industrial safety.'' Bush administration lawyers told the high court that a fetal protection policy could be legal, but that it should be judged by a standard more stringent than the ``business necessity'' test used by the appeals court. In a strongly worded dissent to the appeals court ruling, Judge Frank Easterbrook called the case the most important Title VII case ever and said such policies could ``consign more women to `women's work' while reserving better-paying but more hazardous jobs for men.'' He noted that lead is only one of many workplace substances that could harm fetuses, and said as many as 20 million jobs could be closed to women if the 7th Circuit court's rationale were adopted nationwide.

DOC.HEAD: Seagull to Acquire Oil, Gas Properties from Mesa
DOC.TEXT: Mesa L.P. has agreed to sell a portion of its oil and gas properties and undeveloped land to Seagull Energy Corp. in a deal that could reach $476 million, the companies announced today. Under terms outlined in a letter of intent, Houston-based Seagull will pay $376 million in cash for reserves and acreage and assume $50 million in liabilities. Mesa also could receive up to an additional $50 million in 1994, based on the weighted average price of natural gas sold from the properties between 1991 and 1993. The de the properties,al, which covers about 15 percent of the oil and gas company controlled by corporate raider T. Boone Pickens, is subject to approval by Seagull's board and financing. The deal is expected to close in December. ``These properties will greatly diversify our total reserve portfolio, give us significant reserve positions and exploratory prospects in geographic areas other than our historic Gulf Coast area of emphasis, and extend the average reserve life of our company's reserves,'' said Seagull Chairman Barry J. Galt. The assets to be purchased include Mesa's Midcontinent, Rocky Mountain and Gulf Coast offshore properties and operations. Pickens said the sale would help Mesa increase ``our concentration of hp of northern islands seized at war's end. Japanese newspapers and the Kyodo News Service reported this weekend that the Soviets had offered to return two of the four disputed islands and sign a peace treaty within five years. But Moscow on Monday denied offering any concessions, and its news agency blasted the Japanese reports as ``disinformation'' aimed at setting back a rapprochment.

DOC.HEAD: Experts Say Hearing Not the Best Ending, But the Closest Thing
DOC.TEXT: With or without Ivan Boesky, the first public hearing on charges against financial felon Michael Milken is sure to leave some followers of the biggest Wall Street fraud case feeling, well, cheated. The ``mini-trial'' scheduled to begin Thursday is designed to give U.S. District Judge Kimba Wood more information when she sentences the former Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. executive to anywhere from zero to 28 years in prison. It will include new allegations of wrongdoing by Milken, testimony by former junk bond co-workers immunized against prosecution and counterattacks by top-line defense lawyer Arthur Liman. But some legal experts say that after a four-year investigation and unprecedented charges painting Milken as Wall Street's Butch Cassidy, Milken's plea bargain and the limited hearing are a poor excuse for justice. ``We will never have confidence in knowing what happened,'' said Albert Alschuler, a criminal law expert at the University of Chicago Law School. ``If he is the biggest financial crook of the century it's not severe enough,'' he said of Milken's April guilty plea to six felonies. ``If he hasn't done anything wrong it's way too severe.'' The Milken case has come to symbolize the free-spending, merger-manic 1980s. Supporters portray the 44-year-old Milken as a saintly philanthropist, humanitarian, savior of American finance. Prosecutors call him systematic, calculating, greedy. Despite agreeing to pay $600 million in penalties as part of his plea bargain, Milken's wealth still is estimated at $700 million. But he lives modestly with his wife and three children in Encino, Calif. Through hard work and what some call genius, Milken helped create a $200 billion market for IOUs known as junk bonds that transformed second-tier Drexel into a model of '80s success and power. For those reasons - and the millions of dollars the government has spent pursuing him - many legal experts feel the public deserves a full examination of what if anything Milken did wrong. The mini-trial will focus on three allegations of insider trading and securities fraud excluded from Milken's guilty plea. Federal law permits sentencing judges to consider unproven crimes in assessing a defendant's character. The proceeding itself has come under criticism because standards of proof are lower than at an ordinary criminal trial. It's called a Fatico hearing, after a 1979 case involving a thief whom prosecutors wanted to show had ties to organized crime. ``If the government believes Mr. Milken has committed these additional crimes and should be punished for them, it should be required to prove them beyond a reasonable doubt at trial,'' Ira Glasser, head of the American Civil Liberties Union, and Norman Siegel, head of the New York Civil Liberties Union, said in a letter to The New York Times this week. But others said the investigation, the abandoned 98-count indictment, acceptance of the guilty plea and the Fatico hearing are part of how the legal system works. ``Its job is not to tie all the loose ends of the plot together,'' New York University law professor Stephen Gillers said. ``Judge Wood's job is to get the sentence right.'' The government plans to call more than a dozen witnesses to implicate Milken in illegal transactions involving securities of Wickes Cos., Storer Communications Inc. and Caesar's World Inc. dating to 1983. Prosecutors said Tuesday that Boesky, the inside trader who led the government to Milken in 1986 after turning state's evidence, wasn't likely to testify. Milken is expected to be in court during the two-week hearing but it is unclear whether he'll take the stand. The hearing amounts to a confrontation between young prosecutors and Liman, best known as Senate counsel during the 1987 Iran-Contra hearings. The government wants to demonstrate Milken's crimes were serious, not technical violations. The defense will attempt to disprove any Milken link to insider trading or predatory behavior against his clients. Each will have 20 hours for testimony and cross-examination. ``Strategically it's not useful for Milken,'' Gillers said. ``The government's going to be able to try to prove its other criminal acts and there will be two weeks' worth of headlines about those.'' Liman has complained that the abbreviated hearing undermines Milken's rights. He said government delays in turning over boxes of evidence and listing witnesses have hampered his preparation. In a letter to the judge, Liman wrote that no one envisioned that ``the peace that a plea agreement is intended to bring would be turned into full-scale warfare.'' Nonetheless, the hearing for the first time opens the window on the government's case and could offer a revealing snapshot of Milken's professional behavior. Wood has said she also will consider Milken's charitable work and personal character, reflected in scores of letters from friends and associates. But proving the allegations ``would go very far to justifying the time and effort the government has put into this case,'' said John Coffee Jr., a Columbia University securities law professor. ``You're talking about someone who was at the crossroads of financial capitalism at the most dynamic firm on Wall Street,'' he sai0.75, down from $395.50 late Tuesday. Bullion dealers said their market was slack, with strong resistance at attempts to push gold above $392.50. They said they did not expect much activity until there are major developments in the gulf. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold closed at a bid $392.15, down from $395.35. Silver bullion traded late in London at a bid $4.53 a troy ounce, down from $4.68.

DOC.HEAD: Teamsters President Not Seeking Re-election
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES thruout with McCarthy announcement, Durham as board's candidate; no pickup. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Teamsters Union President William J. McCarthy announced today he will not seek re-election to the post due to ``personal reasons.'' R.V. Durham of North Carolina, a union vice president, has been endorsed by a majority of the union's board members as the board's candidate to replace McCarthy, the Teamsters also announced. McCarthy, 71, has had a minor stroke and open heart surgery. He made the announcement at a union board meeting in West Palm Beach, Fla. A brief statement was released by the union's headquarters in Washington. ``He has decided for personal reasons not to seek re-election to the post. ...'' the statement said. Union sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said there were deep political divisions within the Teamsters' 21-member board. Certain factions were opposed to McCarthy running again, the sources said. McCarthy succeeded the late Jackie Presser two years ago. His departure left the union's executive board free to assemble a slate of candidates for officer positions without him. At least 15 of the board's 21 members are endorsing Durham as McCarthy's replacement, a Teamsters official said. The union's elections will take place in three stages before December 1991 under government-supervised procedures agreed to in a settlement of a civil racketeering suit brought by the Justice Department.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Exploring Cross-Border Stock Offerings with Canada
DOC.TEXT: An agreement that would allow U.S. and Canadian companies to sell their securities across the border using their own countries' approved disclosure documents could be in effect as early as next year if a proposal aired Wednesday is approved. The Securities and Exchange Commission voted unanimously to seek public comment on rules changes that would allow Canadian companies to use forms and documents from their home country to satisfy U.S. disclosure requirements. A reciprocal agreement allowing U.S. companies to use U.S. documents when selling stocks and bonds north of the border is pending in Canada. SEC Chairman Richard C. Breeden said the proposal could be ``a prototype for offerings between the United States and other countries.'' The SEC proposal cannot become final until the SEC staff reviews the comment letters and submits the rule change to the commissioners for a final vote. Breeden said he hoped that could be achieved by the end of the year or early 1991. The five-member SEC was created by Congress to oversee the stocks and bonds markets and other aspects of the securities industry to protect the investing public from fraud. SEC regulations require companies offering securities for sale to the public to disclose enough information for investors to make informed decisions. Among other things, companies issuing securities must say why they need the money from securities sales, who runs the company and how much money it owes to banks and other lending institutions. Some foreign companies have opted not to offer their stocks or bonds in the United States because they are unwilling to divulge such information. Others simply don't want to bother with the added expense of hiring lawyers, accountants and other professionals needed to complete the complex documents. The proposal, a revised version of one first offered in July 1989, would allow Canadian concerns, under certain restrictions, to sell their securities here using disclosure documents approved by Canadian regulators. For example, the revised rules would let any Canadian company sell stock in the United States using Canadian disclosure documents if the firm has been registered with a Canadian regulator for at least three years, has $75 million in shares outstanding and $300 million market capitalization. A reciprocal agreement allowing U.S. companies to sell their stock in Canada using U.S. disclosure documents will be considered by securities regulators in the provinces of Quebec and Ontario, where Canada's major stock exchanges are located. Canada does not have a nationwide securities regulator. ``The purpose of this rule is to make it easier for companies in both the U.S. and Canada who want to raise capital to support their activities, growth and development,'' said Breeden. The public meeting was the first attended by the newest SEC commissioner, Richard Y. Roberts, who was sworn in last week. It marked he first time in more than a year there were no vacancies on the five-member commission.

DOC.HEAD: States Attract Banks With Card Deregulation
DOC.TEXT: In the great chase to attract jobs, state after state banked on deregulation during the 1980s to bring credit card issuers to their doors. South Dakota acted first, attracting the plum of the industry, Citibank, in 1980. Delaware followed quickly, and 18 other states have since removed their ceilings on rates or fees as they scrambled to create cozy environments for credit card issuers. But critics question whether the state legislatures in their rush to deregulate plastic have trampled over consumers by allowing the banks to charge high interest rates and the now-prevalent annual fees. ``There's no question in our minds that one of the reasons the states are taking these actions is to lure bank card operations from other states with the promise that these card operations will be able to charge any rates and fees they choose,'' said Elgie Holstein, director of Bankcard Holders of America, a Herndon, Va.-based consumer group. ``From that standpoint, there has been throughout the 1980s a continuing willingness by state policy makers to look the other way as rates go higher,'' he said. Holstein said that prior to 1980, there were virtually no annual fees for credit card users. Now, they're commonplace and cost anywhere from a few dollars a year to an average of $34 for premium ``gold'' cards. Credit card interest rates also have remained consistently high in recent years - hovering around 19 percent on average - regardless of changing economic conditions. ``When there's been periods of rate decline, credit card rates remain stubbornly high,'' said Robert K. Heady, publisher of Bank Rate Monitor in North Palm Beach, Fla. For example, he noted, rates for certficiates of deposit fell 1.66 percentage points since April 1989, while at the same time credit card rates rose an average of two-thirds of a point. Nonetheless, state officials say deregulation has proven itself to be a solid means of attracting jobs. And the bank industry maintains deregulation has benefited consumers by increasing competition among card issuers and widening access to credit. South Dakota and Delaware, by acting early in passing attractive legislation, have won a solid hold as the premier host states for credit card business and continue to dominate the field. A ripple has been created in Georgia recently by the success of American Telephone & Telegraph Co.'s Universal Card, which was introduced last spring and already has 2.7 million cardholders. The card is issued by the Universal Bank, a subsidiary of Columbus, Ga.-based Synovus Financial Corp. Credit card banks such as Universal, which deal exclusively in bankcards, are sometimes called ``non-banks'' and are not subject to all the regulations as full-service institutions. ``They're not street-front operations. They're strictly second-floor operations,'' said Robert Moler, deputy commissioner of the Georgia Department of Banking and Finance. Non-banks have become more prevalent since the wave of credit card deregulation that began a decade ago when South Dakota changed its laws to attract Citibank's credit card operation from New York. That move came in the wake of a 1978 U.S. Supreme Court decision that said banks must adhere to the credit card interest rate limits of their home state. Some banks then sought to locate in states with unlimited rates structures so they could ``export'' those rates. ``The whole concept really comes down to jobs,'' said Steve Szekely of Payment Systems Inc. of Tampa, Fla., a industry research organization. ``When the banks started making moves, the states had to relax (interest rate) restrictions to keep the jobs.'' Richard Duncan, state banking director in South Dakota, said Citibank and the eight other credit card issuers who have moved to his state since 1980 have had a significant impact on the economy there. ``What it's done for the state is bring in employment and revenue that I'm sure has exceeded what was anticipated,'' Duncan said. Citibank employs 2,000 people in South Dakota and pumps in more than $20 million a year through the state franchise tax. ``In a state the size of South Dakota, which only has about 700,000 people, that makes a difference,'' Duncan said. Still, consumer groups say the job impact from the average issuer - much smaller than the Citibanks of the world - does not justify the higher rates and fees that accompany deregulation. The credit card business is extremely capital intensive and generally does not require a large work force, said Holstein, of the Bankcard Holders. ``You're getting a handful of jobs but millions of dollars extra (are) paid by consumers,'' he said. But Virginia Stafford, spokeswoman for the Washington-based American Bankers Association, said deregulation has increased access to credit by putting more players in the market and making banks more competitive. ``The bank card business is a volume kind of business,'' she said. ``It's allowed consumers to have access to credit cards that they ordinarily wouldn't have access to locally.'' Without deregulation, credit cards may have become available mainly to wealthy customers, considered safe risks by the banks, she said. Standardized disclosure requirements, in place since last year, also have provided consumers with more information about the cards so that they may shop around for the best deal, Ms. Stafford added. South Dakota's Duncan maintains that competition from the growing field of card issuers has helped keep rates from getting out of hand. ``You can get credit cards from a barrage of sources,'' he said. ``The price may be a little higher but I think people are willing to pay a little more to get the convenience.'' Moler, of the Georgia banking department, said the credit card banks, because of their narrow focus, escape some of the regulations applied to full service banks, such as being tested for how well they serve the needs of a community. But the banks' activities are restricted to issuing cards. AT&T spokesman Bruce Reid said his company put in more than two years of research before deciding on the Georgia bank to unveil the Universal card. ``Georgia laws are very favorable, as they would be in South Dakota and Delaware. The regulatory climate . . . was what we were looking for,'' he said. The Universal Card's temporary offer of a lifetime ban on annual fees, and the ability to use the card as an AT&T calling card has contributed to its success, analysts say. But it also prompted some banks who issue MasterCard and Visa, including Citibank parent Citicorp and Chase Manhattan Corp., to file complaints with the federal government that the Universal ``non-bank'' had an unfair advantage because of its telephone tie-in.

DOC.HEAD: Sagging Exports, Improved Weather Send Prices Lower
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices closed mostly lower Wednesday on the Chicago Board of Trade as the market reacted to sagging export demand for U.S. products. Corn futures were influenced by slack demand from overseas, with the Soviet Union denying it had purchased U.S. corn overnight in Europe. It received some support from reports the Soviets would eventually make a purchase. Slack sales by farmers also gave a boost to corn prices. Overall, the market was pressured by forecasts the rains of the past few days will be ending. That will allow farmers to get on with the harvest, said Joel Karlin, an analyst with Research Department Inc. in Chicago. Trading was cautious in anticipation of the release Thursday of the U.S. Agriculture Department's October crop production report. The report is expected to put the estimated soybean crop at 1.832 billion bushels and the corn crop at 8.060 billion bushels, said Victor Lespinasse, an analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. in Chicago. At the close, wheat was 1 cent to 3{ cents lower with the contract for delivery in December at $2.76\ a bushel; corn was a \ cent to 1\ cents higher with December at $2.35{ a bushel; oats were a { cent to 1 cent higher with December at $1.23 a bushel; soybeans were 4{ cents to 9} cents lower with November at $6.25 a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: CBS Earnings Down 30 Percent in Third Quarter
DOC.TEXT: CBS Inc. on Wednesday reported a 30 percent decline in earnings in the third quarter, citing higher television expenditures, partly for news coverage of events in the Middle East. The network said net income fell to $43.5 million, or $1.69 per share in the quarter ended Sept. 30, compared to $61.9 million, or $2.40 per share during the same period in 1989. Net sales during the quarter were up 12 percent to $662 million from $593 million in the year-ago period. Laurence A. Tisch, CBS president and chief executive, said increased programming costs contributed to the weak quarter. He said the televison network spent more money on new program development, first-run summer programming and the aquisition of program rights for sporting events. The company said sales growth increased primarily from broadcasts of major league baseball games. ``CBS's earnings are likely to continue to decline,'' Tisch said. ``However, CBS has the cash reserves to steer through an economic downturn, while sustaining our long-term plan to improve ratings.'' CBS reported earnings of $266.8 million, or $10.36 per share, for the first nine months of 1990, compared to $236.8 million, or $9.20 per share, in the 1989 period. Net sales for the nine-month period were $2.34 billion, compared to $2.096 billion. Also Wednesday, the company's board of directors declared a cash dividend of $1.10 per share on CBS common stock and a cash dividend of 25 cents per share on CBS series A preference stock.

DOC.HEAD: Westinghouse Earnings Rise In Third Qarter
DOC.TEXT: Westinghouse Electric Corp. said Wednesday its earnings rose nearly 9 percent in the third quarter as the company's broadcasting, electronic and energy divisions posted gains. Net income totaled $255 million, or 87 cents per share, on revenue of $3.17 billion in the third quarter of 1990. That compared with earnings of $235 million, or 80 cents a share, on revenue of $3.12 billion in the same quarter of 1989. Profits for the first nine months increased 10 percent to $717 million, or $2.44 per share, compared with $652 million, or $2.23 per share, in the year-ago period. After adjusting last year's results for the divestiture of the company's transmission and distribution business, revenues increased about 11 percent in both the quarter and nine months, Westinghouse said. ``I am very encouraged by our overall results in both the quarter and year to date,'' said Westinghouse Chairman Paul E. Lego. ``In light of the slowing and uncertain economy, this is an excellent performance that reflects the great contribution that all of our employees are making.'' Recently acquired radio stations boosted the broadcasting division's revenues and operating profits substantially in the quarter, Westinghouse said. Revenues for the electronic systems division were higher because of a better mix of business, the company said. Revenues and operating profit for the energy and utility systems division were up significantly, mostly due to the strong performance of the power generation business.

DOC.HEAD: NYSE to Soviets: Sell Stock in Aeroflot, Intourist and Oil Companies
DOC.TEXT: Wall Street executives teaching the Soviets about financial markets said Wednesday they told their hosts to start by selling shares in the profitable state airline, tourist agency and petroleum businesses. The U.S. delegation led by New York Stock Exchange Chairman John J. Phelan Jr. also met for 90 minutes with President Mikhail Gorbachev and signed a formal cooperation agreement with finance officials to exchange information. Phelan told a news conference that Gorbachev asked them to continue advising his government on its switch to a market economy, which includes the re-establishment of stock exchanges. Several plans proposed to rescue the Soviet economy envisage a stock exchange by the end of this year, but the government hasn't set a specific time frame. ``I think that the stock exchange itself will emerge ... as the result of the development of market relations in general throughout the country,'' Finance Minister Valentin Pavlov told reporters covering the NYSE delegation. ``How soon we will be able to realize that, I don't think we are in a position - anyone is in a position - to give a firm answer.'' More than 400 Soviet bankers, academics, researchers and brokers-in-waiting attended a seminar given by the Americans in Moscow's international trade center. They absorbed detailed descriptions of how American markets work and prodded their government officials to move faster to copy them. Many members of the Wall Street delegation recommended the government start its privatization program with its most profitable enterprises, such as the Aeroflot state airline, the Intourist travel agency or parts of the nation's huge oil industry. The government is drafting legislation to permit stock exchanges, but a businessmen's committee said it will register one in Moscow next month whether or not the regulations are in place. The new Moscow Commodities Exchange, which held one day of listless trading last month, said it was also trying to set up an equities section. Pavlov predicted any fledgling Soviet stock exchange would begin by trading bonds, rather than equities. That would give the government time to develop a plan to sell off its wealth of factories and other means of production. Since June, it has allowed some state enterprises to become joint-stock companies but has generally retained a majority interest. Bonds, usually issued by governments, pay the buyer a fixed annual interest rate and can be redeemed at a specified date. John Chalsty, president of the securities firm Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc., said trading in bonds would be ``a logical first step.'' ``There's more familiarity, I think, with fixed-income securities bearing specified interest rates,'' he said in an interview. ``It was my sense that a securities exchange can in fact be established in relatively short order, that it can start trading securities, mostly fixed-income, but that it will be a slow process before you actually get stocks, shares of ownership, traded on the exchange,'' he said. ``I don't know when that will come because that will depend on the progress of privatization.'' Phelan said a successful stock exchange will also require a cultural change among the Soviet people, many of whom remain suspicious of entrepreneurs. ``There also has to be ... a feeling that it's not illegal to have a profitable negotiation between two people, that profit is what drives the economy and makes it more efficient,'' he said. ``That's going to take time to change and come about.'' Pavlov agreed. ``As soon as neighbors will become aware that it is profitable to buy stock, much more profitable than hoarding money in the mattress, then we can expect a breakthrough,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Forstmann Planning New Buyout Fund
DOC.TEXT: Buyout strategist Theodore Forstmann is seeking investors for a $1.5 billion fund that would finance acquisitions of companies by using debt, a source knowledgable about the proposal said Wednesday. The venture is likely to be watched by Wall Street as a barometer of the market for debt-financed buyouts. Since the collapse of the junk bond market a year ago, many investors have shunned the idea of funding acquisitions primarily with debt. The source said Forstmann is planning to offer investors in his fund yields 1 percent above the interest rate on five-year Treasury bonds, which now yield about 8.5 percent. Forstmann is seeking about 20 institutional investors, according to the source, who spokeon condition of anonymity. A spokesman for Forstmann, John Scanlon, declined comment on the proposal, and refused to confirm or deny the buyout strategist's plans. Forstmann has long opposed the use of junk bonds - which have yields as high as 20 percent - to fund buyouts, although his debt funds, like junk bonds, are subordinated, falling behind bank debt and secured debt in credit rankings. However, Forstmann says his brand of debt financing differs from junk bonds because it is not publicly underwritten and because his investors take a 37.5 percent equity stake in acquired companies. Despite the slowdown in mergers and takeovers, Forstmann's buyout firm, Forstmann Little & Co., has been quite active, acquiring General Instrument Corp. for $1.6 billion in August, and participating in the buyout of Chrysler Corp.'s Gulfstream Aerospace Corp. earlier this year. Last year, Forstmann tried but failed to put together a fund, known as a white squire fund, that planned to take large stakes in companies that were overburdened by debt.

DOC.HEAD: Delaware Will Join Lawsuit Against Federal Reserve
DOC.TEXT: The state of Delaware plans to join a lawsuit against the Federal Reserve Board to overturn an order that blocks Citicorp from selling and underwriting insurance nationwide. Citicorp filed suit against the Fed late last week in U.S. Second Circuit Court of Appeals in New York. In early September, the Fed ruled that a new Delaware law allowing banks to sell and underwrite insurance nationwide gave financial institutions powers prohibited by federal regulations. Citicorp is arguing the Fed lacks jurisdiction over Delaware law because Citicorp's insurance company, Family Guardian, is a division of the bank, not a subsidiary. Delaware Bank Commissioner Keith Ellis said Tuesday the state plans to ask the court to allow it to become a party to the suit, rather than limit itself to filing a friend of the court brief. ``The state has a real interest in becoming a part to the suit as a way of showing our independent interest in the case,'' Ellis said. Citicorp began selling primarily life and health insurance through Family Guardian after Delaware's legislation became law in May. Delaware officials said the law satisfied requirements of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. to protect insured deposits. But the Fed said the state went too far to protect depositors.

DOC.HEAD: EC Unemployment Up in August
DOC.TEXT: Unemployment in the European Community rose 0.1 percent to 8.4 percent in August, the EC Commission said in a statement Wednesday. The rise is the first in the 12-nation trade bloc since February and prompted Commission Vice P resident Henning Christophersen to call for the speeding up of economic and monetary union within the EC. Christophersen said in a statement, however, it was important not to ``over- interpret'' the increase, with many graduates entering the job market for the first time. Overall unemployment in August 1989 was 9.2 percent. The Commission figures showed unemployment for persons under 25 running at 15.8 percent in August, down from 17.3 percent a year earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Bull Semen Profitable
Laserphoto AUS1
DOC.TEXT: Their names were Fuji, Judo, Mazda and Ryusho. Before they died of old age years ago, they left behind a genetic legacy worth millions for cattle breeder Don Lively, but which the Japanese claim was a stolen national treasure. The legacy is semen - collected from the four Japanese bulls and brought to the United States in a shroud of secrecy 14 years ago. Some people now say the semen is a rare commodity that could revolutionize the beef industry in both countries. Lively's stockpile of semen from the famed Wagyu cattle (pronounced Wog-you), believed to be the only ones of the breed to ever leave their homeland, is estimated to be worth $2 million. Cattlemen and agribusiness companies from all over the orld have come clamoring to Lively's LoDo Ranch to buy some of the semen so they can start breeding their own herds of Wagyu cattle. The Wagyu's tender, slightly sweet-tasting meat, called Kobe beef, is considered a delicacy that fetches up to $180 a pound in Japan. The spindly legged and swaybacked beasts once only brought bewildered stares from U.S. breeders, who prefer much stockier cattle. Research from Texas A&M University indicates Kobe beef is markedly lower in cholesterol than other beef. But ever since Japan said it would lift beef import quotas by 1991, American cattlemen have hungrily eyed the Wagyu. So have Japanese investors with vast holdings of land in the United States. ``They can't increase cattle production in Japan. They don't have the land,'' Lively said. Lively and his business partner, Rosebud rancher Fred Hildebrand, already have sold off hundreds of the semen samples, used to artificially inseminate cows, for about $1 million. Each vial costs $250. ``People used to think I was crazy for having these cattle,'' says Lively, 62. The Japanese have always been fond of the cattle and reluctant to share the breed with the rest of the world. They have closely guarded the cattle and steadfastly refuse to export them. ``You'd be classified as a traitor if you brought it out of Japan,'' Lively says. ``The Japanese are resentful that we have Wagyu cattle. Some of them won't even admit these are Wagyu when we show the cattle to them.'' ``If you could raise Wagyu cattle here and be the first one to back into Japan with Kobe beef you got yourself a market - be it a niche or the corner on a billion dollars. It'll probably be a billion dollars,'' he said. Lively and others in the beef industry also believe U.S. breeders could reap huge profits off Wagyus in the domestic cattle market, where some Wagyu cattle have sold for $20,000 to $30,000 a head. There are about 900,000 head of Wagyu cattle in Japan today. Fewer than 60 purebreds exist in the United States. Lively and his partner own most of those. The first four Wagyu bulls, Lively says, were brought to the United States by a Texas cattleman named Morris Whitney with the help of a mysterious Japanese partner. Whitney later sold them to a Georgetown veterinarian. Both men tried in vain to turn a profit on the cattle, seeking out investors in a high-stakes cattle venture that soon went bust. Lively says he and Hildebrand eventually ended up with the seemingly worthless Wagyu bulls. Now their semen is worth a small fortune and a smiling Lively refuses to eat any other kind of beef other than the Kobe meat he raises. ``Why would I do that?'' he asks. ``I'm already eating the finest beef around.''

DOC.HEAD: Amerada Hess Buys Stake in Gabon Oil Reserves
DOC.TEXT: Amerada Hess Corp. said Wednesday it had formed a joint venture with the government of Gabon and purchased a stake of an onshore oil field believed to contain 425 million barrels of crude in the African nation. Amerada Hess paid $300 million to Gabon and will own 67 percent of the joint venture. The joint venture has obtained 10 percent of the Rabi-Kounga oil field. Amerada Hess said in a statement that it hopes production in the field will reach 140,000 barrels per day next year.

DOC.HEAD: Three Justices Voice Doubts About Fetal Protection Rules
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS spelling of Marsha in 12th graf, Marsha Berzon
DOC.TEXT: Three of the Supreme Court's nine justices gave a chilly reception Wednesday to an employer's ``fetal protection'' policy that excludes women of childbearing age from some hazardous jobs. In a case that could affect millions of working women, Justices John Paul Stevens, Sandra Day O'Connor and Antonin Scalia voiced doubts about the wisdom and legality of such a policy. The court is expected to decide by July whether the policy amounts to illegal sex discrimination. The three justices, along with Justice Anthony M. Kennedy, dominated an hour-long argument session. They posed numerous questions to the two lawyers before them, firing their most biting inquiries at Stanley Jaspan, who represented the Milwaukee-based Johnson Controls Inc. Stevens seemed dubious when asking Jaspan about the overall risk posed to women working at Johnson Controls' 13 battery-making plants. When Jaspan argued that exposure to lead, the principal material used in making batteries, ``poisons the fetus and causes permanent brain damage,'' Stevens interrupted to ask, ``How often does this happen?'' He asked whether ``the slightest risk'' was enough to render inapplicable a federal law, Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, banning on-the-job sex bias. O'Connor and Scalia took issue with Jaspan's interpretation of what legal duty employers face under a 1978 amendment, called the Pregnancy Discrimination Act, to the law. ``You are not coming to grips with the effect of the Pregnancy Discrimination Act,'' O'Connor told Jaspan. And Scalia said Jaspan's suggestion that employers may treat pregnant workers differently if fetal health is an issue ``is to make a farce'' of the 1978 law. ``You're making it a ridiculous piece of legislation,'' Scalia said. But Jaspan held firm in defending the company's policy. ``It would violate common sense ... to require an employer to damage unborn children,'' he argued. Marsha Berzon, the San Francisco lawyer representing the policy's challengers, told the justices, ``The net effect of a policy like this is to sanction the re-segregation of the work force.'' She said such policies could ``render women marginal workers and oust them from the workplace.'' One federal judge, calling the case the most important sex-bias dispute in decades, said the estimated number of women affected runs as high as 20 million. Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and Justice Byron R. White each asked only one question during Wednesday's session. Three court members - Justices David H. Souter, Thurgood Marshall and Harry A. Blackmun - did not ask any questions. The nation's largest manufacturer of car batteries, Johnson Controls adopted its policy in 1982, declaring certain jobs off limits for fertile women. Those who could not prove they were infertile were transferred to other jobs, although their salaries were not cut. Some of the women were in their 60s. Fertile women now hired are ineligible for top-paying jobs with the greatest lead exposure at the company's plants in California, Delaware, Florida, Illinois, Kentucky, North Carolina, Michigan, Missouri, Ohio, Oregon, Texas, Vermont and Wisconsin. The policy was upheld in lower courts.

DOC.HEAD: Silver Tumbles, Dollar Mixed
DOC.TEXT: Silver prices fell Wednesday to the lowest level in more than 13 years, following crude oil prices lower as anxiety over tension in the Middle East influenced currency and commodity markets. Gold prices also fell, but not as sharply as silver. The dollar was mixed. On New York's Commodity Exchange, silver bullion for current delivery settled at $4.409 a troy ounce, down from Monday's $4.593. Silver bullion traded late in London at a bid $4.53 a troy ounce, down from $4.68. It was the lowest level for silver since August 1977. ``The big loser today was the silver market,'' said Bernard Savaiko, senior metal analyst for Paine Webber Inc. ``It seemed to follow the crude oil market lower.'' Oil prices, which have doubled in the two months since Iraq seized Kuwait, were wrenched down late in the day, partly because of an unfounded rumor that Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein was dead. ``I think its mostly oil news today,'' said Robert Ryan, corporate foreign exchange manager with the Bank of New York. ``The dollar really hasn't done anything overall. There's just been a lot of trading back and forth.'' Traders said the Japanese yen was the only currency to show real strength Wednesday. In Tokyo, banks and markets were closed for Sports Day, a national holiday. In London, the dollar was quoted at 130.35 yen, up from 129.95 yen in Tokyo late Tuesday. In New York, the dolla settled at 129.48 yen, down from 130.25 yen on Tuesday. In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.9675, cheaper for buyers than $1.9705 late Tuesday. In New York it cost $1.9695 to buy one pound, less expensive than Tuesday's $1.9730. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday's rates included: 1.5278 German marks, up from 1.5238; 1.2810 Swiss francs, up from 1.2735; 5.1145 French francs, up from 5.1015; 1,145.00 Italian lire, up from 1,142.25, and 1.1491 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1506. Late dollar rates in Europe compared with late Tuesday included: 1.5285 German marks, up from 1.5245; 1.2785 Swiss francs, up from 1.2765; 5.1160 French francs, up from 5.1005; 1.7225 Dutch guilders, up from 1.7185; 1,143.25 Italian lire, unchanged; and 1.1495 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1507. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery fell $1.60 to settle at $388.10 a troy ounce. Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for gold at $388.25, down $2.50 an ounce from late Tuesday. Gold traded late in London at a bid price of $390.25 a troy ounce, down from $396.25. The late bid price in Zurich was $390.75, down from $395.50 late Tuesday. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold closed at a bid $392.15, down from $395.35.

DOC.NOTE: EDS: ADDS four new grafs at end with weekly API numbers
DOC.HEAD: Oil Falls on Rumors After Hitting New High
DOC.TEXT: Oil prices seesawed wildly in the futures market Wednesday, first jumping into record territory above $41 a barrel then tumbling on a vague rumor that Iraqi President Saddam Hussein had been killed. ``It's been a rumor-driven day,'' said Ann-Louise Hittle, a senior oil analyst with Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. ``Disregarding the rumors, some of the strength we have seen is not being sustained.'' Light sweet crude closed $1.71 lower at $38.69 per barrel for November delivery contracts on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Later delivery months were all down by more than $1 a barrel. In early trading, crude futures had moved to an all-time exchange high of $41.15 per barrel, after closing above $40 per barrel for the first time on Tuesday. Early oil prices were following the London futures market, which had advanced on a rumor that U.S. troops had been dispatched into Kuwait. The U.S. government squelched the rumor before the New York exchange opened, but that failed to stop the momentum that oil had gotten from the story. ``The strength was retained, just on general nervousness,'' Hittle said. Oil later turned downward on the Saddam death rumor. ``A lot of people thought that was a good reason to start selling,'' said Peter Beutel, an oil analyst with Pegasus Econometric Group Inc., in Hoboken, N.J. Once the selling started, there were no buyers pushing prices back up, traders said. The recent speculation surrounding oil contracts in the futures market drew criticism Wednesday from Sen. Joseph I. Lieberman, D-Conn., who asked regulators to take a closer look at the way business is conducted on the mercantile exchange, a leading petroleum market. ``The teeth of these speculator sharks are ripping away at the muscle of our economy,'' Lieberman said. Lieberman suggested oil speculators should have to put up more money when they make deals. He said the amount of oil they trade on the futures market should perhaps be limited. The exchange has raised the amount investors must now put up to make oil deals in what officials believe is an appropriate response to the recent wild fluctuations, a spokeswoman said. At current prices, traders are required to put up about 20 percent to 25 percent of the value of the contract. There are limits on the amount of oil that can be traded at once, basically 1 million barrels for next month delivery. But for big oil companies, the limits can be raised to levels that the exchange will not make public, the spokeswoman said. Oil's dive on Wednesday was imitated by other energy futures. Wholesale home heating oil dropped 5.10 cents to $1.0105 per gallon on November contracts, with other months all down. Wholesale unleaded gasoline was down 4.66 cents to 93.60 cents per gallon on November contracts, with all other months down. Natural gas was unchanged at $1.94 per 1,000 cubic feet on November contracts, while later delivery months fell. After the futures market closed, the leading industry group released a report showing the U.S. crude stockpile had fallen farther than many analysts had been predicting. The crude stocks dropped to 350.4 million barrels, from 354.6 million barrels a week earlier, but they remained above the level of 337.1 million barrels a year earlier, the American Petroleum Institute said in its weekly report. Gasoline stocks rose to 225.7 million barrels, from 223.9 million barrels a week earlier, although they were below the level of 225.8 million barrels a year earlier. Stocks of distillates, which include home heating oil, fell to 133.3 million barrels, from 134.8 million barrels a week earlier, but they remained above their level a year earlier of 121.8 million barrels. The nation's refinery capacity fell to 87.6 percent, compared with 91.2 percent aweek earlier and 88.3 percent a year earlier, API said.

DOC.HEAD: Alaska Settles With Another Oil Company in Royalties Case
DOC.TEXT: Freeport-McMoRan Oil & Gas Co. will pay Alaska $331,000 to settle a lawsuit alleging the company underpaid the state for its royalty share of North Slope oil, the state announced Wednesday. New Orleans-based Freeport is the third company to settle with the state in what is known as the Amerada Hess case, after the first of 12 companies named in the lawsuit. Amerada Hess Corp. settled last year for $318,624 and ARCO Alaska settled last month for $287 million. Freeport was involved in the case after buying the interests of Petro-Lewis Corp., which was named in the original lawsuit. Gov. Steve Cowper said the Freeport settlement was not large but is another step in bringing the 13-year-old litigation to an end. Negotiations continue between the state and other companies named in the lawsuit. The largest pending claim is $334 million against BP Exploration (Alaska) Inc.

DOC.HEAD: Macmillan to sell Encyclopedia Company
DOC.TEXT: Macmillan Inc. said Wednesday it will sell its P.F. Collier Inc. subsidiary to a German firm for an undisclosed price. Collier is one of the country's largest encyclopedia publishers. It makes Collier's Encyclopedia, a 24-volume set, and Merit Students Encyclopedia, which are sold in 30 countries. The sale to Bibliographisches Institut & F.A. Brockhaus AG also includes a British subsidiary that sells Collier's Encyclopedia in the United Kingdom. A statement by the companies said a definitive agreement would be signed by Nov. 15. Macmillan Inc. is a subsidiary of Maxwell Communication Corp.

DOC.HEAD: Progress Reported in Taj Mahal Debt Restructuring Talks
DOC.TEXT: An adviser to bondholders of Donald Trump's Taj Mahal casino reported progress Wednesday in talks to restructure $675 million of the casino's debt. ``The talks are proceeding in a constructive fashion,'' said Wilbur Ross, senior managing partner at Rothschild Inc., but he added, ``You don't have a deal on anything till you have a deal on everything.'' The Taj Mahal faces a $47.3 million interest payment Nov. 15 on the $675 million in bonds. The bonds were issued to finance construction of the Atlantic City casino. Fitch Investors Service Inc., a credit rating company, reported Wednesday that bondholders may seek an equity stake of up to 50 percent in the Taj Mahal. Ross said he had no comment on the report, and would not discuss what concessions bondholders are seeking from Trump in return for the restructuring. Trump currently holds all of the equity in the Taj Mahal as well as his other Atlantic City casinos, Trump Plaza and Trump Castle. Trump Plaza has fared the best of the three, but all suffer from the same cash flow malaise that has afflicted all casinos in the city. In June, Trump reached an agreement with bankers who lent him $65 million to meet interest payments on his bonds while he looked for a more permanent solution to the problems of his debt-ridden real estate and casino empire. Trump has an estimated $2 billion in bank debts in addition to the $1.3 owed to casino bondholders. There have been a number of reports over the past few months that Trump would sell the Plaza Hotel in New York or the Trump Shuttle, the airline serving New York, Washington and Boston, to help reduce his debt. However, there have been no announcements from the Trump Organization about any asset sales. Fitch reported that some bondholders were seeking the closure or liquidation of the Taj Mahal, but Ross called the report ``extremely far-fetched.'' Ross said Trump also owes about $100 million to contractors and banks who loaned him money for the Taj Mahal, which opened earlier this year.

DOC.HEAD: Strike Deadline Looms for GM-Canada Workers
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp. of Canada and union leaders worked down to the wire Wednesday night to come up with a contract proposal before a midnight strike deadline. Bob White, president of the Canadian Auto Workers, said the deadline would not be extended. But on Wednesday evening, a union spokesman said financial matters had been settled, leaving only local issues to be resolved. The CAW represents 36,500 workers at GM. The company has 13 plants in Ontario and one in Ste.-Therese, Quebec. White said the main stumbling blocks in negotiations were the company's plan to close a van plant in Scarborough and to lay off workers at a trim plant in Windsor. GM has said it will cut 700 jobs at the Windsor plant, which employs about 2,500 people making seat covers, seats and doors. But the company announced last week it would delay closing the van plant until spring 1992, giving 2,500 workers a few more months of work. Key issues for the company are cost-competitiveness, job flexibility and improved attendance. The basis for the talks is a contract the union reached with Ford Motor Co. of Canada last month after a nine-day strike. It gives the company's 12,800 workers pay hikes averaging 6.4 per cent a year for three years. It also provides more long weekends and a vacation bonus of 500 Canadian dollars ($435 U.S.). In the United States, the United Auto Workers reached a tentative agreement Sunday with Ford. It closely follows a contract the union reached last month with General Motors Corp., which allows the automakers more flexibility but gives workers a greater degree of job security.

DOC.HEAD: Tentative Accord Reached On Auto Emission Standards
DOC.TEXT: Congressional negotiators reached a tentative agreement Wednesday on auto emission standards, removing a major obstacle that had threatened approval of a clean air bill this year. A dispute over state enforcement of auto pollution requirements had held up agreement on the motor vehicle section of the bill for more than a week. The compromise calls for tougher tailpipe emission controls, a phase-in of alternative fuel vehicles, and cleaner gasoline blends in areas with the worst smog problem. ``It's a major breakthrough,'' said Sen. Max Baucus, D-Mont., head of the Senate negotiating team. He said the motor vehicle section of the massive bill was ``the toughest obstacle'' to resolving differences in the clean air bills that passed the House and Senate earlier this year. With the touchy issue of auto emissions out of the way, the staff negotiators, meeting behind closed doors, turned immediately to what new controls should be imposed on industry to curb the release of toxic chemicals. Congressional leaders, meanwhile, told heads of both the House and Senate negotiating teams Wednesday they wanted the legislation completed by Sunday, so the measure could clear Congress before the planned Oct. 19 adjournment. Baucus said in an interview that he hoped the House-Senate conferees might formally approve the legislation by next Monday. ``That's the goal,'' he said. The bill would be the first tightening of federal air pollution laws in 13 years and imposes new emission requirements on electric utilities, factories, thousands of small businesses and automobiles to curb urban smog, acid rain and toxic releases. Agreement on the motor vehicles section had been considered one of the trickiest areas to resolve in the talks which have been going on since July 13. Both Senate and House negotiators said the agreement on motor vehicles was a major step forward, but some still expressed concern that the bill might be derailed in the closing days of the congressional session. ``We've got two big sections left,'' said Sen. John Chafee, R-R.I., one of the negotiators. These sections deal with toxic chemical releases by industry and acid rain pollutants. Chafee estimated there was a ``70-30 chance'' of a bill clearing Congress this year, but warned that even if a compromise bill is completed by Sunday it still must then be approved by both chambers where ``a very few people could derail it.'' The compromise reached by staff members on auto emission must still be approved formally by members of the House and Senate conference committee, but that was described as all but certain. The compromise would require a 30 percent to 60 percent cut in various smog-causing tailpipe emissions by 1998. It also calls for a phase-in of alternative fuel cars through a pilot program in California, which other states also could adopt; require fleets to use alternative fuel vehicles and require that oil companies sell cleaner burning gasoline in cities facing the worst smog problems. Daniel Weiss, who has followed the clean air debates for the Sierra Club, called the compromise a ``very ambitious program'' for cleaning the air in America's cities, but said in many areas the benefits will not be seen until toward the end of the decade. ``The auto and oil companies would have to reduce their pollution by far less than what they're capable of doing'' said Weiss. He said in many areas such as alternative fuels for fleets the controls were pushed back several years under the compromise. The compromise resolved concerns over state enforcement of auto emissions standards, which had blocked significant progress in the negotiations for more than a week. State air pollution control officials and others, including Gov. Mario Cuomo of New York, had strongly objected to a provision in the legislation that would have prevented states from adopting and enforcing tougher emission controls already in effect in California. The bill would have left enforcement to the federal Environmental Protection Agency. But under the compromise, that provision was modified to require that states adopt either the California emissions controls or stick to the federal controls. Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich., had sought the prohibition to keep states from adopting numerous standards, which he argued would require automakers to produce specially designed cars in various states.

DOC.HEAD: Silver Hits New Lows
DOC.TEXT: Silver futures prices plunged sharply Wednesday on New York's Commodity Exchange as the market continued to be burdened by abundant supplies. On other markets, oil prices declined on a market influenced by rumors; grain and soybean futures were mostly lower; gold prices fell; and livestock and pork futures retreated. Silver settled 18.4 cents 20.7 cents lower with the contract for delivery in October at $4.409 a troy ounce. The 18.8 cent plunge for the December silver contract dropped the metal to a 13-year low. ``The (reason) for the overall weakness of silver is simple. There is a lot of silver around. The supply is enormous,'' said Peter Cardillo, an analyst with Jesup, Josephthal & Co. Inc. in New York. Analysts noted that production of silver is increasing as demand from automakers and the photographic industry is decreasing. Adding to the weakness of silver is the perception it is a base metal and is prone to recession and inflation concern. ``Silver was once considered the poor man investment,'' Cardillo said. ``In the past, silver would react to international turmoil. Unfortunately, in recent years that has disappeared. It is not considered the safe haven that it once was.'' Profit-taking fueled a selloff of energy futures on the New York Mercantile Exchange in trading that saw prices influenced by rumors. Reports that U.S. troops have invaded Kuwait sent prices higher in early trading. But prices fell after the State Department denied military action was taking place, and slipped lower on rumors of the death of Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. Those rumors were also proven false. Profit-taking was the primary factor behind the drop in prices, said Andrew Lebow, an analyst with E.D. & F Man International Futures Inc. He noted there was little fresh news from the Middle East to influence the market. Light sweet crude was 41 cents to $1.71 lower with November at $38.69 a barrel; heating oil was 1.87 cents to 5.10 cents lower with November at $1.010 a gallon; unleaded gasoline was 2.70cents to 4.66 cents lower with November at 93.60 cents a gallon. Gold futures were pushed lower due to weakness in energy market, analysts said. Cardillo noted that gold has not reacted strongly to the crisis in the Middle East because producer nations continue to unload their gold supplies. Gold was $1.60 to $1.80 lower with October at $388.10 a troy ounce. Grain and soybean futures prices closed mostly lower on the Chicago Board of Trade. Corn futures were influenced by slack demand from overseas. It received some support from reports the Soviets would eventually make a purchase. Slack sales by farmers also gave a boost to corn prices. Overall, the market was pressured by forecasts the rains of the past few days will be ending. That will allow farmers to get on with the harvest, said Joel Karlin, an analyst with Research Department Inc. in Chicago. Trading was cautious in anticipation of the release Thursday of the U.S. Agriculture Department's October crop production report. Wheat was 1 cent to 3{ cents lower with delivery in December at $2.76\ a bushel; corn was a { cent to 1{ cents higher with December at $2.35{ a bushel; oats were a { cent to 1 cent higher with December at $1.23 a bushel; soybeans were 4{ cents to 9{ cents lower with November at $6.25 a bushel. Livestock and pork futures were lower in trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Pork prices were pressured by a drop in cash prices. Slack demand for beef products pushed livestock futures lower. Analysts said the market also was pressured by concerns that the U.S. economic outlook is weak. Live cattle were .37 cent to .88 cent lower with October at 79.20 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .25 cent to .85 cent lower with October at 87.70 cents a pound; hogs were .15 cent to .50 cent lower with October at 56.57 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 1.10 cent lower to .20 cent higher with February at 63.40 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Acquits Sundstrand Execs Of Lying To Government
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge acquitted three former Sundstrand Corp. executives Wednesday on charges of lying to the government in connection with the defense contractors' admitted Pentagon fraud scheme. The ruling left pending charges of conspiracy to defraud the government and scheming to conceal the conspiracy. U.S. District Judge Prentice H. Marshall said he will rule on those counts next Tuesday morning. Marshall granted a defense motion for acquittal that was entered after the government rested its case last week. The bench trial began Sept. 10. ``Would you be surprised if I said I was pleased?'' said Michael B. Nash, the attorney for Ralph G. Hamann, former Sundstrand section manager for government contracts. Hamann was charged along with Joseph J. McCarthy, Sundstrand's former vice president for finance and administration, and Ray John Chapel Jr., former director of business planning. Chapel and Hamann each were charged with four counts of making false statements to government officials. McCarthy was charged with two counts. All of the charges carry the same maximum penalty: five years in prison and a $250,000 fine. Keith Syfert, the lead prosecutor in the case, declined comment on the ruling. The three men are the only Sundstrand officials to have been charged in connection with the Rockford company's 1988 admission that it overbilled the Pentagon from May 1980 through August 1985. The company pleaded guilty to five counts of criminal fraud, was suspended for nearly four months as a government contractor and paid the government $199 million in fines and penalties, the largest defense contracting fraud settlement ever. In its plea agreement, Sundstrand admitted billing the government millions of dollars for such expenses as babysitting, golf, movies and snow plowing for executives.

DOC.HEAD: Hasbro Lays Off 90 White Collar Workers
DOC.TEXT: Slow domestic sales have forced toy maker Hasbro Inc. to lay off about 90 white collar workers, a spokesman said Wednesday. Hasbro, which makes G.I. Joe, Cabbage Patch Kids, Tinkertoys and the New Kids on the Block doll, laid off employees from sales, research and development, marketing and administration, said spokesman Wayne S. Charness. ``It cut across the domestic toy staff,'' he said. The reduction represents about 3.6 percent of Hasbro's statewide work force of about 2,400 and about 1 percent of its 8,000 employees worldwide, Charness said. In a statement, Alfred J. Verrecchia, chief operating officer, said the company had to cut costs because of the slowing economy. About 750 people were laid off in Lancaster, Pa. earlier this year when Hasbro moved the operations of a manufacturing plant there to New England. Other than the traditional seasonal slowdown around Thanksgiving, no other layoffs are expected this year, Charness said. Seven weeks ago, Hasbro chairman and chief executive Alan G. Hassenfeld announced a sweeping reorganization to prepare for new spending cuts and to help lift sagging profits. A general retail slump saw second quarter profits drop nearly 52 percent from the comparable period a year earlier. The Pawtucket-based company earned $8.7 million from April through June, compared to $18.1 million during the same three months of 1989. The estimated costs of the layoffs will appear in Hasbro's third-quarter results. Charness said the workers received a generous severance package, but declined to provide details.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Milken Hearing Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are details of three alleged illegal transactions prosecutors claim were committed by junk bond financier Michael Milken that will be aired at a special court hearing starting Thursday. The allegations were contained in the government's pre-sentencing memorandum accusing the former Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. financier of widespread wrongdoing beyond the six felonies to which he has pleaded guilty.
DOC.HEAD: Caesar's World Inc.
DOC.TEXT: The government claims Milken used nonpublic information to buy more than $3 million in Caesar's bonds in 1983 prior to announcement of debt restructuring managed by Drexel. The government says the bonds were bought by Drexel and sold two days later to Milken's personal retirement account. The government says the idea for a debt-for-stock swap was broached at a June 29, 1983, meeting among Milken, other Drexel executives and Caesar's representatives. The government claims Caesar's officials favored the idea and committed to it July 1; the defense maintains that didn't happen for a week. The bond purchases by Drexel were dated June 30 and in turn were sold to Milken a day later. Milken's lawyers said the Securities and Exchange Commission in 1985 investigated the trading and found no wrongdoing. They said Caesar's had not decided on a restructuring when Drexel made the purchases.
DOC.HEAD: Storer Communications Inc.
DOC.TEXT: Prosecutors allege Boesky bought Storer securities in July 1985 after Milken tipped him about a proposed leveraged buyout by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Co., which hired Drexel to secure financing. Prosecutors claim more than $1 million in trading profits were credited to Drexel in January 1986. According to court papers, Milken allegedly bribed money managers to buy risky Storer securities by selling other securities of the Florida cable television company at below market value. They allege Milken also misappropriated warrants that would allow a purchase of 25 percent of the company to private partnerships in which he had an interest. The government alleges that cash proceeds from the Storer transactions surpassed $325 million, with Milken and another unidentified individual personally making $172 million in 1988. Milken's lawyers say the claims are ``based both on misunderstandings and misstatement of the facts and the law.'' They say KKR gave Drexel discretion to sell warrants and that money managers have denied the alleged kickback arrangement.
DOC.HEAD: Wickes Cos.
DOC.TEXT: The government claims Milken asked Boesky to buy a large block of shares of Wickes, a California building products business, to push up its stock price and make it qualify for a special and costly dividend. Wickes hired Drexel in 1985 to raise money via a series of securities offerings, including two promising a high fixed dividend of $2.50 per share. The company did not have to redeem the shares for three years unless its stock closed above $6.12{ for 20 out of 30 consecutive trading days. The government alleges Milken pushed his traders to find buyers of Wickes stock to drive up the price. When the stock reached the level on 19 of 28 days in spring 1986, Milken allegedly had Boesky buy 1.9 million shares late in a trading day, pushing it above the required level. That helped Wickes avoid having to pay the expensive dividend for the full three years.

DOC.HEAD: Energy Department Selects Successful Bidders in Reserve Test
DOC.TEXT: The government said Wendesday it got no takers for almost a fifth of the nearly 5 million barrels of crude oil offered from the Strategic Petroleum Reserve. The Energy Department said it has selected 11 companies for the purchase of a little less than 4 million barrels of oil from the reserve under the test drawdown order givn by President Bush last month. The department said the amount was short of what had been expected to be sold because there were no bids for more than 800,000 barrels of high-sulfur ``sour'' crude that were offered. The sour crude was one of six types of oil offered from the reserve stocks in salt domes along the Texas and Louisiana coasts. Buyers will take 1.35 million barrels of other kinds of sour crude. Some refineries cannot process high-sulfur crude because it corrodes their equipment. The lack of interest in the sour crude was attributed to an expected increase in the amount of similar oil from Alaska's North Slope at Gulf Coast ports next month. Energy Secretary James Watkins said as much as 100,000 barrels a day of sour crude is expected to arrive at Gulf Coast refineries in November when most deliveries will occur from the government reserve. ``It is quite likely that this has reduced the demand for the type of sour crude we offered,'' said Watkins. That rejected sour crude would have come from Weeks Island, La. Sour crudes that were accepted will come from other storage sites. Amoco Oil Co., will receive the most oil, 1.12 million barrels, from the drawdown. Other selected bidders are BP Oil Supply Co., Citgo Petroleum, Fina Oil and Chemical Co., Mobil Oil Corp., Marathon Petroleum Co., Phibro Energy, Shell Oil Co., Sun Refining and Marketing, Transworld Oil USA, and Ultramar Inc. The department said there was adequate demand for the other types of oil that were offered as 33 companies submitted bids for 10.4 million barrels. Successful bids ranged from $32.64 to $39.06 per barrel. The department will be able to adjust those prices somewhat to reflect changes in the oil market before delivery.
